PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.
Bill presented by Mr Humphreys, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Bill before the House makes a number of important changes to procedures associated with the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. These have been announced previously either as part of the 1987-88 Budget package or in decisions taken as a result of the efficiency scrutiny into the payment of pharmaceutical benefits conducted earlier in 1987. Honourable members are well aware of this Government's scrutiny of all areas of expenditure and, in regard to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme in particular, the measures implemented last year to better target assistance on those in greatest need, especially families who require large numbers of drugs.

The changes incorporated in this Bill, although less significant than the changes made last year, maintain this momentum in achieving value for the taxpayers' dollar and improving efficiency. Amendments included in this Bill will make significant changes to the operation and activities of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC). The role of this Committee is to advise the Minister on the listing of drugs and medicinal preparations as pharmaceutical benefits.

The Government is concerned about the increasing cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme over the last two years, much of which has been caused by greater prescribing of expensive drugs. For example, in 1986-87 the average price of drugs supplied to pensioners under the scheme was $8, some 24 per cent higher than in the previous year. As mentioned in the Budget Papers, the major changes implemented in November 1986 are expected to save about $100m in 1987-88. If these changes had not been introduced expenditure on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme would have reached an estimated $970m in 1987-88, an increase of 58 per cent in the two years since 1985-86.

This Bill includes amendments that will require the PBAC to take account of comparative effectiveness and cost in recommending drugs as pharmaceutical benefits and in considering any change to prescribing restrictions applying to pharmaceutical benefits. In the past the PBAC has not been required by its statutory charter to take costs into account when making its recommendations. In practice it has taken price into account when considering drugs of similar efficacy and toxicity, but only as a secondary consideration. The obligation to consider comparative effectiveness and cost will require the PBAC to give consideration to alternative forms of treatment, for example, surgery, in making recommendations. The Committee will not be allowed to recommend the listing of a particular drug which is substantially more costly, unless it is satisfied that, at least for some patients, the drug provides significant therapeutic advantages over alternative therapy.

The Government has no objection to paying high prices for new drugs that offer significant therapeutic advances over existing drugs or other forms of treatment. But it does not believe the taxpayer should foot the bill for very expensive drugs that offer only minimal advantages over much cheaper alternatives. To assist the Committee to take account of these wider considerations, the Government intends to upgrade significantly secretariat support for the PBAC, with greater utilisation of specialist consultants to advise on selected areas of drug therapy.

Together with the upgrading of the PBAC secretariat, the Minister will be empowered to increase membership of the Committee by up to three; all of the additional members must be medical practitioners. This enlarged membership, additional secretariat support and greater resources to engage consultants complement the provisions in the Bill for the PBAC to appoint sub-committees to provide the best available advice in this technical area.

In addition, this Bill deals with the Minister's power to remove an item from the list of pharmaceutical benefits. The proposed amendment will enable the Minister to act quickly when circumstances change; for example, where a cheaper alternative drug becomes available. When taking action under the proposed amendment, the Minister will be required to have regard to previous views expressed by the PBAC. Clause 4 of the Bill requires that the declaration removing an item from the list of pharmaceutical benefits under these circumstances be tabled in the Parliament and be subject to disallowance.

I turn now to two other provisions of the Bill, which arose out of the efficiency scrutiny of the payment of pharmaceutical benefits. Honourable members will be aware of delays which have occurred in the past in paying pharmacists for pharmaceutical benefits they had supplied. A major initiative to prevent delays in paying pharmacists' claims and reduce processing costs has been to encourage pharmacists with compatible computers to submit claims on floppy disks or via modem to the central claims processing facility. This method of submitting claims has a number of advantages which include more rapid and accurate processing. The Bill provides for a cash incentive of 2.5c per pharmaceutical benefit to be paid to pharmacists and other approved suppliers who utilise this claims transmission system. The incentive payment may be paid for a period of two years to each supplier using this system. The rules governing the payment of the incentive will be made by the Minister, published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette and laid before each House of Parliament for its scrutiny.

The provisions in the Bill will formalise interim arrangements under which the incentive has been paid to eligible pharmacists since 1 July 1987. Earlier this year the Government announced that the incentive would be paid to all pharmacists, and other approved suppliers, who are ready to submit computer-readable claims by 1 November this year. Already the proportion of pharmacists participating in the claims transmission system has jumped from 11 per cent in February to more than 37 per cent at the end of September.

A further initiative to prevent delay in reimbursing pharmacists is provided for in clauses 5, 6 and 7 of this Bill. This is the establishment of an alternative payment system whereby the reimbursement to pharmacists is calculated based on processing a random sample of prescriptions submitted in each claim. The proposed arrangement provides pharmacists with greater flexibility in the ways they can receive reimbursement and will also assist the Department in handling peak work loads which occur from time to time.

Pharmacists will be able to participate in this arrangement by voluntary election. The Australian Bureau of Statistics and the Department of Finance have been involved in the development of the sampling arrangements. The Pharmacy Guild of Australia has been consulted and has given its approval in principle to the sampling arrangements. Further consultations will take place on the detailed rules which will govern this alternative payment method. The Bill provides that a copy of the rules be published in the Gazette, as well as being tabled in each House of the Parliament. It is expected that the rules will preclude from these arrangements very small pharmacies and those with computers capable of submitting data under the claims transmission system. The rules will specify how samples will be selected and how sample sizes will be determined for each pharmacy.

To minimise the sampling variation in payments and take account of high priced items, the rules will allow pharmacists to submit up to 10 per cent of items in a claim for full proces-sing, with the remainder to be reimbursed by the sampling method. In order to encourage pharmacists to choose this method of processing, the rules will provide that sample claims will receive both priority in processing and an incentive payment of 2.5c for each pharmaceutical benefit covered by the claim.

Clause 7 of the Bill will extend the Commonwealth recovery power to any overpayments made under the sampling method. Together with the other provisions in this Bill, the sample pro-cessing arrangements are expected to contribute significantly to the efficiency of the pharmaceu-tical benefits scheme. While it is impossible to be precise about the expenditure savings flowing from the changes in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee's procedures, these have been estimated at $5m in this financial year. These will be offset by the additional expenditure of $0.5m for additional staffing and consultancies. The operational savings from the claims transmission incentive and sample processing will depend on the number of approved suppliers participating. If 50 per cent of approved suppliers participate in the claims transmission system and a further 25 per cent elect to have their claims processed by the alternative payment method, the gross operational savings are estimated at $7m and $3.5m respectively in a full year. Offsetting these savings would be the incentive payments themselves, amounting to $1.25m and $0.6m per annum respectively. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tuckey) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The appropriation debate on the Department of Social Security is significant principally because the Department is responsible for expenditure of one of the major areas of the Budget. There has been a growth in expenditure this financial year to $18,176,252,000, representing approximately 22 per cent of the Budget. However, the tendency has been to see these figures purely in terms of the role of the Department in meeting the income problems of sections of the Australian community which, for whatever reason, are not able to meet or maintain what is regarded as a minimal standard of living.

SPEECH.PARA: In the short time available to me, in addition to questioning this issue as well as the problems of fraud in social security and other matters relating to the Department generally, I would like to canvas briefly the philosophy behind the role of the Federal Government using the Department of Social Security to establish an attitude of mind as well as mechanisms which will ensure that Australians and their children are able to maintain an adequate standard of living and that social attitudes and the attitude of government towards families should be given much greater consideration.

We have recently in this place and elsewhere participated in a national debate on the issue of the Australia Card, which we are well aware has now reached its rightful demise. In that context, however, one of the issues raised by the Government was that the Australia Card would have a major impact upon dole fraud and cheating of the social security system. The role of the Department of Social Security in this context, therefore, is very important. For example, the Department administers some 15 income maintenance programs, has some five million clients and makes some 100 million payments per annum. It is a vast administrative machine. As I said earlier, it is responsible for administering substantial amounts of money.

A recent report tabled in this House, Review of Systems for Dealing with Fraud on the Commonwealth, makes particular mention of the role of the Department of Social Security. Page 181 of that report contains a very interesting table relating to detected overpayments against programs. I emphasise the word `detected' because we have no idea-I hope the Minister will be able to assist us in this matter-exactly what the potential undetected fraud or overpayments against those programs may be. Over the years methods of recovery of such overpayments have varied from extremely poor to less than adequate, which would be a generous way of putting it. No one disputes for a moment the difficulties encountered in this area. I think it is significant that, in evidence given to the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, the Department said that only 0.6 per cent of fraud was due to false identity and that the majority of people who were participating either actively or passively in such fraud were those who were experiencing changed economic circumstances about which the Department had not been informed.

As I said earlier, when one is dealing with some five million people, of course some difficulties will be encountered in managing those programs. However, evidence that has been put to the House and that is contained in other reports tabled in the Parliament cause one to question whether in fact enough is being done and whether what is being done is being totally effective.

For example, in February of this year in Sydney and elsewhere in Australia the Department carried out a crackdown on dole cheating. I think it is fair to say that on the face of it that crackdown was effective in some areas. For example, it is said that some 4,000 people were interviewed by five teams of social security officers in areas where social security officials had identified a concentration of abuse. They found that one in four of those interviewed should not have been receiving the dole. That would suggest, if we were to extrapolate from those figures, that up to 180,000 people receiving the dole throughout the country are not eligible to do so. We do not know what has taken place since February this year-whether significant further reductions have taken place in that particular area-but no doubt the Committee will expect the Minister to go into further detail about that matter.

Movement in this area has been somewhat late. After all, we are now considering the Government's fifth Budget; it has had plenty of time to move on fraud and overpayments. The activity to date has been quite belated. Nevertheless, there are serious cases of social security fraud. According to the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) in his report, either such cases have not been investigated or the methodology of the investigation has been less than satisfactory. I should just mention in passing that when I was Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts under the previous Government we drew attention to precisely that issue. When we were examining the problem of medifraud, for example, it became very clear that the submissions to the then Commonwealth Police and to the prosecutor's office were too often of such a dubious nature and character that it was not possible to maintain successful prosecutions in the courts.

The Director of Public Prosecutions Office says that it has met with the Australian Federal Police and the Department of Social Security because of its concern that welfare fraud has not been effectively controlled. We accept, as does the DPP, that there are some reasons for this, but the DPP claims that the essential reason is that many of the cases are not being adequately investigated. Though the Department claims that it naturally utilises its resources on what it regards as the most serious cases, according to the DPP the real problem now is that a significant number of what I shall call intermediate cases of fraud are effectively being passed over, allegedly because of inadequate distribution of resources to investigate them. The point is also made that the evidence coming from the Department of Social Security is not of good quality and often, therefore, is not an adequate basis for the DPP to carry out the necessary action before the courts.

As I said earlier, I want to widen this discussion briefly to cover a point of great importance, the future of the family. The policies of this Government have been essentially anti-family for the past five Budgets. Despite its approach to poverty on the one hand, it is effectively making middle income families significantly poorer than they have been in the past. The result of that is a significant reduction in Australia's birth rate, to 1.8 per cent, which has fallen below the replacement level. Australia is now the only Western country not to have significant tax relief measures that recognise the costs of raising children.

Over the past five Budgets every attempt has been made by this Government to remove from the Income Tax Assessment Act the range of deductions that were previously permitted for Australian families. The issue that support is given only on the basis of need totally misses the difficulties of determining need at the margin. As the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) is well aware in the context of his own much-heralded poverty package, the simple realities are that families in poverty will in some cases be hit by a marginal tax rate of 110 per cent. For example, families with two children and on $374 to $394 per week, with three children and on $410 to $437, with four children and on $450 to $480, and with five children and on $490 to $520, will find themselves in a poverty trap. That will be a significant disincentive for families in those brackets to increase their income, as they will be better off if they stay on lower earnings and remain dependent on social security. In other words, the Government is effectively giving with one hand while trying to grab back with the other.

Effective marginal tax rates show the effect an additional dollar earned of taxable income has on the amount of money that a family has at its disposal. Deductions from that extra dollar are made by both the taxation system, including Medicare, and the Department of Social Security, through the income test. It is relevant that the Government at the time of the Budget chose to ignore the impact of the Medicare levy on people in that marginal position. That again demonstrates the fact that there are a whole range of isolated-nevertheless very significant in statistical terms-reasons why we must have a basis for social welfare policy which shows a greater integration of the taxation arrangements with social security than we have at present to achieve nationally acceptable objectives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 September the Treasurer (Mr Keating) delivered to the nation a portentous Budget. The reason for its unusually significant status is that it provides manifest evidence that Australia has finally turned the corner. It has turned the corner and, at the same time, turned its back on the years of malign neglect of the poor and deprived in our society. Just over three weeks ago the Government delivered in full its election promise to commence the fight to eliminate poverty in Australia, and so laid a solid foundation for the growth of social justice. Over the past few years we as a nation have been subjected to severe economic restraint in order to break out of the downward spin the country succumbed to in the early 1980s. It was a necessary time for belt tightening for both ordinary Australians and government alike.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Labor Government came to power, 16.9 per cent of Australian children had been categorised, according to reports and studies, as living in poverty. That figure was substantially higher than corresponding numbers in countries such as Great Britain, which in 1979 recorded a figure of 10.7 per cent; Germany, 8.2 per cent; and Sweden, which tabled only 5.1 per cent of its child population as living in circumstances of poverty. Therefore, the centrepiece of this year's Budget is of particular significance because it addresses the very question of child poverty.

In June this year the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made a commitment to eliminate child poverty within three years. The introduction of the family package is the first step towards achieving this goal. This is in stark contrast to the great poverty creating measures of the previous conservative Government, which used its high unemployment policies as an economic weapon. The family package replaces the old family income supplement. It creates a range of new benefits for at least 200,000 low income Australian families. Eligible parents earning $300 a week will receive $22 a week for each child under 13 years of age. That amount will rise to $28 a week for children aged 13, 14 and 15. This extra $6 is in line with recommendations put to the Government by the Social Welfare Research Centre of the University of New South Wales that children in this age group require an extra amount in view of the higher costs incurred in satisfying their basic needs.

The family allowance supplement will be paid in addition to the basic family allowance now payable to every family earning less than $50,000 a year. The ceiling limit of $50,000 for the recipients of the benefits was announced by the Treasurer initially in the May economic statement. These two measures underline the Government's ethos of redistributing benefits in the welfare area away from those who have the capacity to look after themselves. It is consistent with the Australian Labor Party's philosophy that those who can readily support themselves should do so rather than put out their hands to the taxpayer.

In all, this year's Budget directs $250m towards the family package for the 1987-88 financial year. That figure should grow to $500m by the following financial year. Hence, in December the family allowance supplement will be introduced to replace the current scheme. Those on social security benefits currently receiving child payments will automatically receive the increase in the family allowance supplement (FAS) rates. Family allowance supplement eligibility will be subject to a more liberal means test than the one now in existence. For instance, a single income family with two children, earning $350 a week and renting privately, will receive an extra $40 in FAS a week. In all, the family allowance supplement is expected to benefit more than half a million families and one million children.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great achievement.

—As the honourable member for Bowman says, it is a great achievement. Another increase in the Budget concerns a vital aspect of welfare assistance, namely, rental assistance. It is to be remembered that this payment is the first that any government has granted to assist low income families with private rental costs. Parents currently on unemployment benefits renting privately have to wait six months before they are eligible for a maximum rental assistance of $10 a week. Under the new family package the rental assistance benefit will be increased by 50 per cent to $15 a week.

SPEECH.PARA: From next month the new child disability allowance will replace the old handicapped child's allowance scheme. The new scheme will involve an increase in current benefits available to disabled children by almost 20 per cent, from $92 to $112 a week. The new allowance, unlike its predecessor, will not require any means testing and completely does away with the previous two separate categories of benefit under which a child needed to qualify, namely, of being severely disabled or substantially disabled. Thus the new allowance removes the distinction between benefits and rates of payment and introduces one all-encompassing payment. It also alleviates the expensive administrative processes and difficulties involved in ascertaining eligibility for each separate category.

Another significant measure introduced in this Budget is the relaxation of earning restrictions for ordinary pensioners. From 1 November, eligible pensioners will be entitled to an earnings credit system. This means, in effect, that once a pensioner has built up an earnings credit of $1,000 based on the amount he or she is able to earn each week, that pensioner can earn up to $1,000 in casual income over a four-week period before his or her pension rate is reduced or fringe benefits are withdrawn. Further, as from 1 January next year, pensioners will be able to keep their health benefit card for up to three months if their income rises by no more than 25 per cent over the fringe benefits limit, which at the moment stands at $75 for single pensioners and $126 for couples. These changes should remove the problems previously experienced with small fluctuations in pensioners' private income, which may come about through interest earnings or exchange rate movements.

I have already looked at the effect of the family package on my own electorate, and the effect is indeed considerable. I have calculated that approximately 6,000 families will gain immediate benefit from the changes announced. However, there is a limiting factor that, in my few remaining moments, I would like to raise. I refer to the accessibility of Department of Social Security offices to welfare users. Like all government departments and services, the Department of social security has had restrictions placed on it in recent times. This means that in some cases whole communities and large numbers of benefit recipients have to travel consi-derable distances to gain access to a social security office. Obviously, we will never reach the stage where every individual community will have a social security office within it; that is simply beyond the country's means. However, I believe there is in my electorate a very genuine need.

At present, there is no social security office in the Fisher electorate. The area is covered by several offices, the two most important being the Redcliffe office, which covers the Caboolture area, and the Chermside office, which covers the Pine Rivers area. Both of these areas are among the fastest growing in Queensland, evidence of which is the fact that the Fisher electorate has received the largest number of successful applications under the first home owners scheme, which I believe demonstrates not only the rate of growth within the area but also the type of growth which is towards the lower economic scale. As a result of these changes in the population, over 40 per cent of the clients at the Redcliffe social security office come from the Caboolture area. The need for an office in the area has been recognised by local officials and I am delighted that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) will be visiting my electorate and the Caboolture area later this month to assess personally the need for an office in the Caboolture area.

In summary, the Budget is to be commended for its social security policies. It is a Budget which recognises genuine need and contains poli-cies which target those areas of genuine need. Essentially, the main issue which this country is facing, that of poverty, particularly child po-verty, has been tackled very effectively by this Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —While I recognise the sincerity of the sentiments of the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) I hope that when he has been here a little longer he might turn a slightly more critical eye on some of the social security policies of his Government. Unfortunately, time is very brief in the committee stage so I will not be able to cover very many topics at this stage. But there are a couple that I want to talk about, and I think the honourable member for Fisher may be interested in the first one. If he is in the position of not having an office of the Department of social security in his electorate at all, this is undoubtedly a problem that will present itself to him. It is certainly one that has presented itself in my electorate and will be alleviated to some extent by the very welcome decision by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) of a few months ago to set up a social security shopfront in the town of Beenleigh, which is part of my electorate. There is a very high rate of social security payments in that area and, previously, those people had no choice but to travel to Woodridge, which is very relevant to the first point I want to raise.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year in the Budget debate I referred to the Government's decision requiring recipients of the supporting parent's benefit and the widow's pension to report to an officer of the Department of Social Security shortly after reaching the status of pensioner to explain what they were doing about getting employment. At the time I could get no response at all from the Government on the effect of this decision. I was very sorry about that because I thought it would be something that would concern certainly its women members to some degree. But I received no response on it. At the time I described the policy as callous and heartless. It has now been in operation for some time and we have had an opportunity to look at its actual operation.

I made the point then that women who would not qualify for the supporting parent's benefit or widow's pension unless they had dependent children, and since they were also coping with either a bereavement or a breakdown of marriage, they were in a very vulnerable position. I felt that to require them to present themselves shortly after bereavement or marital breakdown and to explain to some bureaucrat why they did not have a job, was very unfeeling and certainly did not show any understanding of their position. At the time I also queried with the Minister the cost of implementing this scheme. If there was to be all this checking on these recipients each quarter, and if they were to be counselled each quarter on how to get jobs-in other words, to have pressure put on them to get jobs-obviously it would be very costly. At the time the only comment made by the Minister-as I recall, by way of interjection-was that the cost would be covered by the savings.

What actually happens, I understand, is that a recipient receives a letter saying, `Mrs Jones, it is time for you to report to the Woodridge social security office and tell us what you are doing about getting a job. Please bring this letter with you'. Mrs Jones, who lives at Eagleby and has no public transport to the Beenleigh railway station, pays a taxi fare, possibly carting along two or three pre-school age children, travels to the social security office, and presents the letter. The staff take out a list, tick off her name, and say, `You may now go'. No effective counselling is taking place. It might soften the blow a little if it were.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an interview.

—There is no effective counselling, in my experience. Furthermore, I am informed, there is no requirement to prove identity. The letter in the hand is supposed to be proof of identity. It is possible that Mrs Jones is in fact in a job and is receiving a supporting parent's benefit, and her neighbour, who is not in a job, presents the letter and is ticked off on the list as being Mrs Jones. If the system were to work properly, it would incur major costs. Having made the decision-a pretty tough decision given the personal hardship it creates-the Government has not been prepared to fund what ought to flow from the sugar coating of the pill, because it would be enormously expensive.

SPEECH.PARA: The other anti-family, and certainly anti- female, action of the Government this year was the means testing of the family allowance. When the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced in the May statement that the family allowance would be means tested on joint parental income over $50,000, no explanation was given of the implications. The first opportunity I had to ask a question of the Minister about that matter was during the first week in June, which was, of course, the last week the Parliament sat-in fact, as I recall, it was the last day of the sitting. On that occasion there was no opportunity to follow up the Minister's answer to my question.

I asked the Minister what would happen in the case of divorcees or people separated from their spouse where, as on most occasions, the female is the custodial parent and the recipient of the family allowance. I asked the Minister whether the Government intended to set up files on everybody receiving family allowance in Australia. The Minister slid off on to the topic of handicapped children and did not give me an answer to the main thrust of my question. What will happen with recipients of family allowance who are unable to obtain from the other parent-the test is applied to joint parental income-information about that other parent's income?

Forms have been sent to recipients, asking them to enter on the form the taxable income of the other parent. Last week there was a news item that some tens of thousands of recipients of family allowance have not responded. I am aware that at least some women have returned the form with the notation, in relation to the taxable income of the other parent, `He will not tell me'. I am aware that there are other women who simply cannot find out. I am concerned about what happens. A lot of them will not have returned their forms yet. Are they to lose their family allowance? If not, under what circumstances will the Government pay family allowance without knowing joint parental income, and how are those circumstances framed so that the means testing is effective at all? Is it possible that a woman can send back the form saying that the father of her children will not tell her what his taxable income is? Maybe it is $100,000 a year, or some major sum of money. I do not know how the Government gets around that problem. I will be interested to hear how it can effectively means test without causing hardship to what I believe is a considerable number of women who are not in a position to respond to the Government's request.

I am sure that some honourable members realise that while many women know, or think they know, what their husbands earn-they know what he gives them for housekeeping-they really do not know what is on his tax return. I think that there are many women in that position. Many of them would not have cared previously, but now they need to know. It was my opinion, at the time, that the Government was opening a hornet's nest with that particular item. The Minister for Social Security might justify it on the grounds that family allowance should not go to people of high income. Before those words leave his mouth I ask him to give some thought to the things that were said by members of the Labor Opposition in relation to family allowance when it was introduced by the Fraser Government, and when in a subsequent Budget proposed the so-called newsboy tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —The infamous newsboy tax.

—That is right; the infamous newsboy tax. I am on the public record as opposing it at the time, but so are a number of present Australian Labor Party members of parliament. The reason I opposed it was that we said at the time that family allowance was introduced that it represented some sort of economic recognition of mothering, or parenting, if the Committee prefers. The point is that approximately 99 per cent of its recipients are women. The criticism that was made by the Labor Party of the newsboy tax was that it was an attack on the principle of family allowance. When family allowance is means tested the same attack is made.

SPEECH.PARA: For many women in this country it is the only truly disposable income they have, in terms of total discretion, to themselves. By requiring these women to become social security recipients with a file in the Department of Social Security on the subject and by having them enter into a different sort of financial relationship with their husbands or ex-husbands, the Government has overturned all that, and in so doing has shown a very poor understanding of the significance of family allowance to nearly all the women who received it.

There is a subject I do not have time to speak on, but it is referred to in an excellent article in the Catholic Leader of 27 September 1987. It is about the care of acutely ill patients, particularly the elderly, in hospitals. I seek leave to table that article.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I always find it interesting to hear members of the Opposition criticising the Government on the measures it is taking to try to improve the plight of people in poverty. I am not questioning the sincerity of the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan); I am saying that this Government is at least trying to address the problem. When I was in opposition I do not recall the Fraser Government doing that sort of thing at all. I think one has to recognise the efforts of this Government and the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who is at the table, to try to overcome these very severe problems. I will be talking about a problem of one of my ex-constituents in a little while.

SPEECH.PARA: In my speech on the second reading I congratulated the Government on the family package of $250m. We honoured our election promise, but there are still a number of problems. I would like to quote from a very excellent short paper called Welfare: A Fair Slice of the Cake recently prepared by Julian Disney, who is the President of the Australian Council of Social Service. He said:

The number of Australians living in poverty has increased very substantially over the last decade or so. Precise measurement of poverty is impossible but the number of people living below the Henderson Poverty Line, which is the most widely-used measure in Australia, has more than doubled since the mid-1970s and is now in excess of 2 million.

In the short time available to me I want to deal mainly with a problem in relation to an ex-constituent of mine. I mentioned it during my speech in the second reading debate. It relates to the circumstances of Mrs Olive Richards and her daughter, Adele. I know that Olive would dearly like to be able to speak directly to the Minister, but she is at least speaking to him through me. She will be aged 50 years on 17 March next year. She owns her own house and she has a daughter, Adele. She is, however, living below the poverty line. She is finding it extremely difficult-increasingly difficult-to make ends meet. She is a widow on a Class A pension of $276.30. When Mrs Richards' daughter Adele reaches the age of 18 on 3 January 1988, having left secondary school on 23 October this year, Mrs Richards will fall back on to a Class B widows pension of $224.30 per fortnight. Mrs Richards also receives an English widows pension of #23.88 per month, which varies according to the sterling-dollar exchange rate, which has not been in Mrs Richards' favour over the last few years.

In December Mrs Richards will lose #15.20 per month from her English pension, which will then fall to #5.97 per month. In confirmation of these matters I quote from the letter which Mrs Richards received on 10 August 1987 from the Department of Social Security:
Dear Mrs Richards,

You are currently in receipt of a Class A Widow's Pension at the rate of $276.30 per fortnight being made up of $224.30 per fortnight payment in respect of yourself, plus $28.00 per fortnight Child's Allowance and $24.00 per fortnight Mother's Allowance in respect of your child.

We make this payment because you are supporting a student child, should this child cease to be a dependant on you or leave school you will receive a Widow's Class B Pension at the rate of $224.30 providing your domestic and financial circumstances remain unchanged.

Mrs Richards also received a letter from the Department of Health and Social Security in England which advised her that her pension from there would be made up of the widowed mother's allowance at the personal rate of #2.17 and a child dependency increase at the rate of #3.80, making a total of #5.97. The letter stated:

I should also advise you that while you are living in Australia permanently, you do not qualify for the annual increases of widow's pension. This is because we do not have a reciprocal arrangement on social security with Australia which allows for the increases of widow's pensions to be paid to persons living there.
I say to the Minister that I think it is unfortunate that we cannot have some reciprocal arrangement. I now quote directly from Mrs Richards's letter:

Believe it or not I am now to be taxed on my income. I cannot claim for daughter as she receives Austudy $2,086 and she works after school. I have double checked that with the Australian Taxation Office.

Mrs Richards then explains that she pays $367.76 to the Commissioner of Taxation and she gets a pensioner rebate of $109.75, so the total amount of tax that she must pay is $178.01. Her letter continues:

If I don't pay, I'm given an extension of time to pay. If I still don't pay I am summoned to court, and have to pay tax plus court costs. If I still refuse to pay-articles are taken out of my home equal to the amount owing. If I won't let them into my home, I may go to prison.

If I had worked at a paying job . . . earning the $40.00 per week allowable income before it takes 50 cents in the dollar out of my pension, allowing for public holidays, my earnings would have been $2,000, of this I would have to pay $900 Tax!

This bad news has dashed any hopes of me even bothering to look for paid work next year. The only paid work I would under-take now, would be strictly CASH, and this is precisely what the Hawke Government wants to outlaw.
Yours, fed up,
Olive Richards
This letter demonstrates the rather desperate straits Olive Richards is in. I would like now to go to another quote from Julian Disney's paper, in which he says:

Popular prejudices about sole parents are often based on images of young girls conceiving children without any serious relationship in order to enjoy a comfortable life on social security. In fact, more than 80 per cent of sole parents who are receiving social security bore their children while living with a partner . . .

A further cause of increased poverty in the community has been that over the last decade all categories of social security payment to meet the costs of raising children have fallen in value. Family allowance, for example, has fallen by about 30 per cent in real terms and the special payment for sole parents (the mothers/guardians allowance) has fallen by about 20 per cent. Moreover, most income tests for these payments have become tougher.

I want to draw the case of Mrs Richards to the attention of the Minister. I know he is concerned for people like her. I do not believe the social security package which we brought forward for families in poverty will help Mrs Richards. This problem relates partly to taxation also, and I know the Minister cannot have direct responsibility for that. The Treasurer should be made aware of the problems facing these people, and there should be a tie-up between the Social Security Department--

TALK.START.PARA: —We would like to give him a go at that, though; put him in charge of taxation.

—Perhaps that will happen one day; it remains to be seen. Meanwhile the Minister is doing a very good job where he is. I think we will find that the record will show he is one of the best Ministers and one of the most caring Ministers that this country has seen for many years. I bring this case to his attention in the hope that something might be done for people like Mrs Richards. She finds it very difficult, at her age, to get a job, and in fact all the schemes being run now are for much younger women. I believe something has to be done for people like Mrs Richards, and I hope that the Minister might find some way around her problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was impressed by the compassion shown by the previous speaker, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), for certain clients of the Department of Social Security. Compassion definitely needs to be shown to many people who are suffering because of the inadequate administration of many of the Government's welfare programs and because of the inefficient and perhaps uncaring administration within the Department. I am sure that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) is well aware of this issue and I would be very interested to hear in his remarks later what he proposes to do about the appalling level of staff morale within his Department and also the almost unmanageable industrial relations situation that exists in some States.

SPEECH.PARA: Without citing individual regional offices of the Department of Social Security-and I am quite sure that many members of this chamber are aware of the problems I am going to allude to as a result of their own experiences within their electorates-there are major morale problems, and regional managers are encountering major discipline problems in terms of achieving work targets and the objectives of government policies within the Department. The major consequence of this is that the people who are in need of help are suffering. Only the other day we saw a 24-hour strike within the Department of Social Security. Pity help anybody who was in trouble on that day, because the Department just closed its doors and said, `Tough; if you are in trouble! We are more interested in our staff positions than in helping the people we are getting paid to help'. I wonder what the Minister has to say about that. He was conspicuous by his silence on that whole issue.

As I said before, the question of industrial relations within the Department of Social Security is a joke. I refer to the radiation testing of the visual display unit screens that was forced on the Department by the union, and I might ask the Minister how many screens have been found to be faulty as a result of that. When he is answering that question he might also tell us how much money he spent buying new furniture as a result of demands made by the unions, where the old furniture is and perhaps how many people he could have helped had he not bought that unnecessary equipment. He might also make reference to some of the other problems of his Department in terms of repetitive strain injury, or whatever they choose to call it right now, and the way in which the Government buckled to the union's pressure in that area.

Unfortunately, that is perhaps only the tip of the iceberg in terms of the problems within Social Security. This Minister, for I do not know how many years, kept telling us that there was no problem with fraud and overpayment within the Department and then, as a result of immense public pressure and pressure from members on this side of the chamber, it was suddenly decided that there was a need to do something about it, and something is beginning to be done about it. The regret is that literally billions of dollars were wasted. There is no way of accurately checking the figures that the Government lays claim to right now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you make it trillions, Charles?

—Every time the Government makes a new initiative, it is very hard to reconcile that initiative figure with the previous one. We have saved hundreds of millions of dollars of waste on the Minister's own admission in his Press releases and in the Press releases put out for him by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). If we go back a little further we will see Press releases in which he himself said that there was no problem within the Department. I wonder exactly what sort of detailed understanding he has of the Department's administration. Perhaps he would do better to spend more time running his Department and less time involved in factional brawling. The Minister interjected to ask why I did not make it trillions. That is a pretty weak response. The reality is that the administration of the Department of Social Security has gone downhill dramatically since he took over. He knows that. The Department knows it. The Government knows it. And the people of Australia know it. That is what it really comes down to.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a social security review, which is a very good idea. It is about time we had consistency within social security policy in this country. But we have not achieved it. We have seen new income tests introduced for pensioners. The commentary on that is that they are so complex and so confusing that most people do not understand how they are going to operate. It is another example of the Governments changing the rules of the game after the game has started. That is what it did with pensioners, with the assets test, with the superannuation tax and now that is what it is doing with the income test. The great pity is that is does not know where it is going. Whilst it is playing around with changes in this area, what is it doing to make sure that the changes in terms of income support are consistent with the programs of welfare delivery in other departments?

TALK.START.PARA: —Your Government did nothing when in office, nothing at all.

—The honourable member from the back bench interjects that my Government did nothing. Let me remind the honourable member that I have never been in government. I suggest that what he really ought to do next time he goes into the Caucus is to ask this bloke at the table what he has been doing for 3 1/2 years. The answer will be, `A big fat nothing', because there are more people in poverty in Australia right now than there were when this Government came to office. We are spending more money on welfare than we ever have before and we are doing less good. He knows it. The left wing knows it. The Minister knows it. The Treasurer knows it. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) knows it. And the reality is that the people of Australia know it.

SPEECH.PARA: Welfare in Australia is out of control because the Labor Party, which comes to office saying, `We are compassionate, we understand welfare, we know what we are going to do', does nothing. It takes three years to set up an inquiry. Once it gets an inquiry, it starts rewriting the reports because it does not like their conclusions. Let us talk about family assistance and about the inconsistent approach in averaging incomes for the family assistance program and what this Government has not done for pensioners. How come it can lag the reductions in income support for families but cannot provide the same sort of concession for the income test for pensioners? Where is the consistency in that? How come the Caucus battle was lost when tax cuts for wage and salary earners were obtained but nothing could be done to implement anything to relieve poverty traps at the same time? Where is the compassion of this Government? It has not got any.

The Government is making an unholy mess of maintenance collection. We have had a number of statements. We have had some inadequate booklets. The other day the Minister, instead of putting down a statement in this place, came in here, answered a dorothy dixer and said nothing. The expectation that has been raised in the community is significant. The detail that the community has been given is almost non-existent. We do not know what is going to happen. We have not been told how it is going to be enforced. We do not know whether it is going to be universal. We have no idea what stage 2 is going to consist of. We do not know what the formula is. There has been no genuine consultation. It is typical of the way in which this Government operates in this area. What it does not appreciate is that, while the bureaucrats may be quite cosy out there in some high rise bunker working out what they are going to do, there are literally millions of people in Australia who suffer as a result of this sort of total confusion.

We have a government that has no direction and a Minister who has no real concern for his Department's administration. We have a Minister who cannot appreciate that there is a need on a day to day basis to make sure that the shopfront operates properly. I invite the Minister to visit a few social security regional offices and just have a look. The Minister should walk in with a false moustache, make sure that counter staff do not recognise him and see what their attitude is when he applies for something. What is he going to do about the attitude and efficiency of counter staff? What is he going to do about the efficiency of communication with his clients? Not a thing. A few years ago we had a big Press release which said--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I take a point of order. While I understand that you have discretion to allow pretty wide debate on the Appropriation Bill, I suggest that you advise the honourable member to address himself to the appropriation and to indulge rather less in his usual whingeing, whining personal insults.
—There is no point of order. The appropriation is to pay for the running of the Minister's Department. The honourable member is talking about the running of the Minister's Department.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. The Minister's pathetic point of order underlines his lack of understanding of what constitutes the administration of his Department. He is probably not even aware that his Department has a computer that generates the most impersonal confusing letters to his clients. It would be a good idea if he read some of the things that go out under his Department's letterhead because, let me tell him, what is written is almost unintelligible. This Department regularly writes to people at the wrong address, demanding repayment of debt or offering cash discounts for debts that have yet to be proven. The detailed administration mistakes within the Department of Social Security are absolutely horrendous.
—It is a long time since you have prepared a speech on social security.

—The Minister sits at the table and makes gratuitous interjections. It is a long time since he did any policy work in social security. When someone does put a policy up to him, either he does not like it or it gets rolled in Caucus or Cabinet. That is the problem. It would not be so bad except that millions of Australians are suffering as a result of the inadequacies of this Government's social security policy.

—What about the report that was prepared recently. You should read the report-- Mr BLUNT-The Minister sits there talking about the Cass report. I pose this specific question to him: Why do we have an inconsistent approach to income averaging for families and pensioners and how does he justify that if he is genuinely concerned about consistency within the Department in respect of its income support programs and equity within the Australian community? I would be interested in his justification.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harvey Mrs E.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that it is rich to hear the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) criticising this Go-vernment's implementation and administration of social security policies. Of course, the Opposition when in government had no problems with the implementation of its new programs because it did not have any.

SPEECH.PARA: In addressing the social security aspects of the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88, I wish to concentrate on one feature, namely the provisions made in it for the security of income for the aged in our community. This latest Budget represents a continuation of the commendable action which this Government has taken over the last 4 1/2 years to maximise that security. Income and services for the aged are of vital concern to me because, as I have said before in this place, I represent the electorate with the largest number of aged people in the country where almost 20,000 people are in receipt of an age or similar pension. This fact is certainly not lost on me and neither, I might say, was it lost on the Opposition candidates in Hawker during the last election campaign.

In its dealings with the aged people of this nation, the Opposition usually works on two premises-one incorrect and one correct. The first premise it works on is that old people are fools. The second is that old people are easily scared. Old people are not fools. I have never assumed that they were and my dealings with them have shown that they have an accumulated wisdom and common sense which I respect and a canniness born of experience which enables them to see through people who are trying to put something over them. However, many elderly people are easily frightened. Because of their age and, in many cases, their infirmity or illness, they can be easily alarmed at any threat, real or perceived, to their well-being. For the Opposition to exploit this propensity for fear, as it has done and did in particular during the 1984 anti-assets test campaign, is shameful indeed.

The misinformation and distortion of facts and the mental acrobatics in which the Opposition candidates in Hawker engaged during the last election campaign in order to ingratiate themselves with elderly people and turn them against the Government were remarkable to behold. We had the Joh Nationals candidate running on the platform of a better deal for pensioners, while the economic guru of his party, the then Senate candidate John Stone, was on record as advocating the cessation of the indexation of pensions, restriction of the portability of pensions for some Australians who had migrated here from other countries and a massive $12 billion in spending cuts which, by necessity, would have impacted hugely on aged services such as nursing homes, Meals on Wheels and home and community care. Yet, in this context, we had the bizarre spectacle of the Joh Nationals candidate running around Hawker on a platform of a better deal for pensioners.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do not worry about him any more.

—No, I will not. Either he did not know what his Party's policies were, which is a distinct possibility, or, more likely, he chose to ignore that policy and try to deceive the elderly into thinking that they would be better off under his Party. However, as I said, elderly people are not fools and the size of the National Party vote in Hawker-1.9 per cent-attested to that.

SPEECH.PARA: The candidate for the Liberal Party of Australia distributed a pamphlet throughout the electorate claiming that the elderly had been forgotten and deceived by Labor. To disprove this allegation, we need only look at the facts. In the 4 1/2 years of this Government, pensions have risen in real terms by 7.5 per cent, while, during the seven years of the Fraser-Howard Liberal Government, they increased by only 1.5 per cent in real terms. In addition, funding for services for the aged, particularly through the home and community care scheme, has increased dramatically since this Government came into power. So who is deceiving or forgetting the elderly? It is not us. This Government has done all within its power to ensure adequate income and services for the aged.

This Budget includes two major initiatives affecting pensioner incomes. These are, firstly, an earnings credit scheme to come into effect on 1 November this year and, secondly, a relaxation of the fringe benefits income test. The earnings credit scheme gives pensioners the incentive to go ahead and supplement their income. This new earnings policy means that pensioners with limited private income can take short term jobs without worrying about cuts to their pension. Under the earnings credit scheme, eligible pensioners will be able to earn up to $1,000 each from casual jobs without losing their fringe benefits or having their pension reduced. At present, people on a pension or the supporting parents benefit can have gross weekly income of up to $40 for single people and $70 combined for couples before the pension is reduced. An additional weekly income of $12 gross is allowed for each dependent student or child in a pensioner's care. Pensioners will be able to accumulate an earnings credit equal to the difference between such amounts and their actual income.

The new policy on fringe benefits means that pensioners will be able to reduce their entitlement despite short term fluctuations in the level of their income, and this will be of particular assistance to those receiving indexed sources of income, such as superannuation, and those receiving overseas pensions, which are subject to fluctuating exchange rates. From 1 January 1988, pensioners will be able to retain their fringe benefits for up to three months as long as their income does not rise by more than 25 per cent above the fringe benefit cut-out levels. These levels are $75 gross a week for single people and $126 gross a week combined for a couple, plus $20 for each child or student in their care. If the income does not drop below the 125 per cent level within that three-month period, eligibility will then cease.

This Budget adds to the measures already introduced by this Government to remove the separate income test on rent assistance and to increase the income test free area for pensions. This Government has already made progress towards achieving its commitment to raise the standard rate of pensions to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. I believe that at the moment that figure is 24.8 per cent of average weekly earnings.

One area related to pensioner incomes is a cause for concern for many people in my electorate and for me, and that is the erosion of the gap between pensions and the tax free threshold. This difference has reduced considerably over the last few years. For example, in 1983-84, the difference between the annual pension income and the tax free threshold was $744.60. In 1985-86 it was $517 and in 1986-87, $478.10. With the present additional income that pensioners can now earn without losing their pension, many of the people in my electorate are rapidly approaching or overtaking that tax-free threshold. I am pleased to note that at the moment the Government is examining the whole relationship between the pension and the tax free threshold. I commend the Government for undertaking that examination and I look forward to a positive result from it. I commend the Government for its actions in this Budget in the social security area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments on the Government's Budget allocation for family assistance and in particular the allocation which constitutes its new family assistance package. I believe that we on this side of the chamber must acknowledge the necessity and significance of the new family assistance allocation. If my colleagues wish to form an objective judgment of the assistance package I refer them to the assessment of the package by the Institute of Family Studies, when it was first proposed during the election campaign, and to a paper entitled `Ending Child Poverty: An Assessment' by Peter Saunders and Peter Whiteford from the University of New South Wales. Those two assessments make it clear that this package of extended assistance will bring about a significant increase in the disposable income of low income families with children. Support for families with children with disabilities will also improve significantly. The Minister will be pleased to learn that I regard that as being positively praiseworthy.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw honourable members' attention to six general points from the Saunders-Whiteford assessment which I think provide context for this Committee discussion. Firstly, child poverty has increased dramatically, with the incidence of child poverty over the last decade rising from 8 per cent to just over 20 per cent. I believe, and I am sure the Minister will agree, that that is a statistic of which we all should be ashamed.

Secondly, child poverty in Australia in the early 1980s was significantly higher than in all other countries except the United States of America. That international standing is not one we should accept, particularly as we enter our bicentennial year. Thirdly, despite the fact that family assistance in Australia is available to all families with children, the level of payment has simply been too low in relation to need. Fourthly, the effect of the Government's package is to reduce this poverty headcount by 130,000 children, or by around 23 per cent.

Fifthly, the raising of the rate of payment for younger children to the older child rate will raise another 165,000 children out of financial poverty, at a cost of $250m at November 1987 prices. However, that will still leave some 285,000 below the poverty line. Sixthly, two other policy areas-employment and housing-can significantly affect poverty levels, and policies designed to get people jobs and into affordable housing are essential to the long term fight against poverty.

I wish to respond in a number of ways to those six points. I believe, along with my colleagues on this side of the chamber, that in the long term, responsible government should make significant improvements in family disposable income and independence by lowering taxation levels and interest rates and removing the current barriers to job creation that exist in an over-regulated labour market. The elimination of poverty should not be achieved at the cost of making people permanently dependent on the state. I hope that the Minister will bear that point in mind. Those should be our long term goals. In the interim, additional community assistance should be available. I believe we should be realistic and accept that, even with significant tax cuts, interest rate declines and a deregulated labour market, there will be many families who, through no fault of their own, need assistance from the community via the social security system.

The second thing I want to say is that if it is true that employment is such an important factor in helping a family out of poverty and into self-reliance, it is time we considered whether preference in employment should not be given to those applicants who do not already have a job, have dependants and would not, by being appointed to a job, simply bring a second income into a family already receiving an average income. My first comments have to do with the need for this assistance package and for all welfare payments to be subject to ongoing and rigorous review and assessment. It was unfortunate that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in response to a question the other day, seemed to accept that a by-product of this package would be that it would be a poverty trap for approximately 20,000 families. He seemed to say that that problem was outweighed by the benefits that would flow to a larger number of families. Frankly, that kind of utilitarian approach to social policy is dangerous.

Let me draw the attention of honourable members to the comments of two researchers which I think are significant in considering the need for constant monitoring of social policy. The first comes from a ground-breaking work by Charles Murray on social policy in the United States undertaken in the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s. The work is called Losing Ground and many honourable members will be familiar with it. Murray writes:

Government's social policy helps set the rules of the game-the stakes, the risks, the pay-offs, the trade-offs, and the strategies for making a living, raising a family, having fun, defining what `winning' and `success' mean. The more vulnerable a population and the fewer its independent resources, the more decisive is the effect of the rules imposed from above. The most compelling explanation for the marked shift in the fortunes of the poor is that they continued to respond, as they always had, to the world as they found it, but that we-meaning the not poor and un-disadvantaged-had changed the rules of their world. Not of our world, just their's. The first effect of the new rules was to make it profitable for the poor to behave, in the short term, in ways that were destructive in the long term. The second effect was to mask these long-term losses-to subsidise irretrievable mistakes. We tried to provide more for the poor and produced more poor instead. We tried to remove the barriers to escape from poverty, and inadvertently built a trap.

The second set of comments comes from a recent article on the impacts of policy actions on the family and household by John Ermisch of the National Institute of Economic and Social Research in London. In the article Ermisch finds that a number of social policies over the years in the United Kingdom have had `significant influences on important aspects of the way in which we live, and in most cases these demographic effects were not recognised by policy makers'. In particular he found that `the structure and generosity of income maintenance programs can have substantial effects on the rate of marital breakdown and the formation of one-parent families and households'. I point out to the Minister that the present cost of the breakdown of marriage is approximately $500 for each of our four million families in Australia. The cost of the Government's marriage education program designed to stop this utilisation of our social security funding is only 25c for each Australian family. That is a matter about which the Government should give some thought. As we know, marriage breakdown is the major cause of child poverty in Australia. I hope that the Minister and the honourable members will accept my remarks in good faith. My concern about the package and our social security system in general is that it is possible that we are simply throwing money at our problems of poverty in an attempt to salve our consciences by simply altering income statistics.

In all cases we should be concerned with the long term impact of any policy on the family unit, and in particular on the underlying social values that we are nurturing or undermining by law and social policies. It is with this concern in mind that I and my colleagues on this side have pressed for implementation, for example, of work for benefits schemes as one way of addressing the attitudinal and value questions which can be so crucial in breaking poverty cycles. I ask the Minister to take these comments seriously. I ask the Minister also to consider whether more use could be made of the Institute of Family Studies in providing multi-disciplinary monitoring of the impact of government policy on families. I am sorry that the funds of the Institute are being reduced in the latest allocation from the Attorney-General's budget.

There is one other aspect of the social security package before us on which I wish to echo the concerns of the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) in regard to cuts to widows' pensions. At the very least, no community can, in conscience, accept the work of women in raising our children and then not provide comprehensive and sensitive programs that assist them in the transition from family care and pension to full time participation in the work force for which they are unprepared and disadvantaged. More importantly, both sides of the chamber need to reconsider their policy decisions to deny eligibility to women who have sacrificed career and income to care for their children under the additional burden of being alone in that task when their children turn 13 or 16 years of age, or, so far as I am concerned, 18 or 21 years. I also refer the Minister again to the suggestion I raised last year that both widows and the community would benefit if widows were allowed to earn significantly more than the $36 they can earn now before losing their pension by raising the figure maybe to $136.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In taking part in this debate on the estimates for the Department of Social Security, I should like to open my comments by bringing to the attention of the Committee a quotation that appeared in a recent journal published by the Department of Social Security. The quotation is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: A nation's compassion may be shown in its care for the disabled and those past work, but for the evidence of its concern for its future (which also includes its capacity to exercise this compassion) we can only look at its care for its children.

Whilst I would be one of the first to wish us to achieve that desirable goal of removing child poverty, I am deeply concerned that the way in which we achieve that goal should be such that we raise the standards of all children and not bring their standards down to the lowest common denominator. I recognise the Government's attempt through its family assistance package to focus attention on poor families, but I think it is a very bad thing. It shows a lack of compassion and concern for all children if we remove poverty from poor children by making other children poorer. That is what the Government is doing. The cost of providing for the poor children of the nation through the family assistance package is being met by squeezing the benefits that are available, or have been available, to other children.

If we look at the level of family allowances, we find that in this year Australian families as a whole will receive $1.1 billion less in family assistance than they were receiving in real terms under the Fraser Government, because this Government has frozen family allowances. As a result of that, families with children helped, in a unique and special way, carry a burden that single taxpayers and families without children were not called upon to pay to cover the Government's deficit and, in this current year, to meet the cost of providing for poor children. So we are making all children poorer so that we can make poor children less poor.

Over the years that the Labor Government has been in office families have been denied $3,170m as a consequence of the freezing of family allowances. It is worse than that because, in addition to freezing family allowances and in spite of the Government's promise, the spouse rebate has been frozen. A significant proportion of the spouse rebate-a reduction of tax liability to families where there is a dependent spouse-is a tax relief that assists families with children. This year families who have a dependent spouse or a single income will be denied $320m compared with the amount that they should have been relieved of tax had the spouse rebate been adjusted to take account of inflation.

I have a view that we are going about the situation of providing family support in totally the wrong way. I believe that if we want to be concerned about the future of the nation, we should be providing for all families tax relief, or cash allowances equivalent to the tax relief, and cash allowances we pay to children and families who are totally dependent upon the Department of Social Security. Yes, I know that will be a major change, but we are faced with a major crisis. Our population is not replacing itself. I read a headline in the Australian newspaper some weeks ago entitled `The birth dearth'. Australia is not replacing her own population because our birth rate fertility rates are below the replacement level.

It has been customary wisdom to say that population policy cannot be influenced by giving substantial family allowances. I think that customary wisdom is wrong. If one studies the history of Western industrialised nations over recent years, takes account of the change in social attitudes as a result of people's capacity to have birth control, and looks at the peaks and troughs of economic fortunes, when a country's economic fortunes are down, like they were in the Depression, one will see that the birth rate fell. That was because people took a conscious decision recognising that they could not afford to have families, or to have larger families than they already had.

I believe that honourable members constantly meet with young people of child bearing age who say, `We are putting off having children and when we do have children we will have two'. Families who have two children say, `We would love to have more children but we will not because we do not believe we can give more than two children a fair start in life'. Why is that? Why are they saying it? They are saying it because the tax system is crucifying them. They are taxed as single individuals. In our public policy for families in general, other than those on the social security system, we are treating them, as the economists would say, as though they were consumer goods. We are not recognising them as people from the date of birth to the date of death. We are saying, `While you are a child you are a luxury of your parent, the indulgence of your parent'.

The parent, in making the decision to have children, must pay the total cost of maintaining those children over the 16 or 20 years, if they go on to tertiary education, that it takes to get them to a stage where they can be independent and self-reliant. Here we are picking up the poor children who are becoming poor because our total tax and social security system denies the existence of the children in the intact families. I want to look for a moment at the effect of this Labor Government's policies on intact families compared with separated families and ask the question whether or not these differences cause a change in social behaviour.

I have chosen in my first illustration to pick a family that, looking at overall averages, would be regarded as being one of which there were probably quite a number-a family with two children and an income of $25,000. After allowing for tax, adding back spouse rebates and family allowances, the disposable income of that family would be $20,380. But if that family splits up, what is the disposable income of that family? The disposable income is not $20,380; the disposable income of the split family is $28,323. A family is $7,900 better off if it is split. It is crazy that we should be funding families in a way that gives them a financial incentive to split--

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not do it voluntarily.
—You say they do not do it voluntarily?
—Or course they do not.

—The honourable member should study the situation a bit more. A lot of families are stressed because of the Government's tax burdens, its failure to index family allowances and its failure to increase the spouse rebate. That causes family tension and as a consequence of the breakdown of the family the Government rewards them as a total group by giving them an extra $8,000. We need to give every family an extra $8,000 and make a major and genuine reform of the tax system that takes account of those who support dependants-dependent spouses, dependent mothers and dependent children. If we do not do that our population will continue to decline and the number of poor children will grow and add more to the burden of the intact families.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I want to thank honourable members on both sides of the chamber for their contributions to this debate on the Estimates. I was pleased because a number of honourable members on both sides referred to some policy issues and from various points of view made contributions to those policy issues. Certainly I welcome any suggestion that we need to do more thinking about social policy and we need to be more open-minded about the approach taken. It would be a good thing, even when the Senate is considering Estimates, if we put the balance more on to policy and got away from some of the preoccupations about various aspects of administration, particularly if we are going to take, as the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) was suggesting, something of a longer view.

SPEECH.PARA: I now refer briefly to some criticisms and suggestions made by the shadow spokesman, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), that the Government had not made progress in the area of overpayments. Improvement in identification of and procedures for recovering overpayments has resulted in the raising of $89.9m, or an increase of 22 per cent in the 1986-87 year over and above the previous year.
