The overpayment recovery totalled $52m, an increase again of 25 per cent over the previous year's figures. At the end of 1986-87, $170m in overpayments remain uncollected. However, the figures to September 1987 indicate a higher recovery as a result of decisions made and announced as part of the May statement. In 1986-87, 1,813 prosecutions were launched for breaches of the Social Security Act, with convictions recorded in 1,794 cases. Nineteen charges were dismissed. Fines, excluding costs, totalled $650,000 and 173 offenders were gaoled as a result of offences during that period. In addition, there were 284 prosecutions under the Crimes Act relating to social security matters and only four charges were dismissed.

I am sure that more can always be done. I am aware of the context in which the honourable member for Bradfield made his remarks, which was to draw the attention of the Parliament to the scale of the social security system. It has a budget of more than $18 billion, with more than 100 million single payments in any one year. In a system of that scale, clearly vigilance is required and we need to be giving a great deal of attention to seeking to avoid fraud and overpayments. Certainly it is something we have sought to do, and I believe with some effect. That is not to suggest that we may not need to do more. We need to improve the quality of decision-making in the Department. We need to improve some of our procedures, but that is an ongoing task. I hope that in the debate we will seek to avoid what I have regretted most in the past several years, that is, the pillorying of clients by category, some stigmatising of people, which is unfortunate.

The honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) raised the question of the procedures adopted when spouses had separated or were divorced. In those cases the income of the non-custodial parent is not to be taken into account. I think the honourable member also had in mind the case of the spouse not providing an income to the mother. The Department will pursue those cases to ensure that it establishes what the appropriate income level is. In such cases we do not put the onus on the mothers to provide that information. Clearly we will have to concern ourselves with some people. Perhaps a significant number of people will not return forms, and it is intended that they will be followed up. There will be a period of grace, if you like, of three months in which people will be able to secure payment if it has been stopped as a result of non-return of forms by the appropriate date.

As usual, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) traded a great number of unsubstantiated insults about the Department of Social Security, regional offices, counter staff and Ministers. Anyone who came into sight seemed to attract his ire. I do not propose to go through his remarks, except to say that in passing he made reference to the massive problem of repetitive strain injury (RSI). He was suggesting that the Department of Social Security wasted money on furniture, the problem was out of control and no one was concerned about it. I think that was the strength of what he was saying. The Department has taken the problem of repetitive strain injury very seriously, as indeed has the Government. We have sought to do the things the experts believe help in relation to that problem. Clearly, the better ergonomic design of furniture is an important aspect in ensuring that people do not suffer from RSI. If that means that some furniture has had to go somewhere else, it seems to me to be not unreasonable. It has been important to ensure that occupational therapy services are available and that there are proper rest breaks for people. We are operating one of the largest public sector computer based information systems of any department in the world. With such a scale of operations there is a lot of repetitive work and a great deal of attention has to be paid to the conditions of workers. The attention that has been given to the matter by management and very legitimately by staff associations and unions appears to be paying off. The trend certainly is towards fewer working days lost. To go back not all that far, 9,853 working days-the equivalent of 43 working years-were lost in the September quarter of 1985, whereas in the quarter ending June 1987, the last quarter for which figures are available, 4,340 working days, or 19.28 working years, were lost. If one looks at the figures for each quarter-I cannot go through them at the moment-one sees a progressive improvement over that period.

I appreciated the spirit in which the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) entered the discussion. I thought the articles by Saunders and Whiteford and the analysis undertaken by the Institute of Family Studies were of a great deal of interest. I welcomed very much the very objective analysis that Saunders and Whiteford made of the family package. We do have to be careful not to claim too much and we have to be precise about what it is that we are claiming. I think they focused very much on that point. It is a little unfortunate that, when people talk about children in poverty-I think Julian Disney was referred to by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton)-they take the 10-year figure. Without wanting to beat the Opposition over the head, the reality is that child poverty, or the presence of children in pensioner or beneficiary families, grew very substantially during the period that the Opposition was in government. In 1976 there were 283,000 children of pensioners and 89,000 children of beneficiaries, or 372,000 children in pensioner and beneficiary families. In 1983 there were 472,000 children of pensioners and 309,000 children of beneficiaries, or 781,000 children in pensioner and beneficiary families. So, by the time we came into government, one in every five children in Australia was living in a pensioner or beneficiary family.

While the family allowance was introduced in 1976 and while it may have been a very good scheme when it was introduced, it is a fact that it was not indexed and the payments for additional benefit and additional pension for children not only were not increased but fell by quite massive proportions in real terms. Our problem is that we inherited a very large number of children in very low income families. On current figures, just to complete that picture, the figure for children in pensioner and beneficiary families went from 781,000 in 1983 to 786,000 in 1986; so there was not much movement between 1983 and 1986. In fact, the beneficiary population has been reducing significantly during the period that we have been in government. Whereas there were 309,000 children of beneficiaries in 1983, that figure is down to 256,000 in 1986. That indicates the Government's success in dealing with unemployment.

I agree with the honourable member for Macquarie that it is important that these initiatives be monitored. Let me say that we have invited the Institute of Family Studies to monitor the child support scheme. It is my intention to discuss with the Institute of Family Studies the role it might play in terms of what is a very necessary monitoring and evaluation of the changes we are making in relation to the family allowance supplement (FAS) and the other changes affecting income support for families. I am not sure whether very many members of the House have read Charles Murray's Losing Ground but I have read it and I found it of a great deal of interest. But I am not sure that I agree with the proposition in that book that the more one does for the poor, the more poverty one produces.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the way you do it.

—I was going to say that. The quote was that the more one does for the poor, the more likely one is to produce more poverty. That relates to his analysis that the poverty program in the United States of America and some of the changes that flowed out of the poverty program are responsible for, for example, the very massive increase that occurred in the United States in the number of families receiving the AFDC, or aid for dependent children, which is the equivalent of the sole parent benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many different social security systems operating around the world in developed countries but in recent years all have seen a massive increase in the number of sole parents and the number of dependent children in often very poor sole parent families. Frankly, whatever the weaknesses of the American social security system, whatever the weaknesses of the Johnson war on poverty and the various programs that came out of that, I simply do not believe that the poor are so largely responsible for their position or, if you like, that sole parents act to become sole parents or even to remain sole parents so largely because of the characteristics of the social security system.

It followed from the honourable member's analysis-an important analysis in the social security debate-that what we really have to do is to change essentially the attitudes and values of poor people, as if somehow it is that culture in which people live that is fundamental to their being poor. I do not deny that attitudinal factors are extremely important but I believe there is a lot more to it than that. I would not want him to think-I am not sure that he was suggesting this-that the family package is designed to do other than provide incentive for people to move from a pension or benefit into the work force. That move significantly widens the effective gap between the level of benefit, particularly for people with children, and the level of income that they are likely to receive, even if they are in relatively low wage occupations.

That takes me finally to the contribution of the honourable member for Sturt, who decided to take a rather broader and a very much longer term view. Frankly, I do not think that the honourable member for Sturt has thought through the difficulties involved in managing a social security budget when we have the horrendous economic difficulties that this country has been going through. I love the principle of universalism. I suppose I am a universalist philosophically. But how do we cope with the situation in which this country's national income has been falling and in which we have had to frame extraordinarily difficult budgets? In those circumstances it is important to ensure that, whatever else one does, one targets those most in need and ensures that the social security system, and indeed the overall income distribution system, is progressive. We will be paying something like 60 per cent of our total family assistance payments, including FAS and the family allowance, to families who are in the bottom third of the population in terms of income.

The honourable member for Macquarie mentioned relief from the tax system. The reality is that low income families simply do not pay enough tax to get relief through the taxation side of the equation. I would certainly like to see the benchmarks that we are establishing in this year's Budget in relation to the family allowance supplement more generally shared. But the reality in current circumstances is that that is very hard.

I make one further point. We have made some quite strong claims about the family package. Never since the introduction of child endowment in the 1940s have there been any benchmarks or indexation. The crucial element in this package is the commitment to benchmarks and to standards of adequacy. I guess we will have to think about that -that is where the Institute of Family Studies comes in in terms of the real adequacy. Never have we had that commitment to indexation or to the maintenance of the real value of child allowances. Those are very significant policy reforms that will need to be developed in the course of this Parliament.

Though I have concentrated on the comments Opposition members made during the debate, I welcome the contributions made on this side of the chamber. I shall look at the case of Mrs Richards, referred to me by the honourable member for La Trobe and see whether something can be done, although I suspect that part of the problem is that, despite very strong representations, we have been unable to persuade the British Government that it should index payments. Recently a delegation was in the United Kingdom pursuing that issue. Many people from the United Kingdom who are now permanent Australian residents feel very strongly about that issue.

In terms of the tax threshold and the tax rebate, I know there is a great deal of concern about that matter in the pensioner community in Australia. I am sure that the Australian Pensioners Federation raised that issue with members on both sides of the chamber yesterday. I cannot deal with the issue in terms of Mrs Richards's case but we are well aware of the concern that is being felt. I would like to refer to the remarks of the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey). The population in the honourable member's electorate is skewed very much towards the aged. The honourable member has demonstrated her concern for aged people, as well as other groups, in her electorate, but her remarks referred particularly to the aged. I think the Government has sought, in difficult circumstances, to maintain the real value of pensions. But it is important, in terms of our policies towards the aged, not to look only at income security. I appreciated the way in which the honourable member for Hawker referred to the importance, for example, of the home and community care program. I conclude by thanking all speakers for their contributions to the debate.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories
Proposed expenditure, $958,593,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to start the debate today on behalf of the Opposition by addressing the tourist industry and the specific problems relating to it. First, I want to say that the tourist industry is becoming very tired indeed of hearing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) taking full credit for the growth of this industry in recent years. Lately there has been a tremendous growth in tourism to the point where it is now quite obvious that it is one of our largest industries and, without much doubt, our fastest growing industry. Tourism is going to be Australia's golden egg, but let us not pretend that this Government laid it. Certainly, to be fair, this Government-as have previous governments-has played a role in the growth of the industry; but to claim, as the Minister is so eager to do, that all credit should flow to this Government, is an insult and an injustice to the thousands of individual operators who comprise Australia's tourist industry.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are going to talk about distributing credit for the success of our tourist industry, we really should be sharing it among a whole range of factors. Firstly, I think the Government's inability to properly manage our economy has caused the value of our Australian dollar to collapse. This has had the unexpected effect of making Australia a much cheaper place for foreign tourists to visit. At the same time it has meant that it is more expensive for Australians to travel overseas and therefore, in relative terms, cheaper to holiday in Australia. That is an unexpected side effect of what turns out to be this Government's inability to properly manage our economy, which has caused our dollar to fall so far.

Secondly, we have had the good fortune to have a succession of good films which have excited people's interest in Australia. The most obvious example is Crocodile Dundee. This has helped to promote Australia in a most effective way. Thirdly, I want to make it quite clear that in Australia we have an array of entrepreneurs who have worked in the industry to ensure that every possible detail is properly attended to, and that both domestic and foreign tourists have the level of sophistication and service that are now demanded by today's tourists. These include a whole host of people-from restaurateurs, hoteliers, hire car companies and bus and coach lines, to boat hire operators, resort managers and so on. It is these people who ensure that tourists get what they want, that they are satisfied, and that they return home to tell their friends and neighbours what a good time can be had in Australia. At the present time the tourist industry is in uproar over the Government's decision to axe the tourism overseas promotion scheme (TOPS). People in the industry are upset because of a Press release of the Minister on 4 June this year which said:

`I am happy to say that the Government has agreed to a forward commitment cover for the Tourism Overseas Promotion Scheme (TOPS) of $9m for 1987-88', Mr Brown, Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism said today.
That statement was made by the Minister on 4 June, at the beginning of the recent election campaign. In that Press release the Minister went on to say:
Those applications which have been held up pending the resolution of this matter will now be processed forthwith.

The commitment given in that Press release that not only would TOPS continue but the funding of the scheme would be doubled from about $5m to $9m is very clear. The other clear intention of the Press release was to give those tourist operators, who had applications in the pipeline, the impression that their applications would be processed forthwith. For a long time now the Minister has said there will be no axing of TOPS. I wish to quote from a Press release of the Minister on a previous occasion:

The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Mr John Brown, today denied speculation in the trade press that there was any intention of dropping the Tourism Overseas Promotion Scheme (TOPS). The Scheme is fully operational and is proving itself to be the most cost effective incentive scheme.

This sort of impression was being given to people in the tourist industry before and during the recent election campaign. The importance of this election promise cannot be overstated. The tourist industry had been using TOPS extensively. Prior to 4 June, rumours were circulating that the scheme would be axed. With the commitment from the Minister, these rumours were swept aside. The industry went ahead with its plans to commit thousands of dollars in overseas promotion of our tourist product, knowing that the applications were in, that they met the guidelines for funding eligibility, and so had an excellent chance of receiving government funds to reduce the cost of promotional activities.

The sudden decision announced in the Budget Speech to axe TOPS shocked the industry and has left a number of operators financially embarrassed. It is all very well for the Minister to say that these people had no right to expect to get these funds, but he ignores the fact that these people are trusting souls who, on hearing of the Minister's commitment during the election campaign, placed faith in what he said and expected that he would deliver the goods. They were, of course, assisted in believing that this Government would continue with TOPS because the Minister spent a great deal of time during the election campaign saying that the Australian Labor Party was good for tourism because it would maintain TOPS while the Opposition would axe it. I wish to quote from another Press release of the Minister on 8 July, just a few days before the election on 11 July:

. . . all Australians should be aware that the Liberal/National Coalition proposes to abolish the tourism portfolio and the Tourism Overseas Promotion Scheme. Such moves would severely inhibit the startling growth of this industry.

That statement, made three days before the last election, was clearly designed to indicate that the Labor Party in government would continue the TOP scheme and that the Liberal and National parties in government would axe it. It was those words which added to the confidence of operators who made their commercial decisions after the election based on the promises of the Minister.

Of course, the Minister also completely misrepresented the Opposition's policy on tourism. We had written into our policy brochure quite clearly a firm commitment to continue an effective overseas promotion scheme. We recognise the value of such a scheme. TOPS has proved to be a very valuable tool in our tourist industry's attempt to attract foreign visitors to our shores. I could give many quotations to the Committee from the Minister which verify the effectiveness of TOPS.

If there were to have been any changes made to TOPS, they should have been done with plenty of notice to the industry so that there was no one hurt financially by those changes. As it stands now, there are a number of operators who are left considerably hurt and it is worth stating that, like it or not, the Minister's own reputation has been injured; some in the industry would say that it has been irreparably damaged. I asked a question of the Minister on this subject during the week in Question Time. He did his best to wriggle out of the election campaign commitment, but I can assure him that the only person he may have convinced was himself and perhaps a few of his deluded colleagues on his side of the chamber.

Moving from this to a more positive note, I want to raise the subject of work practices within our tourist industry. An impartial observer could comment only that Australia's tourist industry labours under a set of work practices that are a left-over of the Dark Ages. An enlightened person would recognise that there is a need for change to these archaic conditions that handcuff tourist operators' hands to the point that they cannot perform to the level of sophistication and quality of service that is required in today's modern tourist industry. Tourism occurs seven days a week, 24 hours a day. However, the work practices that operate are set by the standards of an industry that should operate Monday to Friday, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.

In April last year, the coalition released the most advanced industrial relations policy ever put forward by any political party in Australia. That policy was specifically designed to cater for the needs of our growing tourist industry. It would have enabled, through voluntary contracts mutually agreed upon by both employer and employee, our tourist operators to provide the same level and quality of service for tourists on a Sunday as are now provided on a Wednesday or any other day during the normal working week. Our policy would have sensibly addressed the issue of penalty rates which at present this Government supports and which presently cripples our tourist industry making it either impossible or too expensive for it to provide proper services outside the hours of 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., Monday to Friday.

I conclude by saying that this Government needs to stop congratulating itself for the growth in our tourist industry. We need to recognise the needs of the industry. We need to recognise that there is a role for an effective overseas promotion scheme like TOPS. We need to recognise that there is a need to change our work practices so that the tourist industry can take full advantage of the potential to earn income for Australia. I also want to put on record that I believe that the Liberal and National parties have the best policy in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak today on the environment. I invite every Australian to consider a recent news story which was casually reported during September which stated that the hole in the ozone layer over the Antarctic was larger than ever and that a reading showed 15 per cent less ozone than the previously recorded minimum in 1985, and 50 per cent less than 10 years ago. I invite every Australian to consider a recent scientific finding that the large hole that has been appearing in the ozone layer over Antarctica each spring since 1985 is not a natural phenomenon.

SPEECH.PARA: The scientific community has reached a very unpalatable finding, that this earth is about to be turned into an immense greenhouse which will spawn higher temperatures, increased sea levels and, in terms of biological effect on humans, will mean an increase in the incidence of skin cancer, especially amongst fair-haired and fair-skinned people, and those living above the 40 degree latitude. It will also increase eye disease. Ultraviolet (UV) is known to be a major cause of cataracts and the main cause of blindness among people in developing countries. It will also damage the immune system. Laboratory evidence has demonstrated that exposure to UV can harm our immune system making us more susceptible to disease.

Environmentally, the impact would be just as serious. The higher ultraviolet levels would cause a destruction of ocean plankton which is the first link in the marine food chain. It would cause the collapse of a complex ecosystem in the aquatic environment. It would also mean a reduction in crop yields. It would also contribute to the climatic changes that are already occurring because of the greenhouse effect forcing the world's agricultural areas closer to the north and the south poles.

We must now accept the very chilling announcement that mankind is actually fouling its own nest. For the first time, the life habits of one of earths inhabitants is upsetting the very balance of all life on this planet. The carelessness of man means that much of the damage that has already been done to the earth's atmosphere cannot be repaired very quickly.

In the short term, the time has come for us to pay the price for our pressurised spray-can existence. Spray-cans are not the only source of chlorofluorocarbons. Chlorofluorocarbons are widely used in refrigeration, air-conditioning, electrical solvents and in the production of some plastic foams. Some manufacturers of spray-can propellants have been very responsible and have changed the method of propelling their products. However, I urge the general public to look at the spray-can before they make a purchase and buy only those that do not contain chlorofluorcarbons or halons. The propellants are usually marked on the outside of the can.

The Australian climate is going to change as temperatures rise two or three degrees centigrade. Rainfall will increase by up to 50 per cent in summer and there will be decreases of 20 per cent in winter. Already in Western Australia, farmers are very concerned about the changes in the rainfall patterns at present. Tropical cyclones will move further south and occur much more frequently. Sydney is being affected by more and more cyclones. The sea level will rise by almost 80 centimetres. The snow lines will move higher. Floods and droughts will become even more common and salinity problems will occur even more rapidly than at the present loss of 100 square miles per year in Australia.

I am sure that many people who live in my electorate of Dunkley will welcome a few more warmer days on our very spacious and sandy beaches around Frankston and Mornington. Furthermore, I am sure that an expanded tourism industry on the Mornington Peninsula will become a reversal of the annual winter exodus to the friendly climates to be found in beautiful electorates such as Leichhardt, Herbert and Capricornia, which are well represented in this chamber. However, I am not so sure that our homes, schools, offices and work places are set up to cope with the large increases in heat and humidity that will occur. I am not so sure that those in my constituency who live along Port Phillip Bay will enjoy the tranquil blue bay lapping under their back doors. More importantly, I am not so sure that those who are enticed to bask in the sunlight will be aware of the heightened dangers to their lives from skin cancer. Maybe the medical profession will gain some joy with the reduction of the ozone layer.

We are about to be overcome by a dilemma that pervades almost every aspect of our very existence. Traditional, often inflexible, areas of our welfare will be assaulted. How will centuries old housing structures stand up to the new weather extremes? What will happen to agriculture? Can the leisure industry adjust? Will the health budget grow even more? Will the benefits of economic growth be cancelled out by climatic changes? Who will pay for the cost of coastal destruction? It is very possible that we may direct the long term scenario. A prescription for recovery and repair is being formulated, but it must be administered in the very near future, lest dramatic and irrevocable impacts of procrastination be felt in the next century.

The moment for talk has passed and an age of consensus now calls for bans. Of course, the year 2000 is only 12 years away, but can we afford to wait until then to see the elimination of chlorofluorocarbons? At present the production of CFCs in aerosol propellants, refrigeration devices and even hamburger packaging, continues to grow. Every one of the additional cases of fatal skin cancer, as well as the damage to wildlife and agriculture, should be a reason to prevent a further deterioration in the ozone layer. Each Australian should understand the basic science behind the greenhouse effect and support further research to provide long term planning. The Government must increase funding for research in this vital area-an area that affects our very existence-and perhaps compensate industries, such as Australia's developing electronics industry, which may suffer when the use of halogen gases is banned.

I call on the Government to implement urgently legislation to limit the manufacture of ozone-depleting chemicals. I also urge it to sign the protocol which was recently written in Montreal. I believe that the States have to be consulted before new laws can be framed. This must be done with the utmost haste to avoid further damage to our fragile environment. If we plan properly for the change in climate and other changes which are coming, we will be able to benefit from them. However, if we stick our heads in the sand and do no research or planning, our nation and our future inhabitants will suffer greatly. Clearly, in order satisfactorily to complete this experiment, an input is required from everyone. The whole world is the laboratory and the life support system crafted by nature over billions of years. It is waiting to be redeemed by us and not crisply toasted-a toasting brought about by ignorance, a lust for profits and a lifestyle which can easily be changed. We must act now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the estimates for the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, I confine my comments to the area of tourism. I commend the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) for his contribution a few moments ago. I thought he was correct to target the abolition of the tourism overseas promotion scheme-the TOP scheme-which has really done a great deal to make Australia capable of promoting itself on the international world tourism markets. I give the Government full credit for introducing the TOP scheme and the help it provided. But parts of the industry are in very deep trouble as a result of the abolition of this scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: I tend to agree, too, with the honourable member for Gilmore in his criticism of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown), for the claims that it has been he and this Government that have brought about this tremendous revolution in the tourist industry. I think the proper credit should be given to a great number of people who for many years did some tremendous work to make sure that Australia did become an international tourist destination. I am sorry that the Minister is not present for this debate. I hope it does not mean that he has lost interest in the industry. I sincerely hope that the Minister will give due recognition to people such as the late Frank Stewart, a former Labor tourism Minister, who did a great deal to form the foundations of our international industry, and the late Sir Phillip Lynch who, in the Liberal Party of Australia, did a great deal to make sure that we had the right basic infrastructure and that we were prepared to go out in the international markets to promote Australia as an international tourist destination.

I also hope that he will give credit to this chamber for what it did in the promotion of tourism. It is now 10 years since the House of Representatives Select Committee on Tourism met to determine whether we should try to encourage a tourist industry in this country. The 48 points that the Committee recommended to this chamber were acted upon by the then Liberal Government and by Sir Phillip Lynch, which laid the foundations for the build-up of this tremendous industry in Australia. It is Australia's fastest growing industry, the only industry in Australia that has a real capacity to be able to provide long term jobs for all Australians. So there has been a tremendous contribution by members on both sides of the chamber. There has been a tremendous contribution from people in the industry who have battled overseas against insurmountable odds to make sure that Australia was promoted. I pay particular tribute to people such as the inbound tourist operators of Australia and the quality hotel groups which went into the Japanese market 15 years ago and which laid the foundation for the buildup of this industry.

While I congratulate the Government on all that it has achieved in tourism, we must never rest on our laurels. One thing about international tourism is that it can be a very fickle industry. One thing about which we must be very careful is that we must make sure that we have the capacity to meet the demands of the international visitors who are coming to Australia in ever-increasing numbers.

One of the reasons that Australia has done so well out of the Japanese market is due not only to the devaluation of the dollar-and this might sound quite strange-but also to the fact that the Japanese who, year after year, went to Hawaii, found out all of a sudden that Hawaii was not safe any more. In fact, the muggers on the back streets of Honolulu have probably done more to promote Japanese tourism to Australia than many of the other issues that are raised. We must make sure that the industry can provide that safe environment to those international visitors. We must make sure that people who are involved and employed in the industry are properly trained and have the capacity to be able to deal with those international visitors. I think that governments, both Federal and State, should feel good about what has been achieved in the training schools and colleges in recent years. But a lot more must be done. It is only now that we have proper tertiary facilities for the training of people in the hospitality industry. The opening of a degree course at the James Cook University of North Queensland in Townsville is a tremendous innovation.

One of the things that have happened in Australia in recent years is that there has been an explosion in the number of large hotels and hotel chains in the country. We have not had the people to manage them. We have had to import overseas expertise to get the tourist industry running. There is nothing wrong with that, of course, because we have a lot to learn from some of the big international operators, but we must make sure that at every level we have the capacity to be able to train our young people to go into that industry and, as I say, to provide the types of services that international visitors need in Australia.

While the Minister trumpets the fact around Australia that at least two million international visitors will come to Australia in 1988, during our Bicentenary, one thing worries me at the moment; that is, whether we will have enough airline seats into Australia to be able to handle the traffic. If one reads today's Press one will see that there is a very great difficulty in Singapore at the moment, where more than 100 people are waiting to get airline seats to Australia. It is almost impossible to get on an aircraft between Japan and Australia, despite the fact that we have gone from just five services a week to about 17 services a week in a few years. We cannot handle the traffic out of there. The expansion of the North American market will continue. Despite the fact that we hear about rows between the Australian and the United States authorities, there will not be enough seats on that route, either, if we are not careful. One thing that has happened is that one cannot get seats on Qantas Airways Ltd aircraft across the Pacific. While it is great that Qantas is the most popular carrier, let us make sure that we do not become so narrow-minded that we are not prepared to open up the skies a bit more.

It is almost impossible to get a seat on an aircraft in and out of Cairns in north Queensland because the Great Barrier Reef has become very much a focal point of Australia's international tourist effort. We hear that it is almost impossible to grant extra services into Sydney because Sydney Kingsford-Smith Airport is stretched to the limit. That is true, but the facts are that overseas tourists want to enter the front door of Australia-the Great Barrier Reef. They do not want to enter by way of the tradesmen's entrances of Sydney and Melbourne. We should make sure that any international carriers which want to apply for traffic rights in places such as Cairns, Townsville, Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth do not have to wait months and, in some cases at the moment, years to get approval to operate those services into Australia. There is no longer the excuse that international carriers coming to Australia are only after the Australian business. Virtually every international air carrier coming into Australia now brings in more inbound passengers than it takes out Australians. Qantas Airways Ltd is a fair example of that. It openly concedes now that 60 per cent of the passengers it brings in are international visitors while only 40 per cent of the passengers it takes out are Australians. That is great for Australia but let us not kill the goose before it lays the golden egg by putting up every conceivable sort of barrier against new carriers or additional services coming into Australia. As I say, although the tourism industry is growing very well, it is a fickle industry and we must make sure that we take full advantage of it while we can.

In so many of the debates in this chamber we tend to confine ourselves to what is happening in international tourism. To some extent we should do that, too, because after all that is the cream and the area that will provide the long term employment. But let us never forget that we do have a significant domestic tourism industry as well and that it will remain very much the bread and butter of our tourism economy. We should be doing all we can to promote it. It concerns me that for one reason or another many Australians do not have an annual holiday; they do not have the capacity to go out and see what Australia has to offer. We hope that special efforts will be made to get those people, for the good of their own health, out of their homes and into some of the magnificent areas that abound in this country.

It seems from statistics available that better than 40 per cent of Australians do not go on an annual holiday. Quite frankly, if we could get that 40 per cent moving we would not have the infrastructure to handle the situation in a domestic sense, let alone an international sense. We must try to do everything we possibly can to get more and more people holidaying in Australia, and especially to get that 40 per cent who never have a holiday out and about. That is why it was essential that the report on the deregulation of the Australian airline industry be released yesterday and that it be examined very closely.

One of the prime reasons people do not go on a domestic holiday in Australia is the high cost of air fares. Not many people realise that only 14 per cent of Australians have ever been on an aeroplane. One of the principal reasons they have never been on an aeroplane is the high cost of air travel. I am confident that with deregulation we will see more innovative fares, that we will see the capacity for more and more Australians to travel around the country, and everyone in this chamber should do everything possible to make sure that deregulation of the airlines occurs in this country in the next three years so that we have that capacity to enable people more and more to move around Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me lay to rest one of the canards floated by the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) when he suggested that an unexpected side effect of our alleged economic mismanagement and the subsequent devaluation of the dollar was a boost for the tourism industry. It was never an unexpected consequence. Every time the Treasurer (Mr Keating) talked about the J-curve, the Opposition pooh-poohed and carried on. The effect of the devaluation was substantial and immediate in the area of tourism, and certainly it was something we anticipated. It was part of the process of rebalancing the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important for us to understand these appropriations in the context of the Budget. We have to understand that this Budget has the second lowest deficit of any Budget for 35 years. It is a balanced Budget. We have to put these appropriations in the context of this time of economic restraint. It needs to be clearly understood that we have had the largest fall in outlays in the 35 years for which comparable data is available. It is the second successive year in which we have had a real fall in outlays. Gross expenditure cuts in this Budget total over $4 billion, with net program cuts totalling $2 1/2 billion. It needs to be understood in that context that some programs and areas of expenditure have suffered as a consequence.

I intend to speak today about the appropriations in the area of sport and recreation. At a time when it was necessary for restraint and a cut in outlays, the Government gave priority to the areas of education and training and family assistance for the needy. We were able to increase expenditure on those priority areas. As a consequence of that and in the context of restraint and economic parsimony at a time of rebalancing and reinvigorating our economy, any impartial observer who looked at the appropriations for sport and recreation would have to say that they are static. Those who have an interest in this area of human activity would say that it is not enough. But sport is not a life and death issue in our society; it is not the most important issue we face. However, it is an issue that relates to the quality of our life and it is very important to the vast majority of Australians.

At the risk of being called a philistine, I would say that there is still in this country a substantial cultural cringe, and while expenditure in the area of the arts remains much more substantial than expenditure on sport I suppose many in Australia will feel that there is an imbalance. One would have to say that in a unique way sport touches the lives of every Australian. Very few families in this country would not have one member-be it one of the children, a parent or a grandparent-in some way or other being involved every weekend in some sort of sporting activity, whether it be participating or watching on television or live. Indeed, it is an integral part of our life. Earlier this week a very famous Australian, Sir Donald Bradman, commented on the social benefits of sport. Many people over a long period of time have suggested that sport is an outlet for frustration and a counterbalance for the changes resulting from the associated difficulties with our sedentary lifestyle and that it plays an important part in educating our society.

As I have already mentioned, when one looks at the budgetary allocations in this area one can only say that those allocations have remained static. I would say that the response of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) and his Department would be that we have tried to produce a more lean and efficient way of administering the programs in which we are involved. The Australian Institute of Sport (AIS) has been asked to tighten its belt. Certainly it has been asked to look for marketing and sponsorship opportunities that perhaps it did not seek in the past. Those sports that have particular programs which benefit from the Australian Institute of Sport funding are being asked to provide more assistance for those programs. Individual programs are being reviewed. I do not have any difficulty with any of these moves, even if it is necessary for me to watch Dr Dick Telford, from the Institute of Sport, selling cereal on television. That is a way these programs can receive additional assistance, and it is a necessary and important form of sponsorship for the Institute of Sport.

The Government, by its commitment to the Institute of Sport, through the enormous amount of infrastructure produced and as a result of the number of programs in place, which continues to increase, has led the way for States to get involved in such institutes. In Western Australia, South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales-many States-we find increasing interest and growing institutes. By leading the way the Federal Government has decentralised even more talent identification and the interest that surrounds institutes of sport and sport in general in the States.

The other important initiative announced by the Minister on 25 September was the establishment of a single national sports body. Through the amalgamation of the Australian Sports Commission (ASC) and the AIS the Minister sees significant efficiencies in administration, and I understand the savings in the first year in rental costs alone will be hundreds of thousands of dollars. Indeed, through that, it will be possible for this national body, which is to include the AIS and the Australian Sports Commission, to provide more money for its programs. The most important increased allocation in the Budget is that to the Australian Sports Commission. That is a response to the many sporting bodies throughout the country that were concerned about the sports development grant which the ASC provides, and it will provide the Australian Sports Commission with the wherewithal to increase the programs which provide grass roots administrative and coaching assistance for the many sporting bodies throughout the country.

It is important that we see these allocations not in isolation but in the context of a time when economic imperatives must take first place. This is a time when the Government has to determine priorities and, as part of the response, I hope that we will find a leaner and more efficient expenditure of money in this area. Perhaps this Budget will teach sport that it has to be more efficient and careful in its expenditure. I hope that the Government's program will, as a result, become more efficient, and that in the future we shall find ourselves in a position to expand these programs further and provide increasing opportunities for Australians to excel and become fitter, healthier and more involved in recreation. I hope that the effect of this period of parsimony will be that we shall have a more efficient expenditure on sport and recreation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address the Government's expenditure priorities in relation to the environment part of the portfolio of the arts, sport, the environment, tourism and territories. I find the priorities that the Government has outlined in this area interesting in many respects and rather disappointing in some others. The way the Government has approached the whole issue of the environment, including expenditure on it, is in many ways not surprising. It is not surprising because the Minister for the Environment and the Arts, (Senator Richardson) is the Minister responsible for numbers within the Australian Labor Party-the man who describes himself as a `born again greenie'. That is not because he is concerned with the environment-we all know that-but because the one thing that he desperately wants is to get new people on the electoral roll to vote for the Labor Party rather than not voting at all. That has been the priority of the Labor Party. That is why the former Minister responsible for the environment, the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen), who did a creditable and sincere job, although there were times when we disagreed strongly with the details of what he did, has been replaced by a man who is, frankly, very cynical in his administration of the portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: That attitude shows up in the 1987-88 Budget estimates for the environment. The environment budget, in a small way, relates closely to the election campaign and to the pay-off now coming from the Labor Party to those more militant environmental groups which gave the Labor Party what it believes to be such valuable support throughout the election campaign. We on this side of the House are of the view that organisations such as the Wilderness Society and the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF)-great beneficiaries of this Budget-behaved somewhat disgracefully during the election campaign. That does not reflect on all the members of those organisations, many of whom have a very strong and sincere commitment to environmental issues, but it does reflect on the very political nature of the leadership of those groups. Some of the claims that they made in support of the Labor Party during the election campaign were outrageously dishonest, and their claims were synonymous with those made by the Labor Party. For example, the Australian Conservation Foundation argued that if the Liberal Party of Australia were to be elected we could kiss goodbye to the rainforests, particularly in the Queensland wet tropics. Nothing could be further from the truth, particularly as some 75 per cent of Queensland rainforests are already within a national park. The Liberal Party said throughout the election campaign that it would support the World Heritage listing of the Queensland wet tropics, provided that the boundaries for the World Heritage area were properly and honestly drawn-there are real questions about the boundaries put forward by the Government-and provided that this was done in co-operation with the relevant State government. Apparently that was not acceptable to the Australian Conservation Foundation, which still persists with its claim that, under a Liberal government, we could kiss goodbye to rainforests-something which is manifestly untrue.

It was also claimed that we would hand over to the Northern Territory Government the Kakadu and Uluru national parks. We did not say that at any stage in the past 12 months. Not once have we said that, yet the ACF, doing the bidding of the Labor Party, claimed that that was our position. As to mining in stage 2 of Kakadu National Park, we have made it clear all along that mining could proceed only if we and the bureaucracy were satisfied that it was environmentally sensitive.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what Joh said.

—Not once was that concession or policy recognised by the leadership of the ACF. It claimed that we favoured oil drilling on the Great Barrier Reef, yet the Fraser Government and subsequent Liberal-National Party politicians at the Federal level have repeatedly said that there would be no oil drilling on the Great Barrier Reef under a coalition government.
—Why do you repudiate Fraser all the time?

—The Tasmanian forests, according to the Labor Party and its friends in the leadership of the ACF, are also under threat. It is interesting that the Labor Party, particularly the Left of the Labor Party, interjects in support of the ACF. Of course it does, because this is the great pay-off. This is the great deal that it is doing.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Chairman. I would like to point out that I am not of the Left and I have been interjecting--

—Order! The honourable member may raise that matter later. It is not a point of order. I remind the honourable gentlemen on my right that they are contributing to spoiling the environment and should remain silent.

—That is a very good point, Mr Deputy Chairman. It has also been claimed that the Tasmanian Forests would be destroyed under a coalition government and under the policies of the Tasmanian Government. There has never been any suggestion that that would happen. Great play was made by the Labor Party, perhaps understandably because it is in opposition to the Liberals, but also on Labor's behalf by the ACF and the Wilderness Society, of the claim that, by abolishing the responsible department, which in any case has been abolished and merged with another department, we would somehow desecrate the environment. All that we were suggesting was merging its function with those of other departments to improve its efficiency, something that the Government has now done. The hypocrisy of the argument put during the election campaign has subsequently been exposed. There has been not a whimper from the ACF or the Wilderness Society about merging the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment with the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism. That is interesting and very revealing.

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout the election campaign, we made positive commitments, for example, to revitalising the national conservation strategy for Australia, which has been completely ignored by this Government over the past 4 1/2 years, and to the need for proper reafforestation programs which, while not quite ignored, has been given a very low priority by the Government. I draw the attention of the other side of the chamber to the fact that funding for the national trees program in this Budget has been reduced in real terms, whereas funding for the ACF and the Wilderness Society has been increased by about 20 per cent in nominal terms and about 13 per cent in real terms.

No concessions were made to our constructive policies on soil conservation and on water quality, but anybody who is genuinely interested in the environment knows that important as rainforests are-they are a very important issue, and one dear to my heart-the issues of soil conservation and water quality are the fundamental issues for Australia. The sort of cant that we get from the other side of the chamber about Labor members being the only people who care and about nobody else being interested in rainforests is absolute, complete and utter nonsense, and Australians ought to know it. The Liberal and National parties care very strongly for the environment. We are prepared to concede-we are quite open about it-that aspects of our policy need to be strengthened. We have said already that our commitment to States rights was perhaps too dogmatic in our policy and that we would like to find an improved formula. We have said already that the decision not at any stage to use the export powers of the Commonwealth in relation to environmental objectives needs to be reconsidered. We have said those things and made those things clear. But our profound commitment to the environment should never be taken away from us.

I have to concede that the Labor Party, in co-operation with the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Wilderness Society, has been very clever in putting together a false campaign which has promoted us as environmental vandals. But the great pay-off for that is in the Budget: grants to voluntary conservation organisations are to be increased by 20 per cent. Interestingly enough, this year's Budget Papers for the first time do not give a breakdown of how those grants are to be distributed. However, in contrast to organisations such as the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Wilderness Society which are to receive a 20 per cent increase in their grants, the World Wildlife Fund will receive no increase in funding. That is a very interesting contrast.

This Government has ignored, in spite of the fact that the matter has been raised in this place, the way by which the Australian Conservation Foundation has been laundering funds through its tax deductible status on behalf of organisations such as the Sydney Peace Squadron, the Movement Against Uranium Mining and the People for Nuclear Disarmament. Contributions to those organisations should not be tax deductible. The Government and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) know that, but they will not do anything to stop this very public scheme because it would offend the leadership of the Australian Conservation Foundation which has done so much to advocate the case of the Labor Party. I am profoundly disappointed that so many people in the Australian Conservation Foundation have been deceived by their leadership.
