SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first opportunity I have had to speak since re-election, so at the outset I would like to congratulate all on their appointments, except probably myself. Anyway, I would like to congratulate everybody. I would like to pay a tribute to my fallen colleague the Hon. Michael Hodgman. He will be sorely missed in this Parliament. He did a good job for the people of Tasmania; he did a good job for the people of Hobart. I have been watching with interest the new member for Denison (Mr Kerr). I heard his maiden speech and I remember a few things that were said during the campaign, but there will be plenty of time for me to come back at him on a few things that he has said.

SPEECH.PARA: The only thing that I would like to say to him is this: please do not talk about parts of my electorate; do not isolate a couple of areas that have been pin-pointed by the so-called experts of the world, talking about the low level of incomes and the high levels of unemployment in that particular area. We can all pick out parts of our electorates and start talking about them, but anybody who has been in this game for 12 years, who knows the people of Bridgewater and Gagebrook and who has worked for them would know that there are problems there. Those people out there are trying to make a decent and respectable living. If people like politicians and the media keep saying that they are such and such and so forth, they will get an inferiority complex. Of course, they have high levels of unemployment. Most of the young people who go out to those areas go out for a roof over their heads; they know that they are unemployed, but they are trying to work out of it. They also know that there are people out there, single mothers, et cetera, who go to those particular areas.

When politicians and other people start talking about statistics that are plucked out of the air, all they are doing is drawing attention to the problems of those people and giving them an inferiority complex. If they had dealt, as I have done for 12 years, with those people, these so-called experts would know that there are out there very decent people trying to make a go of it and that they were behind the eight-ball before they started. The former member for Denison, Michael Hodgman, I am sure, will be fighting to come back, and I am sure he will be back, but his work will be remembered.

Now I have a couple of grievances: firstly, I have listened intently to the ladies in the House, although some of them like to be called women. They are always talking about the problems associated with women. But I very rarely hear them talk about elderly women. Therefore, today I thought I would start talking once again about the aging population of Australia and the lack of strategic directions that we have to look after them. If I cite a few facts, we might start to realise that we have a massive problem on our hands and that all parliamentarians need to work together to overcome this problem.

We have an aging population in Australia: that is, 1.6 million or 10.23 per cent of the Australian population are over the age of 65. In the course of aging, the aged population will continue to increase and the young population will continue to decrease in both relative and absolute terms. Australia must face up to this massive problem. For example, a problem that is never addressed, and one that I think that we had better start addressing because it is right before our very eyes and is starting to bring its own problems, is that women live, on average, 10 years longer than men. In fact, many of the elderly women in Australia today did not want to go out and work but wanted to stay home and look after their children.

The honourable member for Canberra, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), will smile at this because I usually give her a few serves, but she will understand the point I am driving at. I can understand women who have to go out and work, and I appreciate that. But many women who stayed home and looked after their children are now all of a sudden on their own. Some of them have moved to areas to retire. Regrettably, the husband dies, usually 10 years, on average, before the woman. That woman is left, probably away from her family; and, of course, there are problems associated with that. Many of them never learnt to drive, consequently there are problems with transportation. I think that we in Australia had better start addressing this problem.

As I have said on many occasions, we had better start addressing this aging population problem to try to work out systematic schemes that will help them. I hear all this stuff about their being better looked after in their own homes. Who the dickens is going to provide that army of helpers to look after the aging population in their own homes? There are not enough people equipped to do it, and some of them work on the old union rules; they would not even lift a mat to clean the floor. The point that I make is that it is silly to talk about it; we need a systematic plan.

We must realise that the aging population needs special attention and special assistance. For example, an article on the front page of today's Hobart Mercury-everyone probably knows that I come from Hobart; I am the member for Franklin-talks about an 87-year-old lady who is left by herself and needs accommodation. She wants to stay by herself; she wants to stay in accommodation for herself, but she cannot get it because she has a little dog. That is another important point. The point that I make is that she cannot get accommodation because she has got a little dog, probably the only thing that she loves.

We have to start realising that when we get older we change dramatically. I am only young yet, but some on the other side are old and they must realise this. We have to realise that there are circumstances that change one's personality. There are reasons that problems will come to the fore that one has never had before. I mentioned the mobility one: looking after one's own home, the roof and paint and all the other things, when one is left by oneself. As a nation we are going to have zero population growth and an aging population, and we should be very aware of this problem. The women of Australia, the elderly women, those between 50 and 65, should start to realise that they had better plan for that sort of situation because, if they do not, they will be in a problem area. I know that people on my side are starting to realise it. It really hurts me.

I have been talking to the Minister for Forests in Tasmania today, and he was telling me about the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into logging in the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests area of Tasmania. I know that Australian Labor Party members have all gone green. Somebody said to me, `Bruce Goodluck, you would have got more votes at the last election if you had supported the conservation movement, the greenie vote'. I said to them that I was just as dogmatic as they were. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), a very good member, mentioned something about being dogmatic about our concerns with conservation. They are just as dogmatic. We were talking generally about the Helsham report. It is going to cost about $3m. We have QCs and juniors running around, all with their hands out, because they get big dough. They will criticise the politicians for their salaries but, boy, they reap it in. They are going over the same ground again. We all know the problems with the timber industry in Tasmania. We have had about 11 reports. We are going to get another report.

They are all down there in Tasmania with their cameras and spotlights, they are all getting the big dough, and it is costing the taxpayers of Australia about $2m to $3m for a report that is going to contain something that we already know. I think to myself, `We talk about one in five in Australia living below the poverty line, yet we will expend money on this sort of stuff'. They will say, `Bruce, the trees are more important than the elderly of Australia. They are more important than the one in five that is living below the poverty line'. What a lot of rot! That $3m could provide a village for the elderly people of Tasmania, somewhere they could live for the rest of their days in peace and quietness and not have all of these worries that are confronting them. But it is far better to spend the money to save the trees! Save all Tasmania for the fellow with the haversack on his back but forget about the elderly of Tasmania, forget about that one in five who, I heard those opposite tell me today, is living below the poverty line! Things are getting out of all proportion and it is about time we started to wake up to it.

That has got that off my plate. That is one grievance. It is good to see the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) in here supporting me. It seems unusual not to have the former member for Denison in here supporting me.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's not supporting you; he's laughing.

—The honourable member for Denison is not supporting me. No, he has a look on his face as long as a fiddle. We will spin that one up before we are finished, too, so do not worry about that. We will get on to petrol pricing.
—What have you done about that?

—I knew the honourable member would say that. The old Labor Party was going to fix petrol pricing in Australia. It set up the Prices Surveillance Authority-with a lady in charge, too. I heard her the other day. She probably gets a big salary, too. She was going to fix up all the problems of the petroleum industry. What has she done? Nothing. We have poor retailers in Victoria walking out of their businesses because they are taken to the cleaners by the big oil companies. In Tasmania, people are writing letters and are talking about the price of petrol. But let me say that the reason why we have this problem all over Australia--
—Liberal State taxes.
—Yes, because the shortfall to Tasmania by this Government was such that Robin Gray had to impose--
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise an issue, the significance of which it is impossible to overstate. It is interesting, sitting in this chamber, to hear the quantity of trivia that gets debated. Yet I believe we are dealing with an issue that is going to have incalculable consequences both for the present generation and the generations to come.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members would be aware of the concern which has been expressed over the past three or four years about the emergence of a doughnut-shaped ozone hole in the Antarctic region. This concern has been given new impetus with the preliminary findings for this spring of the United States-British study of ozone levels in the region. Those concerned with this problem have been monitoring the situation carefully and anxiously awaiting the release of the results of this spring's monitoring. I believe that these readings, which apparently show that the ozone layer over the Antarctic region is around 15 per cent lower this year than in 1985-which formerly had the lowest readings-will much more unambiguously point the finger at chlorofluorocarbons, generally known as CFCs, as the cause or, at least, as the factor which is distorting and grossly exaggerating the effect of a naturally occurring phenomenon.

It has been argued that people mistakenly speak of the global depletion of the ozone layer and the Antarctic ozone hole as the one issue. In my view, this year's readings, as well as the results of this study, indicate that they can be regarded as just different faces of the same problem and that the problem is a pollution problem caused by us that should be cured by us. Although many people are aware of the effect of ozone depletion, and I know that my colleague the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) has raised this issue on a number of occasions, most recently half an hour ago-and I must confess that I was not aware of that-it is probably worth pointing out briefly the causes and effects of ozone depletion. Ozone is a highly volatile gas which constantly converts to and from normal atmospheric oxygen by interaction with certain ultraviolet rays. The conversion process is from O3-that is, three atoms of oxygen joined together-to O2. However, these conversion processes normally balance out so that the level of ozone remains more or less constant. In other words, there is a two-way process.

The problem with CFCs is that they accelerate the process of destruction and mean that more ozone is destroyed than created. The extent of the destruction of the global ozone layer is still argued, but it is widely believed that its destruction will expose us to dangerous levels of ultraviolet radiation, causing significantly increased rates of skin cancer, immune system damage, an increase in smog and a rise in global temperatures-the so-called greenhouse effect. Even small increases in ultraviolet light damage life on earth.

As to the specific effects of the Antarctic ozone hole, this is such a recent phenomenon that its effects are still a matter of study. However, there is no reason to suppose that its effect will be less harmful than the global ozone depletion and it may introduce new problems. This must surely be of special concern to Australia because of its proximity to the Antarctic region and its already high level of skin cancers. I believe that our proximity also imposes a special burden of responsibility on us.

CFCs are in wide use throughout the world in aerosol spray propellants-although this use has been voluntarily restricted in recent years-in refrigerators, in air-conditioners and in plastic foam. They are also, as I understand it, used in solvents in the manufacture of computers. As we sit in our air-conditioned offices in Parliament House with the windows nailed shut, we are almost certainly contributing to the very problem I am referring to.

Although it is uncontroversial to attribute this global depletion to the effect of CFCs, there has been considerable controversy about the cause of the Antarctic hole. Until the bad news of this spring's ozone readings, it had been widely argued that the hole was a somehow naturally occurring phenomenon. The argument gained a lot of credence from the fact that the hole mysteriously shrank to half the size last year, which is why this year's results were so eagerly awaited to see whether the shrinkage was a trend or an aberration. It now appears to be well and truly an aberration, if these preliminary findings are confirmed.

The theory has been undermined not only by these latest preliminary findings but also by the recent study detailed in Nature magazine last month, which offered the first major evidence of a causal relationship between CFCs and the hole. This study found that chlorine compounds, almost certainly of man-made origin, bloom in the Antarctic at the same time as the hole appears each year. In other words, things are looking bad. Now is the time that serious action must be taken on this. It is imperative that we not wait for incontrovertible proof. CFCs can last in the atmosphere for up to 100 years, so we have already bequeathed the present depletion levels to our descendants. The least we can do is mitigate the effects of our environmental vandalism by the technology developed by our generation. Our technology inevitably develops faster than our knowledge of its ramifications. For example, the Age reported recently that the Cape Grim atmospheric monitoring station in north-west Tasmania is measuring a dramatic rise in concentrations of the particular halogen used in the electronic industry to clean circuit boards, a problem which will presumably increase rather than decrease unless drastic action is taken.

As far as action in international forums which was concentrated on the much better documented global depletion of ozone goes, this Government's record has been good. We are to become a party to the 1985 Vienna International Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer and have consulted widely with interested groups in Australia as a lead-up to this step. However, the proposed international action to freeze the rate of emission of CFCs and halogens and to implement progressive reduction in the 1990s is not enough, dictated, as it inevitably is, by such factors as protecting the interests of developing nations in the high technology industry race and protecting individual nation's industrial and economic interests, The Government is engaging in further consultative processes over the next couple of months prior to signing the international convention. There is no doubt that it will continue to be subjected to lobbying pressure on this.

Australian industry has co-operated over the last four or five years in voluntary reduction of the use of CFCs in aerosols. However, as with the computer industry example I gave above, the reduction of CFCs in the aerosol area is being constantly offset by increases in new areas and the pressure will undoubtedly be on for government not to introduce measures which interfere with the development of industry in Australia. Any regulatory moves will undoubtedly be represented by lobbying bodies as conflicting with this Government's well-known commitment to industry development. I also have a commitment to the development of new industries and high-tech industries in Australia, but I believe that we must ensure that this is not at the cost of the destruction of the environment in this particular fashion. The Government must be resolute in acting in long term global environmental issues and ensuring that industry continues to develop alternatives to these destructive agents, as has happened with aerosol propellants.

In this context, even McDonalds has announced that it is abandoning the use of CFCs as a blowing agent in the foam containers it uses to keep its hamburgers hot in the United States, in favour of an identical looking but differently made foam. The United States actually has a relatively reasonable record in this area, having unilaterally taken action some time ago to ban the non-essential use of CFCs. They have also exerted a lot of pressure internationally, by way of threatened trade restrictions, to ensure that controls are introduced on CFC11 and CFC12, which are the most stable and therefore the most harmful of the CFCs. This was a strong factor in the international acceptance of a 20 per cent cut in CFC consumption by 1993-94 stipulated in the agreement reached last month on international controls on substances depleting the ozone layer. Ironically these cuts would hurt them disproportionately as they have already cut the fat from their consumption.

CFC manufacturers in Australia seem to be using the argument made famous by the tobacco industry, that the Government should go easy on legislative controls on the use of CFCs because of the absence of so-called absolute scientific proof. However, I would say to those who maintain that the argument at present consists more of suspicions than of certainties that, in a situation where a correction of the problem would take up to 100 years, suspicion should be enough for strong action. I strongly suggest that the Government should bite the bullet on the domestic level and take unilateral action by introducing legislative controls which ensure that we become a world leader rather than a follower in the solution to this problem. Voluntary agreements on reductions have not even held the ground, let alone led to real overall reductions. More is called for before it is too late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this grievance debate to raise my concerns and those of my electorate at the economic constraints which are being imposed on Tasmania as the Hawke Government courts the conservation movement. I am proud to be a Tasmanian and I am proud of Tasmania's forests. Forty-seven per cent of Tasmania is currently wooded, the largest percentage of afforested land of any of the Australian States. These areas include some of the most significant forests in Australia: the Huon pine forests of the south-west, the ferntree forests of the west coast and the temperate rainforests of the far north-west.
—They are beautiful.

—They are beautiful, indeed. It is noteworthy that Tasmania contains approximately 30 per cent of Australia's rainforests and is second only to Queensland. Whilst other States have cleared their forests thoughtlessly and suffered the consequences in soil erosion and the onset of deserts and arid land, to this day Tasmania remains the best forested State.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also proud of the Tasmanian forest-based industries. These industries are Tasmania's second largest value-added income earner, contributing $276.4m to the Australian economy in 1984-85. They employ 22,000 people, one in seven of Tasmania's workers. Even without allowing for the multiplier effect of the $124m that they pay in wages and salaries to their workers, forest industries are clearly an integral component of Tasmanian economic life.

Tasmania maintains a responsible managed approach to forest development. In 1985 Tasmania enacted Australia's first forest practices code to ensure that, as forests were cleared, fresh vigorous forest would grow in their place. The code is a process of ensuring that timber harvesting is conducted in an environmentally acceptable manner. It lays down guidelines covering issues such as acceptable equipment to minimise compacting in the forests; how close one can log to a stream; and visual management issues. Good forestry practice in Tasmania is not just a statute, it is an ethos. I have spoken to Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd chainsaw workers in my own electorate who have suggested to me ways in which the forest could be managed better. They know that good forests are Tasmania's future. I have been to meetings of private foresters, 60 or more just recently, who are keen to hear how best to manage the forest environment on their private property. Mainlanders seem to have the impression that in Tasmania the last forest is about to be logged. I can understand that because of the actions of the Wilderness Society and the conservation movement in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Labor Party.

—As the good member for Franklin has said, the Australian Labor Party (ALP) as well. That is simply not the case. Forty per cent of the State forests and 43 per cent of private forests will never be logged. Harvesting is at a sustainable yield; thousands of hectares of trees are being planted to maintain the forestry stock on an 80-year cycle. With life expectancy in Tasmania at 72 years, this is nothing but an investment in the future. Tasmanians over many years have conserved their natural environment. Ironically, it is our success in conserving the natural beauty of Tasmania that has resulted in our being targeted by the conservation movement and its suitor, the Hawke Government. We are like the virgin being forced into a nunnery to appease the conscience of her loose-living sisters.

SPEECH.PARA: A current example of the Hawke Government's purist approach to Tasmanian conservation is its actions in relation to the Lemonthyme forests. The Lemonthyme State Forest was first proposed by the Forestry Commission in 1963. The Tasmanian Cabinet approved gazettal of the area as a State forest in 1983, with logging due to commence in 1987. In June 1986 the Tasmanian Liberal Government and the Commonwealth signed a memorandum of understanding relating to the granting of export licences. Lemonthyme was well and truly on track. I would just like to quote briefly from that memorandum. It said:

In entering into this Memorandum, the Commonwealth recognises the professionalism and competence of the Tasmanian Forestry Commission and accepts that the Tasmanian Government acting through the Tasmanian Forestry Commission will duly and efficiently perform the many activities necessary on its part to give effect to this Memorandum.

But, of course, the Labor Party turned its back on that memorandum. Let me just outline some of the things which are included in it. It included things which show the sensitivity of the Tasmanian Liberal Government to the environment, such as: identification of archaeological sites; fauna habitat protection; visual management systems; linking corridors for fauna movement; the use of machinery and erosion control in such areas that are logged; soil fertility maintenance; genetic diversity maintenance; fire management; and I could go on.

We then had a meeting of ALP secretaries in Sydney which decided that there were votes in conservation. For purely political reasons the Federal Cabinet decided that there was to be no more logging in the Lemonthyme-throw away any memorandum of understanding, do not trust this Federal Labor Government because it does not have any intention of sticking with the agreements which it makes with other governments. The Commonwealth legislated so that no trees in the two forests could be damaged or removed from the protected area until 18 June 1988 while it had an inquiry, the tenth inquiry into Tasmanian forestry since 1972.

Putting aside the 1987 Budget provision of $1.9m for the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into logging in the Lemonthyme and Southern forests area of Tasmania, the Tasmanian forestry industry will lose more than $8.5m in revenue. Tasmania is being forced to lock up one-third of its resource potential. In mainland terms it is like closing down all the resource-based industries of Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria. Clearly such a move would be ludicrous and nonsensical. It is patently obvious that, for electoral purposes, the Government is intent on bringing Tasmania to its knees. These actions restrict the economic development of Tasmania and narrow the revenue base of the State. At the same time the Hawke Government has reduced grants to Tasmania over recent years. For example, the Federal Government's allocation to Tasmania of general revenue funds in real terms has fallen by 11.4 per cent since 1984-85, a cut of 9 per cent deeper than any other State. The home State of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), New South Wales, had 5 per cent real growth in the same period. On a per capita basis this year, Tasmania should have received $24m for Commonwealth capital works, but instead it received only $8m.

Under Liberal government Tasmania has not faltered in its drive for self-reliance, in spite of the fiscal rape by the Commonwealth. Of all the Australian States, Tasmania finances the highest proportion of State government outlays from own source revenues. The Hawke Government continually obstructs development of our resources, from which we are building a strong, dynamic State economy. This Government seems to act on the principle that what matters is votes and that it wins more votes on the mainland than it loses in Tasmania by locking up economic resources in Tasmania.

Let me relate this dilemma to the national economic scene. We are running heavy current account deficits and trying to replace imports with exports. If the conservation movement's objectives in forestry are achieved, more than $5 billion of forest-based products will have to be imported into this nation. As our national debt rises to $110 billion, the resulting pressure on the balance of trade will be enormous. Each month, as our balance of payments wallows in the red, we are taking another billion dollar leap down the Argentinean road. Over recent years, under the leadership of State Minister Ray Groom, Tasmania has developed a forestry management framework which is sensitive and dynamic. He is a good Minister. I believe that in 10 years time the Tasmanian people and the Gray Government will be seen as the acknowledged Australian leaders in forest and environmental management.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must begin by contrasting the commitment of the honourable member representing Tasmania on this side of the House, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), to the betterment of Tasmania and the balance of jobs and protecting the environment with the very distorted view that members of the Liberal Party of Australia display on this important question. I commend the honourable member for Denison for his constructive efforts to protect the environment and to protect jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I wish to use this opportunity to urge members of the House and the people of Australia to use the opportunities presented by the bicentennial year to support initiatives for sensible and progressive constitutional reform. I do not seek to make a partisan contribution to this debate, but rather to assert the view that, without a bipartisan approach to constitutional reform, there will be no real prospect of satisfying the requirements of section 128 of the Constitution, which requires not only a majority of electors to support a proposed change but also a majority of electors in a majority of states.

There have been, as honourable members would be aware, some 36 attempts to reform the Constitution and I believe that only eight of those have been successful, thus demonstrating that, without Opposition support or, at least, acquiescence, the prospect of constitutional reform is bleak indeed. I note that there will be a debate later this day, moved at the initiative of the Opposition, in which some of these issues will be canvassed in greater detail.

As honourable members are aware, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has initiated a bold new move to promote constitutional reform by establishing the Constitutional Commission. The Attorney's idea in establishing the Commission was to take proposals for constitutional reform away from politicians and put them in the hands of a bipartisan non-party political group of eminent Australians recognised for their contributions to our country. I believe that it is essential to the Attorney-General's proposal that the Commission seek the widest possible contribution of the Australian people to ideas for constitutional change by means of publicity, submissions, public meetings, reports and other initiatives such as those already set in train by the Commission.

I note, with great regret, that the Opposition has not given strong support to the work of the Commission. It is, however, heartening to see that the Opposition does not have a closed mind to all proposals. The shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), pointed this out in a news release of 9 September:

As for the coalition we have opposed the Constitutional Commission as a vehicle for reform but we have continued to make it clear that we will take a sensible and considered attitude to any reasonable proposals.

I endorse the view of the honourable member, who went on to say, `Disunity is death not only for parties but also for referenda'. I welcome these words if they mean what they appear to, namely, that the Opposition is prepared to work in a bipartisan way to secure public support for reasonable proposals. I truly believe that all of us will be judged by future generations for the contribution we make to the process of constitutional change in 1988, because that year gives us an unsurpassed opportunity to grasp the nettle of reform, not just reform for reform's sake but because reforms, I believe, will improve the quality of Australian democracy.

The Constitutional Commission is, I believe, a very representative body and is chaired by Sir Maurice Byers, QC, the former Solicitor-General. It includes among its members Sir Rupert Hamer, a retired Liberal Premier of Victoria, who of course was instrumental in establishing the Australian Constitutional Convention. That Convention, regrettably, did not achieve a successful record of constitutional reform, as I have already indicated. For that reason, Sir Rupert and others who share his goal of constitutional reform have embraced the possibilities offered by the Constitutional Commission.

The Commission's advisory committees are also representative of a cross-section of Australian political opinion, and include among their members Sir James Killen, well known to this House, Haddon Storey, a former Liberal Attorney-General of Victoria, George Polites, former Director-General of the Confederation of Australian Industry, Mr Greg Percival, former President of the Australian Council of Local Government Associations, and, of course, the very well-known Mr Peter Garrett. None of these people could be considered pawns of the Federal Labor Government. They are truly eminent Australians and well suited, I believe, to the task that the Attorney-General has set for them.

The advisory committees of the Commission have examined and published reports on the following subject areas; executive government, distribution of powers, trade and national economic management, individual and democratic rights under the Constitution, and the Australian judicial system. The recommendations of the advisory committees will be considered by the Constitutional Commission after public comment has been sought over a period of months, and early in 1988 the Commission will report. It will then be a matter for the Government to assess which of the Commission's recommendations are likely to be able to achieve the majority support of Australians necessary to satisfy section 126 of the Constitution.

As I have already indicated, the likelihood of bipartisan support will obviously be crucial to whether or not a particular proposal is successfully passed at a referendum. The purpose of my contribution, above all else, is to urge members of the Opposition to keep their options open and not to make pre-emptive statements which will rule out the possibility of bipartisan support for a package of constitutional reforms which are broadly supported by the Parliament. I regret that that plea for the Opposition not to sabotage the work of the Commission appears not to have been heeded by senior Opposition spokesmen, as we will hear in future debates today.

I now turn to refer to aspects of the recommendations of the advisory committees as an indication of some of the issues which may form the basis of discussion of future amendments. I stress that the recommendations are still to run the gauntlet of further sustained public debate and subsequent rigorous consideration by the Government and the Opposition. The first report launched by the Commission was on individual democratic rights. This committee adopted what it described as a practical approach, basing its recommendations on not including a Bill of Rights in the Constitution but recommending change to that Constitution to ensure basic restraints on the power of governments to interfere with individuals and to guarantee participation by all Australians in the democratic process. They are, of course, high ideals. We hear in this House many times calls from the Opposition for greater respect of the rights of the individual. Here is an opportunity to enshrine for all time in our Constitution some of those fundamental human rights which we hold dear.

Specific recommendations from a committee's report for considered amendments to the Constitution include proposals, some of which I agree with and some of which I do not, to ensure that one vote one value and the right to vote are guaranteed to all citizens over the age of 18 years; to ensure fundamental common law principles so that individuals are not wrongly deprived of liberty or property; and to ensure fundamental common law values, such as the place of the Queen and English as our common language. They include recognition of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders in the Constitution and the adoption of a citizens initiative approach to proposed changes to the Constitution, as well as the existing approval of referendum proposals put forward by the Parliament.

The recommendations of a further advisory committee on trade and national economic management, I believe, are also worthy of serious consideration by business, by consumers, and by the trade union movement. There are other advisory committees concerning the judicial system and a further advisory committee concerning the distribution of powers. My limited time does not allow me to make detailed reference to those particular proposals.

It is appropriate that I conclude on the theme that prompted me to speak in this debate today, that is, a plea for a bipartisan and reasonable approach by the Opposition to constitutional change. I ask those opposite not to pre-emptively sabotage the work of the Commission. Let us see whether we can work together constructively to propose amendments which will be broadly supported by the Parliament and which we can reflect on with pride, having been successfully carried by referendum in 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many times I have risen in this House and spoken of the problems facing the Aboriginal people in my electorate and, in particular, those people living in Wilcannia. I suppose that Wilcannia is really a microcosm of what is happening in many parts of Australia as far as the Aboriginal people are concerned. I do not think it is a matter, as some people have said, of our not doing enough or not trying to do enough or not spending enough; I think it is a matter of mismanagement by governments, State and Federal-and I am blaming not only present governments but governments before that-and by the bureaucracy. I think it is high time that something very constructive was done about it. That is why I am hoping that the new Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand)-although we are quite far apart ideologically, I think he is a genuine man-might be the man to do something to clear away the dead wood and get this act on the road.

SPEECH.PARA: I have mentioned before that in Wilcannia, because of the hygiene problems, there is probably the highest incidence of hepatitis B in Australia and one of the highest, so I have read, in the world. It is disgraceful that in a country like Australia this should be so. It is more important, of course, that the young people are looked after. There is at the moment an investigation going on. People are trying to raise money to see whether all youngsters in Wilcannia, or particularly the Aboriginal youngsters, should be immunised against this dreaded disease.

I instance in particular the conditions at a place called the Mission, which is on the eastern side of the river. I go there quite often because I am invited there. The Aboriginal people are frustrated. Several times they have asked me, `Can you do something for us, please? Can you please get us out of the terrible situation in which we live?'. Anyone who went over there to have a look would have to agree with them that it is drastic. There are a number of houses there. The roofs leak, the windows are broken, the windows are out of the houses, the doors are off and the taps are continually leaking. Despite this, the Aboriginal people there try to keep these homes tidy. The septic tanks are overflowing. At one stage earlier this year the septic overflow was flowing under the houses and the situation really was desperate.

Despite all this, the Aboriginal people have approached me and said to me, `Why are we living like this? We pay our rent; no one is doing anything about trying to upgrade our existence'. I say to them, `The main thing is to keep paying your rent'. They do that because they have some pride, but unfortunately nothing much is being done. I believe there are some houses planned to be built in that area, but in the meantime the progress is very slow. I did see the other day over there, would you believe, a working gang putting in some kerbing and guttering. I really do not know what that is going to do to improve the lot of those people, but someone must have had the idea that that would help in some way. We are looking forward to new housing at the Mission, where it is bad enough.

If one crosses the river and goes into Hood Street, Wilcannia, one will see there four houses that have septic systems which are always overflowing. I have tried to get something done about those septic tanks, but the tradesmen are very reluctant to empty the tanks out because they are not sure that they are going to get paid. This seems strange to me when I see that the Minister has announced that this year there is going to be a relative 8 per cent increase, I believe, in expenditure on Aboriginal affairs, taking it up to $671.6m. Something is drastically wrong when all of these departments, the governments and the bureaucracy cannot do anything about emptying out a septic tank. The situation is so bad now that the ground is saturated, it is really not worth replacing the pipes that are broken and really the whole system needs connection to the sewerage. That could be done and quotes have been given over the last two years for connecting the septic tanks to the sewerage. The houses that are there are model houses. It would not matter whether one was an Aboriginal person or a non-Aboriginal; the houses are spotlessly clean. I think that these people really need a better deal.

The problem now is that the Aboriginal people have said, `Okay, we want a quote to connect these houses to the sewerage system'. The problem is that now the Central Darling Shire is owed a substantial amount by the various Aboriginal organisations and is very reluctant. I can understand that, because we are talking about a fairly substantial amount of money. The Central Darling Shire is the most isolated shire in New South Wales and covers a vast area. It cannot afford to be paying out money which it knows that it will not get back. I am sure that one of the main problems that I have come across is the number of Aboriginal departments or bureaucrats that are running around the place trying to organise all of these things. Anyone who can get through that red tape is certainly `a better man than I am, Gunga Din'. It is a very difficult situation we face out there and I believe that something has to be done by the present Minister to sort the whole sorry mess out.

I think one of the major problems has been that in the bureaucracy there has been a tendency to try to make sure that the people who are running the organisations are Aboriginal people. To my way of thinking, because these people have not been trained, that is a nonsense. I think we should get the best people for the job if we are trying to help the Aboriginal people to get a high living standard, which they are entitled to.

The other problem that faces the area-I notice here also that the Minister has said that the Government is going to spend $60m on housing for Aboriginal people over the next 12 months-is that there are so many of these departments that they really do not know who owns what, who is entitled to what and who is doing what. For example, there are several anomalies, amongst which are the complication of the Bakandji Housing Trust building on land that the Land Council owns, Land Council's rents being applied to Bakandji at the cost and expense of Land Council tenants, and the attendant legal implications. There is such a mix- up there that I do not think anyone really knows what is going on.

I once again implore the State and Federal Ministers to go to Wilcannia and see what they can do about improving the plight of those Aboriginal people. I know that I have been on my feet in this House many times raising this matter and that there has been very little done about it. It is not because people are not spending enough money. In fact, I believe the Aboriginal Council up there at one stage a few years ago had millions of dollars, not thousands, in its bank account and still these people are living, if I can put it bluntly, in their own excreta. That is really not good enough in this day and age in this country. I would say to the Minister that the sooner he comes up there the better. I know that he is settling into his portfolio. As soon as he is settled into that, I will be making a request to him to come to Wilcannia because I am sure that, if he can solve the problems in Wilcannia, he can solve the problems in the rest of Australia.

Talking about this amount of money that is being spent and the misappropriation, non-responsibility and non-accountability, last year we had a clean-up through a community employment program grant given to Wilcannia. I think it read something like, `$62,000 dollars to clean up around houses and plant gardens'. If for $5,000 I could not clean up around those houses in two days with an emu-bob, with 10 able men, and pick up all the car bodies, take them away and give some people some work, I would give the job away. I know that there is absolute waste. There has to be something done if this $671.6m is going to be spent in the right direction. I do not believe some of the statements by the Aboriginal community and the non-Aboriginal community, church leaders, members of parliament and the bureaucracy that not enough money is being spent. I believe that we could say that about anything. There is enough money being spent, but there is no accountability in some of the areas that I am talking about, despite the fact that some people are trying very hard. I just hope that the present honourable member for Melbourne and Minister for Aboriginal Affairs can do something to sort the situation out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance concerns the activities of a group of companies known as the D. F. Johnson group of companies. These companies operate under the umbrella of a parent company, Ascot Management Corporation Ltd. Over a number of years, the Johnson group has been active in promoting investment in the property market by the use of unlisted private unit trusts. These trusts are created, operated and managed by the Johnson group. As well as management and promotion, a company registered at the same address, Syndicate Nominees Pty Ltd, is used as a trustee for the unit trusts.

SPEECH.PARA: An example of the manner in which the Johnson group operates is the history of trusts numbered 125 and 126. A glossy brochure published in 1980 by this group sought applications for 40 investment units of $7,500 each in the D. F. Johnson Trust. Nos 125 and 126 were established to acquire 16 two-bedroom strata titled townhouses at 17 to 21 Paton Street, Merrylands, in Sydney's western suburbs. These 16 units are in fact contained in a single building and eight units were put into each trust. The purchase price for each of the eight units was $385,000. In addition to the purchase price, $10,500 was required to renovate the units; $30,500 for formation costs, legal fees and stamp duties; and $36,000 for manager's expenses and trust formation fees-for each trust an all-up cost to the unit holders of $462,000. In other words, the building purchase price was $770,000, but the cost to the unit holders was $924,000. In effect, to buy the building, unit holders paid a premium of 16.7 per cent over and above the purchase price. Of that amount, the Johnson group collected a sum of $72,000 or a commission of some 9 per cent.

If a prospective unit holder was concerned by those costs, those concerns were soothed by the calculations on page 8 of the brochure. This calculation detailed a profit of $221,000 for each trust after a period of five years. This profit was described as a capital growth estimated at 74 per cent over five years. Page 11 of the brochure listed 33 trust syndicates, already sold, showing an average annual capital gain per trust syndicate of 16 per cent per annum. The average total return of each syndicate was estimated at 25.2 per cent. Despite the high on-cost to acquire the investment, the brochure cleverly suggested profits.

Why would the two unit trusts be established to buy the one building? Why split 16 strata units into two lots of eight? Was it only to increase the commission payable to the D. F. Johnson group, or is there any other explanation why this procedure would have been adopted? The use of the two trusts was unarguably more expensive for the investors and added greatly to the on-costs of the purchase price. And what is the result in 1987 of these trusts? In a report to unit holders dated 16 April 1987, Mr B. P. Whiting, director, advised that the profit suggested in the 1980 brochure had not been obtained. Various reasons were given for this failure and all of those reasons must be questioned.

The D. F. Johnson group suggested a solution. The Johnson group estimated the value of the property owned by the 55 unit trusts under its control, as at 30 June 1987, at $24,223,500. So it is not peanuts that we are talking about. A public shelf company was acquired and named Integrated Investments Ltd. Integrated has the same registered address as the Johnson group. The directors are all existing Johnson group direc- tors. The unit holders of the 55 Johnson group of unit trusts, the real owners of the estimated $25m worth of real estate, are being offered ordinary shares in Integrated at a par value of $1. In other words, unit holders of trusts Nos 125 and 126, who, it will be remembered, purchased their units in 1980 for $7,500 per unit, are being offered 7,176 $1 ordinary shares in exchange for the $7,500 investment.

It is interesting, Mr Deputy Speaker, to see how an investment valued at $7,500 in 1980 can be reduced to a value of $7,176 in 1987. It is also interesting to see who will profit the most from this offer. I have no knowledge or information to help me make a reasonable value judgment on the original cost of the investment properties. I can, however, express concern at what appears to be an excessive purchase price. After all, the Johnson group also includes a real estate agency. In 1987 the Johnson group engaged the services of R. V. Dimond (Valuations) Pty Ltd to value the trust properties, with the exception of one property only. An information bulletin dated 29 June 1987 from Integrated gave the unit holders the first and only information on the estimated present value of their trust properties.

A question which arises at this point is: whatever happened to Syndicate Nominees Pty Ltd, who, Mr Deputy Speaker, you will recall, are the trustees of trusts Nos 125 and 126? A trustee is placed in a special relationship to the beneficiaries, the unit holders. It is a fiduciary relationship controlled by law and of great importance. Strangely, Syndicate Nominees has at no time corresponded with the unit holders or advised or assisted them in any way whatsoever, and I have no doubt that Syndicate Nominees is a shelf company with no assets and that it would be useless to sue it for breach of duty.

Why should this occur? Why has the trustee played no role at all in this saga? It would appear to me that Syndicate Nominees owes a duty to the unit holders to protect their interest. Yet it has not caused any independent valuation to be obtained. Integrated, on the other hand, has full details on the investment of all of the unit holders. It has also obtained valuations of their property. It is also necessary to examine the validity of the valuation provided by R. V. Dimond (Valuation) Pty Ltd. I quote from Bulletin No. 2, dated 29 June 1987: `The residential property valuations were carried out as in-line values'. I suppose that to the uninitiated that statement sounds very impressive, but what does it mean? What indeed is an `in-line valuation'? I bothered to check with the Institute of Valuers of Australia and the answer is that it means nothing at all. There is no such expression in valuation terminology. The only valuation of any value is a sworn valuation detailing market or cost valuations. So we have a statement made to the unit holders on in-line valuations, which is a meaningless expression and which tells them no information whatsoever. In fact, why has R. V. Dimond, supposedly valuers, used an expression that has no meaning? What is the true market value of these properties and why is such information being withheld from unit holders?

The story is far from over. The real sting is the benefit that the Johnson group of companies stands to gain. It is proposed by Integrated that the Johnson group of companies acquire options totalling up to 20 per cent of the issued capital of Integrated. Such options are to be exercised within three years. If exercised within the first 18 months the exercise price will be $1.05 and, thereafter, $1.10. There is still more to come. D. F. Johnson Investment Pty Ltd will get a consultant's fee of one per cent of the sale proceeds of property sold by Integrated, potentially, on its own valuations, a profit of a cool $2.5m.

I have a view that, if the scheme proceeds, the value of the properties acquired by Integrated will rapidly escalate in value to the advantage of the Johnson group. BIS-Shapnel Pty Ltd in August forecast that Sydney real estate, where all of this property is held, will increase in value by 45 per cent in real terms in the next three years. It is a pretty good scheme for Johnson, is it not? The company takes other people's money and sets them up in private trusts, controlled by no legislation. Over seven years the unit holders of trusts 125 and 126 have effectively seen, according to the Johnson group, the value of their $7,500 share drop to $7,176, yet Johnson proposes that they go into a public company and that all the real estate be transferred so that Johnson picks up 20 per cent of the issued capital at preferential option values. I have no doubt that, if this scheme goes ahead, those unit holders will end up forking out more and more money to the Johnson group. This whole scheme demands investigation. Complaints have been made to the Corporate Affairs Commission of New South Wales. I have contacted the Commission in writing, formally requesting a full inquiry. I am also seeking a full inquiry from the Federal Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the Federal Minister for Consumer Affairs (Mr Staples). It is a scam; it is a scheme; it stinks and it should be stopped.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Attitudinal change in industrial relations by employers and the unions should contribute to a great extent to the abolition of the `them and us' attitude by management and the work force. Co-ordination, negotiation and co-operation by both employer and employee would lead to a greater element of trust in the work place. The coalition policy advocates flexibility in industrial relations, with voluntary agreements between employers and employees. The more flexibility, the more chance of success in determining the wages and conditions which are acceptable to both employer and employee and which respond to the needs and profitability of particular or individual enterprises.

SPEECH.PARA: In what is considered to be a landmark in industrial relations-the Melbourne Age went as far as to call it `nothing short of an industrial relations miracle'-the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd is leading the way, setting the pace for the rest of Australian industry. In the motor industry, one of the most fragile of all our industries, the Ford company has introduced voluntary employee involvement, which has had a greatly beneficial effect on both attitude and behaviour in the work place and helped Ford consolidate its position as market leader.

In 1981 it was a very different story. Ford emerged from a crippling six-week strike with both employees and the management realising that for the company and the industry to survive there had to be change. Wayne Blair, Federal Secretary of the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation, said at the time, `We all knew we had to change. We could not let that happen again'. An editorial in the Melbourne Age aptly put it: `Crisis is often a marvellous catalyst for change'. The implementation of a program of voluntary employee involvement brought about a new spirit of co-operation between management and staff which culminated in the ratification last August of a most significant award under the second tier of the national wage fixing system when a 4 per cent wage rise was granted to more than 10,000 Ford car workers in exchange for a range of efficiency improvements.

In the six years since the strike Ford has lost only two days of working time, and they have been in isolated disputes. For Ford, employee involvement has changed the face of its industrial relations. It is an example which other industries and companies could well follow. But success did not come overnight. Ford has been an industry leader in providing in-house training and retraining programs and has used the focus of these new wages systems on skills development to gain considerable co-operation from the unions. In its plants in Geelong, Broadmeadows and throughout Australia, award classifications have been streamlined to introduce multiskills and flexibility between trades. In the Geelong plant, for example, jobs traditionally performed by skilled tradespeople are being carried out by unskilled workers who have been trained to accomplish simple tasks. This frees up skilled tradesmen for more skilled tasks and means less machine down time. Fitting tradesmen are trained to perform some of their own incidental welding, non-structural welding and so on. This program is aimed at broadening the scope of tradesmen's duties, which traditionally has not been done because of restrictive work practices. The result is a much more efficient use of skilled resources, time saving on the shop floor, greater job satisfaction for the work force and greater productivity. The company has given a guarantee that no employee would fail in job preference or in the full realisation of job potential for the lack of adequate training.

The company has, to a large extent, developed the blueprint for successful employee involvement. The historic 4 per cent second tier wage rise bears testimony to this. Arbitration Commissioner Smith stated that the increase was granted on the basis of productivity gains. Both management and the Australian Council of Trade Unions welcomed the agreement as a credit to constructive negotiations between them. However, Commissioner Smith warned that it must not become the vehicle for a bogus wage increase or any other sham arrangement. Ford claims that the 4 per cent pay rise will be completely absorbed by the efficiency offsets and will not flow on as a rise in price of the company's products. Other members of the industry have followed the Ford blueprint and have recognised the importance of multiskilling and of having involved employees in long term planning; and a sense of trust seems to be developing as an integral part of union-management relationships.

As we move to the twenty-first century, there is a growing acceptance amongst employers and unions of work flexibility to meet the requirements of the technological and organisational changes. These changes are necessary if productivity is to increase at a rate which will allow us to offset the decline in the terms of trade and raise our standards of living. The coalition wholeheartedly supports work place agreements. But the point I would like to emphasise is that they should be arrived at company by company. There should be no flow-on to other companies in the same industry as a matter of course. In the case of Ford, the negotiating skills of the company and the unions allowed them to bring down the agreement which suits both parties on their shop floor.

One might wonder why the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission needs to be involved at all or why a third party should be involved in an agreement between the two consenting parties. What must not be allowed to follow is the flow to other companies in the same industry. Unless companies like General Motors-Holden's Ltd (GMH) and Mitsubishi are able to negotiate their own productivity offsets, why should their workers automatically expect the 4 per cent second tier rise granted to Ford? Commissioner Smith's view is that restrictive work practices must be eliminated before the second tier wage rise is granted.

When he ratified the second tier negotiation between the Ford Motor Co. and the Vehicle Builders Union for restructuring and efficiency agreements, Commissioner Smith used considerable documentation that had been prepared by the working parties over their 100 meetings. This documentation formed the background of negotiation between the parties and their final agreements. In essence, the subject matter covered included: the grouping of award classifications; the make-up of workers compensation; the spread of hours; absenteeism; grievance procedures; maintenance work programs; adult apprenticeships; 38-hour four-day a week programs; preventative maintenance and demarcation problems; and the removal of restrictive work practices.

The impressive feature of the various proposals and the suggestions put forward by the working party was the detail. There was a genuine desire for both the union and management to reach a conclusion that would improve the efficiency of the company's operation and create a more harmonious working environment. In ratifying this decision, the Arbitration Commission, the Ford Motor Co. and the union have accepted the general thrust of the coalition's industrial relations policy in that productivity and work place harmony are very important features of Australia's future industrial relations environment. In the case of this particular decision, the Commissioner said in his judgment:

The restructuring and efficiency principle in itself deals with-changes to work and management practices; reduction in demarcation barriers; advancement of multi-skilling; the provision of training and retraining; broadbanding, and changes to working patterns.

Having had a look at the practical side of these changes, Commissioner Smith has hopefully accelerated the move, both in attitudes and practical application, towards a better way of achieving a happier and more efficient work force in an Australian industry.

The climate is right for change in industrial relations. The speed of change will be determined largely by what can be achieved by direct negotiation between the parties at the enterprise or company level. Undoubtedly, it will lead to a fundamental change in focus of industrial relations and changes in functions of the major participants. The coalition's policy objectives are to achieve a better system of wage fixation and dispute prevention and settlement, and more flexibility and accountability in the Commonwealth conciliation and arbitration system.

Bill Dix, Managing Director of Ford Australia, has led the way in implementing participative management and employee involvement. His company has put theory into practice and shown, without a shadow of doubt, that the program has proved effective and resulted in greater productivity. Mr Dix believes that `if a company shows its employees that it trusts them, they will be so much more likely to trust the company. If it makes sure that they are kept informed, they in turn will respond in the same way by keeping the company informed'. Throughout Ford, middle management is encouraged to handle employees in a human way, recognising problems on the job, accepting and adapting suggestions for practical operational improvements and encouraging a positive co-operative contribution. Seventy-five per cent of suggestions received have been put into practice. The company recognised that it had to be flexible and adaptable to change or it would not survive. In 1981 Ford suffered the crippling six-week strike. Then it was number two in the market. It is currently market leader with 30 per cent of the market, 10 per cent ahead of GMH. Ford's landmark second tier wage increase in return for a 4 per cent increase in productivity bears witness to the success of changes in attitude and behaviour of both management and the work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short period of time that I have in this debate I want to raise a couple of matters that in fact I alluded to some week or two ago in my maiden speech. I refer to two particularly beautiful islands that are situated in my electorate of Bowman, namely, North Stradbroke Island and Moreton Island, which is in the picturesque Moreton Bay district of south-east Queensland. This is an area where industry and the environment actually work together. We are often criticised as a Government and certainly as a Labor Party, the Party that I represent, for being greenies and for always looking at the environment and not being prepared to look at other issues. In fact, that is not exactly the case; it is far from the case. A perfect example of this is in my own electorate of Bowman where we have Moreton Island and North Stradbroke Island. We have a balanced policy on all of these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: On North Stradbroke Island we have a large sand mining company that is a world leader in its field. I refer to Consolidated Rutile Ltd. Consolidated Rutile is actually a world leader in the production of rutile, of zircon and of ilmenite. Those particular products are used in a wide range of commercial activities. In fact, rutile is used in the production of titanium oxide, a pigment used in the paint, paper and plastic industries, and in the manufacture of titanium metal, which has important uses in aerospace applications. Zircon and ilmenite also have a large number of commercial uses. The company exports all these products and it contributes in no small way to the balance of trade situation in Australia. In addition, the company supports a very thriving population which is permanently some 2,000 but which at holiday time extends to some 30,000. To those honourable members that might have the opportunity and the good fortune one day to come to that particular part of the world, I can say that it is probably the most beautiful 26 kilometres of unspoilt beach anywhere in the world, let alone in Australia or in Queensland. One of the things that I am very happy to say is that, as the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) has said, it votes in the right way. The people there are very nice people and they vote the right way in the main; and I thank them for that.
One of the major areas on which this company has to be commended is its rehabilitation program. It has a rehabilitation program that is absolutely excellent.

TALK.START.PARA: —You blokes are against sand mining; tell that to Joh.

—I will tell him. Shortly I will get on to the position with respect to sand mining on Moreton Island, which this Government and my Party are definitely against. If we have anything to do with it, it will never occur on Moreton Island. That is contrary, of course, to what the Premier of Queensland wants. He and his National Party of Australia always like to try to do what they can to sand mine and develop anything they can for a few lousy dollars. The days of the Premier of Queensland are numbered and, of course, that might go a fair way to ensuring that we do not have sand mining on Moreton Island. Even the Liberal colleagues of the honourable member for Maranoa are against sand mining on Moreton Island.

SPEECH.PARA: The rehabilitation program of Consolidated Rutile is an excellent program. In fact, I would dare anybody who comes to the island and sees some areas that have been mined some 10 years previously to point out the difference between the original contours of the land and the land that has been mined. There is no difference to be seen, even from the air. After 10 years it is very difficult to find. I must commend Consolidated Rutile for its rehabilitation programs. Consolidated Rutile is so serious about rehabilitation that it even has on its staff an agronomist. Some six months before the mining begins the company has already planned what environmental matters it is going to look at; it actually replaces the same type of material and the same types of plants that were there before. By the way, it also spends some $10,000 per hectare on the rehabilitation process and employs six to eight people full time. Before I finish I want to turn to Moreton Island.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the difference between the two islands? They are both heaps of sand.

—I am glad that the honourable member for Maranoa brings that up. The fact is that Moreton Island is probably one of the largest sand masses in the world. It is an area of great natural beauty, which the honourable member for Maranoa does not appreciate. It is probably better than areas in his electorate. Only a couple of days before the election, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) visited that island and said straight out that no export licences would be granted. No matter what the Queensland Government wants to do, there will not be any mining on Moreton Island. I will tell the honourable member for Maranoa something else: the only way the position is going to be changed is if the fellows in the Opposition ever get into government-and it probably will not change anyway, because the Liberals outnumber them. Those opposite are going to have a long wait, anyway, so we have nothing to worry about up at Moreton Island.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, this Government is prepared to be balanced in its views. We are not greenies. Where industry and commerce can work together with the environment and do the right thing, we will always ensure that in fact happens. The commitment of this Government to these types of industries is evidenced by what it is prepared to allow to happen on North Stradbroke Island, that is, sand mining, provided the rehabilitation process is allowed to proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's all the same.

—I find it very difficult to be able to say too much about what the honourable member for Maranoa says, and all I can say to him is that the Prime Minister has made it clear that Moreton Island will not be mined-and it certainly will not be.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It really surprises me when I listen to Opposition members yelling out about this, because they cannot cop the fact that we are prepared to look at all matters that are of importance to the people in that area. There are on Stradbroke Island many people who live off that particular industry. For that reason, we, in our balanced view, are prepared to ensure that sand mining, provided those rehabilitation programs are there, will continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:
