TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that the Minister for Trade Negotiations, Mr Duffy, will be absent from Question Time today as he will be shortly leaving for overseas on Government business. He will return to Australia on 21 October. Questions normally directed to Mr Duffy should be addressed to the portfolio Minister, Mr Hayden.

—I ask the Prime Minister to give the House a firm assurance that his Government will not seek through referendum to implement those recommendations of the Constitutional Commission which would cut the powers of the Australian Senate.

—I want to say these things in response to the question from the Leader of the Opposition: firstly, I welcome the initiative of my colleague the Attorney-General in instituting the Constitutional Commission. Without having yet had the opportunity, of course, of reading all that will be coming out of that Commission, I certainly hope that all members will agree that it is important that as we come up to this important period in the life of this nation we should be prepared objectively to look at recommendations coming from a wide group of people as to how the Australian community may be better served by a consideration of some changes to the Constitution, which, of course, was drawn up in extraordinarily different circumstances than those of today. I shall be discussing the issues with my colleague the Attorney-General. The Government will be examining the recommendations. I have nothing to say until we have undertaken that consideration.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade been drawn to the escalating violence in Sri Lanka? Will this continuing violence pose any threat to the agreement recently signed between India and Sri Lanka for an end to the communal conflict there?

—The Australian Government welcomed the agreement, signed on 29 July 1987, between Sri Lanka and India to bring peace to Sri Lanka after years of intercommunal strife. I expressed my support for the agreement in a Press statement on 31 July 1987, which outlined the main features of the agreement, including a general cease-fire on both sides and a surrender of weapons by Tamil insurgents, the establishment of an Indian peacekeeping contingent to enforce the ceasefire and the joining of the northern and eastern provinces into one administrative unit. Since the signing of the agreement, the Australian Government has been increasingly disturbed by the number of violent incidents that have occurred-most recently, the indiscriminate slaughter of about 140 Singhalese civilians. The Australian Government deplores such violence and calls on both governments to take all necessary steps to ensure the full implementation of the agreement. The Government urges all groups in Sri Lanka to respect the agreement and work together to bring peace and stability back to Sri Lanka.

—I ask a question of the Prime Minister. He will recall the report that Australia's credit rating has been significantly downgraded in the recent six-monthly survey of 100 international banks conducted by the American business magazine International Investor. The extent of the downgrading of Australia's credit rating is reported to be second only to that of Brazil. In view of the fact that Australia's unit labour costs are projected to increase by rates well above our competitors, I ask the Prime Minister whether the Government will be opposing the first tier wage increase of 1.5 per cent which is to be considered shortly under the national wage case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have, of course, noted the report to which the right honourable gentleman refers. I want to assure him that the Government is confident about the appropriateness of the policies that we have in place. Indeed, I think the right honourable gentleman will recall the quote I read earlier this week from a relevant international source on that point. I would remind the right honourable gentleman just what has in fact happened in terms of the situation that we inherited from the coalition Government. The Government can understand the desire of the Opposition to ignore these facts, but I remind the right honourable gentleman that from a prospective deficit of 5 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) we have now got the Budget into balance.

ANSWER.PARA: The gross public sector borrowing requirement has been reduced. I ask the right honourable gentleman to notice that that has been reduced from 8 per cent of our gross domestic product in 1983-84 to an estimated 2.2 per cent of the GDP this Budget year. The Government has underwritten the conditions for sustained falls in interest rates so necessary for private sector investment. Our new wage setting system is geared to productivity gains. It comes against the background of falls, I remind the right honourable gentleman, in real wage costs, thus facilitating adjustment without the cost to employment that might otherwise prevail. The fact is-and I do not know whether the right honourable gentleman is interested in facts or not-that we have in prospect in this year a fall of one per cent in non-farm real unit labour costs following falls that have already occurred.

The Opposition does not like to be reminded of what has happened, but I remind it that as a result of the wages policy this Government has brought into place, it has succeeded in securing a situation where during the period of office of this Government there has been a significant fall in real wages-a fall of some 7 per cent. That is the first time that that has occurred in the history of this country in a period of economic growth. That has not happened accidentally. It has happened because the trade union movement of this country has, with a great degree of responsibility, in agreement with the Government said that the interests of its members can be protected not simply by the mechanism of increases in money wages but also by attention to what is broadly described as a social wage, which, without being exhaustive, covers such matters as Medicare, employment, housing, education, and so on, as well as occupational health and safety.

In the event, as a result of the responsible co-operation of the Australian trade union movement, the right honourable gentleman ought to share pride that Australia had twice the rate of employment growth of the rest of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries-not just marginally better, but twice the rate of employment growth of the OECD countries. That has happened because this Government has had a total, comprehensive, responsible macroeconomic policy. The achievement of the Liberal-National Party Government was the historical first of simultaneous double digit inflation and double digit unemployment. Even during the period of devaluation-induced inflation, inflation under this Government never at any stage reached the point that we inherited from the Opposition of over 10 per cent. So we never have reached the level of inflation reached under the former Government, and this Government has produced over 800,000 new jobs-I repeat, a rate of employment growth more than double that of the rest of the world.

Honourable members will be aware that today, the latest statistics show that Australia's unemployment rate is down at 7.7 per cent. When this Government needs any sort of instruction from the Opposition on how to conduct economic policy, then this country will indeed have reached a very sorry point. I remind the right honourable gentleman of the judgment made by people outside this country on whether the economic interests of Australia would be better handled by the Australian Labor Party in government or by this motley collection opposite. I remind you, Madam Speaker, of the assessment made by that institution acknowledged by the Leader of the Opposition to be a responsible and informed organisation, Goldman Sachs. This is what that organisation had to say in regard to the possible outcome of the last election:

. . . a sizable proportion of the industrial and financial business community have expressed a preference for a continuation of the Labor government. In fact, they have even gone so far as to argue that domestic financial markets, and especially the A$, would be significantly more vulnerable if the government lost the election than if they won it. We agree . . .

That is Goldman Sachs saying what is the obvious truth: those opposite are a hopeless mob. They were hopeless in government and, what is even more surprising, they are even more hopeless in opposition than they were in government. This Government will continue to have responsible, comprehensive, relevant economic policies which will produce, as they have in the past, record employment growth, falling interest rates and a stable dollar.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy seen today's Press stories about Japanese coal buyers forcing big price cuts for Australian steaming coal? How does he explain this latest blow to New South Wales steaming coal producers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did see the Press cuttings. They were all over the place. Unfortunately the reports are not well researched. It is true that CSR Ltd has settled the terms of its Japanese financial year 1987 supplies to EPDC, the Japanese power utility, at prices around $A11 lower than for Japanese fiscal year 1986. Its Japanese fiscal year 1986 price was a formula escalated price that was regarded by many as being way above the going price. My Department has been advised that the other three New South Wales producers involved in these negotiations with EPDC will also accept similar terms.

ANSWER.PARA: However, it is quite inaccurate to present this settlement as a new victory for the Japanese utilities. The marker price for Australian steaming coal into the Japanese power market this year was established in a significant deal with Chugoku in April which was reflected in settlements with all other contracted utilities except EPDC. EPDC had been holding out since then for a lower price still. Notwithstanding the unprecedented delay, EPDC was not successful in achieving further price reductions. At today's exchange rate, the EPDC settlement, which is denominated in Australian dollars, is slightly above the Chugoku marker. I refer honourable members to the Sydney Morning Herald, which reports a more balanced view of these settlements.

As to the comments that certain other terms of the contract with EPDC have been eroded, I would simply add that others have been enhanced. For example, the sellers have achieved a mechanism to take much of the negotiating pressure out of the arrangement for future years and see this as most advantageous. The commitment from EPDC to increase liftings from this group of suppliers by two-thirds from 1990 is particularly encouraging. References by so-called analysts and others to the significance of the contracts being written in Australian dollars show a lack of knowledge of these particular contracts, which have been expressed in Australian dollar terms since April 1985.

Notwithstanding all that, as the honourable member for Hunter is aware, it is a matter of very great concern to the Government that conditions in international steam coal markets have deteriorated to the extent they have. I am keenly aware of the seriousness of the situation for Australian mine workers and producers and, indeed, for the nation's external balance. I am hopeful that we may have approached the bottom of the coal market. Oil prices are much more favourable; Japanese power output from coal fired stations has increased markedly; and, of course, there has been significant rationalisation in the coal mining industry. Also, while the Australian coal industry is the most efficient in the world, a position has been reached where steaming coal producers cannot bear further price reductions. Japanese consumers must recognise that it cannot be to their long term advantage to see reliable suppliers at internationally competitive prices put out of business. However, competition in this market is fierce, particularly from suppliers in South Africa, China and the Soviet Union, and a substantial excess supply capacity persists.

The Government is intensifying pressure internationally to hasten the removal of subsidies and other barriers, in an effort to expand the global market for tradable coal. I have also intensified the scrutiny of applications for approval of permits to export Australian coal, with a particular view to curbing unacceptable price competition between rival Australian suppliers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister will recall his public statements on Tuesday about the so-called political realities in Fiji and the inevitability of further entrenchment in Fiji's Government of the position of the minority Fijians-statements which he reaffirmed on Wednesday-and that they were greeted with public happiness and relief by Colonel Rabuka and have reportedly been widely broadcast in Fiji. Does he not agree that what he said amounted to a public concession that illegally enforced constitutional change was inevitable and that his statements were bound to be used by Colonel Rabuka as endorsement for his plans for a racially based minority rule? Was it not a diplomatic blunder by him of the first magnitude to make this kind of concession?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is no to all parts of the question of the honourable member. It is a pity that the honourable member seems to share the inability of Colonel Rabuka and others to understand what has been said on this issue consistently by the Foreign Minister and by me.
—Don Dunstan; some of your old mates.
—Order! Members on my left will cease interjecting.

—So that perhaps even the honourable member for North Sydney and the Leader of the Opposition, as well as Colonel Rabuka and anyone else who is interested, can understand the position, let me make it quite clear that we have said publicly in this place and elsewhere and in direct conversation with the Governor-General that, as far as this Government is concerned, we recognise no constitutional authority in Fiji other than the Governor-General. That continues to be the case.

ANSWER.PARA: What I said in regard to the issue mentioned by the honourable member in his question was, whether we like it or not-and certainly we on this side of the House do not like it; I do not know what the feelings are on the other side of the House-in the developments that have occurred in Fiji, including the involvement of Dr Bavadra in the discussions that have taken place, it seems to be inevitably accepted that the 1970 Constitution as it stands will not continue to operate in Fiji. To say that, to recognise that that is something that has followed not merely from the actions of Colonel Rabuka but the discussions involving Dr Bavadra, is in no way to condone or to endorse but to say that that seems to be the reality.

It having been said that that is the reality, Colonel Rabuka need draw no comfort from that observation. There will be no recognition, in these circumstances, by the Government of his actions. The position will continue to be as I put it to the Governor-General directly yesterday, and I hope, as I said, to be able to speak to him tomorrow morning before I leave for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting to get the most up to date assessment from him. The position will continue to be that we will recognise the Governor-General as the sole constitutional authority.

They are facts. They are not open to any argumentation. It is merely another example of the total irresponsibility and irrelevance of the Opposition to try to read into a statement of that factual position anything more than those words will bear. The tragedy, which is what should concern the Opposition as well as this Government, is that the nation of Fiji and its people are suffering from the unconstitutional action of Colonel Rabuka and will continue to suffer because the damage, to a very considerable extent, has been done. Rather than continuing to grovel around in the political gutter, which is becoming its natural habitat these days, it would serve the Opposition's interests better if responsibly it tried to bring whatever remaining influence it has to bear towards a constructive discussion of this tragic issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. Is the Minister aware of the intense international interest in the development of superconducting materials? What are the implications for the Australian economy if everyday materials are able to transmit electricity with virtually no loss of energy? Is Australia in a position to take advantage of superconductivity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Superconductivity-the fact that electrical resistance falls as temperature approaches absolute zero; that is, minus 273 degrees celsius-is a phenomenon that has been recognised since 1911. However, this has had no practical significance, as such low temperatures could be reached only at extreme expense in laboratories. However, beginning in February this year, there have been a number of significant discoveries in laboratories in the United States of America and Japan which suggest that superconducting can take place at very much higher temperatures by using special ceramic-I stress ceramic, not metal-materials. I have here samples of a superconducting ceramic with the formula YBa2Cu3O7--
—Say that again.

—I will explain it very carefully. It is made up of one atom of yttrium, two of barium, three of copper and seven of oxygen. Rare earths are central to the creation of superconducting materials. China and Australia have 90 per cent of the world's supplies of rare earths. This could place Australia in a very favourable position to supply underground cables for electrical transmission as there would be no heat loss from resistance. Therefore, the cables could be underground, assuming that research will confirm that the temperature at which superconductivity operates continues to rise. Throughout North America, Europe and Japan, there is an extraordinary increase in activity because the economic significance of superconductivity is becoming obvious. If the opportunity is not taken up here, and if superconductivity becomes an economic fact of life, it could have a serious impact on the supply of primary energy materials.

ANSWER.PARA: On the positive side, it could lead to enormous increases in computer capacity because operations can be speeded up without generating heat. It could revolutionise transport with supermagnetic levitation. Think what that could do for Mr Brereton in New South Wales. It could make artificial intelligence a reality and permit more effective medical technologies.
Opposition members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, the natural variety has not worked too well here. Superconductivity may be as important in the 1990s as the silicon chip was in the 1970s and 1980s. Of course, it is a very high risk area. The outcome is still uncertain. Australia is facing superconductivity with its customary caution, not to say sluggishness. The highest priority for us over the next few months will be to develop a strategy for a national response leading to a strong and coherent multi-disciplinary program. This must involve discussions with industry, academia and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation to work out the next steps. We cannot afford to let this one get away.
—This question should go to the Minister for Defence but, as he has dodged the issue and passed the buck to the honourable member for Canberra--
—Will the honourable member just get on with his question.

—I refer the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel to the view she expressed on 25 August that `the Defence Force had to accept the fact that high wastage rates were good for morale and the Services had better get used to it'. Why, then, is the Minister suppressing the monthly Australian Defence Force (ADF) employment statistics, which have been issued since 1973 when, according to the Minister's unique theory, the information contained in those reports should be sending morale through the roof? Is it a fact that ADF separation rates for September are at a record level, exceeding the 1,000 ADF personnel who left in July and the 823 in August? Is it also a fact that over 70 Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) pilots have submitted their resignations in the last three months? What does the Government intend to do about the crippling of our defence forces?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the shadow Minister for his question. There is no doubt that separation rates are causing problems in the defence forces. What I have done with the figures is to issue them annually because we have changed the nature of the figuring in the defence forces so that we have a trained component and a training component. I have received correspondence from the shadow Minister in relation to the availability of the figures, and I intend to reply to him to tell him that the figures will be available on request from the Department.

ANSWER.PARA: On the issue of separations, there is no doubt that they are causing some concern for me, for the defence forces and for the Minister for Defence. But, instead of just throwing our hands up in despair and criticising, as the Opposition is doing, we are addressing them case by case in areas affected. As the shadow Minister said, one of the areas causing great concern is that of pilot separations. We are tackling this issue head on. We are taking a two-track approach to finding effective short term and long term solutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you actually doing?

—On the first track we are talking to Qantas Airways Ltd. I will be putting to Qantas the view that all of us benefit from an effective defence force, and I will suggest that Qantas look at ways in which it might manage its recruitment programs to keep disruption to the Royal Australian Air Force to a minimum. I have already had discussions with the Chief of the Air Staff and the RAAF is looking at a range of options for adjusting its own procedures and practices to help reduce the pilot separation rate, including career streamlining for officers who prefer to continue flying, increasing the retirement age in certain cases, reducing the number of pilots in dedicated desk positions in the Air Force and Department of Defence central offices and, in the longer term, increasing the output of the RAAF flying training system. I will elaborate on all these points in the next few days.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In view of the costly and at times dangerous situation faced by many Lebanese citizens seeking to cross into Syria to visit the Australian Embassy in Damascus on official business, will the Minister give earnest consideration to the reopening of the Australian Embassy in Beirut or, alternatively, the opening of a temporary embassy at a safer coastal location north of Beirut?

—I have given consideration to this proposal, which has been put to me off and on over the past couple of years, and, regrettably, I have to say no. The response is negative because of the dangers to Australian representatives who would be required to serve on the ground in Lebanon. There are other factors which apply to any suggestion that accreditation could be applied to some point outside of Beirut. The Australian Government is accredited to the Government of Lebanon, the capital of which is Beirut. Therefore, it would not be appropriate to open an office outside the capital. To do that would be to give some impression of support for the cantonisation of Lebanon. It would also lead to requests, which it would be extremely difficult if not impossible to resist, to open up similar posts in other parts of the Lebanon. Another consideration is that it would be extremely difficult-again probably impossible-for members of all religious groups to travel to places such as Jounie. Currently visa issuing for people from the Lebanon is carried out at the embassy in Damascus. For those unable to travel to Damascus, other Australian posts-for instance, Cyprus-can issue visas.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support. I refer the Minister to the Menzies report, which he tabled after Question Time the day before yesterday, and to the Government's monumental blunder on the Coastwatch contract. Can the Minister explain how a committee of three people, established only three weeks ago, was able, after that very short period, to discover that the entire tendering process of the Minister's Department was in disarray, and point to no fewer than 15 major shortcomings with the Coastwatch tender document alone? How will the Minister avoid a repeat of the Coastwatch disaster when he calls tenders for the replacement VIP fleet?

—The proposal is that we will review the tender processes in response to the report that we have received. In particular, I understand that the Department will enjoy the benefit of support in the tender process from officers of the Department of Administrative Services who have considerable experience in this area. By applying the procedures recommended in the review and seeking that additional support and assistance, we believe that the matter will be able to be handled competently, appropriately and effectively.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. What are the Government's plans for the ongoing provision of efficient services to Government departments and instrumentalities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am conducting a reappraisal of the mechanisms for the efficient delivery of services to government departments and instrumentalities. The criteria I am using are threefold: firstly, the extent to which the central provision is necessary, as against the central setting of standards but the provision by individual private sector agencies; secondly, the extent to which any provision by a central public authority should be in open competition with provision by the private sector; and, thirdly, the extent and method of application of the user pays principle for partial or full cost recovery or on a full profit-making basis.

ANSWER.PARA: I am preparing a general guidelines paper for consideration by Cabinet and the Government. After that paper is endorsed by the Government, I intend to prepare a number of specific papers which will canvass, on a case by case basis, the delivery mechanisms for the provision of construction and property management services, for instance-and perhaps the guarding service-to government departments and agencies. The name of the game is going to be efficiency in the public sector and, where necessary, competition.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why you are privatising Australian Airlines.

—The honourable member for Deakin raised the issue of privatisation. I can inform him that what I am proposing is definitely not privatisation in the sense that one may read `privatisation' as equalling `sell-off'. That is not what I am proposing at all. What I am proposing is efficiency and competitiveness within the public sector. I am confident that the Department of Administrative Services will be able to deliver this.

ANSWER.PARA: The issue of transport and storage services is of close personal interest to many members of the Parliament. Because of that, and because an example of what I propose has already been achieved as at 1 October, I shall give the House a quick rundown on what will now apply with regard to transport and storage services. I begin by saying that the area of car with driver services for entitlees-Ministers, members, judges and so on-and also self-drive vehicles to agencies and the transport of goods with a security rating will not be open to competition. These services will be provided totally by the new Transport and Storage Group which will be run as a corporation within the Department.

The areas that will be open to competition in future are car with driver services to government agencies, the transportation of non-security goods, storage services and office removals. So, there will be some competition in those areas and the departments and instrumentalities will be able to go out to the private sector, if they wish, and receive those services. But the other side of the picture is important, too, because we must be fair and have a level playing field when we talk about these issues. The new Transport and Storage Group in my Department will be allowed to provide services, on a competitive basis with the private sector, to State governments and their instrumentalities, to local government and its instrumentalities, and to those areas of the private sector which I approve on the basis that the services provided are of a specialised nature.

If I may quickly tell the House about the financial arrangements, they are simply these: when we talk about efficiency and competitiveness in the public sector, we have to talk about achieving a level playing field. Otherwise, it is a bit of a joke. This is what I have done regarding the Transport and Storage Group: first, all the assets will be transferred to the group, which will have control of them. The group will have the right to rationalise property-that is, to buy and sell-and keep the receipts to ensure that it becomes increasingly competitive. The services provided-even personal car transport for members-will be on the basis of full cost recovery. A factor will be included which will involve a return to government of the capital which is deployed. We will also be removing average staffing levels, or ASLs. For Opposition members who do not understand, that means that staff ceilings will be removed so that the departments can be competitive or expand if the opportunities are around.

Finally, in consultation with the unions involved, we will be undertaking a review of any outmoded work practices which may still exist. I expect full co-operation with the unions on that issue. I repeat that the name of the game will be efficiency and competitiveness. I have no reason to disbelieve that, if we go about the reform of some sections of the public sector in the way I have described, it will be capable of providing efficient services in competition with the private sector. As a Minister, I, for one, accept the challenge.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister will be aware that yesterday's announcement that Australian Airlines will be transformed into a government-owned company, still subject to public sector borrowing limitations, will do nothing to overcome that organisation's critical requirement for capital to be able to afford new aircraft to compete against Ansett Airlines of Australia in a deregulated industry. As the Government will not provide the minimum $200m of urgently needed capital, and unless the Government is deliberately reducing Australian's ability to compete against Ansett, does the Minister agree that the only alternative is to privatise--
—Which Minister?

—The Prime Minister. I will read the question again. I said `Prime Minister'. I shall start again; I am quite happy to do that. I said `Prime Minister'; but I want to be sure that he hears the question, because the answer is important.
—Order! If everyone will be quiet, the Prime Minister will hear the question.

—That is right. The question was directed to the Prime Minister from the start. The Prime Minister will be aware that yesterday's announcement that Australian Airlines will be transformed into a government-owned company, still subject to public sector borrowing limitations, will do nothing to overcome that organisation's critical requirement for capital to be able to afford new aircraft to compete against Ansett Airlines of Australia in a deregulated industry. As the Government will not provide the minimum $200m of urgently needed capital, and unless the Government is deliberately reducing Australian's ability to compete against Ansett, does the Prime Minister agree that the only alternative is to privatise Australian Airlines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out to the honourable member that what we have done as part of the decision of the Minister for Transport and Communications yesterday is to announce the incorporation of Australian. I point out to the honourable member that the incorporation of Australian is consistent with the principles espoused in the Government's guidelines on the efficiency of its business enterprises.
—That has nothing to do with trading capital.

—Would the honourable member like to have another go? The Government believes that the incorporation of Australian is essential if the airline is to have a chance of becoming competitive in the deregulated environment which the Government has announced. By incorporating Australian, the airline will be released from the weight of restrictive day to day inconveniences in its relationship with government which Ansett Airlines of Australia and other private sector airlines do not face. In other words, the deliberate decision to incorporate Australian in broad terms, as the honourable member will appreciate, to put it on a similar status and basis to Qantas Airways Ltd, we believe will mean that it will be put in a more competitive position, vis-a-vis Ansett and other operators, than it would have been without incorporation.

ANSWER.PARA: We are very concerned-and I assure the honourable member of this-to ensure that Australian can compete with Ansett and any other domestic carriers in the deregulated environment that will come about. So rather than simply say that we are concerned to see that it can be competitive, we have decided to establish a high level advisory group to advise the Government on what more can be done to enable Australian to compete with maximum flexibility and efficiency. We will await the report of that group with interest and, obviously as a government, we will take into account the recommendations that it makes to us. It would be entirely premature to make any observations until we receive the report of that high level advisory group.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Veterans' Affairs comment on the delays in the hearing of cases before the Veterans Review Board? What are the problems and what is being done to ensure that applicants, who can be sick or in hardship, are not kept waiting for longer than is absolutely necessary?
—The first part of the question is out of order. The Minister cannot be asked to comment. The second part of the question is in order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Petrie for his question. I also take this opportunity to thank him for his service to the Department of Veterans' Affairs and to veterans in Queensland as a member of the Veterans Review Board in Queensland. He has been a member of the Board for the past 2 1/2 years and I am sure that he will be the member for Petrie for many more than 2 1/2 years to serve the constituents of that electorate. I am sure that all honourable members will be pleased to know that in the 1986-87 annual report of the Veterans Review Board, which I tabled in this House on 24 September, there are some very interesting facts about the Board's operations and particularly about the waiting times. I was extremely pleased to note that there was again an increase of 50 per cent in the number of applications for review finalised compared with the previous year, and that there were significant reductions in the average times taken to finalise applications. I am also happy to announce that these trends have continued this financial year.

ANSWER.PARA: The Board has finalised almost twice as many applications as it has received, and waiting times are now 40 per cent less than they were in late 1986. There was also a reduction to $550 in the average cost for each application finalised. This is 35 per cent lower than in 1985-86 and a fall of around 60 per cent compared with the previous period in real terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an excellent record.

—I know. It is a very excellent record. However, I am concerned that there still are a few problems in relation to the hearings of the Veterans Review Board. Only about 43 per cent of the currently outstanding appeals are, in fact, with the Board for hearing and related action. In a further 43 per cent of the applications, action is required on the part of the applicant, or his or her representatives, before the case can be brought on for hearing by the Veterans Review Board. Regrettably there is a high rate of adjournment-almost 16 per cent of entitlement hearings-and many of these are caused by the advocate not being ready to conduct the hearing on the day the case is called on for hearing, despite having given the Veterans Review Board a certificate of readiness.
—I think you will take the Stewart West prize this year.
—If the honourable member is quiet he might help everybody. I know he is not interested in veterans but we are.
—Make a statement.

—I will be happy to make a statement later on for the honourable member. The Board has now introduced measures which it hopes will discourage applicants, or their representatives, from indicating they are ready when they know that they are not. Better case preparation by advocates, leading to fewer adjournments, would reduce waiting times for applicants. Over all, though, I am pleased with the operations of the Veterans Review Board. It is clear that the three-tiered determining system introduced by the second Hawke Labor Government at the beginning of 1985 is working, and working well.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is supplementary to that asked by the honourable member for North Sydney and is directed to the Prime Minister. I remind the Prime Minister that on Tuesday of this week he said:

QUESTION.PARA: I don't think that any of us, including it seems, Dr Bavadra, can realistically expect that there is going to be a constitutional parliamentary system which doesn't involve some greater in-building of protection for the Fijians.
In what way does it involve the politics of the gutter or the politics of misrepresentation for the Opposition to suggest that that particular statement gave aid and comfort to Colonel Rabuka?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has been done by the Opposition in the last few days is totally consistent with the description I have given. Today we have had the Leader of the Opposition delivering another of his desperate Press conferences in which he had this to say of me:

ANSWER.PARA: He showed a double standard. He moralises and lectures about democracy and then in effect says that it is okay for one racial group to have an entrenched privileged majority over another.
The Leader of the Opposition has developed a constitutional incapacity to tell the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister will withdraw that comment.

—I withdraw it and I say that the Leader of the Opposition consistently misrepresents the facts. He does it on every issue these days on which he opens his mouth. It does not matter whether it is about tax evasion or-- Mr Ruddock-I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. Traditionally when honourable members are asked to withdraw a statement, the withdrawal is expected to be unqualified. The length of this qualification does not make it any less an inadequate withdrawal.
—The Prime Minister withdrew.
—It does not matter whether he is trying to talk about his Government's pathetic record on tax evasion or whether it is on the question of Fiji--

—I raise a point or order, Madam Speaker. Relevance is required under the Standing Orders. What the Prime Minister is doing is using the answer that he should be giving as an opportunity for a wide-ranging personal attack, and that is not relevant.
—Order! The honourable member for North Sydney will resume his seat.
—He should be told not to continue.
—Order! The honourable member for North Sydney will not direct the Chair on what to tell the Prime Minister.

—I make the point that the Leader of the Opposition is deliberately perverting my comments into a proposition that I am saying it is okay for one racial group to have an entrenched, privileged majority over another group. That is a measure of the desperation and the incapacity of the Leader of the Opposition properly to present the facts. I have said-and I challenge the Leader of the Opposition to dispute that it is a correct statement-that on all the evidence, including the involvement of Dr Bavadra in discussions with Colonel Rabuka, the Governor-General and Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara, it seems to be the case that all parties involved accept the fact that there will not be a return in Fiji to the 1970 Constitution as it stands. At no point have I or any other spokesperson for the Government suggested that we view that situation with any pleasure.
—Why does Dr Bavadra--
—Dr Bavadra, for instance, is engaged in discussions with Colonel Rabuka--
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mayo.

—Dr Bavadra is engaged in discussions with Colonel Rabuka, the Governor-General and Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara, on the basis, clearly, that there will not be a return to the 1970 situation and the Government has made a statement that it appears on all the evidence that the reality in Fiji is that there will not be a return to that situation. That is indisputable. It does not carry any implication that anyone on this side takes pleasure in that fact.
—You gave the game away.
—The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—At some stage the Leader of the Opposition and those who sit behind him will come to the conclusion-we hope they will-that when they talk about the tragedy which is Fiji they will bring to that discussion an analysis which is reasonable. They should not seek to make cheap political capital out of a situation in which the Government is doing no more than stating a factual position. It is not a position from which the Government draws any comfort. The responsibility of this Government, in the interests of the people of this country, the people of Fiji and the people of the region, is to try not to exacerbate the situation or be abrasive, but to recognise those realities which exist and to continue to say, as we have, that we sincerely hope for a return to a parliamentary system and to an outcome in which the rights and the interests of all communities in Fiji are properly respected and safeguarded.

ANSWER.PARA: That is the position of this Government. That is the outcome that we want to see. Without exaggerating the capacity of Australia to bring about a result from outside, in regard to what will happen inside Fiji, we will continue to emphasise that the sole source of constitutional authority in Fiji rests with the Governor-General. We will continue to assert, as I say, that the interests of the people and the nation of Fiji, as well as, I suggest, the interests of the people of Australia and the region, consist of a return, as speedily as possible, to the parliamentary system and, I repeat, an outcome in which the rights and interests of all communities in Fiji are properly respected and safeguarded. Without seeking to make political capital in the desperate way in which the Opposition does, we will continue to press that responsible position. The tragedy is that the rabble on the other side does not have the wit, the decency or the intelligence to associate itself with that honourable position.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I direct the Minister's attention to comments made by the Tasmanian Premier and Treasurer, Robin Gray, in the Tasmanian Budget Speech on Wednesday, 23 September, in which he stated that Federal funding arrangements precluded the State Government from proceeding with the proposed Claremont Senior Secondary College. Is there anything in Federal funding arrangements that has prevented the Tasmanian Liberal Government from honouring its 1986 election promise to commence the building of that college?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the most disreputable tactics employed by a State government is to make an election promise in an area for which it has total responsibility and then, when it discovers that it cannot deliver that election promise, to seek scapegoats-in this case, the Commonwealth Government. Of course, this is not a new tactic, but it is one which the Tasmanian Government, particularly, has employed time and time again. It is a particularly unfortunate occasion on which to use this particular tactic. We are talking about desperately needed educational facilities in a State which already has the lowest level of participation in its secondary schools. One would have thought under current circumstances that the Tasmanian Government would have given the highest possible priority to the election promise which it made under no duress from us before the 1986 election campaign in that State.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that the Tasmanian Government in its recent Budget decided to allocate $31m of capital expenditure to the education area. Yet it was unable to find one single cent for this election commitment which it gave in relation to the Claremont College, an area--

TALK.START.PARA: —That won't hold a seat in Tasmania.

—I do not know what the honourable member for Franklin has been doing about this matter. I would have thought that it might have served the interests of Tasmanians for the honourable member to join the honourable member for Denison in persuading the Tasmanian Government of the importance of this facility.

ANSWER.PARA: The first point I make is that the Commonwealth has already made available $4.6m this year in capital funding for schools in Tasmania. The allocation of that money and the determination of priorities is entirely a matter for the Tasmanian Government. It decided that many other projects, amounting to $31m, came above the Claremont College. It sought to blame the Commonwealth for its inability to deliver its own election promise. Of course, it is true that over the last few years there has been some reduction in funding for States-not just for Tasmania, but for all States. I also make the point that those decisions to reduce funding were made by agreement between the Commonwealth and the Premiers at the Premiers Conference. There was a national agreement that it was important for the Commonwealth and the State governments to reduce their claim on the financial resources of this country in order to sustain the lowering of interest rates that has occurred in recent times. In the context of the bleatings from the Tasmanian Premier in relation to how badly done by it has been, it is important to remember that in terms of dollars per head, Tasmania is still receiving four times more than New South Wales or Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —Four times?

—Four times more. Under those circumstances one would have thought that it would have been possible for the Tasmanian Government either to fulfil its commitment in relation to its election promise or to say honestly that it had decided not to proceed with it, rather than blaming us.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek your indulgence to provide further information in answer to a question I was asked yesterday by the honourable member for Mallee.
—Please proceed.

—Yesterday, the honourable member for Mallee asked whether the proposed boundaries for World Heritage nomination of north Queensland rainforests excluded `numerous properties owned by radical conservationists and Government supporters'. Further to the answer I gave the honourable member, I advise him that the basis for the indicative boundaries of the proposed World Heritage area, drafted by my Department, was the stringent criteria for national sites laid down by the World Heritage Convention. These criteria relate to the World Heritage values of the area. The Department used this expert advice and available information on these conservation values. My Department did not know who owned land in the vicinity when it prepared the indicative boundaries, and it had no reason to inquire about the ownership because World Heritage listing has nothing to do with land tenure, merely the conservation value of the intended nomination. Furthermore, World Heritage listing of the north Queensland rainforest will of itself have no effect upon ownership of land in the area. It is obviously ridiculous to suggest that conservationists who have been lobbying to have the rainforest protected and to have more land included in the World Heritage area would want their own land excluded from the protection that World Heritage listing would provide. Indeed, we have received submissions from some people whose land had been excluded wanting it included.

ANSWER.PARA: The areas specifically referred to by the honourable member for Mallee were excluded simply because they did not meet the stringent World Heritage criteria. However, the period for nomination of areas remains open until 22 October. Within that period it is open for anybody to suggest that additional areas be included, and some people have already done so. I suggest to the honourable member for Mallee that if he feels very strongly about this, if he feels that his question is justified, he is entitled to nominate the properties he has named for inclusion in the area. My Department would certainly review the issue then.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL HEALTH AND MEDICAL RESEARCH COUNCIL

TALKER.NAME: Dr BLEWETT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to clause 19 of the Order-in-Council which constitutes the National Health and Medical Research Council, I present a report of the 101st session of the National Health and Medical Research Council held in Brisbane, June 1986.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. I claim to have been misrepresented by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). On several occasions during Question Time the Prime Minister quite incorrectly accused me of perverting the truth by quoting back to him some remarks he made about events in Fiji. In support of my contention that the Prime Minister has misrepresented me, let me remind the House that on Tuesday the Prime Minister had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I don't think that any of us, including, it seems, now Dr Bavadra, can realistically expect that there is going to be a constitutional parliamentary system which doesn't involve some greater inbuilding of protection for the Fijians.
On Wednesday, in the course of another Press conference, the Prime Minister had this to say:
. . . including the understanding of Dr Bavadra-that there does appear inevitable that there will be some further entrenchment in whatever happens of the position of the Fijians.
I put it in my question to the Prime Minister, and I have said it outside this place, as have others, that those remarks were taken as giving aid and comfort to Colonel Rabuka.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's only your view.
—The Minister interjects that it is only my view. It happens to be Dr Bavadra's view as well, and it also happens to be the view of the coalition.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will get to the point.

—I am. In rebutting the claim by the Prime Minister that I had misrepresented the true import of what he said, I remind him that Dr Bavadra described the Prime Minister's remarks as indicating support for the views of Colonel Rabuka and that a statement from the coalition parties said that they were appalled by the Prime Minister's comments. They went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hawke must first decide whether he stands for the basic principles of representative democracy and the free expression of the will of the people or whether-
and these are not my words--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I would like the Leader of the Opposition to come to the point where he has been misrepresented.

—I have pointed out where I believe I have been misrepresented, and I have demonstrated a misrepresentation by quoting the reaction of people other than me to the remarks the Prime Minister has made. I stand by what I said this morning: this has crippled the Prime Minister's diplomatic capacity on the eve of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting.
—Order! There is no need to proceed any further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, Mr Deputy Speaker, by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).
—The honourable member may proceed.

—I put a question to the Prime Minister in which I said that he would recall public statements on Tuesday about the so-called political realities in Fiji and the inevitability of further entrenchment in Fiji's Government of the position of the minority Indians. I pointed out that these were statements which he had publicly reaffirmed on Wednesday, and that these statements were greeted with public happiness and relief by Colonel Rabuka and have reportedly been broadcast widely in Fiji. The Prime Minister, in his answer, said:

SPEECH.PARA: What I said in regard to the issue mentioned by the honourable gentleman was, whether we like it or not-and certainly we . . . do not like it . . . -in the developments . . . in Fiji, including involvement of Dr Bavadra in the discussions . . . , it seems to be inevitably accepted that the 1970 Constitution will not continue to operate in Fiji--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will come to where he has been misrepresented, not where someone else has commented on some other matter.
—I have to point to the background. The Prime Minister went on to say this:

SPEECH.PARA: They are not open to any argumentation. It is merely another example of the total irresponsibility and irrelevance of the Opposition to try to read--

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we get to the point where the honourable member has been misrepresented?
—I am showing you. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to try to read into a statement-
he was referring to the statement he had made-
anything more than those words will bear.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for North Sydney has to come to where he personally was misrepresented by the Prime Minister.
—I am coming to that. I have pointed out that he said that I was trying to read into that statement by him more than the words would bear, and he went on to say to grovel in the political gutter--
—Order! I think we have got to the point where the honourable member is no longer demonstrating where he was misrepresented. He is attempting to make a point.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, if you will give me the opportunity instead of interrupting all the time, I will get to the point.
—I am having considerable difficulty in all these beginnings to find out where they will end.

—If you would listen, Mr Deputy Speaker, you would understand. What I did in the question that I put to the Prime Minister was to cite the effects of what he had said on Tuesday and on Wednesday, and I also specifically referred to what Colonel Rabuka had said on Wednesday. In an interview he said, `I am very happy--
—The Chair thanks you very much for all that information, but I do not think that you have elucidated where there was any misrepresentation. I intend to call the Leader of the House.
—I have a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—What is your point of order?
—The point of order is that you have not heard me properly on the question. The misrepresentation was directly to say--

—I have given the honourable member about 2 1/2 minutes to indicate where he was misrepresented. He has given me a whole lot of information which has not elucidated that in any way. Perhaps he can quickly come to the point.

—The point was that I had correctly represented what the Prime Minister had said. He misrepresented what I had said and he misrepresented himself. He should have owned up to the words that he used and not sought to escape them by misrepresentation as he did.
—Order! The honourable member has made his point.

SPEECH.PARA: Is there any truth in the assertion that boundaries drawn for World Heritage listing of Queensland rainforests specifically exclude numerous properties owned by radical conservationists?:

The Minister suggested that I was seeking a further extension of the boundaries. That is not the case. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member has made the point as to where he claimed to be misrepresented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Defence Budget for 1987-88 is the first in which the delineation of Australia's Defence Force (ADF) for the 1990s and into the twenty-first century can clearly be separated from the concepts and strategies of the 1950s and 1960s. The Australian Defence Force of the future will be more capable; a co-ordinated fighting machine, rather than three largely separate services; and equipped and trained to prevail against any credible threat in Australia's area of direct military concern.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government believes in a self-reliant defence of Australia. It believes that our people should know that this is possible, that Australia can do it, can afford to do it, and must do it. This Government believes that our servicemen and women should know that they are members of an organisation that has clear cut direction; that they are at the heart of the most fundamental of national responsibilities-the security of the nation; and that the Government takes its responsibility for defence seriously. The Australian Defence Force now has that direction and, as demonstrated in this Budget, the Government will provide the resources for the reconstruction of our fighting capabilities.

Efficiency improvements in the last two years are now providing a dividend to defence. Further funds for high priority activities will flow from management changes now being undertaken. Each of the three services is being re-equipped with the best and most appropriate weapons, missiles, transport and support equipment that money can buy. The command and control of the ADF is being refined and centralised under the Chief of the Defence Force because the Government intends that, should Australians again be called upon to fight, they will, for the first time, fight as an Australian defence force and under Australian national leadership, rather than as part of some larger nation's force. Our national surveillance capability is being revolutionised, based on Australian technological excellence in the Jindalee over the horizon radar.

The role of the reserve forces has been given higher status than at any time since World War II. In any future time of national military crisis the reserves will be critical to our survival. The rejuvenation of the reserves, the improved recruiting and particularly improved retention show that this is being recognised by them. Industry has been brought into the Australian defence network. At some cost to the defence budget, the capability of Australian industry to produce, support and maintain defence equipment has been dramatically upgraded in the last few years. The submarine project will take this process even further.

Within the ADF the new posture of self reliance, the emphasis on the north and the strategy of defence in depth have required rethinking of old ideas at all levels. The opening of a new Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) base at Tindal, the expansion of HMAS Stirling to be the base for half the Australian Fleet, the transfer of battlefield helicopters to the Army, the requirement to manage over 100 major equipment projects and to bring the new weapons, systems and equipment into service are all providing new pressures in the ADF. The fact that the cost of the new equipment program demands constraint on personnel numbers does increase the pressure.

I am pleased to be able to report to the Parliament that the ADF is responding very well. Australia's service men and women did not join up for any easy life. They joined for a challenging life and to serve their country. There is growing evidence now that the Australian public understands the vital role our service men and women are playing. The public is throwing off the mental shackles that years of miseducation on our alleged inability to defend ourselves imposed. The enormous support defence open days and displays now draw is but part of this evidence. Among young people there continues to be a strong desire to join the forces. We must make sure that the enthusiasm that brings them in continues to motivate them through their service career.

To keep that enthusiasm, our service people need to be aware not only of the challenges but also of the opportunities. Our re-equipment program is producing opportunities for involvement in the use of advanced technology. Service conditions are changing, albeit slowly, to reflect the realities of the community expectations on lifestyles. That those changes are occurring has not been fully understood in the Services or the community. To explain the changes and to ensure that the continuing needs of service personnel remain in focus in government decision- making were the major reasons for appointment of a Minister directly concerned with this area. The opportunities are there for fully satisfying service needs.

This year's Budget follows one of the most extensive and far-reaching periods of review and reassessment in Australia's defence history. In a little over three years the Government has provided shape and structure to the concept of defence self-reliance and an ordered and rational approach to fill the gaps in capability. The same ordered and rational approach has been applied to defence management, both in the Defence Department and Defence Force. By seeking efficiency from improved management and rigorous internal review and control, defence is able to shift resources to enable the Government to correct the deficiencies identified in the White Paper and to get more capability at the sharp end.

The defence budget for 1987-88 is $7,404m. The Budget is a 2.7 per cent increase in dollars and a one per cent real reduction compared with 1986-87. I would add that these figures must be seen against the backdrop of the 2.4 per cent real reduction in Commonwealth outlays in the overall Budget for 1987-88. These statistics, which reflect the relatively beneficial effect of our decisions in relation to the Defence portfolio, demonstrate a continuing strong commitment by this Government to our defence requirements. In the past four years defence spending was insulated from the effects of currency fluctuation while we shaped the strategy and direction for defence self-reliance and put in place the machinery for the management improvements that produced an efficiency dividend. These two key initiatives enable this year's Budget to be held at $7,404m without affecting the blueprint for the next 15 years provided by the Government's 1987 defence policy information paper.
On 19 March this year I presented in this place the defence of Australia policy information paper. In conclusion I observed:

Whatever his critics might think of the Dibb review it has set a new standard for defence debate in Australia. Never again will those who wish to participate in the defence debate in this country simple be able to run off at the mouth with wish lists, persiflage and grandiloquence.
I also said:

The program outlined in the White Paper is a prudent one, with clear cut priorities. It is based on a realistic assessment of our circumstances and our important alliance relationships. We are a powerful nation in regional terms, but with some serious deficiencies. We could not now deny ourselves self reliance in the terms set out in the White Paper. The goal is achievable.

The central message of this defence budget is that the White Paper is on track and will stay on track. Defence self-reliance is realised through a strategy of defence in depth. It gives priority to meeting any credible level of threat that could occur at relatively short notice in Australia's area of direct military interest, that is, the area in which developments can most directly affect our security. It means that any potential adversary knows that he will be faced with a comprehensive array of military capabilities, both defensive and offensive. The Government believes that our focus on credible contingencies strengthens the priority needed to be assigned to the major elements of our capital equipment vote. To be distracted from this course could thus leave holes in Australia's total defence capability.

The Dibb report and the White Paper have shown the direction that the ADF should go to take it out of the 1960s and into the twenty-first century. Force structure developments have emphasised intelligence and surveillance, strike and interdiction, upgrading maritime warfare and mine countermeasures capabilities, increasing the Army's capability for dispersed northern operations, enhancing command, control and communication systems and streamlining administration and logistics. The emphasis on these areas is being reflected in the type of equipment being introduced into the ADF. It is access to adequate intelligence and effective surveillance that gives the defence forces of a relatively unpopulated country such as ours a chance to respond to threats in timely fashion. Timely intelligence is necessary to allow us to respond appropriately to any developing threat.

Some of our most effective indigenous scientific developments are associated with attacking these problems. In this regard, I would like to emphasise the contribution of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO) in developing capabilities that are appropriate to Australian strategic requirements. For example, DSTO is developing a towed acoustic array which is a sensor to be used from specialist surface ships and from our new submarines and which will provide wide area surveillance in important ocean basins and focal areas. Australia is a world leader in this field.

The emphasis on surveillance capability is highlighted by the continued development of the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar. This is the world's most advanced long-range radar and represents a wide area surveillance capability that is essential to the ADF's force structure. It is another of the developments of DSTO's of which we can be justifiably proud. This year $16m is being spent on upgrading the Alice Springs site and I hope later this year to announce the next phase of this important project-the acquisition of computers and the development of specialist software. Given the excellent work that has been done by our scientists, it has been particularly appropriate to give them a Minister of their own. I am pleased that she is present in the House. I believe-no doubt she will have opportunities to discuss this matter later-she will ensure that our scientists get the attention they need and that we are fully able to exploit their product.

Our Navy and our maritime warfare capacities are undergoing a massive restructuring and improvement of capability. Individual programs generate excitement in Australian industry with the attractiveness of their new technologies, but their importance to the new strategy is sometimes missed by the public and in debate in this place. Our Navy is developing the ability to protect vital choke points, patrol considerable distances, sweep our ports clean of mines and strike an enemy's forces at the source. That is a pretty comprehensive array of naval activity. In the debate that surrounded the decision by the previous Government not to proceed with the aircraft carrier, endorsed by us, the considerable potential of our maritime forces was obscured. A navy with these tasks is going to look different from a navy focused on force projection. However, its role in the contemporary era will be more vital.

The six new Kockums type 471 submarines to be built in Australia to replace the Oberons will be the largest, longest ranging and most lethal conventional submarines in the Western world when they enter service in the 1990s. The new submarines will increase our maritime surveillance capabilities, as well as provide a formidable strike capability. The great significance of our submarine fleet runs in tandem with the major upgrading of the maritime warfare capability of our surface fleet. It will leave us with a major increase in the number of platforms. The increased numbers are no accident. They are a result of addressing the enormously difficult problems of simultaneously confronting our need to defend the choke points to our north and south and develop a capacity to patrol further afield in areas such as the South Pacific.

The size of the surface combatant fleet when this Government was first elected was related to keeping one aircraft-carrier battle group operational. Not only was the concept inadequate for the strategy of forward defence and power projection applied in the 1950s and 1960s, but that size force-12 destroyers and 20 patrol boats-was clearly insufficient for the defence of Australia itself. This position is being rectified now with the creation of a rational structure of three levels with the numbers in each related to the tasks and capabilities required for maritime warfare within the strategy of defence in depth. This will largely be a substantial improvement in defence planning over the largely `rule of thumb' approach of the past.

The surface fleet will contain three broad levels of capability. The highest level will be represented by the larger ships-destroyers and frigates; the second level by the new light patrol frigates, and the third by the patrol boat force. At the highest level of capability, $116m in this Budget is to be spent on two new FFG7s being built at Williamstown Naval Dockyard and $45m towards modifying three of the existing four FFGs to carry the new Seahawk helicopters. The first two of 16 Seahawks are scheduled for delivery in November 1988 with $141m being spent in this year's Budget.

Three of the guided missile destroyers are to be modernised at Garden Island Dockyard at an estimated cost of $385m, with $72m of that in this year's Budget. The modernisation will upgrade weapons and sensors and generally extend the operational life of the ships. The first two ships will complete the modernisation program in 1988 and 1989, with the third to complete in 1990. That is a massive level of commitment on behalf of the Australian taxpayer by this Government to that first tier of warships and a substantial amount of it is in this year's Budget. At the middle level of the fleet of surface combatants, we plan to construct in Australia eight light patrol frigates for the Royal Australian Navy (RAN) and up to four for the Royal New Zealand Navy.

The new light patrol frigates will be suitable for dealing with lesser forms of military pressure and capable of extended patrols within our resource zones and proximate waters in our area of direct military interest. They will have superior range, endurance, sea keeping and survivability compared with patrol boats and will be able to carry the Seahawk helicopter. They will be designed so that their sensors and weapons can be enhanced to enable them to contribute in more substantial contingencies.

On 9 September I announced the selection of three ship designers to further develop their ship designs for the Anzac light patrol frigate project. A ceiling cost of $3.5 billion has been set for all activities associated with the procurement, outfitting and support of the eight ships for Australia. The Government has also given a high priority to the development of a capable mine countermeasures force to ensure that our ports can be kept open. Our strategic circumstances dictate that we need both a minehunting and a minesweeping capability. Minehunters are designed to use a forward-looking specialist sonar to hunt mines and then to detonate them using charges placed by a remotely piloted submersible vehicle. Minesweepers are needed to complement the minehunters by operating in deeper waters where the nature of the seabed makes hunting less effective.

In the air, Australia's strike and interdiction forces can hit further, faster and harder than ever before. The Royal Australian Air Force is being re-equipped to play its role in the defence in depth strategy. This means having high-technology aircraft, sensors and weapons with the range and power to find and destroy targets anywhere in our area of direct military interest. The Air Force will get another 18 FA18s this year, making a total of 44. By 1991, there will be 75. The FA18 is a combined fighter and strike aircraft which carries the best radar and weapons for Australia's air defence, ground attack and strike needs. One squadron will be based at a major new airbase at Tindal, near Katherine in the Northern Territory. A major upgrade is being considered for the F111s, to maintain and enhance the long-range, highly accurate land-strike capabilities which they provide the ADF.

A new training aircraft, the PC9, is being built in Australia for the Air Force. It is the best basic trainer aircraft in the world, and it will allow the Air Force new, more flexible and more economical training programs. A new air-to-air refuelling capability is being developed in the ADF to increase the range of the FA18s, and a string of bare bases is being built across northern Australia from Learmonth to Cape York.

Focusing on the defence of Australia has meant a substantial rethink in the Army. The Army is being re-equipped from the boots up to carry out its role of defending Australia. Tactical and strategic exercises are increasingly looking towards the areas in the North in which the ground forces will operate.

In 1989, Exercise Kangaroo 89 across the north of Australia will be the biggest peacetime exercise ever carried out by the Australian Defence Force. The soldiers will have new individual and light support weapons-the 5.56 mm Steyr and Minimi-with deliveries from Australian factories beginning in 1989-90. Operations will be supported by new field guns-the 105 mm Hamel, again manufactured in Australia-and troops transported by Black Hawk helicopters in the biggest upgrade to Army mobility in the last 20 years. We are also considering the acquisition of wheeled armoured vehicles for operations in northern Australia, and the possible upgrading of part of the fleet of M113 light armoured fighting vehicles.

Ongoing projects to upgrade Army mobility include the purchase of a further 600 4-tonne Mercedes-Benz Unimog trucks at a project cost of over $57m and the purchase of 3,300 Land Rovers at a total cost of $145m of which $22m will be spent in this year's Budget. Initiatives to upgrade our communications capability include a number of projects using the latest communications technology. Examples include new Raven tactical battlefield radios and cryptographic equipment, as well as the continued development of the Discon-defence integrated secure communications system-which is planned for completion by the end of 1991. Another important continuing communications development is the Defaussat project, which will provide an enhanced use of Aussat by defence, including field use by the ADF through transportable earth terminals. The system should be operational by 1989.

The White Paper recognises that our people-the men and women of our fighting forces-are our most valuable asset and a vital resource in the security of this nation. A capable defence force needs capable people. But along with the need, indeed part of the need, for a capable defence force is the need for the Government and the community to recognise the special demands that are placed on service men and women and their families as a result of service life. In establishing the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal, the Government broke new ground in pay fixing machinery. A range of pay and allowance matters are currently being addressed by it. We have a positive program in place to improve defence housing, and some key recommendations of the Hamilton report have already been implemented.

I spoke earlier on the strategy of defence in depth. Let me give some detail on the changing focus in defence activity resulting from defence in depth. Any force hostile to Australia must attempt to advance in ships or aircraft. Accordingly, the program gives priority to the air and sea defence in our area of direct military interest; particularly to the north, as this is the region through which major threats must pass. Australia's long-range strike capabilities are being developed to respond-quickly and lethally-to early warnings far from Australia's shores. These include air and naval forces.

Our air strike forces operating from bases in the north will comprise squadrons of F111 long-range strike aircraft; FA18 multirole aircraft and P3C long-range maritime patrol aircraft. In all, over one hundred of these aircraft will be capable of carrying the Harpoon anti-ship missile; the F111 and FA18 aircraft are also fitted for the Sidewinder air-to-air missile, and the FA18 also carries the Sparrow air intercept missile. Australia's long-range forces are also capable of striking land targets such as enemy bases and force concentrations. The F111s are the central element of our land strike forces, and the Government is seeking advice on a major upgrade of these aircraft to maintain them in service. Installation of the precision target acquisition tracking and designation system in the F111 bombers is proceeding, with 12 aircraft now modified and in service. Some $6m has been allocated to the project this financial year.

The effectiveness of the FA18s for long-range missions is being greatly enhanced by the Government's decision to provide aircraft refuelling. The first of the RAAF's four Boeing 707 aircraft to be fitted with this capability will be available in late 1989 or early 1990. We are also completing a comprehensive network of air bases in the north to support these operations. In addition to the major airbase nearing completion at Tindal, a bare base exists at Learmonth in Western Australia and another is being built at Derby in north-west Western Australia. The Government also intends to build an airfield on Cape York Peninsula and to have it operational as early as possible in the 1990s.

Recent measures to rationalise assets and boost northern surveillance capacity have included changes to patrol boat basing. Of the five Fremantle class patrol boats based at HMAS Waterhen in Sydney, one will transfer to Cairns, two to Darwin, and the remaining two will transfer to the reserves-one for the Sydney port division and one for the Melbourne port division.
