This shift is a good example that cost cutting and strategic concerns are often compatible if innovative management is brought to bear. The shift to Cairns is both good defence and good economics. The operational expenses of commanding the patrol boat fleet from Cairns are considerably less than from Sydney. The strategic advantages are that the patrol boats will have quicker access to, and extended cruising time in, our northern waters. The Cairns command basing is likewise more relevant to the increased emphasis on patrol boat activities in the South West Pacific.

Another initiative is the Government decision to strengthen our northern defences by basing major elements of the Australian Army permanently in northern Australia for the first time in peacetime. The 2 Cavalry Regiment of 340 men and associated vehicles will be based in the Darwin area. This transfer will be completed by the end of 1992.

The White Paper goal of greater defence self-reliance has resulted in greater priority being given to the reserve forces. One thing is crystal clear: we cannot achieve defence self-reliance without the reserves. Gone are the days of the reserves being seen as providing a basis for expansion during national mobilisation in some distant future. The reserves are an integral and essential part of our defence planning and of our force structure. The role of the reserves is being substantially widened. Navy reservists will play a vital role in mine countermeasures to safeguard our ports and shipping lanes, while RAAF reservists will be integrated into various units of their host formations to provide an expanded capability. It is in the Army Reserve, which provides the majority of reserve manpower, that the introduction of a total force concept can most clearly be seen.

`Total Army' means integration of regular and reserve forces at unit and formation level. This will allow elements of an upgraded Reserve to enter the operationally ready first line, while the remainder will form the important base element for any rapid expansion at a time of increased tension. The Army Reserve will be required to assist in the surveillance of the country's north. In recent years increasing emphasis has been given to regional surveillance units in the north and north-west and these are predominantly Reserve units. Access to local knowledge and skills in remote areas of Australia could prove vital for the early detection and countering of a military threat. In the more credible contingencies most likely to occur in the north and north-west of Australia, the Army Reserve will have a critical role in the protection of key areas, releasing regular units to conduct offensive operations. Such key areas would include protection of the Darwin-Tindal region, the Learmonth, Derby and Cape York airfields, and other civil and industrial infrastructure.

It is intended that the reserves take a greater responsibility for heavier capabilities, such as tanks and medium artillery, as part of the expansion base. For example, 1 Armoured Regiment will become an integrated regular and reserve unit. The reserves now have a sense of purpose and they can take pride in the fact that they will be directly involved in the defence of Australia. Reserve recruitment and retention rates are both up. Total reserve force strength increased over the year from 25,977 on 1 July 1986 to 27,673 at 30 June 1987. The strength of the Army Reserve at 30 June this year was 24,632, which was 132 above the target strength of 24,500 for 1986-87 and closing in on the authorised ceiling strength of 26,000 which is to be achieved by 30 June 1988. The retention rates are comparable with other Western nations and, indeed, are the best figures in well over a decade.

One further initiative is central to the Government's perception of the new role of the reserves. Legislation passed in June of this year for restricted call-out of reserve forces in situations other than in war or a proclaimed state of defence emergency is a key factor in defining the role of the reserves in the full range of credible contingencies. This means that reserves are now available to be used in the sort of low level threat which could emerge with relatively little warning. Steps will be taken to protect reservists' employment following call-out.

Although defence self-reliance is the major theme of the White Paper and our Government's defence policy, the paper makes it quite clear that this can be achieved only within our current alliance framework. The United States alliance does not suggest an unhealthy dependence on the United States; rather it results from a mature recognition by both nations that their own self-interests are best served by the relationship. Much of the debate in the community on the value of the United States alliance remains sterile. There is too heavy a focus on very unlikely contingencies such as global nuclear war or on the reliability of either partner to guarantee uncritically a force commitment on the basis of the other partner's political judgment. This level of debate is misleading. The nature of an alliance partnership where a threat is not clear-cut is always going to be more subtle and complex. In such circumstances the United States alliance allows us to maximise the options we have in any crisis that is likely to emerge. From Australia's point of view that results in defence, not dependence. If we were to be involved in a conflict our first request to our ally would be for that which is easy to deliver-intelligence, diplomatic support, supply of vital parts, and so on. An opponent wishing to escalate the conflict further, would have to consider the consequences of involving the United States more fully.

Although these questions are hypothetical in nature, I raise them because they go to the heart of considerations which make defence self- reliance a realistic policy for us. More concretely, the alliance provides immediate benefits in the influence it gives us in the arms control process and the contribution we are able to make to deterrence through our co-hosting of the joint facilities.

Another advantage Australia derives from our relationship with the United States is that we have access to technology, equipment and intelligence that would otherwise be unavailable to us. Consequently, Australia is able to maintain a level of defence capability that enables us to realistically aim for defence self-reliance, and at a cost that is acceptable to peacetime governments facing periods of economic stringency. This Government realises that a positive contribution to regional security is an essential part of our contribution to the Western alliance. Consequently, the White Paper focuses attention on the region of our northern approaches and to the south-west Pacific area. As a result of this emphasis, Australia supports defence co-operation activities with regional countries which share a similar strategic outlook.

As I announced in February this year, this Government now gives defence co-operation with our neighbours in the South Pacific the same priority as that given to our older and more substantial defence relations with the nations of South East Asia. This co-operation is being mainly directed towards assisting with the maritime surveillance of their exclusive economic zones. In the current year, additional resources will be devoted to this assistance, principally the Pacific patrol boat project, development of national surveillance centres, RAAF long range maritime patrols, and RAN ship deployments. The estimated cost for the defence co-operation program in 1987-88 is $58.3m. This represents an increase of $3.7m on last year's expenditure. Through our involvement in the defence co-operation program and through the continued consultations and contacts with military and defence officials from nations within our region, Australia is able actively to promote shared strategic concerns and contribute to developing regional stability. This, in the long run, is the best form of self-defence.

I turn now to the area of improved efficiency. It is apparent that the pursuit of improved efficiency and productivity is a considerable challenge in an organisation as diverse and complex as defence. At the same time, because of the extent of the community's resources we consume, there are major benefits both to the defence area itself and to the community at large if we can improve our capacity to meet our objectives in a more cost-effective fashion. I see it as a major task to stimulate an appreciation of the importance of achieving the best possible value for expenditure of the defence dollar.

The defence organisation is undergoing a period of rationalisation to tailor the organisation to meet the economic and strategic realities of the 1980s and the future. This is not a `cutting for cutting's sake' program but a responsible and orderly process of adjustment that makes it possible to contain defence outlay while building up defence capability. More efficient management will mean that resources will be shifted to where they are needed-to the sharp end. A leaner, more streamlined organisation will be created. As the organisation is trimmed, so costs will be trimmed-thus releasing more of the defence dollar to increase combat effectiveness. It is sometimes forgotten in the defence debate that we are unique in our budgeting processes in defence. We have a global outlay so, if we can trim our defence costs by $100m or $200m a year-for example, as we have in the case of the Government Aircraft Factories to the tune of about $100 million-we will be able to expend those funds on other purposes though the total defence outlay will not increase.

To this end, the Department of Defence has instituted a management improvement plan that has identified and set in train substantial changes to its structure aimed at improving its corporate management and the drive for greater efficiency. We are currently spending in the order of $2 billion per annum on new facilities and equipment. We are presently managing some 140 different capital equipment and facilities projects, each costing more than $5m. Defence capital project management is marked on the whole by high investment, high risk, technical complexity and the potential for international collaboration. Managing the procurement of major capital equipment therefore presents the project manager with many challenges not shared by his or her contemporaries in other areas of management. Defence will continue to place a high priority on the training of project staff with continuing in-house training on all aspects of the procurement process, and by the establishment in 1988 of a masters degree program in capital project management at a tertiary institution.

New demands for civil manpower are being generated at a time when the Government is conscious of the need to keep tight control over the numbers of personnel in public employment. A revised approach to manpower is being developed as part of the five-year defence program. The proposed strategy includes the following elements.

We will meet the Government's `across the board' efficiency dividend. Three per cent of the 3.75 per cent civil manpower reduction required over the next three years will be achieved in this financial year. We will continue a vigorous program of rationalisation of the work force in the defence dockyards and production establishments. A high percentage of the manpower savings achieved in the Office of Defence Production and elsewhere in defence will be used to strengthen high priority areas requiring additional staffing.

We will pursue a program of conversion of some service posts to civilian ones using some of the civilian savings achieved from elsewhere, so as to release highly trained service personnel for redeployment in accordance with Defence Force priorities. At the same time, there will be a cut of more than 1,300-to 38,369-in the approved average staffing level for civilians. We will further develop our capacity to meet our existing and new commitments by a vigorous program of management improvement-based reviews and studies, which will include the rationalisation of functions and the contracting out of certain activities.

As the scope exists for overall productivity improvement in the use of our personnel resources, manpower and management arrangements will be major preoccupations over the next two to three years. Specific measures are being addressed across the entire organisation. The rationalisation of the work force in the Office of Defence Production, while achieving a better balance between the size of the work force and the existing work load, is only partially complete and will be pursued rigorously over the next two years.

The Government Aircraft Factories have now been established as a government owned company. Williamstown Dockyard is being sold as a going concern as part of the rationalisation process. Restructuring of the munitions factories has resulted in more direct working hours from fewer people. These rationalisation measures in the Office of Defence Production are being undertaken so that the extent of government subsidy to defence production establishments is reduced significantly and, as I have said, the funds saved are directed to other areas of defence priority.
A review of defence logistics is currently being undertaken. This is aimed at:
improving performance and effectiveness across the range of logistics functions
significantly reducing costs
reducing requirement for service manpower and thus making manpower available for other ADF priorities
rationalising, to the greatest possible extent, property holdings falling within the defence portfolio
rationalising systems and approaches to logistics
putting authority closer to the point of action.

The longer term benefits and savings will be considerable. I expect rapid progress from civilian and service management towards changing some traditional approaches to defence logistics. There will in future be greater focus on:
cost consciousness
greater authority being vested in individual service offices closer to the point of action, together with greater accountability for decisions actually made
introduction of more commercial approaches including the provision of some services by contractors.
The heavy burden of day to day logistics works will continue during 1987-88, for example:
preliminary work on the basing of half of the fleet at Garden Island in Western Australia will continue
work is under way to develop a bare base airfield on the Cape York Peninsula
planning is well advanced on facilities associated with the move of the 2 Cavalry Regiment to the Northern Territory
new measures to merit better management of information throughout the Department will be introduced
the development of a modern, common-core computer based supply system will continue
logistic support arrangements with other countries in South East Asia and the south-west Pacific region will continue to be developed.

Recent months have also seen major initiatives for management improvement within the Services. Efficiency measures are to be effected across the board and the Services are playing their part in ensuring that the defence dollar is wisely spent. It is indeed very much in the interests of every member of the Defence Force because the savings mean more defence capability, not less. This equation is unprecedented in Australia's history.

The new personnel resource strategy for the Defence Force outlined in the White Paper will be implemented in 1988. Part of this important initiative involves moving away from undue emphasis on the strength of the Defence Force on a particular day each year and towards the balancing of ongoing activities, recruitment and separations to produce an average strength over the year. More significantly, the new strategy identifies separate average staffing levels for the year for an operational force of trained personnel, and for a training force comprising personnel undergoing pre-employment training. When higher than normal separation rates are experienced, the training force will be supplemented to maintain the level and capacity of the trained force.

These concepts will allow the strength of the training force to rise and fall in parallel with variations in separation rates while maintaining the trained force at the strength necessary to meet the objectives set for it by government. The manpower resource available to the ADF in 1987-88 will provide an operational force with an average strength of some 63,000 trained personnel supported by a training force of some 7,000 and active reserve forces of 30,800. The planned average regular strengths for 1987-88 are Navy, 15,657; Army, 31,746; Air Force, 22,612. This strategy will improve the management of defence manpower by allowing Service chiefs to allocate resources in a clear and defined manner.

In this statement I have highlighted the main features of the defence budget and shown how it is tailored to meet the real defence needs of Australia. The significance of this budget is that it shows what can be achieved in improving defence capability when the Government gives clear guidance, sound strategy and defined priorities. This budget is not a formula for less defence but a reordering of practices and procedures designed to get the utmost benefit for the taxpayers' dollar that will provide dividends through to the start of the twenty-first century. The 1976 White Paper mooted the notion of self-reliance but failed to grapple with the specifics-that is, the force structure necessary for such a defence strategy. Even that germ of an idea was not allowed to come to fruition because of the previous Government's failure to implement any measures that would have given this country a self-reliant defence policy. Lance Barnard began the process of rethinking Australia's real defence needs some 15 years ago. Once again it is a Labor government that has brought that period of review to a close. A revolution in defence planning and in shaping defence capabilities means that this Government is reshaping the Defence Force for the twenty-first century, and not leaving itself and the Defence Force with the inappropriate legacy of the 1960s.
Motion (by Mrs Kelly) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.
Motion (by Mrs Kelly) agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for McPherson speaking for a period not exceeding 48 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) for the defence budget paper, of which he gave me a copy some two hours ago. I congratulate the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) on her appointment; I have not had an opportunity to do so before now. I noticed that she could not last the distance while the Minister for Defence was speaking but I am glad to see she returned to the House at the end of his speech.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Defence has produced a paper which has managed to avoid all the real defence issues presently confronting us in this country. I really think that the Minister should now be called the Minister for Defence Equipment or the Minister for Defence Reserves, but hardly the Minister for Defence, as he has dodged the real issue, the greatest problem, which is the personnel wastage which is debilitating the defence services almost day by day. In 27 pages of the statement we have just heard, not one single reference has been made to improvements in conditions of service which are bugging the defence forces of this country. The statement gives no hope for the 70,000 uniformed men and women who, for over two years, have been looking to the Minister for Defence in the expectation that he will implement some of his grand rhetoric about improving conditions of service for defence personnel. The statement contains no reference to any initiative which will improve life for those 70,000 men and women. In 27 pages there is only one paragraph on personnel. The Minister and I know-or I hope he knows by now-that that will be the judgment on this paper by the men and women in the defence services.

The paper will ensure the continuation of the record separation rates presently overtaking the services. It is an academic statement by a Minister who is presiding over a defence disaster. The Service chiefs and I have attempted to explain to the Minister-and I am sure the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has also attempted to explain-just what is happening out there. It is beyond me how the Minister for Defence can come into the House and deliver 27 pages of a so-called defence budget paper and not address the biggest single issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because Ros is going to do it tonight. She is the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel.
—You are the Minister for Defence.
—You asked her a question about it today. Why didn't you ask me?

—Mr Deputy Speaker, here is the Minister for Defence again dodging the issue. He says, `It is not my responsibility. I am just the Minister for Defence. Ask the assistant Minister. There are 70,000 men and women who comprise the defence forces of this country but they have nothing to do with me. I just pass the buck to the new Minister'.
—I said she would do it tonight.

—You are the Minister for Defence and you are ultimately responsible for the welfare of those people. I can only conclude that this defence budget paper has more to do with the ultimate political ambitions of the Minister for Defence than with the defence problems now facing this country. The Minister has been left out of the limelight a little; he is feeling that, and so he has come into the House with a paper containing no new initiatives but which has everything to do with his own political career.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister referred to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. I am interested to hear that she will make a statement in the House tonight. We look forward to that, but it is the responsibility of the Minister for Defence to make that statement. So far the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has made several statements. I regret to say this-I do not say it with any pleasure-but to a large extent she has become a laughing-stock in the defence services. She has created so much damage and has achieved a legacy which I think will be difficult for her to overcome. She talked today in Question Time about covering up the figures that we had. She made some flimsy argument that it is better to have annual figures than monthly figures. What would it be like if the trade figures or unemployment figures came out only once a year? That is the sort of stupid argument that has been put today.

She said that it was good for morale in the services that 36,000 out of 70,000 men and women left in four years-that is a turnover of over half of the total defence services in four years. She blamed the number of women leaving the services for increasing the figures. That is about 10 per cent of the total. She blamed all the Vietnam veterans who just happen to be getting out of the Services at the same time. My God, the Vietnam veterans left years ago. The Opposition looks forward with interest to the contribution she will make tonight.
This paper is an insult to the Services. It is academic and patronising. In the paper the Minister for Defence said:
Changes have not been fully understood.

Changes have not been fully understood! Why does the Minister think that personnel are leaving the Services in droves? They understand only too well what is happening out there. What a patronising comment to make. The Minister went on to say:
The service men and women did not join up for an easy life.

Who is patronising the service men and women? They have been struggling with eroding conditions of service year after year, hoping like hell that someone will take note of their plight. In the end the Minister for Defence brings in a paper which does not address even one single issue. It is childish, patronising stuff. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel said that wastage rates are good for morale and the defence forces must get used to it.

Three main problems face the defence forces of this country at the moment. The first and major one is the debilitating effect of record wastage rates. The second is that, despite what in many ways has been a good ground plan for a White Paper, we have no capacity to reach out in our area of interest or to influence events. That has been clearly demonstrated by our lack of capacity to react, if we wanted to do so, to the situation in Fiji.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you suggesting military intervention in Fiji?

—The Minister knows very well that I am not. That was a ridiculous statement and that has never been suggested. I supported what the Minister did in May and I support what he has done this time. It is because of what he did in May that he has been a bit more sensible this time when he realised our incapacity. Our area of interest is 7,000 kilometres by 5,000 kilometres. It is a massive area but we are confined basically to the Australian mainland. So that is the second big problem. The third problem is the reduction of funding support for this grand plan in the White Paper. Year by year it gets eroded.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to some personnel wastage matters and the reasons for the wastage. In 1983-84 we lost 6,700 men and women from the Services. By June this year the figure had gone up from 6,000 to 9,000. In July this year-the figures were not released then, but eventually were, not by the Minister I might add-we lost 1,000 people in one month. In August we lost 823. If we project the figures from those two months over a full year, we see that we will lose 10,000 people in 1987-88. That means that in the last four years we have lost 36,000 men and women from the defence forces from a total base of 70,000. In four years we will lose over half.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the normal loss rate?

—I will give the Minister a normal loss rate. It is a good thing he asked that question. The normal loss rate amongst officers for some years has been 6 per cent. It is now 12.5 per cent. You asked the question and that is your answer-it is double.
—Order! The honourable member will address his remarks through the Chair.

—The average annual loss rate for pilots, who were mentioned in Question Time, over a 20-year period until last year has been roughly 47. To June this year we lost 107. In the first two months of this financial year, as I understand it-I asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel about this and she did not deny it-there were 72 Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) pilot resignations in the Department of Defence. If we project that over 12 months we are talking about nearly 300 pilots which would absolutely cripple the Royal Australian Air Force. The effect of all this on the Services is that the experience level is diluted. We have young and inexperienced people doing very important jobs. I might say that they are doing their very best; some of them are good, but there is no substitute for experience. Because so many people are leaving the Services there are increased postings resulting in turbulence as people are moved around the country to plug gaps. We have this enormous diversion of manpower from the operational squadrons and units to the training establishments so that more people are trained.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that in the RAAF something like one-half to two-thirds of the qualified flying instructor positions are vacant. We have an enormous downward effect on morale as people see others around them leaving the Services, and we have the enormous financial cost. On the most conservative figures, the cost to train the 10,000 who will leave this year will be $350m. By the time a pilot reaches his first squadron he will have cost the defence forces and us as taxpayers about $2m. By the time he is a useful pilot and has some experience-with 1,000 hours-and he leaves the Air Force, the cost will be about $6m. If we lose 100 pilots a year we can work out an average to be $400m.

It is not as though the Minister for Defence and the Government have not been warned about the effect of this enormous wastage. The most prominent warning they got was in a paper from the Service Chiefs earlier this year. It was a long paper compiled by the Assistant Chief of Policy in the Defence central office to say exactly that-that the Services are wasting away and they cannot stand this debilitating damage. Apparently, the Minister ignored the warning, as has the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. They chose to put forward this fantasy until today, when at least the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, in answer to a question, said, `Yes, we have a problem'. That is the first time that it has ever been acknowledged. Maybe that is significant. Maybe we will now get some action in those areas where it is so badly needed.

Let me tell the House why personnel are leaving. They are leaving because they are quite convinced that this Government does not care about them anymore, and the paper put down today by the Minister will reinforce that. They are leaving because they feel that they have become second-class citizens by civilian community standards. They are leaving because the Government has made no attempt to address the damage that has been done in their conditions of service. They are leaving because every time a pay claim goes before the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal the Government, up until now-and I hope it will change-with the full weight of the Department of Defence, which should be in there battling for its employees, opposes it. In addition, there are anomalies in pay. In some cases a major will take home more than his commanding officer who is a lieutenant-colonel.
We recently had the fiasco of the service allowance which again was opposed by the Government. The Government eventually gave service men and women about $700-about $1 for every hour they work.

TALK.START.PARA: —A 21 per cent increase.
—By any recent survey the average working week of a service man or woman is between 52 and 55 hours. Is the Minister defending that allowance?
—It is a 21 per cent increase.
—Does he think it was adequate? The Minister thinks that an extra $1 an hour is adequate compensation when personnel were expecting at least $2 and hoping for $3.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government makes a great claim about an extra $75m for defence housing, and I am very pleased to see that, but it is a sleight of hand trick because $28m of that this year will be going to new base housing at Tindal and about $8m will be going into Rockingham. It is certainly going into housing, but the fact is that the men and women in the Defence Force thought that that money was going into existing housing and new housing in existing areas. Half of it is going to new housing on new bases.

Unit strengths have again been reduced. The people in those units are expected to work more hours and have the same output. The education allowance is a classic. There are 70,000 uniformed men and women in this country. Out of the total 70,000-not all of them are married with children, of course-the number in Australia at the moment who are receiving some education allowance to assist them to keep their children at school as they are moved around the country is 55. If there is one thing that is really getting up their noses it is the education allowance. The consumer price index increase in Defence Force retirement and death benefits, was reduced by 2 per cent in the year before last and there is no sign of restoration.

The Minister talks about the Army being re-equipped from the boots up. I wish he would start with the boots. I mention this because it is boots, belts, webbing equipment and basic mortar ammunition in many units that are in short supply. The soldiers in field units in many cases simply cannot wear the boots they are issued with because they are so badly made. If the Minister is going to start re-equipping the Army from the boots up I suggest he do exactly that and start with the boots.

We have the fire sale that is going on with Cooksey running around saying that we will sell Victoria Barracks in Melbourne and other prime spots. Some of it may well deserve to go and should go. But if the Minister is going to start this business again of pushing the Services out because they are on prime land, pushing them into a corner, which a Labor government did at the end of the Vietnam war-they have taken a long time to recover-they will suffer. There is every reason in the world why servicemen should be placed in prominent positions in our community.

The best example of why personnel are leaving happened a couple of weeks ago in the midst of the defence service housing debacle. The Budget announced that the Government was going to cancel the old scheme and give service men and women a $10,000 grant. It was a further erosion of their conditions. There is no way that $10,000 equates to the $25,000 cheap loan over 32 years that was in place.

For the first time I am getting calls from various units around Australia, from non-commissioned officers and officers, who are saying, `The soldiers are lined up in delegations outside my door, demanding to know what is going on'. I have never heard of that before. The Government had the good sense to back down on that decision, but the damage has been done. All that the Minister has said is that it will be left in place until the end of the year, when a new scheme will be introduced. Having regard to the Minister's record, these people know that the new scheme will not be to their favour. For all of those reasons it is no wonder that we have this enormous wastage rate in the Services.

What has been the Minister's response? The Budget contained nothing in regard to personnel matters, and there was nothing about them in today's statement. He has passed the buck to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, for whom I have a great deal of sympathy. She is trying to pick it up on the run. She has advanced unique theories about management, about losses being good for morale, about women and about Vietnam veterans. In the end, she despaired and she passed the buck to Mrs Mayer. Who is Mrs Mayer?

TALK.START.PARA: —Jobs for the girls.

—It is jobs for the girls. She is the defeated Australian Labor Party candidate for Chisholm. The Minister passed the buck to Mrs Mayer and said, `Mrs Mayer will point me in the right direction'. I suspect that there is probably no one who knows less about defence service problems than Mrs Mayer. How much is it costing us?
—She is not dealing with that.

—What is she doing? Where is she? Is she in Melbourne? That is a good place; there are lots of servicemen there. How many staff does she have? It is probably costing us-- Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER-Order! I again remind the honourable member to address his remarks through the Chair.

—It is costing us half a million dollars to employ Mrs Mayer. The Minister should be ashamed of herself, and I suspect that she is. The Minister suppressed the personnel wastage figures and gave some excuse today, which everyone laughed at, and rightly so, that it is better to have figures every 12 months than once a month. I hope that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel can do something for those people, but she has a long way to go. I say to the Minister: for God's sake, act like a real Minister, take control of the personnel problems and stop running away from them. The problem involves 70,000 men and women. It is not an academic exercise. It is not a matter of playing around with submarines and new frigates. We are talking about the people who, in the end, have to make it work. We can have the finest equipped Army or Services in the world but, in the end, if we do not have experienced, well-trained men and women to run it, we have nothing.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say briefly what should be done as far as personnel are concerned. The first thing that the Government must do is to display some interest and responsibility. It should stop opposing every pay rise on the basis that it is bad. It should stop opposing every service allowance, and give the people a fair go for the extra 14, 15 or 20 hours that most of them work every week. It should stop talking about $75m being spent on housing when half of it is being spent on new bases. It should do something about the education allowance and give service men and women prior access to their superannuation entitlements in the hope that they might stay in the Services. It should stop hiding the figures. It will not achieve anything by hiding those figures. It is a flimsy, fragile excuse. For God's sake, it should come clean and it might get some help from members on this side of the House. It should not try to dodge the issue all the time. It should implement some of the promises that it keeps talking about month after month. The Minister keeps talking about the report of the Hamilton Review of Effect of Service Life on Spouses. Practically nothing has been done to implement the recommendations of that report.

The second major area is that of equipment. The big deficiency, apart from some of the good things that are being done, is the capacity to exert any influence in our area of responsibility. Fiji is a good example. In May we sent some ships and men-and rightly so, I thought. The fact is that, had they been required to do anything to safeguard our nationals, they simply could not have done so. This time, as far as I know, we have not repeated that exercise. I think that that is very sensible. The fact is that we did not, and could not, carry many troops; we could not carry any equipment; we had no air cover; we had no vehicles; we had no helicopters or airborne early warning system. Most of all, we had no way of getting those troops from the sea to the shore, and we still have not. One thing that the Government must do is to reactivate the landing ship squadron-the heavy landing craft, or LCHs. There are three of them rotting away in Cairns, two are involved in survey work and one is in Brisbane with the naval reserve. If there is one thing that has been proven to us in recent years, it is that that squadron must be reactivated. Also, if any credibility is to be given to the White Paper, the Government must provide aerial refuelling for the F111 and get that update for the F111 on the books. I notice that today's statement refers only generally to having another look at it. We have been hearing about it for a long time. We must have some aerial early warning radar system.

The third major deficiency is funding. The Minister, in today's statement, said that the White Paper is on track. When we first started to go down that course, with the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities and the White Paper, the decision was based on a 4.5 per cent real growth in budgetary support. That figure was reduced to 3 per cent, and we were told that that reduction would not make any difference. How one can reduce funding and not make any difference is beyond me, but that is what was said.

In 1986-87 there was zero growth, but apparently that still did not make any difference. Perhaps people are giving us equipment for nothing. In 1987-88 the figure is minus one per cent. We still hear the tired old statement that the White Paper is on track. All the time, budgetary support is going down. In fact, I think that the claim that the figure is only minus one per cent is a bit suspect. The fact is that $7,404m will be spent this year and the Budget figure for last year was $7,415m. So we are budgeting less for this year than we did for last year. We are budgeting more than we actually spent, because somehow we knocked $200m off it last year. I think that the figure of minus one per cent is probably about minus 4 or 5 per cent, when one takes the inflation rate into account.

I say to the Government that it cannot go down this track of saying that the White Paper plan is still on track if the money is getting less and the bets are off. It must reassess its priorities in a realistic way. Where is the extra money coming from? It must reassess its capital spending priorities. There is no other alternative, unless it can get some more money, which it cannot. It must reassess its priorities because it must find money to put into conditions of service for the service men and women of Australia. I suggest that the Government should take a good look at the report of the Auditor-General on fraud totalling $800m. I will be very interested to know what it is doing about that matter. An amount of $800m is not exactly peanuts. If it can cut down the debilitating wastage, it can cut down a lot of its training costs. It could probably save up to $350m if the wastage rates could be reduced to a reasonable level.

While we are discussing defence, let me refer to one or two other things which are very important in the defence debate. Firstly, let me pay tribute to those who marched in, and those who organised, the national welcome home parade last weekend in Sydney. I thank them and hope that that march has gone a long way towards healing some very bitter wounds. Also, I hope that the march did something to restore the defence forces in this country to their proper position in the community. After the Vietnam war those of us who served in it were pushed into a corner. Our wives and children were abused. It was a very uncomfortable period and very hurtful for many people. That was mainly under a Labor government, with Cairns, who I think was then the Treasurer, entertaining North Vietnamese in this country at the very time that we still had servicemen in Vietnam. The Services were badly abused.

TALK.START.PARA: —Traitorous.
—It was treachery; that is what it was.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: I believe that the use of the word `treachery' when describing a former Minister and member of this House is unparliamentary and ought to be withdrawn.
—I ask the honourable member to withdraw.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I--
—I ask the honourable member to withdraw.
—I regret that I cannot withdraw.

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: there are no provisions in the Standing Orders for you to require that remarks such as that made about a former member of this place, whether or not he was a Minister, be withdrawn. Whilst you may ask the honourable member for McPherson to withdraw, I put it to you very respectfully that he is not obliged to do so.

—I realise that you have raised an important point of order, but I have asked the honourable member for McPherson to withdraw. To maintain the decorum of the House, I would prefer that he withdrew that statement. Is the honourable member prepared to withdraw?
—I do not think I will.
—In that case, you are placing me in a very difficult position.

—That is why I hesitate; I have no wish to do that. The former Minister was hosting and entertaining North Vietnamese in this country while we were engaged in operations against them. That, I believe, was treachery and that is the word I have used.
—Again I ask the honourable member whether he is still not prepared not to withdraw.
—I am.
—In that case, the House will stand in judgment on you on this matter.
—So be it. I hope that the Vietnam veterans march will go some way towards restoring the proper place of the Services in the community in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the matter of submarines for this country. Again I ask the questions that have already been asked of the Minister. What is the position with the first submarine? Is it to be built overseas or not? If it is to be built overseas, why do we not have a statement to that effect? Who will foot the bill for the final integration of the submarines? It does not seem to me, from any statements I have read, that that matter has been addressed.

We generally support the frigate project but we want to know where it is at the moment. We know one plan has gone up to the Minister and that the Minister has sent it back to the Royal Australian Navy. When will we see some finalisation of those frigate plans, and why were they sent back to the Navy? The patrol boat program with which we are assisting countries in the south-west Pacific is an excellent one, but I notice in a statement by the Papua New Guinea Defence Minister that the ones we are providing to that country must be modified. I ask the Minister why that is the case. There are problems with the defence computer, and the supply systems computer project is still floundering around after four years, employing some 50 to 100 people per year. What is to happen to that? I see in the paper presented today that the project is continuing, yet I understand that consultants have been brought in to advise the Government.

I believe this is a lightweight and patronising paper. It has all been said before. It has little to do with defence and everything to do with the Minister's political aspirations. It is notable for its omissions. It has not addressed personnel matters, it has not addressed our capacity to extend our influence in this part of the world and it has not addressed the very real question of funding for the measures referred to in the White Paper. I say to the Government, `Reassess your priorities, even though the White Paper is only six months old, and address the problem of wastage of the Services, above all'. To the Minister, I say, `For God's sake, show some concern for the 70,000 men and women in uniform who are looking to you to fight their battles and which so far you have completely dodged'. If the Minister is not very careful he will find he is the Minister for an empty shell and the problems that I have outlined will overwhelm him.
Debate (on motion by Mr West) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As honourable members will be aware, it has been the custom of this Government and past governments to regularly review progress of the new Parliament House project and to report on that progress to the Parliament. I will accordingly report on the nine-month period to May 1987. During this period progress was at a sufficient pace for the new Parliament House to open on schedule in May next year and for the Parliament to be operational by August 1988. The building budget updated for the nine months to May 1987 now stands at $862.15m while the budget for non-building items is $164.75m. The total project budget is therefore increased from $987.4m to $1,026.9m at May 1987 prices. This updating includes $24.6m for adjustment of the uncompleted portion of the project for the effects of inflation in the nine-month period. This procedure has been applied throughout the life of the project. Additional components include an allowance to cover the costs of industrial disputes, insolvencies of contractors and exchange rate fluctuations-costs outside the control of the Parliament House Construction Authority of $9.9m, $4.6m and $0.4m respectively, a total of $14.9m.

SPEECH.PARA: The five components of the total revised budget of $1,026.9m are the original 1978 building budget of $220m; the original 1981 non-building budget of $82m; the accumulated inflation escalation adjustment of $463m; an allowance of $66m for costs beyond the control of the Parliament House Construction Authority for industrial disputation, contractor insolvency and exchange rate variations; and $196m for accumulated budget additions. The $196m comprises $87m which should normally have been allowed for as contingency allowances, including $36m for contract variations and contractors' claims, $8m for adverse ground conditions, $11m for changes to non-building items and $32m for associated fee costs on the foregoing items; $104 for approved extensions to the building, including $4m for placing the eastern carpark underground, $41m for accommodating additional senators and members, $9m for minor user changes, $20m for sound-vision equipment and furniture, $33m for design-user refinements; and $9m for associated fee costs on the foregoing items. The overall cost of the these additional items was subsequently reduced by $12m following a reduction in costs in other areas, and the $104m figure includes $5m for reinstatement of landscaping.

A number of conclusions can be drawn from this full disaggregation. The non-building budget of $82m and the contingency allowance of $87m ought to have been included in the original budget. There is no doubt about that. On a project of this nature, one cannot simply say in 1978, `$220m for this new building' and not include a contingency allowance, as everyone in the private sector does and certainly as my Department does in the public sector, or an assessment of a non-building allowance. That is the first conclusion to be drawn from the disaggregation. The Fraser Government should have included the non-building budget and the contingency allowance in 1978. There is no argument about that. I do not think even honourable members opposite would disagree with it.

The second conclusion is that it was not possible to escape the effects of inflation, at $463m. Thirdly, it was not possible to escape the costs of industrial disputation, insolvencies of contractors and exchange rate variations-a factor of $66m all up-which on a pro rata basis are probably less than would be experienced on most major private sector construction projects anywhere in Australia. Finally, the other additional factors were the $104m for approved extensions, such as when the size of the Parliament was increased in 1984, and the $5m for landscaping. These figures show that the claims of massive cost over-runs are a misunderstanding of the true nature of the full disaggregation of the costs involved. All this is not to say that, in some limited instances, cost over-runs or control lapses have not occurred, but it clearly refutes these sensational claims of unrestrained cost blowout.

The new Parliament House building has been created, designed, built, and furnished by Australians and Australian made products and artworks. It highlights the pinnacle of Australia's building, architectural and construction talents, products and natural resources and should be a source of national pride for future generations. The construction phase has almost been completed. Nearly all of the external pre-cast concrete wall panels are in place, and a large proportion of the granite cladding of the curved walls is completed. The flagmast is finished. Work on the forecourt is progressing rapidly. The western and northern sides of the site are almost clear and shaping of the landform is proceeding.

Internally, the building is taking on its final appearance. The staircases in the foyer are complete and the House of Representatives chamber is well advanced, as are the offices in that wing. In many places built-in furniture is in place and equipment has been delivered and is soon to be installed. Permanent power has been supplied to the north, south and east zones of the building and the central energy and air handling plant rooms have been commissioned. So the project is now well advanced. We can expect it to be operational next year. This is an achievement, considering the constraints of design time together with providing the additions required to accommodate the larger Parliament. It is a building on which honourable members can be sure that all Australians can justifiably be proud.

The project has, of course, as have previous major national, State, and private sector projects, been subject to criticisms. I have already generally covered the `cost blowout' allegations made by some sections of the media. Also, the Parliament House Construction Authority has prepared a detailed response to the Auditor-General's report. This report was tabled on 2 June 1987. The report and the response will now be considered by the Public Accounts Committee in accordance with normal Parliamentary practice. I intend to table the response to the report, as is only fair, at the conclusion of my speech.

Perhaps the most unfair allegations made against the project involve misrepresentation of the project's industrial record. I will not, of course, sanction unjustifiable work practices or strikes. However, some of these types of allegations have been proven wrong and in other instances, private sector industry practices have been wrongly presented as being somehow peculiar to the new Parliament House site. It has been asserted that the project has been a pacesetter for wages and conditions in the private sector. However, the project has consistently been short of labour by up to 200 because of the attraction of other private sector projects in Canberra and interstate which offer more attractive financial rewards. Because of the nature of the project, it has often been the pressure point for industry-wide issues. For example, the 14-week dispute in 1984 was caused by industry-wide pressure to obtain superannuation and severance pay. At the time, the Authority was congratulated for not giving in to these demands and becoming a pacesetter.

As everyone will know, the new Parliament House site was also a focal point during the very difficult period in which the Builders Labourers Federation was deregistered. The site industrial agreement has generally proved a successful way of resolving disputes resulting from on-site issues but cannot be expected to cope with industry-wide disputes. Given the nature of the project and the potential for disputation, I believe that the Parliament House project has a reasonable industrial record. There is little basis for claims that the project has `an appalling industrial record' or that it has been a pacesetter in wages and conditions. With a few notable exceptions, most unions on the Parliament House project have acted responsibly within the terms of the site agreement to create a safe and satisfactory work environment, which has in turn generated a team spirit and pride in the project.

However, the Hawke Labor Government is determined to continue the control that it has exercised over the past four years. This project, if it is allowed to run the course it is currently on, will be completed on time-a marvellous achievement. However, I will sound a clear note of warning. The run up to completion dates could be the most difficult and challenging phase of the entire project. The Government will not bow to blackmail by either unions or contractors. Industrial disputes or forced contractor insolvencies must not be staged in the belief that the Government will be willing to capitulate in order to have this building fully operational by August 1988. As I have said, this project has not been an industry pacesetter, and this position will remain. Building industry union claims should be processed within the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's wage principles. Contractors and unions should note this and act accordingly to ensure the smooth completion of this magnificent national project.

The target date for opening by the Queen is 9 May next year and the new Parliament House is targeted to be operational from August. These targets will be achieved with clear co-operation and commitment from all involved. If my warnings are disregarded, the opening will still be in May, but the Government will make the necessary adjustments regarding timing of occupancy. In the interests of providing honourable members with detailed information, I table further data and graphical representations of the project's budget and the Parliament House Construction Authority response to the Auditor-General's report. I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of the Opposition I would thank the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) for presenting to the Parliament his progress report on the new Parliament House. Having been a member of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House for the past 4 1/2 years, it is the source of personal satisfaction and gratification that it would seem the building is going to be finished on time and, apart from a few hiccups, within a reasonable budget considering the size of the undertaking. Members of the House should be reminded that the new Parliament House is by far the nation's biggest building project to date and they should also be reminded that the 4,500 rooms in the complex will accommodate something like 3,500 people working in the building, in addition to visitors who are expected to total more than one million per year. It should also be borne in mind that the new chambers will seat more than 1,000 people in the public galleries and there will be over 2,000 underground and ground level parking spaces provided. It is, in anyone's language, a very large building.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, it is of great concern to many members of the House that on this occasion we notice that the total project budget has hit the billion dollar mark at May 1987 prices. It is interesting to see that the accumulated inflation escalation adjustment of $463m is the basic cause of the $724m increase over the original 1978 building budget of $220m and the original 1981 non-building budget of $82m. Many members on this side of the House who did not vote for an increase in the number of senators and members are noting the fact that there has been a $41m cost for accommodating the additional senators and members.

However, one of the most intriguing increases I have noted in the Minister's statement is the $5m for the reinstatement of landscaping in the Parliament. This follows a ridiculous decision by the then Executive to have almost impossible cutbacks in the last financial year regarding the completion of the building, and the present Executive Government also stands condemned for its actions at that time. It is interesting that there has been an additional cost of $5m for the reinstatement of the landscaping, a cost that was totally and completely due to a foolhardy Executive decision by this Government to stop the landscaping, and the Government must stand condemned for this basic waste of money. It would be appreciated if the Minister could inform the House now or at some future time as to the final cost of landscaping following the stop-start decisions by the present Government.

I find myself in agreement with the Minister about the sensational claims of unrestrained cost blowout. The Opposition is certainly aware of the controversy surrounding this new, national building and has not been unaware of problems that have been facing those charged with the responsibility of having this very large building project completed in such a relatively short time framework. After all, we should all remember that the first sod on Capital Hill was turned on 18 September 1980, only seven years ago. I am pleased to note that proper parliamentary processes are in train and have been in train since the undertaking was announced in 1978. I believe there has been a proper management task performed, and when one considers the enormity of the size of this project, then one must sit back and be impressed that so much has been achieved in this period by this Government and past governments.

I would like to take this opportunity to pay tribute to the many people who have been responsible for the progress of this project. One thinks immediately of Gordon Peatey, Chief Executive of the Parliament House Construction Authority; his executives, Ian Fowler, John Marr, Brian Harrison, Frank Toman, Rod Dalgleish and all the staff of the Authority; of the Chairman and members, past and present, of the Parliament House Construction Authority; of the architects, Aldo Giurgola, his partners, Ric Thorp and Pam Berg; and the curator, Katrina Rumley. All these people, as well as the 2,000-strong team of construction workers, have shown a remarkable pride in this project.

Let me remind the House of a very fine incident. When the flag was flown for the very first time on 24 January this year, members of the Joint Committee, along with executives, visitors and large numbers of the construction workers were on site to see this happen. During the playing of the national anthem, the flag was broken. The whole crowd, as one, broke into cheers. It was quite an emotional moment and I am sure this will be the case when the building is finished next year and opened by Her Majesty on 9 May. There is tremendous pride in the building by the workers on site and, though I do not wish to take this opportunity to talk of industrial matters on the site, I agree with what the Minister for Administrative Services said in his statement. It is true to say that there have been extremely trying and difficult circumstances over the past seven years for all concerned.

I praise the workers, the Executive, the planners and the consultants on the fact that these very trying and exacting moments have been overcome by consultation and, occasionally, by tough action. However, I do note that the Minister said in his speech that the Government will not bow to blackmail either by unions or contractors. This is welcomed and, on behalf of the Opposition, I place the Government on friendly notice that we in the Opposition will be monitoring the Government's performance and comparing it with the words the Minister has used today.

Because of the forms of the House, it was not possible for me to make a contribution to the debate on Tuesday, 6 October regarding the decision not to take the present Speaker's chair to the new Parliament. I believe the decision not to take the chair is wrong. I believe the arguments used for its non-transfer are specious and I have grave doubts that the planned replacement chair will be completed in time for its use as from August 1988. The only fresh argument that has been put forward in recent days has been the alleged difficulty in transporting it to a new site. When this objection was overcome a series of lightweight, inconclusive arguments was used and it saddened me to see this House divide on party lines without having thoroughly considered the matter. Let it be noted that the Joint Committee vote was also on strict party lines. I regretted that equally. When one considers that no decision at all has been taken with regard to the future use of the provisional Parliament House, I believe it is scandalous that the Speaker's chair, this revered symbol of parliamentary government in Australia, should be left here, deserted to fulfil no role whatsoever.

May I conclude by referring to the opening of the Parliament in May and the symbolism of that opening. The opening of the new Parliament will be not only a symbol of the expertise and skills and talents of Australian artisans, craftspeople and artists, but also a fitting monument to what many people sometimes conveniently forget about this building and the new building, and that is their role as the focal point of our democratic way of life for generations to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I join the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) and the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) in complimenting the people who have worked on the planning phase of the new Parliament House and the people who have worked on the construction phase of it. I have been a member of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House since 1979 when I was first elected to this Parliament. I think only two or three of the current members of the Committee have been on the Committee for that long or longer. I think the honourable member for Cook is one such member and the President of the Senate is another. I think the three of us are the only members of Parliament who have been on the Committee since 1979.

SPEECH.PARA: Members of the Committee have witnessed many changes up on the hill. Some of us are fortunate enough still to be members of Parliament so that we will see the work come to fruition next year. The Minister for Administrative Services, his Department and the workers on the site have done a marvellous job in bringing to fruition what was a concept some years ago and what will probably be one of the most important public buildings constructed anywhere in the world. It is a tribute to Australian workers, Australian craftsmanship and the creativity of Australians that this building is now coming to fruition.

I might just say a couple of things on what the honourable member for Cook said about the Speaker's chair because it was a matter of some debate the other day in the House. I think the case for leaving the chair here should be put. It does not get down really to the question of whether there is difficulty in getting it out of the building or, indeed, the cost. People have put a little bit too much symbolism on the chair. Indeed, I suppose if one looks at the symbolism that the Clerks are interested in-and I recall that a Clerk of one of the Houses in a paper I read referred to the Clerks as the golden thread that held democracy together-they might say that the table is more important, because the journal of the Clerks of the Commonwealth parliaments is called The Table, and they call themselves the Clerks at the table. So it might be said that the table has great symbolism, and to some people it probably has.

The chair no doubt does have symbolism, and that symbolism has more merit in some eyes than in others. But if members asked me what I saw as the important symbol of the independence of the Parliament, then I think it must be the Mace in this House and the Black Rod in the Senate. There is no doubt in anyone's mind that we shall take those two symbols of the independence of parliament up to the new House. As well, we shall take the symbol of parliament in the Westminster system in one of the few copies of Magna Carta available in the world, which is owned by this Parliament. I would think that that is one of the most precious objects this Parliament owns. It is one of the original vellum copies of Magna Carta. But to suggest that the Speaker's chair is all that holds together the rule of law in Australia is a bit of a thin argument.

The important thing when this building becomes a museum is that when people come here in the future they should see what 87 years of Australian parliamentary history have been and what 60 years of parliamentary history have been in this chamber. To take that chair out of this chamber would leave this place unlike it should be, the same as to take the table, or these benches, or other parts. There is no doubt that the chair, the table and this whole chamber have some symbolism, but the important thing that I think we are taking up the hill to the new Parliament is the body of Standing Orders that this Parliament works on, the body of laws that are the laws of Australia, and the parliamentary practice that we have determined here in Australia, which is unlike the parliamentary practice in England, or in Ottawa, and is a uniquely Australian system of government.

For some who suggest it is not, I guess we should just wait and hear the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) on the matter of public importance when he will be most certainly telling us very shortly how important the role of the Senate is in Australia. Of course, that role that the Senate in Australia has is an abhorrent role to the people who sit in the House of Lords in England. So to suggest that we should be saying that the most important thing that we here in Australia take up to the new Parliament House is British parliamentary traditions is to miss a little bit of the symbolism of this Parliament moving from the lake shore to the commanding heights of the city.

So, while a number of people hold quite properly to a view that there is a lot of symbolism in the chair and it should not be kept here, I think the other argument that says that the chair is part of the history of this chamber and should stay with this chamber is just as valid, and in my view is more valid. The important thing that we are taking up the hill is the system of parliamentary democracy that we have developed here in Australia. That is embodied in all the individuals in this chamber and it is represented by the independence of the Parliament, by the Mace and by the Black Rod in the Senate. It is important for members to recall if we are looking at the sentimental argument about the chair that the senators who tend to think more about symbolism and form than is sometimes thought about in this House had no compunction in leaving in the present Senate chamber the President's chair, which was a gift to the Australian Senate by the Canadian Parliament. The senators were quite happy to move up the hill and have a new chair. I found it interesting at the committee meeting that some of the people who were interested in telling members of the House of Representatives what they should do with their chamber were senators who had already made the decision to leave the President's chair in the old Senate chamber when we move. So, I commend the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) and his Department on the way that the people who have worked for them have built the new building. It is a great credit to Australian craftsmanship and Australian workers. Indeed, it is a credit to those people who have been on the parliamentary committee over the years, who chose the design in the first place, that they have persevered for so long. They will see the fruit of their labour in May of next year when the building is opened for all to see.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I should only like to observe, as one who did serve on the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House for a short while, that this matter was one that excited a good deal of interest over time, and it has done so again today. That matter is the removal of the chair in which you sit, Mr Deputy Speaker, to the new Parliament House or its remaining here in this chamber. I was interested, having regard to what were some incidental remarks commenting on the statement of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) from the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie), that we had a lengthy statement from the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) on those short remarks of the honourable member for Cook, because that ought to be compared with the comments made the other day by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young)-I think I have got his full title. He suggested on that occasion that this was a trite matter, that it was not deserving of serious address, and he was very critical of the fact that it was raised in the context of a discussion on the Speaker's statement by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard).

SPEECH.PARA: I am glad that we have had this opportunity today at least to hear some more detailed reasons from the honourable member for Grayndler why this decision has been pressed. I am glad because I think it shows the shallowness of the views which led the majority of the members of the Joint Committee to come to this view. I can remember well, as a former member of the Committee, the strength of the views of a former Speaker, Harry Jenkins, when it was suggested that the Speaker's chair might be left in this chamber. I would have to say that he, as a former Speaker, held very strong views about the symbolism of the chair. Any prospect of its remaining here in this chamber was one that he greeted with a good deal of foreboding.

I must say that, if we knew with any certainty the Government's intention for this chamber, we might well see some significance in leaving it here. If we knew that it was to be left here symbolically to show the way in which former Prime Minister Whitlam chopped off the head of Jim Cope as Speaker and that people were able to know that that was the place where it happened, there might be something in that symbolism, but at this stage we do not even know whether the Government has in mind turning it into some glorified convention centre, or perhaps a place where we can hold international conferences where the symbolism would be that there would be a whole lot of other people sitting in the chair.

Now, I must say that it needs a good deal more thought than was evident, and I found the statement of the honourable member for Grayndler on this matter a poor justification for the Government's decision. I regret that, in a matter that might well have been simply a discussion of a reasonable report from the Minister about the blowout of costs in relation to the building of the new Parliament House and the very reasoned response from the honourable member for Cook, it has become a revival of a debate that occurred on the Speaker's statement to this House.

I should like to make only one other observation, in view of the politics introduced into this subject by the honourable member for Grayndler. One of the very significant cost blowouts mentioned in his statement today was the extra $41m the public of Australia has had to pay for the benefit of the enlarged Parliament, a decision of the Australian Labor Party. We are now starting to see, as a result of that decision, the additional costs the Australian people are having to bear. That is what I think ought to be seen as significant, not the remarks of the honourable member for Grayndler endeavouring to justify the very poor decision of the Government to leave the Speaker's chair in what may be a museum or what may be something else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BURR; CAMERON; GOODLUCK; HALVERSON; HICKS; ROCHER; RUDDOCK
PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth:
1. The proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians.
2. Therefore your petitioners request a national referendum on the Australia Card bill before the proposal is resubmitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Burr,Mr Donald Cameron,Mr Goodluck,Mr Halverson,Mr Hicks,Mr Rocher and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BEALE; CHYNOWETH; HALVERSON; KENT; MILTON; SCOTT
PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Chynoweth,Mr Halverson,Mr Kent,Mr Milton and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
