DEBATE.TITLE: ROLE AND POWER OF THE SENATE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The fundamental threat to the role and power of the Senate contained in the proposals of the Constitutional Commission.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal and National parties bring this matter of public importance before parliament because it does in every sense of the word fit the description of a matter of public importance. On 2 October the Constitutional Commission published a series of proposals relating to projected referenda to be placed before the Australian people that, if implemented, would effectively reduce the Australian Senate to having no greater powers than those possessed by the British House of Lords. These proposals go far beyond a mere tinkering at the edges; they go to the fundamental role and power of the Australian Senate. They are nothing more, in the view of the Opposition parties, than a continuation of the vengeance streak that has consumed the Australian Labor Party since the events of November 1975. They must be judged by this Parliament and by the Australian people in that context.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposals are being put forward as a package designed to bring about something which in general terms a great number of people in Australia think desirable; that is, the replacement of the present three-year term of Federal parliaments with four years. It is a great pity that the Constitutional Commission has confused the two issues. At the outset I say to the Government that, if it wants to get a referendum for a four-year Parliament accepted by the Australian people, do not wrap it up with proposals to destroy the power of the Senate. If it is serious-and let me say that many on this side of the House would support the concept of four-year parliaments; they make a great deal of sense-for heaven's sake do not confuse it with its malice inspired desire to destroy the power of the Senate. Keep the two things completely separate and it will have some hope of getting a referendum for four-year parliaments accepted by the Australian people.

The other thing I suggest the Government do is not to confuse the presidential system of government that obtains in the United States of America with the Westminster system that obtains in Australia. I fundamentally reject the concept of fixed term parliaments. Four-year parliaments, yes; four-year fixed terms, no. Four- year parliaments wrapped up with a package that destroys the power of the Senate, also no with a capital `N'.

Let me turn to the recommendations of the Constitutional Commission. I have a great deal of personal regard for a number of people who sit on the Commission, in particular its Chairman, Sir Maurice Byers, a former Solicitor-General of the Commonwealth who has served with great distinction political parties and governments of both persuasions. What the Constitutional Commission is proposing is nothing short of a constitutional revolution so far as the Australian Senate is concerned. The main proposal is not the four-year proposal. That may be the public relations gloss. The main proposal is that which would in effect take away from the Senate any power to do other than delay for more than six months a measure passed by the House of Representatives. In effect, what the Constitutional Commission is recommending, and what the Government would be supporting if it put those proposals to referendum, is a suggestion that a money Bill as defined by the Constitutional Commission could not be delayed for more than 30 days and that in the event of any other measure being rejected by the Senate, the joint sitting proposals now contained in section 57 of the Constitution could be invoked, not after an election was held but after a subsequent rejection by the Senate after a period of three months.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate would be a rubber stamp.

—The Senate would be no more than a rubber stamp. The Liberal and National parties say to every voter in Australia, particularly those residing in the less populous States, that this is a charter to overturn the federal compact. The federal compact rested upon the understanding that the less populous States would enter the Federation on the basis that, having a popularly elected House of Representatives reflecting the overwhelming numerical superiority of New South Wales and Victoria, that in turn would be counterbalanced by the States House which would adequately protect the position of the less populous States. This is nothing more than an attempt to overturn that. The remarks in this debate are therefore directed particularly to those people residing in the less populous States who quite properly see in this a charter to overturn the basis of the federal compact.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very instructive to go back to 1949. My research has gone no further back than 1949. If the joint sitting provisions that are now proposed in the Constitutional Commission's report had obtained since 1949, it is a fact that on every occasion the government of the day would have had a majority at a joint sitting and that, as a consequence, it would not have been possible for a non-government majority in the Senate to delay for more than six months any measure which had been passed by the House of Representatives. If that does not reduce the role of the Senate to that of a mere rubber stamp and to a mere cipher, nothing does. If that does not destroy the protection that the Senate as now constituted gives to the people of Tasmania, Queensland, and Western Australia in particular, nothing does.

In a nutshell, the basis of our objection to these proposals, the basis of our rejection of these proposals if the Government puts them forward at a referendum, is that they will reduce the Australian Senate, one of the most democratically elected chambers in the world-a body which at present more faithfully represents the popular will of the total Australian people at the last election than does the House of Representatives; that is a fact in terms of the proportional representation system-to a body with no more power than that of the British House of Lords.

Is it not ironic that the Australian Labor Party, which so derides our so-called colonial links and which wants to throw out our magnificent Speaker's chair because it is an over-weaning reminder of our links to Westminster, is about to embrace some constitutional changes that would reduce the power of the Australian Senate to no more than that of the British House of Lords? Under the 1911 Act passed by the United Kingdom Parliament, the power to delay legislation was reduced virtually to no more than a delay of some three to six months. That is all we will have. That might be all right if the Australian Senate were an appointed chamber, but the Australian Senate is a democratically elected chamber on full adult franchise. That is the difference. That is why we find utterly untenable the proposition that the existing powers of the Australian Senate ought to be destroyed. I say to the Government: get off your 1975 kick. Do not maintain any rage over this proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why should we get off it?

—There is the little matter of the fact that the Australian people twice told those opposite that they had no kick to complain about. That is the reason. Out of the mouth of the honourable member for Dunkley have come the words as to what it is all about. Some of the others are not maintaining their rage, but there is absolutely no doubt that he is maintaining his rage. I say to the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen), who is at the table-I think he may be genuinely interested in some serious constitutional reform-that he has no hope of getting a referendum carried for a four-year parliament if he wraps it up with this absurd Senate-destroying nonsense. That is something that ought to be fundamentally understood from the very beginning.
—Aren't you ashamed of 1975, John?

—Not in the least. As I have been asked, let me say that I will defend to my last breath the action taken by the Liberal and National parties in 1975. The only thing that is shameful about 1975 is the way in which those opposite have persecuted and destroyed by character assassination a former Governor-General of this country. The treatment of that man by the Labor side of politics is one of the most shameful chapters in the political history of this country. He was the chosen and appointed constitutional keeper of the ring. If those opposite have any venom and any wrath, let them expend that venom and that wrath on us, but not on a man who took an oath to uphold the Constitution. It is the honourable member for Kingston who should be ashamed of himself.

SPEECH.PARA: Having dealt with that aberration, if there was any doubt that this Constitutional Commission is all about 1975, that doubt has been dispelled in the last five minutes. That is what it is all about. I simply say to the House that there is nothing like something to do with the Constitution to bring out the sort of hidden desires of the Labor Party. The former Federal President of the Labor Party wants an Australian republic. I wonder where the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) now stands on that issue. He used to favour it. It is still in the Labor Party platform. But do those opposite believe it? I wonder where the Deputy Prime Minister stands on this issue. In 1981 the Deputy Prime Minister wanted Australia to become a republic. The Prime Minister wanted Australia to become a republic when he delivered the Boyer lectures. He said in 1984 that it was inevitable that it would happen.

This is absolutely priceless: Biggles, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), has been waxing lyrical about deregulation of the airline industry. But he is even better on the Senate and the flag. Listen to this:
The Senate has by all accounts always been rather a silly and pompous-
fancy Evans talking about pomposity-

institution, but now it is obvious to most people that it has become a very dangerous one as well. If one believes, as I do, along with all good Labor men and women true, that the Senate ought to be abolished, or at the very least deprived of its capacity to destroy properly elected governments, there is surely no better forum in which to promote its insidious heresies than the institution itself.
That was Senator Evans. The reality is that beneath the surface the Labor Party still believes in a unicameral system of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is their policy.

—That is the Labor Party's policy. It does not really believe in the Senate. It does not believe in protecting the rights of the less populous States. Under the cover of promoting the idea of four-year parliaments, what it will want to do with this proposal is to bring about a constitutional revolution that will undermine the power of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the Liberal and National parties, I say to those opposite and to the Parliament that we will campaign against these proposals right across the country from this day onwards, and those opposite will suffer the same defeat on them as they have suffered on their discredited identity card proposals. If the Government dares to put these proposals to a referendum, the defeat of the Bill of Rights and the ID card legislation will look like a holiday weekend by comparison. These proposals represent nothing more than the final working out by the Labor Party of its agony of vengeance over the events of 1975. It could never accept, in a month of Sundays, the simple principle by which democracies live or perish, and that is the will of the people.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The Chair points out to the House that, while it elected to play the advantage rule, that did not make the interjections from its right in order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter of public importance which relates to a matter which I consider could not be more important to Australia-that is, the review of our Constitution and how well it is working for this nation. When one listens to the recent remarks of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the histrionics about what has always been the underlying factor, the hidden agenda, it is no wonder that the people of Australia say, `A plague on both sides. We do not want any reform. We do not trust any of you'. I do not know whether that is the Opposition's view.

SPEECH.PARA: In fairness to the Leader of the Opposition, I give him top marks because when he started the debate today he admitted for the first time that he had a high regard for the members of the Constitutional Commission. That is a little different from what some other people have been saying. I acknowledge that the Leader of the Opposition did not agree with the establishment of the Constitutional Commission; in fact, he favoured its abolition. But, the Commission having brought down a report, the Leader of the Opposition is good enough to acknowledge that some of the matters it tries to identify as being matters which could be solved certainly would encourage debate.

But let us face the issue of what we are about in this nation. When the debates on the Constitution took place, it was proposed-indeed, it was hoped-that those who occupied positions in the Senate would not be wedded to any political party. The Senate was to be a House of review. It is a fact of life in Australian political development that that is never going to be the case. Senators are there by political organisation. All parties represented in this House are effectively represented in the Senate, with the addition of minority parties. That is the problem that probably is bedevilling a genuine review of the Senate because senators are instructed how to vote as soon as legislation is introduced in this House. There is no question of the senators changing; the party organisation guarantees that the independence of the Senate has gone out of the window, because it becomes necessary in a party organisation to dictate to the senators how they will vote.

As a result, there has developed an extraordinary situation which was the target of the Constitutional Commission-the frequent elections in this country. Since World War II 22 Federal elections have taken place. The average life of a parliament is two years.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have told you how to overcome this; just introduce a four-year parliament.

—I do not want the assistance of interjections by the honourable member for Sturt. He will have an opportunity to speak in the debate. The facts of life are that everyone knows that too-frequent elections are a curse and a worry. I think we all would like to follow some of the examples of the States and say, `Why cannot we have a four-year term?'. I know that that is a valid statement; but the facts of life are that one can never get a four-year term if one cannot get a guarantee of the term.
—Why not?

—One cannot get a guarantee of the term. I do not know why the honourable member is so abysmally ignorant of that. One cannot get such a guarantee if the Senate decides not to give it. That is the position.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make this point in fairness to the Constitutional Commission: I can think of no better expression of opinion than that of Sir Rupert Hamer. Opposition members will admit that Sir Rupert is considering this matter from the standpoint of what is in the best interests of the nation, and not from any party political advantage or with the madness of Professor Blainey thinking he has some vested interest in making this statement. Sir Rupert said:

The proposals are a package because they all contribute to a central idea, which is to ensure there is at least three years ahead of a new government as it comes into power, barring the loss of its majority in the lower house. To achieve that, there has to be . . . a trade-off. The government of the day loses its power to call a premature election and the senate of the day loses its power to force one.
No Opposition members have addressed their minds to that point. That is the issue-a concession on both sides of the coin. Sir Rupert went on to say:
I think people who have the interests of good government at heart will accept that.

The Opposition would be fooling the people of Australia if it said that it favoured a four-year term because, if the Senate has the power to get rid of the lower House by refusing Supply, for example, it will not be a four-year term; it will be whatever the Senate dictates. That is the position. I will not hark back to the heart-rending circumstances of 1975: one can see what a disaster that has caused here today. Nothing will be achieved by saying, `What about this and what about that?', except that it was a party political decision by the Opposition to instruct its senators how to vote. That procedure will continue. The one miracle that happened, which might have prevented civil disturbance in this country at the time, was that the Government, by accident-and I mention that-passed Supply in the Senate. As a matter of interest, the Government did not know that it had been sacked.

I ask honourable members to consider the troubles that would have been caused to this country if Supply had not been passed by the Senate. The Opposition could not have got Supply through the Senate because it did not have the necessary numbers. If the Government had withdrawn the Appropriation Bills, this nation would have had no Supply from November onwards. Assuming the Governor-General acted, as he did, and an election was called in December, can honourable members imagine this nation's problems with no money for State governments, schools, hospitals or the ordinary services of government in the ensuing period? Thousands, perhaps millions, of people would have been out of work. Perhaps that was the lesson we needed to learn in Australia-what the people would have thought of an action that refused annual appropriations to keep government functioning. That would have been the test.

All that the Constitutional Commission is saying is, `Do you really want to undergo that again?'. I am not here to argue the powers of the Senate about other Bills. The Leader of the Opposition has addressed his mind fairly to the question whether the Commission has got the balance right in saying, `We will ensure that all Bills, except money Bills, are passed, because there will be a joint sitting of both Houses'. There may need to be some reassessment of that proposal. But it is a fallacy to be talking about having a four-year term with a hostile Senate. The Senate does not even have to go out for review by the public. That is the great weakness in this debate. All that the Government is asking-and it still requires the consent of this Parliament-is to put a number of propositions to the people of Australia. The Government will not be able to put anything through unless the Parliament agrees that it can be put as a question.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you want four years.

—One wants four years and one will need to get it on the basis that the Commission has addressed part of its mind to the inability of the Senate to reject a government in the first three years. One will need to do that on Supply.
—Why?
—Once the Senate rejects a government, that government cannot stay; it has no power--
—Once in 87 years?

—That is not so from now on because the Opposition created a precedent that in future it is in order to instruct its senators. Obviously every future government will face the problem of a hostile Senate. One has no idea what might be the view of other parties. Some parties, seeking increased representation, might favour dissolutions sooner than other parties would. It would depend on the climate at the time. I am not impressed by the Premier of Queensland-whom the Leader of the Opposition at times sought as an ally, though I doubt whether he will do so in future-welcoming these things because he wants to go out and fight the idea of constitutional reform. That is the very reason I am trying to keep the politicians out of the debate at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: What value are Opposition members to the debate? They should look at their performance today. They should look at their performance in the constitutional conventions where they did nothing but cause trouble on the basis of arguing with each other. The propositions we put up they could not agree on. Malcolm Fraser wanted simultaneous elections, but by the time we got around to putting the proposal even the States would not agree with it. It was a ridiculous problem. I do not know what their alternative is. Their view is to live in the hope that the Senate in the future will not exercise the powers that they know it now has. They say that is good enough for them. Twenty-two years of history shows that we are facing the people every two years. We have had double dissolutions four times since 1974. If honourable members opposite look at Hansard, particularly in 1973, they will see that their Party in the Senate was threatening the refusal of Supply for no other reason than that it was deemed to be valid to do it in 1973. It was threatened again in 1974. In fact, we had a double dissolution. It was threatened again when Sir Billy Snedden was Liberal leader. It is a normal thing to try to force a government out. We can understand the game of politics. How long would any honourable member stay in opposition if there was a chance to get into government? They would use opportunities as fast and as often as they could. What will happen to this nation if that is the issue? They do not give a damn. It is only a question of expediency. All politicians would grasp the nettle if they could, knowing that it was to their advantage. But it does nothing for this country. The Commission is not to be lambasted on this issue; it has asked for constructive suggestions from Opposition members.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commission got them today.
—That is good. The point I want to make is that it does not add up. Sir Maurice Byers said:

SPEECH.PARA: You can't have a fixed term unless the Government has the money to carry on government. That's obvious . . .

It is nonsense to say that governments will have four-year terms unless they have the money to carry on the terms. That is the issue. If we accept that the Opposition can refuse to grant Supply, this problem will arise. The Opposition invented this refusal to grant Supply; it accepted it, encouraged it and, in fact, exploited it. Conventions in the past endeavoured to face up to it. The House will recall the issues that were suggested by Sir Charles Court, and by everybody else who was not in this Parliament of course, as to how best we might be able to manage the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —But Sir Charles did not agree with this.

—No, I am talking about what he suggested, which was, `We put a proposition to the Senate and, if it is rejected, we will have a double dissolution; and if we then win, it will have to be passed the second time round'. Such ideas are just as cumbersome for the Australian people to understand. This is not the only matter I want to see put to the Australian people; there are a number of matters, all of which, I think, are very healthy from the point of view--
—Some of the others we might agree with.
—I hope you do.
—What about the defamation laws?

—Yes, but the only problem with the defamation laws is that the media themselves have a view about defamation laws. We could have got uniform defamation laws if the media had agreed that they were liable if they defamed someone after his death-the question of truth and public benefit. These are the issues that would prevent only uniform defamation. That is not a problem. The problem with uniform defamation is getting the media to agree to what they will accept. That has been the discussion with the Attorneys-General.

SPEECH.PARA: Coming back to the point, what we are about here is constitutional change. Sir Maurice Byers made it very clear that the proposals are now in the public arena. They have been made available with a view to informing the public about what the Commission is thinking. It is not stated that this is the absolute position. When they were selected he invited modification of the proposals. He made it very clear that he would welcome any constructive suggestions from members of the public and, because it is a fair proposition, from the Opposition as well. It is worth noting, as I am reminded, that other people in Australia, such as Mr Eric Mayer of the Business Council of Australia, think that this is an excellent set of recommendations. The business community, although it does not address itself to the detail as we do, knows that having elections every two years is fatal.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can fix that without this.

—It cannot be fixed in the way that the Opposition has suggested. It is a parrot like repetition of something we know cannot last unless we have the compliance of the Senate to allow the Government to remain. We are not going to get that if there is that chance, in a Senate that is hostile, to remove Government.
— Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about a matter of public importance which is the fundamental threat to the role and power of the Senate contained in the proposals of the Constitutional Commission. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has just said that we cannot go ahead with just a straight out increase in the term of the House of Representatives to four years because we would not have the compliance of the Senate. That is what the Australian Labor Party is all about. It is about having the Senate doing its bidding. It is as simple as that. This sort of proposal from the Constitutional Commission is not about four-year terms; it is about having a Senate that will lie down before the executive government-and a Labor government at that. The Opposition is saying today that it will fight the proposal to slash the powers of the Senate. We will fight it long and hard. We will fight it throughout the country. We will fight to ensure the maintenance of the powers of the Senate. The reality about the Senate is that it is one of those checks and balances against excesses of executive power by governments.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent years this Labor Government has put up a number of propositions which if passed would have fundamentally altered the relationship between the government and the Australian people. On each occasion the Government's proposals have been for nothing other than more power for Canberra. Things like the Bill of Rights and the ID card have been nothing but barely disguised attempts to increase the power of executive government.

One of the reasons I am in Parliament, and interested in politics and our institutions of government, is that I believe that one of the safety mechanisms for the Australian people is to ensure that political power is spread throughout the community as widely as possible. Thomas Hobbes said:
Freedom is political power divided into small fragments.

Or to put it another way: power corrupts and absolute power corrupts absolutely. I am in the Liberal Party because it believes in markets. One of the reasons it supports a free market is that it is a mechanism for distributing economic power. It distributes economic power, of course, to the consumers and keeps it out of the hands of the bureaucrats and the central planners. These are always the characteristics of totalitarian regimes whether of the Left or the Right.

The reality is that the Labor Party loves to attack the Constitution, and it does so because it has an agenda for change. Basically, that agenda is all about removing those checks and balances against the excesses of government. That is what it is on about when it attacks the Constitution and when it puts up proposals such as these from the Constitutional Commission. They are simply a grab for more and more power in pursuit of Labor ideals. Associate Professor Mark Cooray of Macquarie University described it:
The Labor Government's approach to Constitutional reform is based on a conviction that a Constitution should serve the aims of a Government which holds power at a given moment.
The Constitution itself should be an instrument of Labor Party ideology. He continued:
The present Government has learnt from the lessons of the Whitlam times. The Whitlam Government was honest and told the people what it intended to do.
Of course, the people responded as one would expect them to respond, but the Hawke Government takes another approach. Professor Cooray continued:
Its tactic is to introduce changes gradually without the people knowing what is happening . . .

That is absolutely right. We have seen it in relation to the ID card. It is no wonder that Labor Party members were not keen to ensure that that got the sort of coverage it should have been given during the election campaign, because it was part and parcel of the agenda of the Labor Party, which was keen to see greater power centralised in Canberra.

What we are about this week is ensuring that the Australian community understands the extent and the ramifications of these proposals. This week marks the start of that campaign to ensure the safety of the mechanisms embodied in the Constitution. One of the institutions which the Labor Party has long been keen to undermine is, of course, the Senate. Many people, like the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth), do not really understand the issues. For him, of course, 1975 was the start of it all. Of course, for others, it goes back much longer than that.

The late Lionel Murphy is often referred to as a great supporter of the Senate. He used it for political purposes when he was in opposition. But the reality was that he was an opponent of the Senate's powers. When he was Attorney-General he appeared before the High Court of Australia to attack the powers of the Senate by claiming that the House of Representatives was the leading legislature and the Senate basically had to do the bidding of the House of Representatives That was the proposition that he, as Attorney-General, put in the 1970s. It was a proposition which was obviously, and quite properly, rejected by the High Court when it made it clear-if it was ever in doubt, and I do not believe it has ever been in doubt-that the Senate and the House of Representatives are co-equal. The ideologues have been at it since 1975. Last week, when the massive bungle and blunder of the ID card was revealed, what was Labor's response? Labor's response was, `Look, the Senate has to bow down and do what we in the House of Representatives tell it to do. It is all constitutional vandalism if you don't give us a cover for our monumental blunder on the ID card'.

The proposals released by the Constitutional Commission last Friday are, of course, very popular with many members of the Labor Party. Senator Gareth Evans, a former Attorney- General, has introduced similar proposals previously. This week the Attorney-General indicated to the House his support for the slashing of the Senate's powers. He did so again today. It was a disgrace that at Question Time, when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), was asked this straight-out question, `Will you give the Australian people an assurance about maintaining the powers of the Senate?', he gave not a word of assurance. No; he will keep the door open for a referendum in 1988 to cash in on the euphoria of the Bicentenary. That is his game plan. We in the Opposition say that that is not a game plan to which we will be a party.

Members of the Labor Party love to talk about the events of 1975 as constitutional vandalism. What they forget is that the resolution of the events of 1975 was that an election was called. They will not accept the result of that election. The reality is that they are continuing to whinge about it. Their constant whinging about 1975 is not about the Constitution; it is about the fact that they would not accept the will of the people in a general election in the Australian democracy. They ought to be big enough to wake up to the reality of what they are on about.

Labor Party members have been full of talk and full of rhetoric about constitutional reform. Of course, until now, when it comes to what is in their greatest interests, their interest in constitutional reform has been marked by nothing but the greatest cynicism. Last time some of these proposals were put forward was in 1983. They ditched them for one reason: because the right wing of the Labor Party decided that it wanted an early election in 1984. That is why they ditched the proposals then. When it came to what was to their advantage, they said, `What is to our immediate, practical advantage? Shall we go ahead with some constitutional referenda or shall we back off and pave the way for an early election?'.

When the Attorney-General puts forward these proposals on the basis that we have too many elections, I invite the Australian people to remember that the present Prime Minister has had the opportunity to call two elections since he has been Prime Minister, and both of them have been early. Government members have the cheek to say that they are concerned about the number of elections. The reality of the arguments by Labor Party members about the frequency of elections is that they are just the coating of a poison pill, and it is a poison pill which has at its centre one of Labor's cherished ambitions regarding Australia's Constitution-that is, to knock down the Senate. Labor wants to knock down the Senate because that means more power for the executive government and more power for Labor Party members to enable them to undertake their agenda for radical reform of the Australian community. We will fight them tooth and nail.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find this debate to be a tragedy, because there has never been a better time in the history of the Commonwealth of Australia for a proposal to be put forward for a comprehensive series of referenda which, I believe, in the spirit of 1988, has every chance, not just for a successful passage through the Parliament, but also of attaining the support of the Australian people. Honourable members know that it is not my practice to inflame division and to take a partisan approach to a debate when there is some possibility of building common ground with members of the Opposition about important matters of public policy.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a bitter irony that in the grievance debate a few hours ago I called for an attempt at bipartisan consideration of constitutional change. I argued that the view put forward by the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), who has just spoken, that disunity means death for constitutional change, was a view that had some great substance. But the problem is that, in order to be able to have any attempt at reaching a bipartisan approach on these important questions, one first needs rational debate. I regret that the contribution made today by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), both in this debate and in his comments outside the Parliament, do a disservice not only to himself and his Party, but also to the Parliament and the country. What he has done is clearly to launch a pre-emptive strike which, I believe, is calculated to sabotage not just the proposal for a change in the Senate's powers, but to undermine completely the work of the Constitutional Commission.

The whole idea of setting up the Constitutional Commission was to take the process of constitutional change away from the rarefied atmosphere and the passions of this House and this Parliament. I believe that, if ever we needed evidence that the view of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in setting up that Commission was fully justified, we have seen it today in the contribution of the Leader of the Opposition, who referred, in the course of his remarks, to everything from the ID card and the Bill of Rights to his suggestion that the proposals that were put forward were `a malice-inspired device by the Government to destroy the power of the Senate'. He said that the idea behind the proposals that were put forward was part of the vengeance kicks of the Australian Labor Party. He said outside the chamber today that there was a vengeance streak in the Labor Party regarding the events of 1975 and the proposals that were put forward were intended to castrate the Senate. He went on and on about castration and vengeance-hardly, I would have thought, the sort of language and approach that one would expect from an alternative Prime Minister in relation to the process of constitutional change.

I would ask not just members in the Parliament today but the people of Australia to have regard to the sorts of people that the Leader of the Opposition attempts to label as having a vengeance streak and who seek to castrate the power of the Senate. The members of the Constitutional Commission are hardly the sorts of people one would find in the precincts of an Australian Labor Party branch meeting and are hardly, one would have thought, tools of this Government. They are eminent and esteemed Australians who I believe have been defamed by the Leader of the Opposition both in the Parliament and outside.

The Commission is chaired by Sir Maurice Byers, a former Solicitor-General. One of its members is Sir Rupert Hamer, a retired Liberal Premier of Victoria who was instrumental in establishing the Constitutional Convention. He supported the setting up of the Commission because the Convention had failed in its attempts at constitutional reform. The Commission also has on its advisory committees a whole range of people who could hardly be said to be embittered about 1975. Sir James Killen saw fit to lend his esteemed services to the work of the Commission. Yet the Leader of the Opposition comes in here today seeking to sabotage the work of that Commission. Also on the Commission is Mr Greg Percival-not a friend of the Labor Party but indeed someone who has made a great contribution to local government in this country. There is also Mr Haddon Storey, a former Liberal Party Attorney-General in Victoria. I would have hoped that the Leader of the Opposition, as someone who sees himself as an alternative Prime Minister of this country, would have been able to come into this chamber and engage in a rational debate instead of rambling and ranting in a way that I believe, as I said, did a great disservice not only to him but to the Parliament as a whole.

It is extremely important that people understand just what the Constitutional Commission recommendations are. They are not government recommendations. They have never been discussed in a Labor Party Government committee, they have not been discussed in the Labor Party Caucus and they have not been discussed in the Cabinet-they are recommendations of an independent commission. I would have thought the dust would have been allowed to settle after those recommendations were first made before we had the Leader of the Opposition causing an incitement and orchestrating a reminder to this House of the bitter divisions caused in 1975.

It is for that reason that I believe the bringing forward today of this matter is clearly a misuse of the Parliament. It is not a Government proposal. I remind the House that the Constitutional Commission was established because of the failure of the Constitutional Convention, and that of some 38 proposals it put forward for change only eight were successful. I might also say that the belated support now given by the Opposition to the Constitutional Convention stands rather uncomfortably with its failure even to have that Convention meet during a large period of the former Government.

I heard in the course of the remarks of the honourable member for Flinders a great deal of debate and a number of assertions about individual rights and not allowing power in Australia to become concentrated. If the honourable member is serious about pursuing those things there are many people on this side of the House who would willingly join with him in moving towards constructive change in order to be able to confer additional rights on individuals. I note that one of the proposals put forward by an advisory committee to the Commission is to ensure the principle of one vote one value. I would have thought that at least the members of the Liberal Party of Australia would have some sympathy with that principle, although I do not expect that that view will be universally shared by members of the National Party of Australia, and certainly those from Queensland. The Commission's advisory committee also recommends the enshrinement of common law principles so that individuals are not wrongly deprived of liberty or property, and it proposes also extending constitutional protection to provide just compensation for the appropriation of private property by any government, including State governments. The existing constitutional provision simply does not apply to State governments.

I appeal again for some rational debate on the processes of constitutional change, and I ask people to contrast the way the Attorney and I have approached the matter with the attitude taken by the Opposition. If Opposition members want to get a quick headline, if they want to knock off the Constitutional Commission as any sort of effective body, if they want to have years of work by that Commission, including innumerable public hearings and submissions and efforts by a whole range of people, including members of their own Party all simply result in the abandonment of any attempt at constitutional change, they can probably do it. They can probably achieve that end, but let me tell them this: history will judge them, as it has judged them before, as the wreckers and the saboteurs of progressive and reasonable change in this country. They are on the wrong track and I ask them to think again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —A unique feature of the Federal Budget is that it includes the budget for the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). There is no separate State budget for the Australian Capital Territory as there is for the States and the Northern Territory, nor is there a separate municipal budget for Canberra such as is prepared by every local government council in the country. This is because the Federal Government has complete and absolute control over how the people of the ACT are taxed and what funds are spent here. The people of the ACT have no power to determine budget priorities in Canberra. That is one of the central reasons why we must have self-government. I will return to that theme in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1987 budget for the Australian Capital Territory makes significant advances in preparing the way for self-government. For the first time revenue collected in the Australian Capital Territory has been recognised as part of the Territory's own budget. In the past, tax revenue from the Australian Capital Territory went straight into Consolidated Revenue and the Commonwealth gave us back whatever it thought appropriate. The Government has not unreasonably decided that taxes in the Australian Capital Territory should be at levels comparable with taxes in the States. This was, in effect, recommended in the last report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission. There is no reason why the people in the Australian Capital Territory should welcome this; on the other hand, it is important for us to demonstrate to the rest of Australia that we are paying our way. This we are now doing.

The Australian Capital Territory is continuing to receive from the Commonwealth grants which are broadly in line with those made to the States and which take into account the special conditions which apply to Canberra. These arrangements bring Canberra to financial maturity but leave us as politically backward as ever. The Australian Capital Territory budget provides for an increase of 7 1/2 per cent in outlays-a little more than the increase in funds given to the States, but then population is growing in Canberra faster than the Australian average. A large increase would have been desirable, because there are many high priority programs needing additional funding, but the parameters for this Budget were set by Australia's poor trading position. Outlays for all programs had to be restricted so that the Government could make a contribution to the reduction of imports, and the ACT had to make its contribution to this restraint.

Despite these constraints, there a number of important new initiatives in the Budget, and several existing programs are to be improved or extended. Amongst major new initiatives are the School for Hospitality Studies at the Canberra College of Technical and Further Education, and a sharp increase in pay for nurses. Most people in the community recognise the equity of increased pay for nurses and will therefore support the $16m being allocated for their pay rise. Much of their new pay structure has been agreed, but there are still some important areas of disagreement between the Royal Australian Nursing Federation (RANF) and the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority. This is an industrial dispute between the nurses and their employers which has to be resolved either by negotiation and compromise or by arbitration. So far, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has thought that its role should be limited to statements of general principle about the new pay structure rather than to direct mediation. This is a pity because the Commission could have played a more constructive role in the resolution of this conflict. The value of mediation was shown by the effect of the involvement of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) in drawing the parties much closer together and resolving several of the issues in dispute.

The dispute between the Health Authority and the RANF, together with the doctors' strike and the recent disputes between the Authority, the Hospital Employees Federation of Australia and the Professional Officers Association, suggests that health industry-industrial relations in the Australian Capital Territory need a thorough overhaul. From outside, it is impossible to know what all the underlying causes of the conflict are, nor where compromise would be responsibly possible. Therefore, I have suggested to the Minister for Industrial Relations, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown), the Health Authority and the unions that an industrial relations expert be engaged as a consultant to study the causes of the problems and recommend solutions. The consultant would have to be acceptable to all the parties-that is, the Authority and the unions. I have also spoken to the President of the Arbitration Commission, and he has recommended someone who might be appropriate. I hope that this proposal will be implemented quickly, because the people of the ACT are thoroughly tired of perpetual conflict in the health area. Far more importantly, the health and security of hundreds of people are being eroded by the frequent stoppages and the loss of morale which inevitably flow from such sustained conflict.

Canberra is a dictatorship-a benevolent dictatorship, certainly, but a dictatorship. One man has complete power over every aspect of government in Canberra. This is not a personal criticism of the present Minister, but simply a factual statement about our system of government. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has, among all his responsibilities, complete and final power over most aspects of government in the Australian Capital Territory. In fact, with the amalgamation of all major aspects of government into the Australian Capital Territory administration, and the consolidation of all outlays and revenues into an Australian Capital Territory fiscus, the Minister has more power than ever. He not only controls more functions but also no longer has to consult his ministerial colleagues about his decisions.

The Australian Capital Territory residents have no direct way to influence the Minister's decisions. Not only is there no elected Parliament or council for the Territory which would be accountable to the community for decisions, but also the elected members of the Federal Parliament have no direct involvement by right in most decisions affecting the Territory. Of course, we have influence and can make suggestions which are taken seriously, and are often consulted, but this is a most informal and inadequate means of representation of the Territory's interests.

The Australian Capital Territory is the only part of any Western democratic nation which does not control any of its own affairs. At present we are a dictatorship without direct representation in the decisions affecting us. The only way in which Australian Capital Territory voters can influence the choice of dictator is by voting at national elections, which determine which party will govern the country. At the last election, the vote for Labor in the Territory increased. In fact, the vote in Fraser went up by more than in any other safe Labor seat in the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I thank the honourable member. Some 65 per cent of people, nearly two-thirds of all voters, supported Labor in Fraser on a two-party basis. That was a strong expression of support for the Labor Government, and the Government remains committed to self-government for the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: You may remember, Mr Deputy Chairman, that the Government tried to introduce democratic government for the Australian Capital Territory about 18 months ago, but it was stopped by the coalition parties and the Australian Democrats in the Senate. They opposed the electoral system being proposed by the Government-a system which had been reorganised to recognise their concerns. I see the previous Minister, the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes), sitting here, and I congratulate him on the fine work he did in preparing those proposals. At that time, the Government was suggesting an Australian Capital Territory council in which about half the members would be elected from single member constituencies by preferential voting and half from a Territory-wide electorate elected by proportional representation. This would have provided an opportunity for the representation of small parties, while at the same time providing a framework for stable government. This was a fair compromise between the concerns of all parties, yet even that was rejected.

Electoral systems are now being reconsidered, but it will be difficult to find a more reasonable compromise than that previous proposal. Therefore, I hope that each of the other parties will reconsider its position in the coming months so that agreement can be reached on an appropriate system. The introduction of self-government for the Australian Capital Territory is essential for the good government of Canberra. That is increasingly widely recognised in the community, and the election results are some indication of that. The Government will try again to introduce self-government, and I hope that this time the Opposition parties will co-operate. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some remarks in this debate on the appropriation for the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Firstly, I wish to bring to the attention of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) the enormous potential that I see in the introduction of regional games throughout rural Australia particularly, and possibly in the capital cities. In Victoria there has been some experience in the organisation of regional games. In 1983 regional games were conducted in south- west Victoria. In 1984 similar games were conducted in Hamilton, with 600 competitors taking part. Since then we have seen games conducted in other areas throughout the State as well as in Queensland, where I believe that such games have had enormous success. In 1984 the first north Queensland regional games took place in Townsville, with some 6,500 competitors in 42 sports. In 1986 these games were held again in Mount Isa with 54 sports and in 1988, as we know, the games are to be conducted in Cairns.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently I placed before the Minister a submission prepared by Mr Richard Coppin, the Executive Officer of the Northern Mallee Sports Assembly in my electorate. This is an organisation of over 50 sporting bodies operating throughout the Sunraysia region and representing over 10,000 active sports people. This group has managed to put together a submission which has been accepted on a tri-State basis and which will result in regional games being conducted for the first time, with sporting bodies representing the Riverland of South Australia, Broken Hill in New South Wales and the Sunraysia region in my electorate.

I believe that the benefits that will accrue to sports men and women, sporting groups and business houses in our region is most significant. This opportunity to initiate the tri-State concept is unique, and, I believe, if handled correctly would enable us, through the Minister in Canberra, to achieve national attention. I believe that in the not too distant future regional games, if given the support of State and Federal governments, will be a significant part of the sporting calendar throughout most of Australia. Ultimately, they may be the regional component of a true Australia games.

In the past I have supported the concept of Australia games being held in the period between the Commonwealth Games and the Olympic Games. Those games have not been as successful as they should have been; they have not attracted the sorts of competitors and competition from overseas that we would have liked. Such games have also been extremely costly to hold. I ask the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to consider seriously this submission and whether his Department, and the Australian Sports Commission in particular, can allow this concept to be promoted across Australia.

The second point I wish to raise is the very significant issue of chemical use in this country-an issue that is creating real concern. It is vital that the Parliament does not allow the debate on chemicals to degenerate in the same way as the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) has allowed the debate on the Queensland rainforests to degenerate. It has done so mainly because of his macho, dictatorial campaign of misinformation. In 1982 the Joint Committee on Environment and Conservation, of which I was a member, took a reference that required it to examine the adequacy of Commonwealth and State legislative arrangements and to research the assessment and dissemination of information on the use of chemicals in this country. The report brought down by that Committee very largely has not been acted upon.

We are all aware that chemicals play a large part in our every day lives. Probably the current standard of living in this country and that throughout most of the Western world and parts of the remainder of the world is very much dependent upon chemical products. It is therefore important that we have a balanced debate on this issue and ensure that the essential gains that we have made through chemical use are consolidated and not outweighed by deleterious effects. Of course, the farming community is very interested in this issue. I guess it has been brought to the fore by the crisis in the beef industry. However, it should be remembered that farmers have no desire to use chemicals. They basically use chemicals for two major reasons: firstly, because they are such a part of farm management operations and technique and, secondly, because, particularly in this country, domestic policies, especially in respect of crude oil, have forced the farmers, because of cost, to use chemicals in the major part of their farming operations.

I ask the Minister to get his Department to examine the report that was produced by the Joint Committee on Environment and Conservation in 1982. The Committee found that the control of chemicals in this country is poor; that there was enormous fragmentation between the States and the Commonwealth; that there were tremendous deficiencies in the assessment and control machinery of chemicals; that most industrial chemicals, particularly cosmetics and toiletries, did not require any assessment or clearance prior to their being marketed in this country; and, perhaps of more concern, that the public health structure of the National Health and Medical Research Council was not sufficiently comprehensive and it was very slow in coming to grips with problems associated with chemical use.

The Minister should ensure that his Department acts quickly on this report. It is not the role of primary producers or those engaged in secondary industry or manufacturing to understand the effects and the hazards of chemicals. Suitable agencies such as the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the Commmonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the National Health and Medical Research Council and the committees of this Parliament are responsible for the assessment of hazardous chemicals. It is their role to look into these matters, and they should do so immediately before some of the problems that were encountered in recent weeks in the beef industry are imposed upon us.

I wish to refer now to the Queensland rainforest situation. The debate on that matter has been conducted in such a way that we have been provided with no information that would allow us to make a balanced assessment. I particularly blame the Minister for the Environment and the Arts for the present situation. Even at meetings held this week, in answer to three questions posed to him, he virtually stated without any explanation that the heritage listing would go ahead, no matter what, and that all logging would cease, no matter what. The only topic open for discussion was the very vague one of compensation.

In the few minutes I have left, it is worth while to make a few points about the Queensland rainforest issue. We know that no clear-felling of rainforests for timber harvesting purposes has been taking place in Queensland State forests. We know that less than 20 per cent of the rainforest is available for harvesting; that is, 75 per cent of the 850,000 hectares in that area which stretches some 500 kilometres from Townsville to Cooktown, is either designated national park or is not available for logging. We know that in the areas where logging does take place in that less than 20 per cent of the rainforest, only six to 10 trees are harvested per hectare. Only one-half of one per cent of rainforest is disturbed by harvesting in any one year. Only trees marked by forestry officers may be harvested. Their professional management and dedication to their environment have ensured that Queensland has this enormous and lasting resource of rainforest potential. As we know also, harvesting is carried on only in a 40-year cycle.

It is ironic to contemplate where we will get our timber supplies from if timber operations in this country are curtailed. Last year Australia exported some $324m worth of timber and imported $1,607m worth of timber. In other words, our import-export ratio is 5 : 1. It seems to me that we will have to seek alternative sources of hardwood for importation from areas such as Asia and Brazil where forest management is often substandard. If the purpose of the lock up of Australian rainforests is to preserve the world's rainforests, I believe the opposite effect will be achieved. The morality of stopping the harvesting in Queensland is highly questionable. It is surely wrong to shift the harvesting out of sight-in other words, overseas-simply because we are an affluent country. Apparently it is immoral to chop down trees in Australia but it is all right for it to be done overseas.
Sitting suspended from 6.27 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak tonight in relation to the estimates for the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, but particularly in relation to the Territories aspect and in relation to the environment. Firstly, I want to raise one brief matter on which the Minister may care to comment. I do not know the way in which stationery is used in the government service, but I must say that members on this side of the chamber are disturbed always when information comes into their hands where obviously the facilities that are provided to employees of government are abused by, in this case, an organisation called the Redeployment Action Group. The president of that group happens to be one of our parliamentary colleagues, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), although I am sure he would not have been involved in this himself.

SPEECH.PARA: On 7 October this letter, in which Government members might be quite interested, which is rather caustic, in fact, of the Government for ignoring its long-standing responsibilities for the work force engaged by the Australian Public Service, was sent on stationery headed `Department of Territories'. It is a matter I think that warrants some investigation as to how the facilities of government departments come to be used in that way-I suspect used quite improperly-and I am sure my colleague would want the matter investigated. I am sure also the Government itself would like to know how it comes about that the facilities of departments are used quite improperly in that way.

The other matter that I want to address relates particularly to the carriage of toxic chemicals on our roads. Honourable members may recall that some weeks ago there was a toxic chemical spill on the Hume Highway near Breadalbane, between Yass and Goulburn. There, on 11 September this year, some 30 of 70 drums of poisonous solvent, methylene chloride, ruptured after falling from a truck which had taken a corner too sharply. Honourable members will remember well, I am sure, the photographs that appeared of men wearing special gas masks, and equipment designed for mopping up this solvent. They needed full protective clothing and breathing apparatus to ensure that the road could be cleared. But, of course, the road on that occasion was closed for something of the order of 12 hours.

I know that investigations are proceeding and it is perhaps too early to state whether the truck was going too fast or whether all the statutory requirements for the carriage of dangerous goods were being met. Of course, it has been reported that the driver has been charged with negligent driving. Although the full details of the accident are not known and there are still many worrying aspects that need to be addressed. Members will be aware that the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation undertook two inquiries into the carriage of hazardous chemicals. When the first Committee report was brought down it contained a recommendation that if State governments had failed to incorporate the Australian code for transport of dangerous goods by road and rail into legislation by 1985, the Commonwealth should legislate to enforce the code to the full extent of its power.

There was a second report tabled in the Parliament. That report said specifically that it repeated its earlier recommendation and further recommended that the Australian code for transport of dangerous goods by road and rail be amended as soon as possible to include a comprehensive and detailed response to measures which take into account environmental hazards associated with chemical emergencies. I have never seen a response to that Committee report, but I understand that we are still in a situation where all States, except Victoria, it seems, have incorporated into legislation the Australia code for transport of dangerous goods by road and rail, the fourth edition of which was published in the periodical Commonwealth of Australia Gazette of 7 April, 1987.

The code was put together under the auspices of the Australian Transport Advisory Council and was based on recommendations prepared by the United Nations Committee of Experts on Transport of Dangerous Goods. The fact of the matter is that this chemical, methylene chloride, is listed as packaging group III under that code. That is the least dangerous of three categories. I might say that some of the material that I have seen published on these matters suggests that this particular product is one of the fastest growing in terms of usage and, of course, is more frequently being carried on our roads as a result of that growth factor. The approved method of transport of methylene chloride is in fairly ordinary 44-gallon-type steel drums, according to the Department of Transport and Communications, and such drums need survive only a 0.9 metre drop under standard conditions without leaking. If methylene chloride had been classified as packaging group I, then the approved drums would have to survive a drop of two metres.

While there are clearly much worse chemical nasties around than this chemical product-for example, explosives, poisonous gases, such as chlorine and substances which react violently with water-there is good reason for the listing of methylene chloride as a dangerous substance in the code. Standard reference books in the Parliamentary Library refer to it as very dangerous to the eyes; decomposing by contact with hot surfaces and open flame to yield phosgene, a highly toxic gas, and, hence, a disaster hazard; a narcotic; an anaesthetic in high concentrations, and can lead to death; and is becoming one of the most important halogenated industrial solvents, especially at low-temperature extractions.

Methylene chloride appears to have been listed by the United Nations as only a group III chemical because of its relatively low toxicity compared with the most common industrial solvents, but the overall hazard is really different because of the different speeds of carriage, the different standards of roads and, of course, how often it is being transported. I have indicated that it is being transported more frequently on our roads at this time. Other important hazard factors include the release of toxic phosgene under conditions of heat-which is likely in a road accident, and, of course, this is more likely to occur in some of the more isolated and certainly dry areas of Australia-and an inhalation hazard in enclosed situations, where deaths have occurred.

To sum up, a relatively mild type of accident such as occurred on the Hume Highway has resulted in a significant spillage of a chemical which could have been very dangerous under different conditions, where we could have seen fire in an enclosed space or if it had occurred in a built-up area, and so on. In effect, the listing of methylene chloride in the dangerous goods code seems to change nothing so far as its transport and packaging is concerned. The approved packaging is in an ordinary drum which could be used anywhere. One can therefore ask whether the code is helpful at all in preventing such a spillage. The method of securement of drums to trucks is not well spelt out in the code, so securement and drum strength emerge as particular problems in this accident, apart from the negligence of the driver. Perhaps securement could be tested by swerve tests on a standard course using a truck loaded with drums of a harmless liquid of equal density to dangerous chemicals such as methylene chloride.

I have made some inquiries in relation to the availability of drums and the cost involved of making a change to ensure that this product is carried in a drum which will enable it to survive a two-metre fall. If one obtains the closed head type with two small holes in the top for pouring, heavy duty, which is the most expensive, it costs $42.59. That is used for group I and some group II chemicals of the highest density. The medium gauge drums would cost $33.73, and the light gauge, for group II and group III products, would cost $30.86. The costs for the open head drums are different again. One can see from the costs I have mentioned that for a mere $12 more one would be able to have this dangerous product carried in a drum that would be able to survive a fall, which is very likely if it is loaded on the back of a truck and the truck has an accident.

Is it any wonder in this case that 30 drums went off the back of the truck, fell that short distance and broke open? For 12 hours the most important highway in Australia was closed to traffic and many people had to put themselves at risk to clear the area. The community was put to very considerable cost and difficulty as a consequence. There is a need for urgent action on the Government's part to enable this particular problem to be addressed. We deserve a clear response from the Government to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation report which, about four years ago, raised some of these problems and difficulties. Although a parliamentary committee has sought action, there has been no response of an adequate nature. There has been a further accident on our roads, which indicates the nature of the continuing problem that faces us. Clear and unambiguous action is required on the Government's part to ensure that this difficulty is properly addressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for the enlarged audience as I speak on the estimates for the Department of Community Services and Health. This Department has the responsibility for the Government's housing program, and that is the matter I wish to address. I can recall not so long ago, when I was a Government member, time and time again Labor members of parliament emphasising the plight of young people anxious to obtain their own homes in our great cities. One of the aspects I lament most is that tonight those honourable members seem keen to leave the chamber and not participate in this debate. I would have liked the opportunity to take them through their speeches about the plight and circumstances of our young people who are not able to acquire their own homes. What I want to do in the course of this debate is to ensure that people are aware of what is happening in our society today, because it has never been more difficult for young people in the Australian community to obtain their own homes than it is at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: It is well known that interest rates under the Australian Labor Party have risen to quite extraordinary levels. Though there has been some levelling recently, the high levels of interest rates have made it very difficult for young people to obtain accommodation. With the prospect of interest rates levelling out and young people being given the opportunity to seek loans to obtain homes, the Government has been reducing its own commitment through first home ownership schemes in general, and the prices of houses have continued to rise at a rate which will place ordinary homes outside the reach of young people aspiring to own their first homes. In the city I come from, the city of Sydney, it is quite clear that the significant level of prices for homes in areas close to the city is flowing out to locations more distant from the city. House prices there are reaching quite astronomical levels. It can cost in excess of $100,000 to buy an ordinary two-bedroom or three-bedroom home. Prices of this order are out of the range of most young people when they are first setting out to acquire a home.

One of the reasons for this change in the level of prices in Sydney is not, as the Labor Party would have us believe, that there has been a limited number of foreign investors seeking to invest moneys in property in Sydney. The primary reason it has occurred is that the whole pattern of investment in this country has changed as a result of the tax policies of the Labor Government. The most significant issue that has impacted upon prices has been the imposition of the Government's capital gains tax. The capital gains tax, implemented as it has been so the principal home is exempt, has meant that many people are now investing in upgrading their homes. They are putting more money into extensions, buying more expensive homes in more expensive or salubrious areas.

The flow-on effects of those investment patterns have been considerable. In Sydney some homes are now approaching prices not of $1m or $2m but $8m, $9m and $10m. The principal reason for that has not been the investment by people from overseas in properties in that city. It has been substantially because of the Government's taxation policies whereby people have been encouraged to change their investment pattern.

The Labor Party would have us believe that the change announced in the recent Budget, whereby the Government reintroduced negative gearing after having previously abolished it, will have a significant impact on private investment and that larger numbers of rental properties will be made available. I have to say to the Government that its belief that the reintroduction of negative gearing will be a significant factor in encouraging people to invest in rental housing, to build new home units and so on and put them on the rental market, is a very naive approach indeed.

The fact is that the disinvestment in rental properties occurred not only because of the abolition of negative gearing; the more significant factor, in my view, in the changed investment pattern was, once again, the introduction of a capital gains tax. That tax that the Government brought in is still in place. It is very unlikely that the reintroduction of negative gearing will have the impact that the Government thought it might have when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced this change in the recent Budget.

I say to the Government that, as I have moved around my electorate, particularly during the last election, one of the most significant factors I noticed in areas such as Ryde, West Ryde and Meadowbank was that, where there had been significant investment in rental accommodation in previous years, those sorts of investments have not been taking place in more recent years. Rental properties have become in short demand and, as a consequence, rentals have been increasing significantly. It was a major factor in the swing against the Government in metropolitan Sydney in particular. Young people who otherwise would have sought to acquire their own home or to rent accommodation in Sydney were finding that the prospect of either renting reasonable accommodation or owning their own home was getting beyond their reach. When that occurs we see very significant changes. None of the decisions by this Government in the recent Budget has addressed the problems that young people face in finding housing in the major urban centres of Australia.

The fact is that the Budget, particularly the budget of the Department of Community Services and Health wherein the responsibility for housing now lies, will mean that the plight of the young people in our community will be aggravated even further in future years. I say to the Government that, when it faces an election at some future time, there will be a very severe problem facing young people, and at the ballot box the Government will face a very significant rebuff because of the extent to which it has failed to recognise the enormity of that problem. It is in that context that I believe that we ought to look very critically at the budget of the Department of Community Services and Health and encourage the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) to look not only at the direct lines in the Budget where he allocates funds for housing but also at the particular tax changes that the Labor Party introduced without any real knowledge of the way in which market forces operate. I refer particularly to the capital gains tax which has had such a disastrous impact on the housing needs of young people in the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address my remarks to the appropriations for child care within the Department of Community Services and Health. This Budget provides the Government with the financial resources to implement the 1984 election promise by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to create 20,000 new child care places by 1988. It will also enable extensive indexation of subsidies from 1 October. Total child care spending is up from $175m to $235m, that is by 34 per cent. No comparable program has experienced such growth. Amongst those increases for family day care, the operational subsidy is indexed and a new equipment grant of $50 per place will now be payable to new services. These measures will improve conditions for family day carers and are a positive response to considerable public pressure for an increase. For outside school hours care, the operational subsidy is indexed and existing services will get a once only upgrading grant of $300 for the purchase and maintenance of equipment. In addition, the establishment grant for new services has been increased from $500 to $1,500.

SPEECH.PARA: In the area of vacation care, Commonwealth grants to the States and Territories are up by 10 per cent, from $3.5m to $3.8m. For centre based day care, the amount allocated for the capital upgrading of existing services is up from $1m to $2.8m, and the operational subsidy is indexed. An extra $0.7m has been provided for supplementary services, in addition to the $5.4m already provided this year. These services will improve access to mainstream services for groups with special needs, a real priority under our child care program. The operational subsidies for occasional care are indexed and are up from $16 to $17.

In times of economic restraint, this Government's support of child care has grown markedly over the last 4 1/2 years, but it has not been easy. It is an expensive program and it still does not service the existing need, let alone the growing need. Government initiatives to assist women in the work force, such as equal opportunity and affirmative action programs, go hand in hand with the need for access to affordable quality child care. Yet, even when the 20,000 new places are all delivered, nine out of 10 Australian children will not have access. The demand for child care will continue to increase as a result of the likely increase in women's labour force participation rates.

Every member of this chamber is aware of the demand-of the long waiting lists at child care centres, the legitimate expectations of families who need two incomes to exist and the desperate cases of those unable to find child care. We know that the number of families in poverty would double if women could not go to work.
