So, of course, this program is one of the utmost importance to this Government and will remain so while we continue to try to fill the need. That is why I find it incredible and offensive that now, with the essential nature of the program so well established, we are starting to hear questioning of the Government's involvement in the provision of child care and to hear suggestions that it should perhaps be left to the private sector. We hear attacks on the cost of the program, questions on the very need for it and questions on the need for standards of quality care, which include attacks on carers as being self-serving. Worst of all, we hear claims that this child care program subsidises middle class women at the expense of the poorer taxpayer. That is a complete misunderstanding of the aims of, and the need for, the child care program and a complete misrepresentation of the facts of the current provision of child care.

I want to nail the false propaganda being put about and I want to give some facts. The first piece of deceitful propaganda is that the Labor Government wants to, or should, get out of its involvement in child care funding. The Australian Labor Party remains committed to the program it has developed as a result of its policy commitment in 1973. It understands as a government the necessity for the program and will continue to give priority to it. It has no intention of relinquishing its role. We believe that the provision of affordable quality child care is one of the keys to social justice and the elimination of poverty.

The second falsehood is that this Government could ever come to the view that child care should be the responsibility of the private sector. The fact is that the private sector is interested in profit, has never had a large investment or an interest in the field and has consistently fought government regulations and standards. The third falsehood being spread is that the child care program is one which merely subsidises the middle class. The fact is that fees in Commonwealth funded services are charged on the basis of a family's capacity to pay. The lowest income families receive the highest fee relief subsidy. One who spreads falsehoods is David Clark. In an article in the Australian Financial Review of 28 September he said:
All but $4-$5 of the $91 average cost of centre based care is provided by the Commonwealth.

As Deb Brennan has pointed out, that is completely false. As she says, people on joint incomes above about $33,000 or $34,000 a year are paying fees of about $90 a week, but their subsidy from the Commonwealth is about $14 or $15 a week. So, those attacks are based on a complete reversal of the facts. I remind Mr Clark that joint incomes of $33,000 or so a year are probably the incomes of two people earning about $15,000 or $16,000 a year each-in other words, probably unskilled workers and hardly the middle class.

In the same article David Clark said that children of wealthy parents keep the children of poor families out of child care centres. The fact is that places in Commonwealth funded child care centres are allocated according to priority of access guidelines. These guidelines give pri- ority to parents seeking employment or training or who are in the work force. In addition, high priority is given to children with disabilities, Aboriginal children, and children from ethnic communities.

Again, David Clark talks derisively about the `potty lobby'. Apart from his facile insults, particularly to the many men and women who are part of the child care lobby, does David Clark not understand the need for, and the provision of, out-of-school services for children between the ages of five years and 12 years-a vital part of the Commonwealth's child care program?

The history of this program is that at the 1973 Australian Labor Party conference, the Party adopted a policy to provide comprehensive, community based, government funded child care to be delivered on a priority of need. In the years since then, that policy has been developed. It was adopted as a response to the demand from working women and women in need all over Australia. I was one of three women who attended that conference to lobby for the adoption of this resolution, because it expressed the needs of women throughout Australia. I cannot believe that now, in 1987, we are having to fight again some of the arguments that were advanced in those days by people who simply did not understand that working women were leaving children tied to their cots, leaving them in locked houses, because they could not provide them with child care or else they were making private child care arrangements which were far from suitable for their children.

Our policy did not originate from a middle class push; it was quite the reverse. It was because of the way our policy developed, and because it was responding to the needs of working women, that we had to abandon our original submission-based model and make sure that the Government discovered where the need lay. The submission-based model meant that often people from the better heeled sections of the community, and people who knew the ropes, were able to make a submission and get child care. More importantly, many of those areas where the need was greatest did not have the know-how to put in those submissions. We have now adopted a program whereby committees in each State assess the availability of child care, investigate the need and decide where child care services will be established.

This Government has a proud record in child care. It has achieved more than all previous governments. The completion of the Government's program for 20,000 new places at the end of 1988 will mean that the number of child care places funded by the Commonwealth will increase from 45,000, when we came to office, to 110,000. This is the most substantial growth in child care funding undertaken by any Australian government. There is still a very long way to go, but I can assure all those who need child care facilities that this Government will not withdraw from an essential responsibility to fund those services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pity that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) cannot take part in this debate tonight as I think he would have a lot to say about the programs administered by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). The Minister for Finance has some fundamental concerns about the philosophy of those programs. It was he who said the other day-I think in Perth-to the Society of Labor Lawyers that one of the great mistakes was that child care was ever taken out of the private sector. I do not think the Minister's reasons for that comment were reported comprehensively, but let me just go through some of the mathematics so that people listening tonight will perhaps understand why Senator Walsh, who probably has greater claims to be Treasurer of this nation than the present incumbent, would make such a remark.

SPEECH.PARA: If the money currently spent by this Government on community based child care were put into the private sector, another 20,000 child care places would be available. What that really means is that there are 20,000 children in the community who, as the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) said, are tied to beds and locked in houses because this Government is committed to public sector child care. If the funds were put into the private sector, 20,000 additional places would be available on an annual basis. I see the Minister for Community Services and Health is taking notes. In order that he might have comprehensive notes, let me go through the mathematics for him. Private child care is about $7 a day cheaper than public child care. The basis of that calculation is simple. There are about 38,000 community child care places. If they were shifted to the private sector, on the basis of a saving of $7 a day, about 20,000 more places would be available. Using the example of a child care centre in Brisbane-and the centre makes a profit-the cost is about $13 per child per day. The cost of a community child care centre in Melbourne is about $20 a child per day, and it does not make a profit. The difference is $7. If one starts looking at the allocations, it is fairly simple to see where the additional 20,000 places come from.

A previous Minister for Community Services, the much missed Senator Don Grimes, said that one of the great problems he had with the militant feminist lobby was that he did not believe there should be gold plated child care for a certain privileged section of the community while the overwhelming majority missed out. I think the logic of Senator Grimes's argument is most compelling. In a community where we cannot provide for everybody access to this important facility, what right do we have to provide gold plated child care for a certain privileged section of the community? I believe that the Minister for Community Services and Health, as a good, committed democratic socialist-and he is certainly not a bourgeois, from the remarks I have seen attributed to him in various places about identity cards and the right to hold private property-would certainly agree that there should be an egalitarian model for child care. On that basis perhaps he would have some sympathy for the argument that there should be maximum access to child care facilities.

That brings me to the point of the philosophy of the Department of Community Services and Health at the present time. I have high hopes that under the administration of the Minister, who has a reputation for intelligence, logic and a rational approach-and I hope that reputation will not be undermined simply because of his ill-guided attempts to introduce a facility that would name, number and photograph and otherwise identify about 16 million Australian men, women and children-the remainder of the Administration will see that he is applying a degree of intellectual rigour to the expenditures of his Department to ensure that we optimise the benefit to the Australian community.

We have a problem not only in child care, as a result of departmental attitudes, but also in domiciliary care. The Department-I hope not with the blessing of the Minister-has gone to the service model approach. The problem with the service model approach is that it really does not take into account the needs of those people who are seeking domiciliary care. It pretends that in some circumstances a group of people who are providers of that care, or who are arbitrators of the system, can determine what is the appropriate type and style of care and conditions of service for those people.

I have spoken to a number of community groups who are involved with people with disabilities. There is a fundamental disagreement with the philosophy of the Department with the expenditure of these funds. The consequences of this difference in philosophy are seen again in the number of people who actually benefit from Commonwealth Government expenditure. As a result of the commitment to the service model approach, the number of people who will benefit from the expenditure has been reduced dramatically. I would like to quote from a report on the Department of Community Services and Health from the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled (ACROD) to its members in which it deals specifically with disability services. ACROD. In the report, talked in part on the national attendant care scheme. It said that the scheme had survived as a government program. It expressed some gratitude that it had. The report states:

When announced last year funding was estimated at $0.5 million in 1986/87, $4 million in 1987/88 and $6.5 million in 1988/89-the same as the figures presented here. What is different, regrettably, is the number of people who will benefit under the program. Originally it was thought 100 people would enter the scheme in the first year rising to 360 by the end of 1988/89.

I remind honourable members that we are talking about a national program and 100 people are not really significant in terms of the Australian population of people with disabilities, and really 360 is not all that significant. But it is a start and I believe that the Government should be given some recognition for moving in the right direction. The report goes on:
The first $0.5 million we understand has been fully expended and only about 50 people are now on the scheme.
The original estimate was 100, so that is a 50 per cent failure in the Government's estimates. The report continues:
The steep increase in the costs of the service model are the problem-
I think the Minister should take note of this and ask his Department to give some explanation as to why the cost effectiveness of this program has been reduced-
especially since the introduction of new award rates in several States-at this rate we will not reach 200 people by the end of the third year.

And, I add, not the 360 estimated in the program. ACROD has expressed some concern about this. While 360 or 200 people are not really significant in terms of the total number of people who are seeking this sort of assistance and who are in genuine need of this sort of assistance, what is really important is to examine the consequences of a particular approach to program spending.

As I said when I was talking about child care, this country cannot afford gold plated anything right now. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating), depending on the mood of their rhetoric at the time, would probably agree. The Prime Minister at times has said that we are at war, that we have the most difficult economic circumstances we have encountered for some time. If the objective of the Department of Community Services and Health is to provide the best possible assistance we can afford to the maximum number of people consistent with responsible fiscal administration, perhaps we should look at the approach we use to expend these moneys.

It is fine to cave in to the trade union movement if we can afford it, but it is not appropriate to cave in to militant trade unions when it is at the expense of people with disabilities. Let me tell the Minister that that is exactly what is going on right now. We have awards that have been handed down in various States which are concerned with the benefits and conditions of people who are providing the service and not with the people with disabilities. That is something that has to be looked at.

If there were more time in this debate tonight I would like to address the question of nursing home residential care for aged people. There has been, on the part of this Government, a willingness to politicise the provision of this very important facility in the Australian community. There has not been, in the four years of this Government's administration, any concerted attempt to come up with a comprehensive, consistent and viable policy for aged care in Australia. Not only has the Government failed in terms of income support-we do not have an effective retirement incomes policy in this country-but also we do not have a viable aged care policy. All we have got is a piecemeal approach to provide patches to the existing system.

After four years one would think a government with a commitment to this area would have done something. I hope that the Minister is not tempted to say at the conclusion of this debate that nothing was done by the previous Government. It is a bit like saying that nothing was done by the Fisher Government. After four years in the job, it cannot pass the buck. It has had a majority in this place for some time. It has had the capacity to do something and it has done nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose tonight to confine my remarks at the committee stage of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. In so doing I wish to put matters in perspective. Next year, 1988, this country celebrates 200 years of white settlement on the east coast of Australia. Being from the west coast, I particularly mention the east coast of Australia. Yet in the euphoria surrounding the Bicentenary it is important that we do not forget the original settlers, who we now know were living in Australia as long as 40,000 years ago-the Aboriginals of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government cannot take the high ground in debates in world forums on racialism when there is still too much racialism displayed in this country against Aboriginals. One cannot forget the vicious and mischievous propaganda put out by the mining industry against land rights-a campaign blatant in its misuse of the facts concerning land rights acquisition. The legacy of that campaign still lingers on. This places an onus on the Government to embark on a program of education to combat the rampant racialism that still exists in this country.

After 200 years of white settlement, we find that all the major social indicators show that Aboriginal people are Australia's most deprived and underprivileged. No white Australian can be proud of the fact that life expectancy at birth is 20 years less than for all other Australians. We cannot be proud of the fact that Aboriginal child mortality is three times higher than the national average. We cannot be proud of the fact that in some communities up to 36 per cent of Aboriginal children aged under 10 suffer from some form of trachoma compared with 1.6 per cent of non-Aboriginal children. We cannot be proud of the fact that many Aboriginal families live in sub-standard housing or temporary shelters. We cannot be proud of the fact that the unemployment rate for Aboriginals is six times the national rate. Nor can we be proud of the fact that the imprisonment rate for Aboriginals is 20 times that for the total population. That is a sorry recital of the state of play in Aboriginal affairs in this country today. It is not my intention to look for scapegoats, for this situation has been brought about by years of neglect by governments of differing political persuasions at both the Commonwealth and State levels. We all share the blame for this sorry state of affairs.

This Government since 1983 has had a commitment to overcome these problems and to assist Aboriginals in the achievement of these goals. This can be demonstrated by the fact that since 1983 the Government has greatly increased spending on Aboriginal programs. In the 1987-88 Budget there has been an increase of 8 per cent in real terms. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who I note, is at the table, has made that clear, and I quote:
The Government is determined to increase and improve Aboriginal economic independence and to ensure that essential services are delivered to Aboriginal communities.

He has a difficult task. Knowing the Minister, I am aware that he does not underestimate his task. I am sure, however, that he will devote all his energies to accomplish his aims. I must, however, intercede with a word of warning: it does not help the Aboriginal community for the Government to provide large sums of money if that money does not filter down to the grassroots where it is most needed. Too many people involved in this area are taking some of that money before it reaches the grassroots. There is a need for strong accountability. There is a need to co-ordinate services among the State, Territory and Federal governments. We cannot afford overlapping and duplication of services. This is a problem of which I am sure the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is aware, and he will attempt to overcome it.

I have already referred to the health problems of Aboriginal people. I note in Budget Paper No. 1, Budget Statements 1987-88, that the Government is committed to raising Aboriginal health standards to the level enjoyed by all Australians. Of the amount provided for Aboriginal health programs in 1987-88, $23.6m, compared with $19.6m in 1986-87, is expected to be applied to the operating costs of 55 Aboriginal health services, including four that were established or first funded during 1986-87. I am also very pleased that $4.6m will be allocated for programs to combat problems caused by alcohol, illicit drugs and the sniffing of volatile substances such as petrol and glue. In my travels with the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs-the present Minister was with me on many of those trips-the extent of petrol and glue sniffing in the outback was alarming. It is an issue which we cannot leave alone. We must try to come to grips with the problem and overcome it.

The lack of water and sanitation in some communities leads to poor health. The Government deserves to be congratulated on providing $7.9m for the provision of public health works, such as safe and adequate water supplies, sewerage systems and associated power generation, to alleviate the ill health that arises from sub-standard living conditions. I am pleased that the Minister has read with understanding and sympathy the report of members of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs entitled Return to Country, who were unanimous in their support for the Aboriginal homelands movement. The Government is considering that report, which is intended to address the critical needs of outstation centres to ensure the availability to dwellers in such communities of the minimum basic living standards which are commensurate with their lifestyles. That Committee in its travels around the outback certainly saw some of the most depressing sights that any committee could have witnessed. There are Third World conditions in Australia which need very urgent and critical attention.

Finally, I appeal to the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles)-who, I am glad to see, is present-to follow the example set by his predecessor, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), who showed a real willingness, as a member of the Standing Committee, to work towards a bipartisan approach in this very sensitive area of public policy. Having got to know the shadow Minister, I am sure that I can look forward to his co-operation in the tasks ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak tonight about the area of health. I would like first to make a remark about the speech made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard). I do not want to be critical of him, but when the honourable member, who spoke so strongly on behalf of the Aboriginal people, realises that $500m a year is spent in this area, he might ask himself what we are doing wrong. I think the problem might be that we have thought that money would solve the problem. I sincerely suggest that we must look very carefully at how we are spending the money and how it should be delivered to those areas of need.
—That is what I said.
—Good; we agree on that. We are having a good night so far. I wish primarily to talk about the problems of health.
—We are in fact doing it too, by the way.

—I think we have tended to satisfy ourselves by allocating the money and maybe not allocating the effort. Of course, expenditure on health has again moved ahead of interest charges to the Commonwealth. I do not know which Minister has responsibility for interest charges; I suppose it is the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Last year interest charges to the Commonwealth exceeded our expenditure on health, defence, education and, in fact, everything but social security. The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) may be pleased to know, although I am concerned about it, that health is consuming more of the Australian taxpayers' money than interest charges. It is a huge amount of money, of the order of $8,212.9m. That figure comprises an estimated $3,527m for medical services and benefits, $1,685.5m for hospital services and benefits, $999m for pharmaceutical services and benefits, and $1,442.8m for nursing home subsidies and domiciliary care services. These are huge amounts of money, and there are other lesser amounts. In particular, expenditure in the area of pharmaceutical services and benefits is 14.8 per cent higher than the figure for the year before, whereas expenditure on medical services and benefits has grown by 8.8 per cent, and on hospital services and benefits by 8 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The point that I want to make, of course, is that the Australian people have had to fund this massive increase. The estimated total increase for the year is $713m, of which $350m is to be picked up by the increase in the Medicare levy-something, of course, that Australians were promised would never happen. A free medical service was to be funded by a one per cent levy on tax revenue. It should be remembered that the tax base has increased dramatically. Nevertheless, the Government has found the need to raise the levy to 1.25 per cent. If we are prepared to make the calculation, we will see that the area of medical services and benefits is the area which is primarily serviced by the levy. The levy, which this year will bring in an estimated $2,065m, barely compares with the $3,527m of expenditure on medical services and benefits. Quite clearly, some of that money must also be spent in the area of hospital services and benefits.

I think that the Minister should make it a practice in these debates of telling us the true cost of the service we understand to be Medicare. It is very difficult to find it in the Budget Papers as a single, one-line item. Considering the publicity it gets and the amount of claims that the Government makes on its behalf, one would think that the Government would be quite prepared to tell us exactly what the service costs. I guess it could say that there is some difficulty in doing that, but it would be very helpful to us and to taxpaying Australians in order to make some judgment as to whether the service is worth it. I do not think it is worth it. I think now everyone knows that Medicare is a disaster.

We have talked about the cost of Medicare, and it is notable that health was one of the major areas of cost overrun following last year's Budget. Quite huge amounts were involved. Pharmaceutical benefits overran by $76m, hospital services for veterans by $42m, nursing home benefits by $30m, nursing home assistance by $25m, and home and community care by $9m. A large number of other cost overruns, particularly that in nursing homes, were related to substantial increases in awards for nurses. The community and I would agree with many of those increases, but it shows what a tiger the Government has by the tail in attempting to give the community free medical services when in fact many could afford to pay themselves. I think the Government's responsibility should be better directed, towards those who cannot. I do not think the Government's intention was to provide service for those who cannot afford it; it just wanted to grab the medical services of Australia by the throat.

Earlier today the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) was boasting about how efficient he would make his Department, about how he would make it compete with the private sector. He did not really tell us how it would compete with the private sector, although he did tell us that the private sector would not be able to bid for work in many areas. We have discovered the same situation in the health area. Instead of the public sector facing the healthy competition of the private sector, particularly from private hospitals, the Government has denied private hospitals the opportunity to compete in the open market. There is a special market for public hospitals. People who choose to pay just the levy and go to hospital as public patients have to go where they are directed-and they are not directed to private hospitals. We have this most remarkable situation of huge waiting lists. We are going to start a club for the patients in waiting. I am sure that in time the Minister will be embarrassed by their activities.

The reality is that, as I understand it, probably every day of the year we have some 9,000 vacant beds in the private sector. They are public resources already invested in health and it is absolutely ridiculous that the Government should boast that this year it asked the Australian taxpayer to contribute an additional $25m-almost the sum of the deficit, if the Treasurer has it right-for the purpose of expanding the public hospital sector whilst we have those sorts of vacancies. We can call them private resources, we can call them public resources-it is people's money sitting there, having been invested, and those resources are being underutilised purely and simply because of government policy. That does not make sense to me; it would not make sense to anybody but a socialist who believes that those things do not have to be explained and that there is some difference between private money and public money. When we take the public money from private people, it is all the same.

It is obvious that governments should look at that, and they should be prepared to accept the discipline of the efficiencies of a private hospital versus a public hospital. We get it to a degree, and we are told there is probably a $100 per bed per day cost difference. I know that figure cannot be used properly because of the additional responsibilities often accepted by public hospitals, particularly their responsibility as teaching hospitals; but it does not change the fact that when all that is accounted for it just happens to cost more to run a public hospital than a private hospital. If people had a choice and the Government contracted to buy the cheapest beds in the market-place, there might be some sense in what it is doing. The Minister would not want to say that I am therefore suggesting a substantial lowering of services. In my mind getting the cheapest in the market-place means getting the cheapest price for the same service.

We have here a remarkable situation. A noted tertiary educationist, a man of considerable intellect, said to me on a plane a couple of years ago that it would be absolutely essential-this was rather refreshing, coming from the education sector-to introduce tertiary fees. That was his argument, not particularly mine. It was based on a simple premise: the longer tertiary education stayed hooked on the Government, the closer students would be to getting from that sector exactly what they were paying-namely, nothing.That is the situation that will confront people in the health area before very long. The Minister is well aware that, as much as he would like to, he cannot conscript doctors, and doctors will maintain an independent stance and become less and less available to the public sector. It is no good bullying them and trying to tell them that they are cheats and things like that, even though some of them might be. The reality is that the Government would be much better letting them provide the service and assistance to the community instead of trying to run, with its State colleagues, a huge business in the delivery of medicine. Furthermore, in most cases, the smaller it gets in terms of unit delivery, the better it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The appropriations for the Department of Veterans' Affairs total some $3.8 billion, but there is a significant program over and above that amount which delivers to veterans a unique form of redress in their claims for pensions. That program is the pensions appeal system. The key element of that program is the Veterans Review Board (VRB). The Board's function is to review decisions of the Repatriation Commission, and seamen's pensions and allowances committees, on such matters as claims for the acceptance of injury or disease as service related, claims for war widows' pensions and the assessment of the rate of pension paid for service related incapacity. In other words, the Board considers appeals from the Repatriation Commission on disability and widows' pensions. The disability pension is awarded at two basic levels: the general rate and, the most valuable of all pensions, the special rate, or the totally and permanently incapacitated pension-the TPI.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the many success stories in repatriation has been the work of the Veterans Review Board. I was privileged to serve as a member of the Board in Queensland from its inception in January 1985 until my resignation prior to my election to the House. The Board was established by this Government in order to shorten the lengthy queue of appeals to its predecessor, the Repatriation Review Tribunal. The Board for the first time enabled the establishment of panels of review in each State, including Queensland, which has the third largest veteran community, where previously they had existed only in Melbourne and Sydney.

The Board is the second tier of the review process, which commences at the Commission and ends, on the matter of review of the merits of a case, at the senior Commonwealth tribunal, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. As I wrote in a recent edition of the Queensland Law Journal, one measure of the maturity of a government is the ability of the individual to seek the reasons for a decision and for a government to supply those reasons. Although the whole area of redress to decisions of governments as they concern the individual is an expensive one, I can assure the chamber, from my experience, that administrative tribunals are a very fair and civilised way indeed to conduct open government. Administrative tribunals have their critics, but the fact that a veteran, with or without an advocate, and at no cost, can have a hearing, can have his day in court and receive written reasons for the decision of the Board, is a marvellous thing.

In the many hundreds of cases that I sat on, I always remember how nervously some veterans started out, but how calm and relaxed they were by the conclusion of the hearing. I remember these were people of senior years who were suffering serious illness and/or disability or, in the case of the widows, a grieving loss. It is a mark of good government that the so-called bureaucracy can handle these people with such sensitivity, care and fairness. These sorts of success stories are rarely told.

It is sometimes difficult to keep it in perspective that these people before the Board are our veterans. They are the people who made great sacrifices during World War II and in the later conflicts of Korea, Malaya and Vietnam. It is difficult for me as a young man to come to grips with the experiences of our veterans. I did my best to acquaint myself with their experiences, though such knowledge was inherent in each panel of the Board as each panel had an ex-serviceman as a member. The best illustration of war experiences other than from the mouths of the veterans themselves was a book I read about the war in New Guinea. The book, called Green Armour and written in 1945 by Osmar White, is a brilliant illustration of the sheer physical endurance that our soldiers showed during the very difficult New Guinea campaign. But that was over 40 years ago. Today the veterans, especially those from World War II, who are the biggest client group, require great care and attention.

The number of claims before the Board has reached a peak in the last few years, a direct reflection of the fact that these men and women are reaching retiring age, and an age when ill health is readily apparent. There are currently some 17,000 applications before the Board Australia-wide. The Board is in fact the largest single jurisdiction tribunal in the country. It costs $7m per year to run and published nearly 11,000 decisions in 1986-87. The key change in the system of review has been the huge gains in productivity. This increase in productivity is a credit to the previous Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Arthur Gietzelt; the present Minister for Veterans Affairs (Mr Humphreys); the principal member of the Board, Mr Stephen Skehill; and all members and staff of the Board. The Board commenced with a huge backlog of cases, and it commenced operations at a time when the number of appeals was rapidly rising.

The increase in productivity in the operation of the Board is the key reason why the backlog has not only been stabilised but has started to decline. In the figures published in the Board's annual report of 1986-87, the following achievements were posted: In the last year, an increase of 50 per cent in the number of applications finalised; a reduction of almost 9 per cent in the number of applications outstanding; significant reductions in the time to finalise applications; a 28 per cent reduction in the average waiting period for a hearing before the board; and a reduction in cost of around 60 per cent for each application finalised. Such achievements are impressive indeed. Another element to such productivity, however, is not just the speed of the decisions, but their quality, their accuracy. The veteran has the right to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) over decisions of the Board, at no cost to himself. Despite this, only 6.6 per cent of cases before the Board were appealed to the AAT and, of that group of appealed cases, only 20 per cent were conceded at the AAT. In other words, the VRB is getting its decisions right, it is not simply passing on the difficult cases to the higher tribunal.

Even more recent figures, up to September this year, indicate further improvements in productivity. In the 12 weeks prior to September 1987, there have been 1,752 lodgments, which is an annual rate of 7,600. The applications finalised were 3,477, which is an annual rate of 15,000 a further 16.5 per cent increase on top of the 50 per cent previous increase. In other words, finalisations have virtually doubled the intake rate. The Board is finalising twice as many cases as it receives. At the peak of lodgments in late 1986, there were 21,008 applications. At the end of the last financial year, there were 19,205 cases outstanding, but as of September 1987, the number was down to 17,466. By whatever yardstick one would care to use, whether in the public or private sector, this is indeed a marvellous achievement.

These achievements are to be applauded, and I would like to compliment my former colleagues on the Board for their good works. I congratulate especially the principal member, Mr Stephen Skehill, for his skilful efforts in lifting productivity. More particularly, I would like to thank all of my colleagues on the Queensland Board for sharing their knowledge and experience with me. I would give special mention to Mr John Gallagher, senior member, a very talented lawyer and adjudicator, and to Mr Tom Shaw, service member, and former New Guinea coast watcher who has served the Board with great compassion for the veteran, and who retires at the end of this year.

The critical element of the Board's operation for me was the integrity of its deliberations and its decisions. The difficulty of decision-making in a medico-legal area has to be experienced to be appreciated. But let me say that decisions were rarely made easily, and rarely without considerable debate. In past years, review panels have consisted solely or mainly of medical practitioners. Then, the emphasis was all wrong. The emphasis was on the veteran to demonstrate his ailments, not to demonstrate the connection between a given ailment and war service. The emphasis now, and quite rightly, in matters of entitlement, is on sifting evidence to demonstrate the relationship between a disability and a veteran's war service. To the credit of all members of the Board, such decision-making was always based on intelligent and informed debate.

It is too easy to criticise the repatriation system or an administrative tribunal. I can say that the veteran community has been well served by the repatriation system in general and the Veterans' Review Board in particular, and it should continue to be so. I wish the board well in its future deliberations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I start, Mr Blanchard, by commenting on the remarks that you made, when speaking as the honourable member for Moore on the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. I will endeavour, as did the previous shadow Minister, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), to be as helpful, co-operative and bipartisan as possible. I note that he is in the chamber at the moment. I trust that, particularly over the next year or so and perhaps for the length of the Parliament, we will recognise that there is a great need for sensitivity, understanding and a common-sense approach to the issues that face Australia in regard to Aboriginal affairs as we celebrate the Bicentenary.

SPEECH.PARA: That having been said, I must go on to a few other issues which I believe to be of concern in trying to achieve that sort of bipartisan approach. It was largely due to the policies of the Australian Labor Party in pursuing national land rights which, once it got into government, it realised could not be delivered, that that bipartisan approach was broken in the period 1982-84. It was a tragedy for Australia that we were not able to maintain a fairly bipartisan approach to this area of administration. I see the same difficulty arising again with the proposal for a treaty.

I believe that again the Labor Party is going to fail the Aboriginal people, having raised expectations beyond what can be delivered. I refer to its promise to the Aboriginal people in its 1986 policy platform that it would meet all Aboriginal housing needs within six years. That expectation among the Aboriginal people will, I believe, not be satisfied. It is a great tragedy that, so far, one of the hallmarks of the Labor Government in this area has been the way that it raises expectations with crucial promises that cannot be delivered. I remind the Government that at this stage about 17,600 housing units are required. If the Government is to fulfil its platform promise to the Aboriginal people, it will have to build at the rate of 3,000 or 4,000 units a year, which is obviously beyond its resource capacity unless there is a great change in the income of the nation.

Tonight we are debating a budget that covers $671.6m. New programs are involved and the Government has kept certain older programs which it refers to as priority ones. I wonder whether the Government is spreading its resources in the Aboriginal affairs area too thinly by undertaking these new programs when some of the key priority areas, such as housing, community infrastructure, education and health, are not being satisfied. Are there roadblocks that prevent the money getting to the grassroots of the Aboriginal community; or are there inefficiencies in the system which are really soaking up millions and millions of dollars in this area?

Let me put it this way: I think it was in your speech, Mr Deputy Chairman, that you were talking about various social indicators. It is interesting to note that the unemployment rate among Aboriginal people is now six times the national rate, but in 1981-82 it was four times the national rate. It is interesting to note also that Aboriginal life expectancy has not changed over the past three or four years, since this Government came to office. The income level of Aboriginal people also has not changed. The mortality rate of Aboriginal children has not changed; it is still three times higher than the national average.

It appears that the trachoma rate among Aborigines has actually increased slightly. However, the rate of imprisonment among Aborigines has increased from 14 times the national average in 1982-83 to 20 times the national average at present. Yet, in that time the Government has allocated to the Aboriginal affairs area, including the allocation in this Budget, $2.5 billion; and there has been no change in that period in the social indicators. If anything, they have got markedly worse in two areas. That indicates to me that real problems are being encountered in the money allocated to Aboriginal people getting through to the grassroots of the Aboriginal community to bring about the change that is so desperately needed in so many areas.

In the course of your remarks, Mr Deputy Chairman, you spoke about alcoholism, petrol sniffing and those sorts of matters. Obviously such things are of great concern to me. We should be trying to establish for the Aboriginal people a program-we probably cannot even think in those terms-that will achieve greater dignity and a sense of self-worth among the Aboriginal people. I know that achieving that goal will require a mammoth effort.

In the few minutes remaining to me I wish to refer to a couple of other matters. One is the Aboriginal capital account, an account that was set up in 1980 as a recognition of the need to compensate the Aboriginal people for their dispersal; it was set up also in an effort to provide them with the means of self-management and self-sufficiency. The Labor Government has not contributed one more dollar to that account. If contributions to that account had continued at the level at which they were made when Senator Fred Chaney, as Minister, started that account-that is, $10m-we would now be providing for between 8 per cent and 10 per cent of the financial needs of the Aboriginal Development Commission, which would make it self-sustaining. I believe it is important that we move down a track which will enable the Aboriginal leaders to have a great deal of say in and control over financial matters so that Aboriginal communities can become self-sufficient in the future. I think that is very important, and I certainly support that sort of approach.

I believe the community development employment projects scheme to be worthy of support. I note that $68.74m is to be allocated to that scheme this year. It is hoped that the scheme will provide 1,600 extra jobs. We support that scheme, which was originally established by the coalition Government. We certainly believe in that style of approach to the Aboriginal affairs portfolio. We believe it to be a positive and healthy step if Aboriginal elders are able to take control of dole moneys payable to Aboriginal people and use those moneys to assist their Aboriginal communities.

Finally, some of the performance indicators within the Department are very broad and very general. In fact, they are broad and general to the point where I do not believe they can be measured. In that circumstance they are really not very good performance indicators. It is important that the Department measure its performance by using specific quantity figures rather than just having general aims which, as everybody who has carried out an evaluation of any program knows, cannot be evaluated.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Blanchard, first I wish to endorse your remarks about expenditure on Aboriginal affairs. In particular, I endorse your remarks in which you emphasised the need for the Government to examine the public awareness program in an effort to combat the racism that has been evident in campaigns waged against Aboriginal interests by some sections of the community. I also endorse very strongly your remarks in relation to the Aboriginal homelands movement. I suggest that the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) would do well to read the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. I invite the honourable member for Braddon also, if he is truly interested in a bipartisan approach to Aboriginal affairs in Australia, to have discussions with those people in the community who have sought on previous occasions to divide the community against the interests of Aboriginal people, and specifically against the aspirations of Aboriginal people towards land rights. In that regard I suggest that he sit down and have a yarn with the Australian Mining Industry Council, whose offices are located on Northbourne Avenue, and those who seek, like the Australian Mining Industry Council and the Western Australian Chamber of Mines, to divide the Australian community on the issue of race.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I wish to raise two matters in relation to the Aboriginal affairs portfolio. The first of these is in the area of employment, education and training. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who is present in the chamber, announced a package of measures in the Budget to address the appalling employment and economic disadvantages of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The package is part of the Aboriginal employment development policy (AEDP) which was developed in response to the findings of the Committee of Review of Aboriginal Employment and Training Programs-the Miller review. The purpose of the Aboriginal employment development policy is to promote Aboriginal economic independence and to reduce welfare dependence through the creation of jobs in rural and remote areas where nearly half the Aboriginal population lives; by ensuring that Aboriginal people have fair access to jobs throughout the conventional labour market; and by improving educational opportunities for Aboriginal people.

The Aboriginal employment development policy was established in August 1986 in response to the report of the Committee of Review of Aboriginal Employment and Training Programs-the Miller report. It is a long term and comprehensive policy and aims at equity between Aboriginal people and other Australians in the areas of employment, education, training and economic development by the year 2000. This is in response to the demands from Aboriginal people for measures aimed at lessening welfare dependency and enhancing economic independence. The AEDP has been designed to take account of the different aspirations and employment needs of Aboriginals living in different geographical areas and situations across Australia. This is essential if the AEDP strategies are to meet the diverse needs of Aboriginals throughout Australia. The AEDP involves both a restructuring of existing Aboriginal employment, training, education and enterprise programs, plus new expenditure in 1987-88, as well as the new expenditure provided in 1986-87.

The overall equity objectives of the AEDP include: employment equity with other Australians by the year 2000; equity through access to education and training opportunities for all Aboriginal Australians; income equity with other Australians by the year 2000; and a reduction in welfare dependency to a level commensurate with that of other Australians by the year 2000. Almost half of Australia's Aboriginal population live in rural and remote communities where the Aboriginal employment rate is often over 80 per cent. That is a matter on which I commented in a previous debate. The other half of the Aboriginal population lives in and around larger towns and cities and faces severe unemployment which is compounded by racial discrimination and lack of education and job skills.

In 1987-88 the Government will continue to emphasise the development of education, employment and training and economic resource programs and the restructuring of existing programs. The aims of the AEDP can be summarised as follows: to create jobs in remote and rural communities; to ensure that Aboriginal people have fair access to jobs throughout the conventional labour market; and to improve educational opportunities for Aboriginal Australians. The portfolio appropriation is made up of $93.575m to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and $26.07m to the Aboriginal Development Commission. A significant initiative under the AEDP will be the expansion of the community development employment project scheme, a matter which I commented on last night in the discussion in this chamber on education.

I would like to address my attention to the community development employment project (CDEP) scheme for the remainder of my time. I had a particular interest in this project. It was devised primarily by Dr H. C. Coombes, otherwise known as Nugget, who, as all honourable members know, since his retirement from public service for the Australian Government, has spent most of his spare time, if I could call it that, working at the Australian National University on projects invariably associated with research into the problems of Aboriginal Australians. One of the proposals he put forward in 1976 was over the matter of CDEP, and it is basically an initiative of his which the Fraser Government, through the offices of Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, was able to implement. That project was devised in response to Aboriginal criticisms of the effects of unemployment benefits on Aboriginal recipients in their communities. It is very important that members of the Committee accept and examine what in fact this means.

The principle that the Government accepted in agreeing to the request for Aboriginal Australians to have CDEP was on the basis that residents of communities participating in the CDEP would not receive unemployment benefits; that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs would pay to such communities funds to enable them to offer part-time employment to those who would otherwise be eligible for unemployment benefits; that the amount of these funds would be equivalent to the average unemployment benefit multiplied by the estimated numbers of unemployed to be offered work; that award rate wages for the hours worked would be paid for work decided upon by the community, or its council, within general guidelines; that the on cost of wages would be met by an addition of 20 per cent to the wage funds towards costs of administration-for example, for materials and equipment; that employment under the CDEP would not replace full time positions provided for in the departmental and community establishments; and that there would be periodical reviews of the program.

It is very important, Mr Blanchard, that people understand exactly what this means. In 1986-87 the Budget figure for community development programs was $39.4m. In 1987-88 that figure will be in the vicinity of $58.5m. As the honourable member for Braddon pointed out, it would mean allowing for an additional 1,600 Aboriginal people to come within that program. But it is significant-and I do not think it is recognised by many members of this Committee-that what that in fact means is a reduction of $48.8m in the unemployment benefits bills of this Government. I think it is significant that we ought to get the Australian community to recognise that it is only Aboriginal Australians, those people who are denigrated by many sections of the community, who have seen themselves able to approach the Government, in effect, and say, `Instead of unemployment benefits, we would like you to give us a bulk sum which we can administer ourselves and distribute for our own work purposes'.

It is significant, therefore, that it is understood that CDEP allows Aboriginal people to determine the nature of work that is undertaken. I think that is important, because it means that we are not dictating to Aboriginal people about what we regard as work. That is very significant. Only two weeks ago, Mr Deputy Chairman, I was at Kintore in the Northern Territory with the head of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Perkins. That community suggested-in fact requested-that it come under the CDEP.

TALK.START.PARA: —Kintore is a disgrace.

—I know that the honourable member for Bradfield has a very great interest in the community of Kintore and has spoken of it in this place on a number of occasions. I understand he may have even visited there on one or two occasions. Let me tell him, just for his information, that the new store is magnificent and the food is terrific. The prices are even commensurate with what one would expect to pay in communities elsewhere in Australia. I know that the honourable member was very interested in the standard of food being supplied at the store. Let me tell him that the Aboriginal Development Commission has funded a magnificent enterprise in the store at Kintore and a number of other enterprises in that community.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that the Kintore community, in my view, get support for its application to come under the CDEP, because it is this sort of community that will benefit most by such a program. I would like to inform the Committee, for the information of honourable members, that the Kintore community is a relatively new community and it is a result of people moving back to their lands. I go back to the point I made earlier about the support of the homelands movement. I would suggest to the honourable member for Braddon that he make contact with his counterparts in the Northern Territory Government and suggest to them that they would be wise also to support the homelands movement, because they have previously indicated that they are not prepared to support the movement in communities of fewer than 50 people except for the establishment of water.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak this evening on matters within the Appropriation Bill that actually affect Aboriginal grants and also the Department of Veterans' Affairs. I have to say that yesterday at Question Time I asked the Prime Minister whether unrealistic demands from parts of the Aboriginal community for 40 per cent of Australia's land mass and 7 per cent of gross domestic product had been fuelled by his reckless proposal for an Aboriginal compact. The Prime Minister dismissed this suggestion and emphatically said no. It was interesting that he actually proceeded to contradict himself. He said he was only trying to stimulate a consideration of the relationship between the 200 years of European settlement and the 40,000 years of Aboriginal tradition. `It is obvious', he said, `that in such a consideration the representatives of the Aboriginal people themselves will make demands . . . that to us may seem outrageous'. He thus admitted that his stimulation-that is, his compact-had fuelled such outrageous demands, and, of course, he did not offer any indication as to what he thought that his compact might contain.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been informed that the demands reported by Mike Seccombe in the Australian newspaper on Monday last are contained in the draft treaty submitted to the National Coalition of Aboriginal Organisations in Sydney only two weeks ago. I have a copy here of this draft treaty, which is circulating freely within the community. Copies are certainly available to people wherever they may happen to require them. I have nothing against the principle of that. I want to make that quite clear. But what I am concerned about is that the strength of Australians, both the whites and the Aboriginal people, rests very much upon the unity of all of us concerned. Over the years my own association with Aboriginals, in the Lyne electorate has been very close indeed because I have great respect for them. I have worked with them; I have played sport with them over the years, and they always feel free to come to me to discuss any of their problems.

I would be very concerned if the Prime Minister is leading the Aboriginal people to believe that they will receive something that they may not receive finally from the Government. I do not want to see their expectations built up, but they are going to be a disappointed group of Australians. I think this would be very sad indeed. The reason that I raised the matter this evening is just to point out that fact and to request the Prime Minister and the Government not to build up the expectations of the Aboriginal people to something that they finally may not receive. I appreciate the fact that this submission is only a draft one. It is to be considered by the body that is responsible. I hope that there are sensible negotiations, because you, Mr Deputy Chairman, and I and others fully appreciate the fact that today what the Aboriginal people require in Australia is understanding because of the basic traditions of their race, and subsequently they do need this extended help with housing, health, work and other problems within the communities. This is taking place as time goes on.

If we in a sensible way are going to integrate the two races, because we are both the same, and if this is to continue to make a pleasant Australia in the way that we would want to see it done, this can only take place over the decades ahead. I am sure it can in the approaches being made, but I sound that warning to the Prime Minister. I do not want to see the Aboriginal people I represent let down because of these expectations he may have. We know he made the statement because he was so pleased with the Budget and pleased with what was occurring after the elections, and the Bicentenary is next year. However, he will not keep the Aboriginal people quiet by promising them a compact, an arrangement of some kind, unless he speaks with them, unless the community knows what is going on and their realistic demands are considered. I wanted to raise that point on behalf of the Aborigines I represent because I think it is most important. They are a proud and happy people in their own way and they deserve all the assistance we can give them.

I wish to say something about the estimates of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. It is pleasing to see some very sound things in the Budget Estimates. I am pleased to see extensions to the benefits for World War II ex-service women included. That is long overdue. It is pleasing to see a $10,000 lump sum payment to the prisoners of war who were in nazi concentration camps. It is nice to see that a new garden of remembrance is to be constructed in New South Wales. It is also pleasing to see increased expenditure for hospitals, particularly the repatriation hospitals, and for equipment.

It is sad, though, to see that all the veterans admitted to nursing homes in the future will be required to meet the statutory patient contribution as from January 1988. There will be 750 veterans affected by this. I suppose many in the community will ask why the veterans should not be placed on the same basis as any aged person. However, I think we as representatives of the people have to appreciate the fact that these people have served their country in time of need, and it is very important that we recognise this by giving them these various concessions. Over the years concessions have been taken away from ex-service men and women. The concessions or entitlements they may lose concerns them, and they worry about it. These people are getting on in years and they have a tendency to worry. They want to know who is going to care for them, and the like.

I know that defence service home loans have been discussed in this place over recent days, ever since the Treasurer (Mr Keating) brought down the Budget. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) has made it quite clear that he has changed his mind and it will be the end of the year before it is finally determined what the new setup will be. Ex-servicemen, and present day servicemen from the Williamtown Royal Australian Air Force base in my electorate, have come to me and pointed out that the proposal before us-which has been placed aside for a time-is detrimental to them. They will lose some thousands of dollars. A loan of $25,000 is not a large one when one has to buy a home today. Even in country towns a home will cost $70,000 to $80,000. Servicemen and ex-servicemen like to buy homes of the same quality as any of us. They are entitled to that. A loan of $25,000 is not a lot of money.

If this is changed and they are given a grant of $10,000 to purchase a house, what occurs with the entitlements a widow receives upon the death of a veteran? I think I am correct in saying that the rental available under the old scheme is very low. What happens once they receive this grant? What happens to those people who have stayed in the service for 15 or 18 years and actually retire after 20 years when someone who has been in the services for six or seven years retires and is entitled to the loan? The person who has stayed there and done the job over the years may not be entitled to the loan. I think these are factors we have to look at.

It concerns me also that, as the Budget and the accompanying papers show, the home care service for veterans is now part of the home and community care (HACC) program. I have no great objection to that but HACC has to have the money. There is $2m extra available in the Budget for this. As one travels around the countryside one finds that HACC is unable to meet the demand of aged people or any person in the community who needs assistance, simply because funds are not available. I know that a reorganisation is taking place. It is voluntary help that counts but some funds have to be available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this committee debate I wish to comment on the allocation of funds for measures to combat the transmission of acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS). Firstly, I acknowledge the significant comments made in this place by the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) last Tuesday. Honourable members would benefit from reading his speech. I shall not go to the trouble of quoting the statistics of the problem AIDS constitutes, as the honourable member's speech covered them quite comprehensively. I also commend the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) for the additional funds available this year for AIDS prevention and research. I believe the Minister can be justifiably proud of the reputation Australia has internationally for its AIDS programs. I do not want the Minister to float away, but I am quite sincere about this. The community owes him its thanks for the speed and success of his efforts to introduce AIDS screening of blood donations for transfusions. It is to his credit that he identified the significance and urgency of the challenge that we face and that he was able to gain from Cabinet the increased allocations we are considering tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest also that the effectiveness of the work in preventing AIDS is not as great as it could be, as the community, this Parliament and the Government have not come to grips with the fundamental questions that the AIDS epidemic poses. I believe we are ignoring at our peril five fundamental questions. I ask them now in order of priority. Firstly, what is the role of government in nurturing or moulding community values and individual behaviour? Secondly, what is the obligation of the Government to prevent harm to innocent individuals caused by the behaviour of other individuals, if necessary by restricting the freedom of those other individuals? What is the nature and extent of individual accountability to the community for behaviour which creates significant financial burdens on that community? What balance is to be struck between individual privacy and liberty and community interest when dealing with an extremely serious epidemic of the type the AIDS epidemic represents? Finally, do our young people in schools have the maturity, conceptually and morally, that sex and AIDS education programs assume they have? I do not believe our allocations will be effective until we have gone through the process of addressing these questions. The Government in particular will be directionless and constantly responding to various pressure groups if it does not consciously clarify its views on these five very important questions.

I wish to put my own views briefly on these five questions. The Bishop of London, Dr Graham Leonard, recently stated that he believed that many of the problems that we face today as a community and polity have arisen because the West has lost its soul. He went on:

I believe that this has happened because it has rejected the one essential belief which marked it for centuries, namely that man, by his very nature, has to be obedient to an authority over and above himself.
He continued:

The rejection of such authority leads not to freedom but to tyranny-a tyranny which springs not as in past centuries, from a fundamentalist approach to truth, but from the bestowal of absolute authority on the expression of what individuals, or a group, believe to be self-evident truths but which, in fact, only reflect contemporary fashions.
[This] subjectivism is based on the belief that principles and values are in essence no more than statements about the likes and dislikes, desires and aversions of those who hold them.

Across the Atlantic, a Harvard professor recently described values as being `personal preferences so central to our collective lives that as a political community we cannot properly be neutral about them'. He-I agree with him-endorsed the observation of another academic that a principal purpose of publicly proclaimed laws and regulations is to stigmatise anti-social behaviour and thereby to influence citizen values and behaviour code.

It is time that we restored the role of the Parliament, the courts and our schools in helping citizens to form a view of what is right and wrong in human relations. Our laws have ventured into this area in race relations and on sex discrimination. It is time we pondered the potential educative role of law in anti-social behaviour that spreads AIDS.

Secondly, I believe it is patently obvious that the balance of rights and duties has not been achieved in the AIDS context. Too many innocent people are being harmed-indeed, killed-because we refuse to limit the freedom of irresponsible individuals. I do not say that all AIDS carriers are irresponsible, but there can be no doubt that many are, and consciously so. One solution would be the compulsory testing not of any one group but of the whole population. My colleague Senator Stone has noted that tuberculosis was a comparatively mild disease compared with this new acquired immune deficiency syndrome, yet, in the course of its eradication, all Australians at the time submitted to a nation-wide program of testing for it-and that despite the undeniable, if minor, radiation hazard of the testing process. As to the accountability of those who consciously put others at risk by refusing to alter their sexual behaviour, I believe social and legal sanctions are increasingly legitimate. The drug-using prostitute, the unfaithful bisexual spouse or the militant gay should be held accountable for the human and financial harm and costs that their conscious actions cause.

I deal lastly with our education programs for young people. Recently I read a review of a United States of America National Research Council study on adolescent sexuality, pregnancy and childbearing. The reviewer noted, firstly, the findings that young teenagers are handicapped in assessing the personal risk of pregnancy because of their cognitive immaturity-a very significant point. The research also argued that, since many teenagers are still incapable of thinking abstractly and relating actions to specific consequences, they have a difficult time planning for sexual intercourse and using contraception. The reviewer concluded his analysis as follows:

Since pregnancy due to contraceptive failure will issue either in abortion or in birth, with the former raising the chances of future infertility, and the latter increasing the risk of death to a young mother by 250%; since early childbearing entails marital and career deprivation, physical, intellectual and social harm to children, and a burden of welfare expenditures to be borne by the rest of society; since there are accelerating risks of venereal disease such as herpes and AIDS the first of which is incurable, the second fatal-for all these reasons one would think it a morally responsible course of action to urge educators and other adult authorities to state such facts bluntly to the young and admonish them against early intercourse.

That is the crux of the problem. Our education programs assume a maturity that is not present. They assume moral relativism and promiscuity and in so doing legitimise both. They give our young people false confidence; I believe they betray them. We do not tell young people to use drugs in moderation. We say, `Do not even try them'. We do not say, `Smoke in moderation', we actively stigmatise smoking altogether. It should be the same with sex outside of faithful marriage, especially with the current AIDS crisis. We need to tell young people that if they fool around it is very likely they will die a lonely and miserable death. They should be warned that through the self-abuse of drugs or sexual irresponsibility they can break a trust with the community, forfeit certain rights and expect certain sanctions. This should also be the view put bluntly to adults, heterosexual or homosexual, who in the AIDS context are acting like children.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the comments reportedly made yesterday by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), it is an opportune time to dwell upon some aspects of medical education. The Minister in his comments may merely have intended to generate debate by gingering up his criticism of universities, which he claims resist change and are `ossified bodies incapable of adaption'. Perhaps the Minister was looking for an excuse for the failings of his Government, or perhaps he was out to make a cheap point. If so, the institutional universities are, of course, an easy target, even though the wealth of talent within the universities far exceeds that of either the Minister who offers gratuitous criticism or the bureaucrat who wrote his speech.

SPEECH.PARA: That Minister, and indeed the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), who is at the table, could inform themselves by studying the remarks of Professor Joske, Dean of the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Western Australia. In a paper entitled `Medical Education in Australia in the Next 10 Years', delivered on 25 August, Professor Joske made it clear that politics as being practised today forces change. I do not think I misrepresent the views of Joske when I postulate that politically imposed change is not always conducive to desirable progress in educating future medical practitioners. While the divorcement of medical practice from politics is never likely to be achieved, and may not even be desirable, the quality of political intervention over recent years has led to regression rather than progression in medical education, and that is likely to continue.

The rhetoric of Minister Dawkins, as reported, is not only unhelpful; it is naive. Perhaps he was pandering to the latent prejudice that plainly exists towards universities in the wider community. Professor Joske said in August-I quote him at length:

In Australia an egalitarian, highly-taxed and somewhat insular community resents the elitism and cost of Universities. Paradoxically, the Universities have contributed to their falling public image by lowering of academic standards to teach the trivial and `relevant', at the expense of scholarship, and by loss of their traditional virtues of tolerance, free discussion and scholarship. The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission recognises this by grouping Universities with Colleges of Education as centres of teaching rather than learning, and by calling for `much greater discrimination . . . as to what is supported in terms of research'.
He went on to say:

All this reflects upon medical education which is tied to the University system. Faculties of Medicine are expensive, and have already received cuts in real funding. Recruitment of academic staff is becoming more difficult: many preclinical departments are without medical graduates. All these factors lead to increasing difficulties in medical education, and will remain major factors affecting academic and other decisions in this field in the next decade.

Those words encapsulate the thinking that might motivate the Government to avoid superficial remarks such as those attributed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. While political intervention in medical practice today might be described as subtle, it is most certainly more pervasive and enduring than ever.
The jewel in the Government's crown of intervention is, of course, Medicare. Of Medicare, Joske says-and I agree with him:
Medicare is not concerned with medicine or care of the sick. It is concerned with money and administrative control of the health fields, and in both areas it has been spectacularly successful.

Joske goes on to comment on some other features of Medicare. Though one remark he makes cannot be said to reflect my amazement at this strange public acceptance, he observes rather dryly that the Medicare levy is not considered to be taxation. The fact that, although based absolutely on income, pay as you earn deductions are made and must be included in the taxation returns we all must file each year and the fact that more than $1.5 billion is raised annually in the process-somehow it is not an income tax but somehow, mystically, it is a levy in the eyes of the Government-are a wondrous deception.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the thimble and pea trick.

—As my friend the honourable member for Dawson says, it is the thimble and pea trick. By removing health and related costs from the consumer price index, the Medicare income tax has had the benefit of reducing automatic wage increases, which has saved governments in this country billions of dollars. Had those same governments not then proceeded to squander the savings so generated, we might have felt that at least that aspect would have been of some enduring benefit. Sadly, it was not to be. Professor Joske also said of Medicare:

SPEECH.PARA: It has led to documentation in Canberra of almost all health transactions and effectively brought health services under control of the Federal Government. In actual provision of health care, Medicare has been irrelevant. It has provided no more doctors, nurses, paramedics, hospitals, hostels or pharmaceuticals. Indeed, it has decreased the effectiveness of existing services by increases in their administrative time and costs. It has had minimal direct effect on medical education.

These are not the words of a terribly self-serving medical practitioner of the type Government members love to malign when trying to justify some aspect of the Government's largely discredited health policy.

While Medicare may have had minimal direct effects on medical education, the indirect effects seem to be much more evident. For example, in its initial rhetorical efforts to justify Medicare, the Government, and apologists for the Government, conducted a campaign of political vilification of the medical profession. That the campaign was successful cannot be denied, and that it prevails even today is sometimes to be deplored. A sad consequence, and therefore indirect effect, is one which led Joske to observe:
