I think we will lose very idealistic students as the personal vilification of the medical profession proceeds.
That is a very sad comment indeed. While expressing reservations about the future for medical students, Joske is nevertheless optimistic when he concludes on that subject:
But overall they will remain the dedicated intelligent youngsters who are the emotional life-blood of medical schools.
However, Joske is less optimistic about the future of academic staff. He said:

. . . the number and possibly the quality of academic staff will decrease as money becomes more scarce and the financial differentials between University and hospital clinicians increase. The loss of medically qualified academics will be greatest in pre-clinical departments, but all will be affected. Those remaining will do more organisation and administration of teaching by non-medical graduates and non-academic doctors in hospitals and private practice. Scholarship and creative research will decline, and morale and recruitment will suffer.

These are but excerpts from the paper which I identified at the outset of my contribution to the debate. For a full appreciation, the paper should be read in its entirety. Its importance derives from the pre-eminence of its author, and it should be compulsory reading for the Minister for Community Services and Health if he wants some insight into the future of medicine as a profession, and medical education as a necessary adjunct to that. If the Minister is sincerely interested, I shall arrange for him to receive a copy of the paper. I urge him to read it at length and to learn from it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Dr BLEWETT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to thank all honourable members on both sides of the chamber who have participated in the debate on the appropriations for the Department of Community Services and Health. I wish to comment briefly on some of the points that have been made. First, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) spoke about homes for young people and problems being experienced in that area, but seemed to become somewhat muddled by then talking about million-dollar homes in Sydney. There was some suggestion that the honourable member had mislaid his notes. I point out to him that this Government, over its 4 1/2 years in office, has made a massive commitment to public housing. As a result of our economic policies, in these difficult times, we have begun to achieve a reduction in interest rates which will flow through to the availability of housing.

SPEECH.PARA: A series of support schemes for rental assistance has been developed, particularly by my colleague the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), which will also benefit young people searching for accommodation. In this year's Budget we have provided increased funding of over 10 per cent for the first home owners scheme. We have developed the supported accommodation assistance scheme, again particularly for young people in need of housing. If one looks at all the efforts of the Government in the housing area, while we recognise the very real difficulties in this area and are not running away from them, the Government has a record in addressing these problems that certainly is second to none in the history of this country.

I would also like to thank the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) for her very clear defence of the Government's child care program. The fact is that we have made a commitment, in the three years between 1985 and 1988, to increase available child care places by 20,000. We have already approved over 17,000 of those 20,000 places. Of course, we have to make sure that the program is fully implemented and operational by the end of next year. The honourable member for Phillip certainly demolished most of the arguments advanced by the critics of the Government's child care program, but it seemed to have no effect on the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), who immediately stood up and talked about the gold-plated standards of our child care approach and made the usual glib comparisons between the cost of government-funded child care and the costs of private sector child care. Those comparisons are glib because they simply ignore the extra demands and directions of the Government's child care policy. For instance, government funded child care often has to provide for very unusual hours to accommodate the needs of parents on shift work. That, of course, is something the private sector operators usually do not worry about as they generally have much more standard hours. However, we need to have those extra provisions if we are truly to support families who need child care.

Again, it is not possible for private child care centres to cater effectively for those in real need in the community. Let us compare child care centres with nursing homes. When nursing homes were simply a private business or private activity, they were littered across the wealthy and affluent suburbs of our cities, and very poor and inadequate provision was made in poorer areas. The entire child care program of this Government has been planned in order to see that there is a proper geographic spread. It is not only the areas that can easily afford to pay for child care that are provided with centres, the distribution must be fair and according to need across the community. That means that we are putting them in areas in which private child care will not be so frequently found because there is not the same affluence and resources to pay for them. Again, because we are basing our whole program on need, we have systems of fee payments so that those who are less well off can afford child care. But we are increasingly demanding that those who have more resources make a bigger contribution. We will continue to ensure that this needs based child care is maintained but, equally, we will be ensuring that it is as cost efficient as we can possibly make it. We do not believe in making glib comparison between the service provided by the private sector-we acknowledge its contribution-and that provided by the government sector. The government sector has a whole series of needs to meet.

Again, the honourable member for Richmond at the tail end of his speech made one of the most superficial judgments that have ever come from his rather superficial mouth. He talked about our aged care program as a piecemeal approach. This is the first government in the history of this country that has had an integrated approach to the needs of the aged. Not only have we maintained the nursing home sector, but also we have supplemented it with a major expansion of hospital provisions, and we have created the home and community care program. For the first time in this country we are offering old people and their relatives the choice of accommodation and support that most suits their emotional, medical and social needs. Of course, we have a long way to go, but it is the first government in this country's history that has not had a piecemeal approach. It is just the opposite to what the foolish honourable member for Richmond was saying. This is the first government that has had an integrated approach to try to provide a whole range of alternative accommodation and support services for the aged.

The honourable member O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) concentrated mainly on the health area and began his remarks with a statement of disasters in the health area. The only obvious disaster in the health area is, of course, the Opposition's health policy. It was the fifth health policy that this Opposition has provided in four years. It was developed during the election. It has now sunk completely without trace and, of course, its designer, Senator Michael Baume, has sunk with it. So the only real obvious disaster we have had in the health policy is the Liberal's health policy. The honourable member for O'Connor noted the overruns that took place in last year's Budget. He listed them as though there was something particularly wicked about these overruns. They occurred in pharmaceutical benefits, hospital services for veterans, nursing home benefits, nursing home assistance and the home and community care program. The one thing all those programs have in common is that they were programs particularly designed for the aged.

We make no apology for the fact that, in the area of care for the elderly people in this country, we had some extra expenditure in last year's Budget. The honourable member for O'Connor repeated the simplistic analysis that the levy did not meet the cost of medical benefits. But, of course, that ignores entirely the fact that well before Medicare all governments provided generously out of general revenue for public hospitals, for pensioners and others. All the Medicare levy and the associated changes do is pay for the extra costs of Medicare. Those extra costs are fully covered by those changes.

I now deal with the very sincere and honest remarks made by the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) who, unlike many honourable members opposite, is genuinely concerned about serious health problems posed for this country by the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) epidemic. The philosophical issues he raised are ones that this community will debate for a very long time. I do not necessarily agree with all of the comments he made, but I believe his approach to this very difficult problem was very genuine. We should judge every possible course of action in relation to AIDS by one simple and single criterion-is it or is it not productive and cost effective in limiting the spread of AIDS?

Finally, I thank the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) for referring me to Professor Joske's speech which I have already looked at. The only comment I make about the honourable member's comments and those of Professor Joske is that they both could have given a little attention to the fact that we have had going for almost 12 months the first major inquiry into medical education that this country has had since the Second World War. This inquiry is conducted by a number of distinguished medical people and educationists. I believe they will produce this Government and future governments with a blueprint for medical education well into the twenty-first century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to answer some of the questions raised at the committee stage of this Bill. The honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) addressed one of the important initiatives of the Budget, the recognition by the Government of the report Return to Country which was prepared by the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, of which the honourable member for Moore was the Chairman. The point he made about the bipartisan approach of that report is worth noting. In the not too distant future the Government will be preparing its response to that report. In an interim way we have allocated funds for that very important area of servicing what we now term the original land areas. We look forward to being able to bring that response back to the Parliament. I say `original lands' in response to the terminology used by the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon). Obviously, he has not caught up with the new term yet. I make that comment in a friendly way to point out to him that perhaps the term `original lands' is better than the term he used.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to comments made by other speakers in the debate, I address firstly the comments made by the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles). Having had a fairly lengthy discussion with him, I say quite genuinely that I look forward to working with him as best I can, given that we are on different sides of the chamber. I repeat what I said to him privately: I look forward to that co-operation that is needed.

TALK.START.PARA: —He'll give you a hand.

—I am looking forward to his giving me a hand. The point he made about a bipartisan approach is one which other speakers addressed. It is important that we do not look back at who said what and who is responsible for the bipartisan approach not being there in recent years. I make the offer to the Opposition to forget the past and look to the future. Perhaps if we work together we can adopt a bipartisan approach to this issue. There will be times, of course, when there will be disagreement.
—That should be; that's healthy.

—That should be. For argument's sake, it would be terrible if we all thought the same way, particularly when one looks at the honourable member for Mitchell. I would not want him to think that I thought the same way as he does all the time. The point I am making in a quite genuine way is that I will ensure that the suggestions from the Opposition about bipartisan attitudes are taken on board. I look forward to that approach occurring. I will do everything in my power to support it. When bipartisan attitudes fall away, the only people who suffer in this area are the Aboriginal people. If we feel strongly about the need to improve the performance of government in this area, a bipartisan approach will be one way in which we can get that level of achievement that we are all looking for.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) made the point that, when looking at expenditure, previous governments and this Government had perhaps-and I stress the word `perhaps'-thought that money should be just handed over for spending in various areas and that that was the right way to go. I inform him and the Committee that we have engaged in an exercise with the States to the effect that every program at the Commonwealth and State level will be looked at. We will address the question raised by a number of speakers about whether there is a duplication of services. I anticipate that towards the end of the year that assessment of programs will have neared completion, and it will certainly enable the Commonwealth, in its discussions with the States in December, to be better informed than it has been in the past as to how the various programs which are being operated by both the Commonwealth and States are performing. The point that the honourable member made is a valid observation. I inform the Committee that we are already addressing that point.

The shadow Minister also referred to the question of housing. I suppose it would be simple for me to read out all the figures about our allocation of money for housing in this year's Budget. I will not do that. I say to him that one must always look at where one started from. Believe me, if one goes back some time, things were very bad. They are not good now. He suggested that people are not trying. I pay tribute to the attempts made by former Ministers in his Party who attempted to address the question of housing and shelter for Aboriginal people. He referred to Senator Chaney. I think that Senator Chaney would be the first to admit that it is not an easy task to fix the question of housing and housing needs of Aboriginal people.

I say to him in a very friendly way that it is not a time to score points. Perhaps he was not trying to do that, but this is not an issue about which we have the luxury, as we do in other policy areas, of having a point-scoring exercise. It is a question of our making sure that what we are all trying to see happen, does happen. Rather than go into the question of how good our performance in this Budget is, I again make the point that we are in the first eight weeks of the term of this Government. We will not engage in a point-scoring exercise. We will suggest to people that we can address these questions together.

Other comments were made by the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) and by the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Braddon, about the treaty and the compact. I say to the Committee that that was the topic of a statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I make the plea to the Opposition that we have a unique opportunity to address this question in a bipartisan way. We should not engage in point-scoring; we should stand back, look at this issue, discuss it with Aboriginal people and hope that, at the end of that discussion process, no matter how long it takes, we are able to achieve a treaty, compact, makarrata arrangement-whatever the title is-that is to their satisfaction and ours. I guess it is a challenge to all of us in this place who feel very strongly, as many honourable members do, about the need for something to be done and some recognition to be given to Aboriginal people.

I think that we have a duty, as elected representatives, to do everything we can in as non-political a way as we can, to achieve the sorts of things for which Aboriginal people have been asking over the last 200 years. I again make the point that they have been here for 40,000 years, but it is really only in the last 20 years that they have had a chance to make any real gain. For the first 180 years they were not considered to be citizens of this country. If we go back 20 years and look at the gains that they as a community have made, we must come to the conclusion that they as a people have made remarkable progress in the way in which they have struggled and taken up the challenges that they have had to face. So there is the question of their 40,000 years of occupation of this land, the 200 years of non-Aboriginal settlement, and the fact that it has been 20 years since the referendum was held which resulted in their being treated as equals in terms of the law. We should look at that 20 years and at the progress they have made.

Again, in regard to the question of the treaty and the compact, the honourable member for Lyne was, I think, quite right to say that there is an expectation in the community and in the Aboriginal community that there will be a result from those discussions. I, for one, have no doubt about it. I cannot see why we cannot reach an agreement that it is satisfactory to all. I will be doing everything I can, as long as I am in this job and afterwards, to see that that satisfactory conclusion is reached. I again make the point to the Opposition that there have been too many examples over a long period of politicians and others point-scoring at the expense of Aboriginal people. Those days must end. I make the point, in answer to an interjection, that I have not been backward in scoring a few points during debates on this issue; I admit that. I say that now is the time, given events of recent times, for us all to put that sort of performance behind us.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's different now?

—Maybe we all mature from time to time. I put it to the Committee in as genuine a way as I can that significant things have occurred in recent months that I think have brought about a change in the community. That change is expressed in the results of some recent polling. If one looks at the results of polls conducted two years ago, I suggest that the figures would not have been anywhere near what they are today. So this shift is taking place in the community. That shift has been reflected by all sorts of people speaking out in the media about the need to acknowledge that there is something radically wrong with the way in which Aboriginal people are struggling in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of the treaty, attitude and bipartisanship arose in the course of the debate. I ask people to look at the Budget allocations, and not to question the new programs in the way in which some people did. The new programs are needed. They address communications; they address basic shelter in the original lands, in the isolated areas of central Australia, where people do not have any shelter, where kids do not sleep under shelter, where kids do not have running water, let alone hot water, where kids are not able to go to school because there is no school. All of the statistics that honourable members cited in the course of the debate today are there to be seen. I am reminded of a comment made by an Opposition member of the Standing Committee which has stuck with me since the day he said it. I refer to the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton), who made the comment that it would do every member of the Parliament good to serve six months on the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. I guarantee that if that were to happen, the changes we all talk about would happen very quickly, because no one could allow the sorts of conditions that exist within our community to occur for very long. They would demand change. Whilst we in Australia are often very critical of and quick to point out the problems of other countries, I say for the record that we as a community and as a nation have been very slow to address the points that were made in the course of this debate.
Proposed expenditures agreed to.
Department of Defence
Proposed expenditure, $7,150,478,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had a fair debate today on defence. I do not intend to go over that ground. I made some points about personnel matters which I hope the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) heard; I am sure that she did hear them. I hope that some of them will be taken on board.
—They need a bit of reinforcement. Why don't you do it now?

—I think she got the message. I speak from the heart on these matters. It is easy for me to say this, having served for many years in the forces, but I very much hope that she accepts what I say as being genuine. If at the end of the day we have magnificent equipment and no men and women to man it, we really will not have very much at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to raise tonight in the short time available some other questions concerning the defence of this country which really need some answers from the Government. I refer first of all to an alleged contracting fraud within the Department of Defence which has been reported recently in the media. I have no idea whether these reports are genuine; certainly some of the allegations refer to enormous amounts of money. The Canberra Times of 9 September cites an amount of $800m. An amount of $800m out of a total budget of $7.4 billion dollars comes out at a bit more than 10 per cent-an enormous amount of money when the defence budget, like any other budget, is short and we are desperately trying to improve the conditions of service for people in the Services as well as purchase all the capital equipment required and improve all the bases. So I ask the Government what is happening. I understand there is a departmental investigation and I hope that the results of that investigation will be made public as soon as it is established one way or the other whether or not those allegations have any truth to them.

I return to the submarines project. We on this side of the chamber support the project but we were very disappointed that the contract was signed so quickly before the last election. I believe it was signed in haste. We asked the Government not to sign it, in anticipation that we would be returned to office and we wanted to have a closer look at it. In the event we were not, and the contract will stay in place. It would not have been repudiated had we been returned to government, either.

Since the election, and since the program has got under way, some questions have arisen. I have asked them two or three times before but to my knowledge they have never been answered by the Government or by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). It is of no use the Minister dodging them. If the Government wants bipartisan support and a bipartisan approach to defence matters, this side-and I speak as the shadow Minister-would be delighted to give that support and take such an approach. No one is here to try to denigrate or in any way belittle the defence of this country, but when there are genuine differences of opinion as to how that defence is to be conducted, obviously there will be debate.

We agree with the submarine project but three questions about the project, which I have asked before, need to be answered. It would appear now that some or all of the first submarine is to be built in Sweden. That admission was dragged, with some difficulty, from Mr Bennett, the Defence Department's Chief of Capital Procurement. To my knowledge, there has never been a statement on that matter by the Minister. The only statements I have ever been able to dig up from the Minister are that all those submarines-they are the words he used in all his Press statements, time after time-were to be built in Australia. Now it would appear that part of the first submarine is to be built in Sweden. That may well be a good thing; there might be good reasons why that should happen. We need a clear statement for the benefit of Australian industry, as to just how much of that first submarine is to be built in Sweden, and why.

Secondly, we want to know what performance standards will be required of that submarine. When the Swedish consortium was tendering it listed a certain set of performance standards. The Royal Australian Navy took that submission and significantly upgraded most of those standards. Now we have the Navy's upgrading of the Swedish consortium's standards and we have the Swedish consortium's own assessment of its performance standards. What are the standards to which that submarine will be built?

Finally, and this is probably the most important point, it seems to me that in the haste to sign this contract before the last election one vital element was not tied up. When we eventually get the hulls and have to put a combat system in those hulls-two separate contractors are involved-who will be responsible for the final integration of the hulls and the combat systems? Maybe that has been tied up. I very much hope that the principal contractor, the Swedish consortium, has accepted that responsibility but I am not clear on that and neither are a lot of other people. If that has not been tied up, who will accept responsibility? In the end we could well be talking about a cost of millions and millions of dollars to get that match right. There will be two contractors involved in the enormous job of integrating a combat system into a very sophisticated submarine. These are not casual questions, and I note with some interest that Mr John Halfpenny-I hesitate to name him; he is hardly a colleague of mine-is also raising some of these questions. Between the two of us, Mr Halfpenny and I in collusion, we may get some answers.

I ask the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel to take on board just a few other quick queries. The M113 project is very important to the defence of this country, especially in relation to the northern development of the Army. Initially there was to be a Project Waler, an Australian developed armoured personnel carrier (APC). That was scrapped. The Government has been talking for some time about the refurbishment of the existing APCs. I see no mention of that in the Budget or in the defence paper presented today; it seems to have been put on hold. It is important that we get a clear statement on that project.

The F111 update also gets only a vague mention in passing. It seems to me that the submarines and the F111s are the two most effective deterrents this country has. I do not think we can afford not to update the avionics on the F111s as they have 25 years of life left, but that issue seems to have been dodged. I also hope very much that the Government will look at putting equipment on the Boeing 707 aircraft to enable the F111s to have an aerial refuelling capability as well as the FA18s. It simply does not make any sense, with our limited capacity to reach out from our shores, not to have the capacity to refuel the F111s in mid-air. I also ask when that 707 aircraft conversion is to start. This Government and the previous Government have talked about that for a long time.

The Opposition also supports the frigates pro- ject, but there seems to be a hiccup with it. I know that the Navy recommendations have been to the Minister's office, and I know that they have been sent back to the Navy. We would like to know what the problem is. Is the whole project to be recast? Was it too expensive? Were the frigates too big, or were they too small? Was there too much equipment? What is the problem, and why have those recommendations been sent back?

Finally, I refer to the Hamilton Review of Effect of Service Life on Spouses, which is more directly the responsibility of the Minister at the table, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. We hear a lot about when the Hamilton report will be implemented. To my knowledge, a few cosmetic measures have been implemented. People spent a lot of time on the Hamilton report, and if the Government could make some genuine effort to implement some of the more important recommendations of that report it would go a long way to proving to the service men and women of Australia that it is genuine in its desire to improve their lot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) on the post-Budget statement on defence matters he made to the House this afternoon. It was a comprehensive and perceptive statement. It dealt with Australia's security alliance with the United States of America, it re-affirmed the defence strategy of the Government, it detailed the capital equipment program, it outlined a specific role for the Reserve Force and it gave a guarantee of continued efforts to improve efficiency in the Australian Defence Force, and that priority would be given to improving the pay and conditions of service for defence personnel. The statement should be required reading for every member of the Australian Defence Force. It should also be required reading for every member of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget enables the Department of Defence to spend $7,404m in 1987-88. Approximately $2,200m will be spent on major capital equipment, other equipment, stores and repairs and new housing and construction maintenance. The Minister's statement this afternoon detailed much of this expenditure. In line with the Hawke Government's commitment to upgrade defence housing stock and standards, this Budget provides $75m to be spent on defence housing this year. Defence personnel based at Townsville will welcome this. Fifteen additional houses will be constructed in Townsville for defence personnel this year. In addition, a further $60m has been committed as part of a program to upgrade single living accommodation. In Townsville, where approximately 11 per cent of Australia's Army is based, it is intended to convert 2,808 existing bedspaces, currently in the four-man-room configuration, into 312 separate modules, each comprising four individual bedrooms of about 12 square metres, a common room shared by the four occupants and a shared ensuite. This important program is expected to be under way in 1988 and be completed by 1992. The work is long overdue, as existing single living accommodation is very much sub-standard. Defence personnel in Townsville will welcome this initiative.

I especially welcome the Minister's remarks on the integrated role of the Army Reserve. The Townsville-based 11th Brigade is now the most highly trained and combat effective Army Reserve formation in Australia, and it continues to improve. Its effective current strength is about 1,800 personnel and this should increase to about 2,300 personnel in the next three years. Reserve defence personnel in Townsville welcome the total force concept advocated by the Minister and are eager to integrate, where possible, with operationally ready and deployable combat forces. Defence reservists in my electorate are proud to serve their country to the best of their ability. They want to be competent, effective soldiers. That they will be, through the implementation of this new concept.

I now refer to some aspects of the capital equipment program. First, I totally support the emphasis that the Government is placing on the program. Significant ongoing projects include the provision of $585m for the purchase of the FA18 aircraft and associated equipment. Twenty-six of these aircraft have already been delivered and 18 are planned to be assembled in Australia this year. I briefly mention other significant projects in the Budget. There is an allocation of $175m for the construction stage of the new submarine project. The first submarine is scheduled for delivery in 1995. There is an allocation of $141m for the acquisition of 16 Seahawk helicopters for operation from the guided missile frigates. The sum of $116m is allocated for the cost of construction of two FFG7 class guided missile frigates at Williamstown dockyard. The sum of $49m is allocated for the purchase of 39 Blackhawk helicopters to supplement the existing fleet of UH-IH Iroquois helicopters. Deliveries are to commence in November 1987 and these helicopters will be based at Townsville. The amount of $88m is allocated for 67 Pilatus PC9 trainer aircraft from Hawker de Havilland, Bankstown. Deliveries are expected to commence in November 1987. There is an allocation of $70m for various army communication projects including the new single channel radios, replacement cryptographic equipment and the hiport/medport trunk communications equipment. Furthermore, $14m will be spent this year at Townsville on facilities for the introduction of the new Blackhawk helicopters to be based there.

There is almost unanimous support within the defence community for the decision of the Government to acquire eight new surface combatant ships, which are to be built in Australia. The Minister described the exceptional capabilities of these ships in his statement this afternoon. The first ship is planned for delivery in the early 1990s. The acquisition of these ships will help the Royal Australian Navy to acquire a two-ocean capability, which is essential for the self-reliance defence capacity advocated by the Government.

The limitation of time permitted in this debate does not allow an exhaustive description of the Hawke Government's capital equipment program. That is a pity. Australians should be reminded often of the failure of the Liberal and National parties when in government to equip the three services with `the best and most appropriate weapons, missiles, transport and support equipment that money can buy'. They left it to the Hawke Labor Government to re-arm the Australian Defence Force. Yet one still hears the carping and the whining by the Opposition that this Government places too much emphasis on its capital equipment program. What items of defence equipment do members of the Opposition suggest are not essential for Australia's defence? Dare they answer? Hardly ever is there a constructive suggestion from the Opposition, so it should lift its game.

I now refer to the pay and conditions of service for defence personnel. Honourable members are aware that defence personnel have never had a wage pause under the Hawke Government. The last wage pause for defence personnel was under the Liberal-National Party Government in 1982. What bitter memories defence personnel still have of that decision. The Hawke Government quickly established the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal. It is an independent tribunal and its decisions are binding on the Government. The Tribunal has made a number of decisions on the pay and conditions of service. Generally, these decisions have been accepted by the vast majority of defence personnel. However, I strongly believe there is still much to do to raise the standard of pay and conditions of service for defence personnel. I urge the Government to continue to give this matter urgent priority. I know that service personnel require continual reassurance that their interests will be protected at all times. Uncertainty among service personnel in this regard can lead to disillusionment. The nation cannot afford that.

I now refer to the defence service home loan scheme. There is tremendous opposition among many defence personnel to the Budget proposal to replace the defence service home loan of up to $25,000 with a non-repayable non-taxable cash grant of up to $10,000 for home acquisition. I am aware that the proposed arrangements are to be discussed with the Returned Services League and other interested parties before a final decision is made. Many serving defence personnel and ex-service personnel in my electorate see this proposal as an erosion of a Defence Force condition of service. They assert that no credible argument has yet been advanced that the $10,000 grant is an improvement on a loan of $25,000. The Government would be well advised to proceed with great caution on this issue. This Government has the trust and loyalty of defence personnel. We must never forget that. Finally, whatever the cost, Australia must have a Defence Force that is well equipped, well trained, well motivated and capable of defending Australia and its people. That is a fundamental duty of any Government. It is an obligation which this Government has accepted and it is an obligation that will be fulfilled by the best Federal Government that this country has had since World War II.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I take part in this debate, because it gives me an opportunity to state again my concerns about one of the major capital equipment projects in the defence estimates; that is, the new submarine project. The amount of money allocated to that project in the Budget statement for the 1987-88 financial year is $175m. Members of the Opposition, including me, have on a number of occasions expressed considerable disquiet about aspects of this project. I think a lot of what we have been saying for a long time is now being confirmed in a number of publications and various sources in this country and elsewhere.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the attention of the Committee to an article written by a former submariner, Peter Scott-Maxwell, in the October edition of the Pacific Defence Reporter-a most professional publication. Among other comments, the article makes these remarks about the submarine project:

Now that the Department of Defence has made a catastrophic decision to buy conventional submarines from a neutral country which has no wartime operational experience, the prospects of the RAN submarine service are indeed dismal.

The Department of Defence is in effect committing the RAN to outmoded technology with which they will have to live, or die, for the next 30 years. The RAAF were not fobbed off with the subsonic aircraft. Why should the RAN become the laughing stock of the Pacific?

A straight technical evaluation per se, does not necessarily ensure an ongoing technological involvement with the main stream of submarine development-whereby the Stirling engine is really only a gimmick and one believes a very expensive one at that.

Now we have Canada apparently taking seriously what this article is all about, namely the small nuclear option with inherent higher speed, and endurance at that speed, which will be imperative to survival. The Canadians have thought out their rather similar problems, where we have not.
The article goes on to say:
Cannot the Department of Defence see that it is committing future generations of submariners to certain death in the event of hostilities. Have that on your conscience!

The May edition of Navy International gives a very frightening update on antisubmarine torpedo development. What it will be like in say 15 years' time when the RAN is locked into old fashioned technology I hate to think . . .

The decision to buy Swedish conventional submarines appears to have been a governmental decision, rather than a recommendation from the RAN-which will inherit the ultimate responsibility for this decision. They will still be there when the government in question will be in limbo.

Peter Scott-Maxwell made some very telling points in that article. It is also interesting to note that Canada is moving in the direction it is because Kockums, the Swedish supplier to our own submarine project, was depending on some economies of scale on a larger production run by possibly obtaining the Canadian contract. That has not now come about, as it never properly should have. So all those rather disquieting concerns have been expressed by Peter Scott- Maxwell, which in fact confirm many of the matters that have been raised in this place by me and others over the past year to 18 months. We now also find ourselves in a situation where the purely pork-barrelling aspects of the project directed at particular State governments are also starting to come apart.

Earlier tonight the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) referred quite correctly to the fact that after all the to-do there was about building all six boats here in Australia, in fact the decision has been made formally and confirmed by Fred Bennett, who has the appropriate responsibility for this area in the Department of Defence, that the forward section of the first boat will in fact be built in Sweden. The publication Defence Industry of 16 September 1987 carries an article on its front page that clearly says:

No matter what light Mr. Bennett or other Defence Navy officials or officers might now wish to place on it, there was the clear impression that the Government's commitment was to build all sections of every hull in Australia. That attitude has been emphasised in official Defence and Ministerial briefings ever since the Hawke Cabinet, through the Defence Minister, Mr Kim Beazley, decided in May 1985, that all the submarine hulls would be built in Australia. This decision scrubbed an earlier option to build the first or lead boat overseas, and possibly even part of the second boat.

That was the great telling propaganda point that Kockums kept putting forward to sell its project to the Defence Department and to this Government, that in fact all boats would be built in Australia. This was supposed to be the great advantage of choosing that company over certain of the other tenderers. Now we learn that that is not to happen and that the much vaunted pork-barrelling exercise directed at South Australia will be considerably diminished. I understand that there is already growing disquiet in South Australia, because that State realises that it will not achieve the expected employment opportunities in industry or the high technology that the Minister said it would get some time ago. I might add that there are suggestions going around that the aft section of the hull of the first boat is also to be built in Sweden. I shall be interested to hear the Government's response to those suggestions because at present they have some currency. If they prove to be correct, I will be fascinated to see what happens, because the Government's proposition in the first place was that the hulls be constructed here in Australia, and that was supposed to be the great advantage of giving the contract to Kockums. Now the suggestion is being made that the hull-certainly the forward section and quite possibly the aft section-is to be built in Sweden. So much for the propaganda that was being churned out some time ago.

That brings me to some of the quite serious concerns that were raised earlier about the security of the project. The building of the boats here in Australia was also meant to be a device by which some of the aspects of probable penetration of the project could be avoided, having regard to many of the security considerations that have permeated industry in Sweden and that have particularly affected its armaments industry and its shipbuilding industry. Recently the Bofors scandal broke in Sweden and it was covered also on British television. It was made apparent that various people in the Swedish armaments industry and in the Swedish Foreign Ministry have been systematically involved in moving Swedish armaments illegally to Iran.

One of the people who have been exposed as being heavily involved in that process is Mr Carl-Johan Aaberg, Under-Secretary of State at the Swedish Foreign Ministry's foreign trade section. He finds himself at the centre of this controversy. He is the Swedish Government official who is alleged to have given the covert go-ahead for the illegal smuggling of arms, ammunition and other war materiels from Sweden to Tehran using South East Asian paperwork as a cover for direct transit to Iran. Mr Aaberg has admitted his involvement in the Swedish Bofors arms deals but has stated publicly that the Swedish supplies of explosives, missiles and high-powered gunboats were not and are not war materiels. That is not a very convincing argument on his part.

What is the significance of Mr Aaberg in this matter? Mr Carl-Johan Aaberg, who has now been shown throughout this exercise not only to have been organising the supply of arms to Iran but also as having an ongoing contact with the KGB, was the Swedish Government official who gave the assurances to this Government in the negotiations on our submarine contract that there had been no Eastern Bloc penetration of Kockums. We now find ourselves in a situation where a major part of the first boat will be built in Sweden, and that opens up once again the whole question of security considerations. At the same time we find that the Swedish Government official who assured us that there was no Eastern Bloc penetration of Kockums is now shown to be in contact with the KGB and heavily involved in the Bofors arms scandal which has just been exposed in Sweden and on British television.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will not get any answers to those questions tonight.
—I shall be interested to see whether the Government has any answers on this occasion or future occasions. The Opposition does not intend to let these questions rest now or at any stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that every honourable member is concerned about the defence of Australia. Honourable members were interested this afternoon to hear the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) deliver his White Paper on budget matters and defence issues. This evening I wish to make some remarks about the personnel in our Defence Force. I am particularly interested in this matter because I happen to represent in this place those stationed at the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) base at Williamtown, situated just north of Newcastle. Over the past week or so I have had the opportunity, at the request of the wives of quite a few of the servicemen, to meet those personnel and to have general discussions with them about the matters about which they are worried at present. I am sure that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) will be interested in this matter because she now has ministerial responsibility for it.

SPEECH.PARA: The defence budget of $7,404m is a very large amount. We must appreciate the fact that most of that money, or the extra funds that are sought, will be used for the purpose of materiel acquisitions. There is a falling away in the fact that those 70,000 service personnel, both the men and women who actually conduct the three arms of the service, are the ones who are being depleted. In fact, I can say to the Committee this evening that in the last week or so five FA18 pilots at the Williamtown base resigned. There were six, but one has withdrawn his resignation. They have resigned only because they are dissatisfied with the actual conditions of service that are available for them at the present time. The wives have pointed out to me, and quite honestly, that the actual conditions of service have deteriorated over a period of time.

We must recall and remember, of course, that is of no use our having all the new submarines, aircraft, ships and guns unless we have the well-trained personnel to operate the three arms of the service. We are losing pilots now at such a rate that it would take at least twelve months to train the replacements for the losses of pilots we have had from the service in the last three months. The Minister nods her head. I am sure she agrees with this, too. I would like to extend to the Minister an invitation to go to that area at some time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to.

—I would love to join her, because I want to co-operate. We will talk with the wives, because the wives are a very important element today of service life. We have to realise that people who are serving within the Services, particularly within the Royal Australian Air Force, are people who are moved from place to place throughout Australia all the time, and even overseas. If they spend a year, or two years at the most, in one centre, they are doing pretty well. But the fact of the matter is that they come and they go. I think actual statistics will show that service personnel have larger families than other people in the community, which is great to see, but they have their educational problems, and particularly housing problems. If honourable members go around the housing areas-particularly in my area, like Raymond Terrace, Nelson Bay and Newcastle-they will find that most of the personnel are actually living in housing commission homes, and the standard of those homes is not as good as others the community.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Defence today made it quite clear that servicemen and service women have now got a clear cut direction within Australia. He said that the service personnel joined for the challenge and to serve the nation. We do not disagree with a word of that. That is true. But it is not doing justice to those people, and that is the thing that I want to raise here this evening. I have spoken about the base. The Williamtown base is a pleasant, happy base. Everybody is happy there. What I speak about this evening are not the conditions existing on the base but those existing in the arms of the Services right throughout the Commonwealth of Australia, and particularly within the RAAF, and these people are worried. That is why I wanted to raise the matter here.

Actual conditions that were available to these people, and I suppose one could say concessions that were available to them 5, 10 or 15 years ago, are now gone. The salaries are not commensurate with the salaries that people receive in private industry. I know that pilots speak about a salary they can get if they go over to Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines or Ansett Airlines of Australia. I do not compare it with that, but I do compare servicemen in all grades with people outside. That is why they are finding that when they look at their conditions today they want to get out and get themselves a job elsewhere within the community.

They pointed out to me that pride in service to the country has gone. They pointed out to me that the special Defence Force dwelling loan that was available before the housing loan, which gave some security to them after retirement, has now gone. They have not got that. They also pointed out the fact that the cheap married quarters that were available for rental years ago are just not available at this point of time. Of course, the Government's dedication generally to the service by the provision of equipment and facilities to enable servicemen to carry out the job safely and properly is not there now. It was there before. I spoke before about the morale. The wives have pointed out to me, as I said earlier, the educational problems and the fact that they have to move from house to house. They find that they have to get jobs. Many of the wives, even with a family, look for work in the community, but the truth of the matter is that it is hard for them to get a job because they are moving and people who want to keep a permanent secretary or a shop assistant will not put on a serviceman's wife because they know that after a time the women will move on. So these are the problems that we have.

If we look at events the last couple of years, we find that the tax on superannuation was a severe blow to service personnel. I know that others have to pay that tax, but look at the conditions of service people. The imposition of the tax upon their superannuation is something that they do not deserve, after serving their country-and all these people are available to serve their country in times of war, to defend Australia, and we must never forget that. We are inclined to forget these important things. We think they just have a job and they are there to do it, but they are the front line so far as we as civilian people in Australia are concerned. Sixteen million people are dependent upon them. We want them well-trained, and we want them happy in their job, because Australia is a producer of food and goods and minerals and the world is dependent upon us. So it is that we have to be actually prepared at all times.

The servicemen and women spoke to me about their defence forces retirement and death benefits scheme. That was a good scheme, but the actual scheme is not much better than any government scheme. They do not receive any further concessions. They are not like an aged pensioner or other pensioners in the community, who are able to get concessions on the railway or concessions on the rental of housing in their elderly period of life. Those things are not available to them. They also pointed out to me the fact that many personnel, particularly the pilots and the air crews, are sent from place to place. They serve very long hours. It surprises me that the five who have just resigned-and all of them are instructors at the Williamtown base-have been grounded. They are not allowed to fly.

I did not inquire, but I doubt whether that instruction came from anybody on the base; it has come from higher up. I wonder whether these people higher up realise the problems that face the personnel below them. I hope the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel will look at this very seriously. I know the Minister is new in her job; I know that she is conscientious, and I have respect for her, but I hope she will look at these things and see that the people who work within the forces are considered and the problems that they have are recognised by the people further up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very decent of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) not to stand because I notice that she is next on the list. I just want to refer to an article run in the Australian newspaper on 18 August this year, an editorial on the personnel crisis in the armed forces. I quote three brief paragraphs which get, I believe, to the heart of our personnel crisis and which I think the appropriations we are discussing tonight ignore. The first quote read:

SPEECH.PARA: Slightly fewer than 25,000 members of the armed forces, or more than 36 per cent of the total defence force, have resigned during the past three years. A record number of just under 9,000 resigned in 1986-87. The losses have been particularly great among officers and senior non-commissioned officers.
The second paragraph I wish to refer to read:
These dreary statistics mean, in short, that Australia, which finds itself in an increasingly unpredictable and hazardous region, is increasingly unable to defend itself.
Finally:

Any economy, however admirably motivated, that puts our national survival at risk is a false economy. The Government must not forget that, if we cannot defend ourselves, all our other endeavours will be in vain.

It is important to note that that assessment of the implications of current resignation rates is shared by the chiefs of staff. Indeed, they have put that view to the Minister in writing. It was also grudgingly acknowledged in the White Paper in March. That paper states:

The Government is concerned at the present rate of separation from the ADF . . . while a reasonable turnover of personnel in the ADF is necessary to exercise the training infrastructure and maintain a young fit force, the present level is higher than desired.

That was the understatement of the White Paper. Unfortunately neither the new Minister-and I am not launching any special attack on the Minister because I know, as the previous speaker, the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan), said, she is very conscientious and will no doubt come to grips with many of these daunting problems that confront her-nor subsequently these allocations appreciate fully the nature and extent of our defence personnel crisis. It will suffice to quote what the new Minister said on 10 August in an Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio interview. I think the Minister may have said something about this during Question Time. The Minister said:
And frankly, I think the whole issue is being incredibly exaggerated. There's no doubt there is an increase in our separation rates over previous years, but it isn't very dramatic.

The allocations under discussion tonight reflect the Minister's failure to understand the seriousness of our problem. Perhaps I am being a bit unfair by saying that. It is not just the personal dimensions of career and family frustration of this crisis which should concern the Government; it is the impact they are having on our operations. Just after the election I was sent a copy of a minute from a former Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) member at Richmond. The minute was written by Air Vice-Marshal Bradford and was critical of the Government's zero manpower growth strategy which, he wrote, has occurred at a time when demands on RAAF manpower resources have increased dramatically. Air Vice-Marshal Bradford states:

During the same time the RAAF resignation rates have increased. Although statistical proof would be difficult, my belief is that operating standards have decreased as a result through lack of experienced manpower . . . Many RAAF sections are so critically manned that productivity is inhibited when personnel are moved from one task to another to rationalise another operational `bush fire', and crisis management results. An unfortunate consequence of this style of management is the significant time that is wasted as personnel are moved from familiar to unfamiliar tasking, because of the learning time that is required. This waste is compounded further if, and when, the moved personnel revert to their familiar tasking with an additional catch-up/learning component.
Of real significance, however, is that section of the minute where the Air Vice-Marshal links manpower and subsequent information management problems with aircraft losses. He goes on:

One area of tasking throughout the RAAF that is slipping, for example, is the amendment status of many publications. This slippage occurs because other higher priority requirements are seen to be more important. Yet publications are the documentation that supports the configuration management and control of our systems. This shortfall will lead to similar deficiencies that caused the aircraft oxygen fires and the Mirage undercarriage related losses. The trend, therefore, will be towards lower safety standards.

I will not comment further on this aspect of the allocation. I refer honourable members and those listening to this discussion to the comments by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) earlier today on the latest statement of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). Not only does the Minister now not have the support of his Cabinet for his portfolio requirements; his academic approach to defence and security is being highlighted by the expertise and experience the honourable member for McPherson brings to the debate as an officer who has actually seen service in a theatre of war.

I will refer briefly to a number of other concerns about these defence allocations. When the Minister for Defence took up his position his guarantee and boast were that the long term planning process and certainty in budget growth would characterise his period as Minister. What these allocations show is that his boast was not based on a realistic assessment of his chances of sustaining political support in Cabinet over a number of years. He-and I want both sides to be honest in this regard-like past Ministers, has failed to deliver on what were necessary goals and schedules. He told us we required 3 per cent real growth in defence allocations over the next several years. He lost in Cabinet. He told us we could get by on zero growth. He lost in Cabinet. He tells us now we can survive with real cuts. That is simply not true. Unfortunately, Australians may not come to appreciate that fact until they face an unexpected security crisis.

I will raise only two other questions with the Minister. The first concerns the following claim put by Vice-Admiral Leach and Commodore Robertson in an article in The Australian recently. The review of our force structure, they claim:

. . . will not be achieved with a Defence Department that is so top heavy that it has an incredible 168 public servants of the equivalent rank of Brigadier or above (including 10 three-star ``generals'', 35 two-star ``generals'' and 12 unattached).

Nor will it be achieved ``they continue'' with a military officer corps which is over-officered to the extent that, in relative terms, Australia has 3 1/2 times as many officers as the US armed forces-which are themselves considered to be over-officered.

I ask the Minister for his response to that claim. The second concerns the need for the Minister to renew public debate on the White Paper. I am not convinced sufficient resources have been allocated to the task of assisting the broader community to participate in what must be an ongoing discussion of defence policy. The vast majority of our citizens are not only unaware of the content of the White Paper but are not equipped to deal with the paper's arguments. Not many people read the 27-page documents the Minister puts down from time to time. The challenge is how to bring the views of the Australian Defence Association and the Peace Research Centre, for example, before those who ultimately determine who sits in parliament to draw up defence policy and send troops into the field.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight few honourable members are in the chamber. We are sitting late and we have a new Minister, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), at the table. No advisers are in the boxes. Honourable members on this side are asking critical questions and taking the debate seriously. They are not being needlessly critical of the Government or vindictive in their speeches. They deserve from the Government answers to these questions. I want an undertaking from the Government that the effort put in by honourable members on this side will be recognised and properly dealt with. We could be calling quorums at this hour of the night; we have chosen not to, but in the spirit of this debate and in the Estimates debate in general the Opposition deserves from the Government proper attention and courtesy that it is not receiving. I shall not extend my remarks. I know the Minister cannot answer the questions raised by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White). They are substantial defence questions. The honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred) raised critical questions on the submarine project. The honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) raised matters of defence service homes and accommodation that could have been answered in the chamber by an informed Minister. The honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) has raised a number of issues in a sympathetic and low key way. I want an undertaking from the Minister that the Opposition will receive the courtesy of the Government in the spirit in which the Estimates debates are normally conducted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs KELLY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I would like to take this opportunity on behalf of the Government to thank all honourable members for their contributions. I can assure them I take very seriously the contributions of honourable members to this debate, especially because this is my first formal speech as a Minister. In fact, I think it is probably the first speech by any woman Minister to the House of Representatives chamber in Australia's history. It is a bit odd making history at 20 past 11 on a Thursday night. Nevertheless, I assure the honourable member for Mitchell that I do take those comments very seriously and I am quite sure many of the issues referred to-of course, some of them were addressed in the statement by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) today-will be addressed in further detail. I was very pleased to hear so many comments about the issue relating to personnel because it is true that this is an area of great importance and significance to this Government. That is the reason I have my portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go into detail on some of the issues that were raised, particularly those relating to separations, I would like to make a few brief comments on some of the contributions. My more general comments will cover many of the points made. I would like to congratulate the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) for his contribution and for his dedicated service to his constituents. I was in Townsville last week and I was made aware of some of the issues he raised. In particular, I had a look at some of the housing that he discussed. I can assure honourable members that the Government will continue its commitment to provide defence service housing, and I will make further comments on that.

I appreciated the comments of the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan). He is obviously very sympathetic to his constituents. However, the issues that he raised are very complex. He discussed the number of resignations from the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF). I will go into that in some detail, but I think the reasons for those resignations are incredibly complex. They do not relate just to conditions of service. What the honourable member for Lyne failed to point out was that the Government is attempting to address many of the issues relating to pay and conditions. It was his Government which put a freeze on defence service personnel salaries, and that needs to be considered in the context of the defence service conditions now being looked at through proper arbitration and industrial relations channels. I can assure honourable members that this is an area of great concern to the Government.

My portfolio covers both the personnel area and the area of technology. Both of these are vital to the effective defence of Australia. This country obviously needs technology, and it needs it where the people are fewest. I want to go on later to talk about defence science and technology because that is a key area in the defence portfolio that seems to get very little consideration.

But the first thing I want to do is to take up the issue that has been raised by many contributors tonight, the issue of separation rates. At the moment, as honourable members will have heard in Parliament today, this issue is the centre of some controversy in my portfolio. By `separations' I mean the number of men and women leaving the Services for any reason at all, including illness, resignation or death. It is a very emotive issue and I am very concerned about it. I do not want to brush it aside but, in the interests of informed debate, it is important that we put it in perspective and get a few facts on it. Then we will deal with some of the key areas where there are problems.

First of all, overall separation rates last financial year stood at 12.8 per cent. The 10-year average has been 11.1 per cent. Some of the reasons leading to an increase in separation rates relate to the changing nature of the Defence Force, to demographic changes. One is the increase in the number of women in the Australian defence forces. Another one is the number of recruits and the use of reservists on full time duty. All of these have higher than usual separation rates, and they account for a percentage. The fact is that the increase in separations among full time male service personnel is accountable for less than one per cent of the overall increase last year.

I do not present this figure as a reason for satisfaction, much less any jubilation. It is a trend that neither I, the Chief of the Defence Force, nor the service chiefs would want to see continue. None of us are burying our heads in the sand of optimism or saying that all will be well and leaving it alone. However, the present figure is not a disaster; it is not a national tragedy. It does not herald the inevitable decline of Australia's Defence Force. Moaning about it and refusing to admit that there is a problem are both equally futile responses. This figure of 12.8 per cent is a trigger for action.

We need to identify causes and address them specifically. There are many reasons for this rise. It is a very complex issue. The effect of the rise does not fall equally on all the many groups that make up the Australian Defence Force. One of the groups that I referred to in Question Time today is the pilots. The honourable member for Lyne rightly highlighted that as a problem. We need pilots not only because they are essential to the defence of this country and to the strategy of the White Paper, but also because we devote large resources to training them.

The basic problem is that pilots are scarce and they are very highly sought after. The Royal Australian Air Force pilots are the cream. They are the best trained and the most highly skilled pilots one can find. Commercial operators want them and currently more are going to commercial jobs than we would like. I will be talking to the senior management of Qantas Airways Ltd to explore how Qantas might adjust its recruiting practices to help the RAAF manage the destabilising effects on the separations of the current recruitment drive for civil pilots.

There is no magic solution to halt the drain of pilots from the RAAF. In consultation with the Chief of the Air Staff, Air Marshal Funnell, I have identified strategies that will work to maintain adequate experience levels in our fighting units. The high number of applications for pilot training shows that flying in the RAAF is still very much an attractive career. As the increased availability of better paying civil flying careers attracts more experienced pilots away from the RAAF, the opportunities for people to enter training must increase. This will be expensive but it must be a major feature of our strategy to overcome the current problem of pilot shortages.

We are also investigating the possibility of a `flying only' stream in the Air Force. The Royal Air Force has had such a scheme for many years. The RAAF may not be big enough for such specialisation but we are keeping an open mind on that possibility. We are also looking at options for increasing the retirement age in certain cases. A step towards solving the problem that some pilots have with flying desks is also being taken. Jobs which have traditionally gone to pilots but which could be performed by other personnel are being targeted for reclassification. The posting of flying instructors will also be stabilised. Currently, some instructors serve for as little as one year on a posting, and this turnover is a factor in the loss of some very highly skilled pilots.

Pilots will be the beneficiaries of the improved conditions of service that are being introduced and constantly being reviewed by the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal. It is in the area of specialist allowances that really useful increases in pay can be directed to serving members of the forces, particularly in areas where we are having the separation problems. The Tribunal begins its investigation of the flying allowance later this month. The Government's commitment to sizable increases in the allowance has been shown just recently with the field allowance, which has been tripled from $4.01 a day to $12 a day, at a cost of $17.6m a year, and the submarine allowance, which has been raised to $6,800 a year for seamen posted to a sea-going submarine.

Other smaller but very irritating problems associated with postings are being dealt with. These may seem little things to people in this chamber but they are big things to many of the Defence Force personnel and their families. I refer to such things as having to change a drivers licence when moving from State to State, accommodation difficulties and all the turbulence of moving. Those things are being addressed. I am addressing all of those things individually for the benefit of all service personnel and their families. It is up to us and to the commanders in the various bases to let servicemen and women know that these issues are being addressed and that practical solutions are being found for the difficulties that may be affecting them. Of course, pilots will benefit from these improvements, too. The RAAF is looking very carefully at its structure and its operational needs. The downstream effect of current enlistment levels, the best allocation of resources, sensitivity to individual posting requests-all of these are under constant review.

As I have previously stated, enlistment is the key. We have been experiencing higher levels of recruitment recently. There are young men and some women who really want to fly and fly the best. There are many-they are the future of our air defences-who see a move from the RAAF to commercial airlines, attractive though it may be financially, as a real waste of their skills. That is a key matter to which we must give emphasis. Flying RAAF planes is in a class of its own. It is almost like comparing driving a racing car and driving a school bus. It is important that we encourage these people to stay in the service by giving them the opportunity to fly, if that is what they want to do. There is no way that we can pay the salaries being paid to commercial airline pilots, so we must consider other things, such as making conditions more attractive and looking at the housing provided. It must all be done as a package, as well as looking at the operations of the RAAF. These matters are being addressed. To me they are an area of top priority, but I think this is the way to deal with the separation problem. We must look at each affected area, attempt to target it, and try to come up with a package of solutions designed for that particular area, in addition to looking at overall conditions in the service.

The other area about which I am most enthusiastic-it has not arisen in this debate but I take the opportunity to give the Committee some education about it-is the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO), the other area of my portfolio. The DSTO is the second biggest research facility in Australia. It has been part of the Department of Defence since 1974. In its role of providing scientific support to the defence forces, DSTO has carried out its task with great skill. It has wide acceptance in the world as being top class. Its budget is about $170m and it employs between 3,000 and 4,000 people, so it is a fairly substantial part of the defence budget and an area which I think is doing some very exciting work.

I am reorganising DSTO to allow it to concentrate on the priorities set out in the White Paper. Australia needs to concentrate its efforts on intelligence-gathering technologies, surveillance technology, mine warfare, command control and communication systems, improved tactical mobility and electronic warfare. To this end DSTO will be setting up a new surveillance research laboratory at Salisbury in South Australia. If any honourable members are interested in this field, I would be happy to organise for them to visit some of our laboratories. There are five of them, centred mainly in Melbourne and in Salisbury in South Australia.

In addition, one of this Government's highest priorities is to broaden Australia's industrial base and to encourage import replacement and export. DSTO has a contribution to make in technology transfer and putting out to industry development work previously done in-house. From now on DSTO will concentrate on the research end of the research and development spectrum. Its work force mix will include more research scientists, engineers, and technical staff who will partly offset the several hundred support staff no longer required because of work contracted to industry.

New ways to commercialise the considerable number of appropriate DSTO inventions are currently being investigated. Exciting possibilities exist in joint ventures and in other commercial links between industry and DSTO laboratories. The organisation has done a marvellous job. The reorganisation of DSTO will streamline and concentrate its operations and widen their impact, thereby providing more effective support to DSTO's principal customer, the Australian Defence Force. Separation rates and high technology are only part of the portfolio of Defence Science and Personnel. If we had more time available tonight and it was an earlier hour, I would go into further detail of some of the areas of my portfolio, but I shall possibly do that in the next sitting week.

As Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, my first concern is servicemen and women, but they are not the be-all and end-all of my responsibility. Service people have spouses and families whose lives are profoundly affected by service conditions. As a result, those conditions cannot take account only of the needs and legitimate expectations of serving members but must also cater for the needs of the wives, husbands and children of defence personnel. This Government has been very much aware of the impact that service life has on families and has actively sought to find out how it can ease the adjustments that families must make.

The Government commissioned the Hamilton report-the Review of Effect of Service Life on Spouses. I do not really want to refer to the report in any detail, but I simply say that I am addressing the contents of the report. In my maiden answer to a question in this chamber by the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey), I spoke about one major area of the report that has been implemented-the Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Service, which is well on the way to being operational. That is only one aspect of the report but I am acting on the recommendations contained in it. Obviously, much discussion is still needed, particularly with the chiefs of personnel, so we can work out the priorities for implementation. But I do place a high priority on the implementation of the report's recommendations.

There has also been some controversy in this chamber today about the appointment of a Helen Mayer to undertake some work as a consultant of mine. Let me say there has been a lot of misunderstanding about that. Mrs Mayer's work is to implement one of the recommendations of the Hamilton report. One of the key issues that affect personnel is the movement between States. What I have asked Mrs Mayer to do--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is Mrs Mayer?
—Order! The honourable member for Deakin will refrain from interjecting.
—I have asked Mrs Mayer to look at the issues that relate to State conditions.
—With great respect, Mr Deputy Chairman, we have had a reference to Mrs Mayer. I am asking who Mrs Mayer is.
