— She is a consultant to me. I am concerned about my constituents, and my constituents are the defence men and women of this country who will have the very best people working for them. I am explaining that what this woman will do as my consultant is look specifically at negotiations with the State governments on issues--
—What salary is she receiving?
—I will go into that in a moment. She will look specifically at negotiations with State governments on issues that affect defence service personnel as they move interstate.
—Is she an expert on this?
—Order! The honourable member for Deakin will cease interjecting.

—I shall give the honourable member an example. Each State has different laws about the adoption of children. I think it is very unfair that when a service man or woman moves from one State to another, they may lose their place on a waiting list to adopt a child. If, for example, they move to Victoria and have been on a list in New South Wales, they can lose their place on the waiting list. We must work out some uniformity in handling issues that affect defence personnel. Another area is car registration. Different States have different regulations. Defence trainees may be located in a new State for only 12 weeks but they must acquire a new driving licence.
—Sometimes they have to pay additional stamp duty. I would like to take that up. I know a few people who have been caught with that.
—That is right. That is a key issue. These are State government matters and are the sorts of issues she will be looking at.
—Who will be looking at them?
—My consultant.
—Order! The honourable member for Deakin and the honourable member for Murray will cease interjecting.
—If the interjectors keep quiet, I shall go into more detail.
—Well, answer the question on salary and qualifications.
—Order! The honourable member for Deakin is close to being warned.

—There has also been some confusion about the amount of money referred to. My consultant will be working out of the Department of Defence in Melbourne. She is on a level 1 salary. She has no staff of her own. She has the use of a steno-secretary in the Department of Defence and that is it.
—What is the salary?
—That is the work she is doing. I think this area is extremely important to the defence forces and we are implementing one of the recommendations of the Hamilton report.
—Why don't you answer the question about the salary? You told the honourable member for Murray that you would say what it was.
—I told you: level 1.
—Order! The Minister will address the Chair.

—So what is extremely important is that we get some results for the defence forces. This is the first time these issues have been addressed. They are things that really niggle at defence service personnel as they move from State to State.

SPEECH.PARA: Another area which is extremely important is that of education. We need to get some sort of uniform school accreditation and reporting procedures as kids and their families move from State to State. At the moment, there is very little uniformity at all. I consider these areas very important and ones which I will address. I have also begun the process of going around various bases in Australia. I have had meetings with the conveners of the National Consultative Group of Service Spouses, which was another group set up as a result of the Hamilton report recommendations, with the Townsville area group of service spouses and with representatives of the Navy, Army and Air Force wives associations. These consultations are enormously valuable. They have given me a very good sense of what the priorities are.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to meet my ladies?

—The honourable member for Lyne has invited me to visit the base in his electorate, Williamtown. I intend to visit that base. I will also meet with service spouses if that can be organised. I have also asked the chiefs of the three Services to report to me on what they see as the most pressing priorities for implementation of the Hamilton report. I expect their reports in the very near future.

SPEECH.PARA: Since I will be introducing into the House later this month the Defence Housing Authority Bill, I will not go into--

TALK.START.PARA: —Another one. It has been off again, on again, gone again, Flannagan.

—It is quite obvious that the Opposition is not concerned about these issues that are of vital concern to the Defence Force personnel and their families. I will not be going into the details of the subject of defence housing tonight because that will be discussed, as I said, later this month. It is enough to reaffirm the Government's pledge of $750m over the next decade to defence housing, to building and maintaining it. I intend that the pattern I have been reporting tonight will continue. There will be ongoing consultation, and specific and effective action taken where a need has been identified. This portfolio is a very challenging one. I am enjoying that challenge. I can assure the honourable members who have spoken tonight that I am very committed to the implementation of improved conditions of service in the defence services. I am enjoying it because I believe that I can really do something of great importance in the defence of Australia. I thank all honourable members for their contribution.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Chairman. The trivia about Mrs Mayer was all very fascinating, but some very serious questions were raised tonight on a number of major capital equipment projects.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—I would like confirmation from the Minister that the serious questions raised tonight by me, the honourable member for McPherson and others will be answered.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. There is no point of order.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Chairman. The Minister undertook to reveal what the financial circumstances were with regard to Mrs Helen Mayer but she has not done so. Would you please ask her to do so?
—It is not within my power to direct the Minister to answer a specific point.
—Are you saying, Mr Deputy Chairman, that, after the Minister having said she would do so, and now not having done so, you are not going to require her to do so?
—The Minister will be in contact with honourable members later.
—Mr Deputy Chairman, are you saying that the Minister will be in touch with honourable members later?
—The Minister will no doubt relay the information that is required to the honourable member later.
—Is that an instruction from you, Mr Deputy Chairman?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —No. There is no instruction. The Minister is quite capable of determining her own priorities.

INTERJECT.PARA: Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Department of Primary Industries and Energy
Proposed expenditure, $349,568,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The figure I wish to concentrate on is the Budget figure for the primary industries sector of $403.6m, down $56m from the previous year, to which can be added $22.4m for fishing and forestry. The first point I wish to make is that the figures for agricultural or primary industry are meaningless.
—You have the Minister for Consumer Affairs in front of you. You are going to be terrified.

—He is going to become a staple in this place, is he not? The figures in the Budget Papers for assistance to agriculture are meaningless. When I say `meaningless', I am not necessarily criticising the Government, but I am criticising the way in which these figures are presented in the Budget Papers. A significant percentage of what many people would think is actual government assistance for primary industry is, in fact, only transfer payments, such as grower levies and promotion for research, or assistance which should really be for the manufacturing industry, such as fertiliser dumping rebates, or assistance under the steel plan with regard to the new grain terminal at Port Kembla.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is time that an accurate Budget figure of assistance to agriculture was provided, not this mixture of transfer payments, growers' money and government assistance. It is high time that the rural Press became investigative, sorted out what is the real figure and what is not, and stopped blindly accepting government figures. If we compare the level of assistance shown in the Budget Papers with the more real assistance given to other sectors of industry, we see that it is dramatically less. To quote the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), `It is under 0.5 per cent of total Budget expenditure'; that is, $426m out of $78,000m. But if we take the real figure, it is considerably less.

The genuine level of assistance to agriculture obviously must vary depending on the economic circumstances of an industry from time to time. Therefore, whether assistance is up or down is not as important as whether it should be up or down to meet those varying circumstances. We must also acknowledge the value of underwriting for a range of different agricultural industries, even if there is no actual payment. One has to view with concern the threat to underwriting of the wheat industry now in the draft report of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC). Everybody in agriculture would be more than happy if no assistance were needed for the primary industries sector, and there would be little need for assistance if all other sectors were treated in the same way as the agricultural sector is treated and if Australia were allowed to be internationally competitive with wages, inflation rates and interest rates and had an equitable taxation and cost-sharing burden. Unfortunately, that is not the case because agriculture must face an unfair burden. One has to acknowledge that real assistance for agriculture is needed and justified on social equity grounds and because of the lack of an equitable cost and tax distribution allocation between sectors. There must be recognition of the forms of assistance for agriculture, our greatest export earner, which will continue to be our greatest export earner for years to come. Despite all the rot about new technology and sunrise industries, there are more innovations, more new products and more dynamism in agriculture than in any other industry in Australia.

One can contrast this with the Labor Government's lack of concern for agriculture, lack of concern for equity in agriculture, and its broken promises. That is the cause of the mistrust of the rural people of Australia for this Labor Government. They know that they cannot trust it. Let us look, for example, at wool promotion. I quote from a telex from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), dated 16 June 1987, to Mr David Moore, Executive Director of the Wool Council of Australia:

In reply to your telex of 4 June 1987 concerning the Government's contribution to wool promotion, the Australian Labor Party is committed to continuing the current arrangements which it put in place whereby the government contribution to wool promotion has been placed on a predictable long term basis by contributing 1.2% of the gross value of wool production. Government funding of wool promotion has risen from $20 million in 1982-83 to over $38 million expected for 1987-88.
Yours sincerely
John Kerin
That was dated 16 June. What happened in the Budget?

TALK.START.PARA: —They pulled the wool over their eyes.

—That is right, the Government pulled the wool over the eyes of the wool growers because it broke that promise in the Budget in September. We do not need to rely only on that example. Let us look at the Industries Assistance Commission and the double standard that the Government applies to decisions in relation to its reports. The level of assistance for agriculture is under half that which is given to the manufacturing industry, and is decreasing rapidly. The IAC reports may recommend the removal of any form of assistance for agricultural industries and the Government automatically accepts that recommendation. But it rejects requests in regard to manufacturing industries and quite often increases the level of assistance. If we look at the unfairness of input costs on fuel we will see that they have been indexed to over 20c since the Labor Government came to power. This imposes a great cost on country people. With regard to the rural adjustment scheme, less than one month after the Minister said that there were more than adequate amounts for the rural adjustment scheme for this financial year, his Labor colleague from South Australia contacted him, saying:

SPEECH.PARA: South Australia is seeking more rural crisis funding from the federal government to help farmers who could be forced off the land.

He was referring to wheat growers on the Eyre Peninsula who are affected by the cut-out of the season. So less than one month after the Budget was handed down, when there was supposed to be this assistance, or additional assistance, for rural adjustment already there is not enough. A further example is export inspection charges. The Commonwealth supposedly meets 50 per cent of the charges. With regard to beef residue testing, which is a legitimate export inspection requirement and an additional cost to the industry of about $35m, the Government has said that it will not meet its half share of this additional cost. In regard to new levies and taxes in the fishing industry, there is a completely new levy of $295 per vessel, as well as the doubling of licence fees in three years.

There has been a lack of consultation with the wool industry and the fishing industry. Labor says, `That is fine because rural people are getting more assistance in the social areas-welfare, quality of life and family assistance. You are given a 008 number and the counselling arrangements are in the rural directory'. I acknowledge that that is a good, positive move to provide information.

If one looks at the real social assistance provided for farming people one will see that the Government has devastated many of the programs that we introduced. In 1975 Labor, when it was in government, refused to introduce the isolated patients travel and accommodation assistance scheme and the country areas program for disadvantaged students. We introduced it and the Government has now allowed it to become stagnant and handed it back to the States. It decimated the fuel freight scheme from $120m to $8m. It introduced the assets test and made it impossible for the self-employed to receive the unemployment benefit if they were farmers. Local telephone charges for many country people are now impossibly high. It has put back remote area telephone upgrading. It has moved against and made it impossible for remote area commercial television. It has in every way down graded not only the industry aspects of primary industry, but also the social welfare and other aspects which are so important to country people.

My final point is that; if one looks at the efficiency of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, one must ask why it is that the Department is increasing its administrative cost requirements so much in this financial year when it is supposed to be taking part in this exercise to reduce the number of public servants and increase efficiency. Why is there this dramatic increase from $51m last year to $60m this year? That is the concluding question that I ask of the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps before addressing a couple of issues relating to the energy section of this consideration of the appropriations for the Department of Primary Industries and Energy I should put a couple of points to the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). He talked about the effect of this Government's policies in the bush. I think the honourable member needs to be reminded that the election and return of the Hawke Labor Government for a third historic term was won in the bush. In fact, every rural seat held by the Australian Labor Party prior to 11 July was retained, many with an increased majority. Of course, we won four additional seats in Queensland. I think that says something about the ability of the rural voters to determine who will support them.
—What about Bendigo?

—Of course, as my colleague reminds me, we won the seat of Bendigo. We won the seat of Northern Territory as well. My concern in tonight's debate relates to the coal industry and, in particular, the ongoing discussion about a coal industry plan. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has indicated in the last couple of weeks that in fact the Government is prepared to pursue the development of a long term strategy for the coal industry. I commend him for that. I commend also the Caucus coal industry task force for the work it is performing in helping to develop that strategy.

SPEECH.PARA: What concerns me greatly is that any strategy developed for the coal industry must take into consideration the wishes of all the participants in that industry. I am referring not only to the miners themselves, who have a vested interest in ensuring that job opportunities are retained, but also to the companies which wish to ensure that economic viability exists and that profitability return to that industry.

What greatly concerns me are some proposals presently mooted in Queensland by the outgoing Premier who has indicated that he supports the development of two brand new coal mines and a new port facility, called, of all things, Port Petersen. In fact, if we talk to people from the Australian Coal Association, particularly representatives from Queensland, they will tell us that there is sufficient productive capacity in existing mines in New South Wales and Queensland to meet the existing contracts or, indeed, to meet any contracts that might be developed in the future. In this regard I am, of course, referring to all those communist countries with whom the Queensland Premier is prepared to trade but which he would put down at the earliest opportunity. I believe that any consideration the Queensland Government gives to the establishment of new coal mines has to be taken with a grain of salt, simple because the productive capacity already exists.

The consideration of the appropriations for the Department of Primary Industries and Energy in respect of proposals for the development of a coal industry plan must also take into consideration the fact that a major structural readjustment is taking place in the coal industry today. It is not, as some people believe it to be, something that comes along in a boom and bust cycle. I think many of us who represent coal mining districts would say that a lot of the present problems have been caused by a combination of factors-both on the side of management and, to some extent, as a result of activities of the trade union movement. Nevertheless, there has been a conscious effort made over the last few months to identify those problems. Indeed, there has been a conscious effort not only to identify those problems but also to try to put forward some reasonable solutions. I am hopeful that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy will develop a long term strategy that will take into consideration all of those concerns developed so far.
Friday, 9 October 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the primary industries section of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) I would like to begin by quoting some of the words of the Governor-General in his Speech at the opening of the Parliament. He said, under the heading `Primary Industries and Energy':

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to the encouragement and promotion of Australia's traditional primary industries, which must remain a very high priority-
they are very interesting words; he says encouragement and promotion should remain a very high priority-
the Government will help rural and provincial Australia gain greater access to Government programs.

I want briefly in the time available to talk a little about those points, and in particular talk about the shameful efforts of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). He has made reference to the promotion highlighted by our shadow Minister, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), but I would like to reinforce the point because it really is a disgraceful effort by the Minister and it is something we will remind him of for a long time to come. There is a lot of talk about access to government programs, but I see this as nothing more than a smokescreen for cuts in country areas to the basic services which are so desperately needed and without which all these other things are irrelevant. Briefly, to put the whole primary industry situation in context it is worth looking at the current issue of the Quarterly Review of the Rural Economy, put out by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. It says:

Conditions in the rural sector continue to improve, although the disparity between livestock and crops is forecast to widen further in 1987-88 . . . the gross value of rural production is forecast to rise by 7 per cent in 1987-88 . . . the value of rural exports is forecast to rise by 9 per cent, to a new record of $13,300m . . .

That shows what a great contribution primary industry is making to Australia's economy, but it does tend to mask the real figures. When we look at farmers' terms of trade we see how they have survived and how, despite very adverse terms of trade figures, they have continued to support this nation dramatically. Taking 1980-81 as the base year of 100, we find that farmers' terms of trade for the coming year, 1987-88, will be down to 76-up only two points on the previous year and three on the year before, which was the all-time low. The consumer price index has gone up to 173 while the farmers' terms of trade figure has gone down to 76. Farmers have continued to contribute to this nation despite extremely adverse terms of trade figures.

When looking at the record of what the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has said prior to elections, it is worth going back to the 1984 election, when he was very quick at a meeting in Horsham to tell farmers in the strongest terms that he would oppose capital gains taxes, the assets test and death duties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was this?
—This was the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.
—What is his name?
—Mr Kerin, speaking at Horsham in 1984.
—He has not been caring very much lately.
—No, he does not care. He said back in 1984 that he would oppose all these measures.
—Is Mr Kerin at the table?

—No. Where is the Minister? Has he gone to bed? Back in 1984, before the election, he was very quick to talk about his opposition to a capital gains tax. What happened after the election? He was silent. In fact, when I asked him a question in this chamber he could not find an answer. Before the election in July he went to the Australian Wool Council and gave it a very clear undertaking that the Government would keep funding going for wool promotion. In fact, he said that the Government would ensure that this funding would continue on a predictable long term basis by contributing 1.2 per cent of the gross value of production. Only two months later, in September, we see in the Budget that the Government has reneged on this, an undertaking that the Minister expected primary industry to take seriously. What is his word worth? It is worth very little.

SPEECH.PARA: The wool industry is even more concerned about the fact that the Government has announced that it will review promotion. One wonders whether the Minister will go even further and renege on even the undertaking that has been given in the current Budget. It is interesting that the Government is prepared to cut back on promotion at a time when we still have a chronic balance of payments problem and a massive overseas debt that is rising.

I know the time is late but I want to touch just briefly on the so-called increase in access to government programs. At the same time we have seen an enormous cut in government services. In particular, I refer to road funding, which has been frozen for the last three years. The money allocated to the road transport program has been cut again this year. One only has to travel around country Victoria and other States to see what this will mean.

The honourable member for Murray also talked about the increased prices Telecom Australia is charging and the increased prices of communications. If basic services and basic infrastructure are to be cut back, what is it worth to have increased access to government services? If people cannot even get access to them, they are not worth much.

It is getting late and other members want to speak, so I will conclude my remarks. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has seriously dented his reputation, not once but twice, in the last two elections. He was very frivolous in making election promises which he had no intention of keeping. He very quickly reneged on them and the Government reversed its decision. The way the Minister has treated primary industry is something he will carry to his eternal shame. More than that, he has to lift his game and show that he is serious about helping primary industry and country people in particular, because without providing the basic infrastructure, decent roads, decent communications and access to telephones at a reasonable price, the Government is failing the country. I have no doubt that after the next election we will see a serious reversal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not intending to speak in this debate but I cannot let the contribution by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) go unchallenged. I want to put an end to the Opposition assertion that this Government has reduced government services in country areas because it is patently untrue and any proper analysis of the facts shows that it is patently untrue.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to give just a few examples of the sorts of services which affect people in my electorate. It is a common electorate in country Victoria; it is very like that of the honourable member for Wannon. It has a high proportion of elderly people. I will tell honourable members what has happened in my electorate during the term of the Hawke Labor Government. New senior citizen centres-not just one or two-have been established throughout my electorate. They have been established in Elmore, Donald, Strathfieldsaye, Wedderburn and Avoca-they are all in the Bendigo area. Five new senior citizens centres are bringing services to country people and that did not happen under a coalition government. What about hostels?

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a dramatic slow down in the care for the aged in Victoria.

—What nonsense! This is the great National Party myth. It is a party on the run; it is losing representation around Australia. It has lost seats in Queensland. There are five new senior citizens centres in the Bendigo electorate, which is basically a rural electorate.

—Order! The estimates before the Committee are for the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. They do not relate to senior citizens centres. The honourable member for Bendigo will come back to the estimates that are before the Committee.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman, for your guidance. I was respondng very briefly to the points that were made by the Opposition. These primary industry estimates show that the performance of this Government, in terms of our primary sector, has been second to none. It is this Government which floated the Australian dollar; it is this Government which has reformed statutory marketing authorities; it is this Government which has seen the rate of increase of farm costs come down from an average of 12 per cent under the coalition Government-the Fraser Government-to 7 per cent this year. The quarterly estimates of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, to which the honourable member for Wannon referred, put the figure at 3 per cent. That is not bad-3 per cent compared with 12 per cent. Yet the Opposition continues with the myth that the Labor Government is penalising country people. I have never heard such nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has referred to the gross value of rural production. Why does it not refer to the net value of rural production, which in 1986-87 increased by more than 30 per cent? In 1987-88, it is predicted to increase by more than 35 per cent. That shows that the Government's strategies of reducing costs and floating the Australian dollar are working. The honourable member for Wannon made ludicrous claims about the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax. Again, it is a pathetic myth put about by National and Liberal Party members in rural seats that farmers would be decimated by this tax when less than 3 per cent of farmers have been in any way affected by it. Those opposite were running around the the country saying that farmers would be paying all the fringe benefits tax and would be going broke because of it, but less than 3 per cent of farmers are affected. Members of the Liberal and National parties keep up this persistent myth. As the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) made clear, the runs are on the board. In all the Government-held provincial seats in the last election, Australian Labor Party members substantially increased their vote, and that is more than we can say for the honourable member for Murray, whose vote substantially declined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words about the primary industry estimates. I do so against the background that there have been recent rises in wool, lamb and beef prices and falls in interest rates, although the falls have not been big. All this has tended to cloak the deep, serious and underlying problem affecting the agricultural sector. The Government has the feeling that the heat is off, but the damage has been done. The Government has done terrible damage to the average farming family with its high interest rates which, over a sustained record period, have plunged Australian farmers into a debt of somewhere near $10 billion. Do not think for one moment that the trouble is over in rural Australia. Farmers there are left with a very serious residual problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget did not attempt to redress the very serious and specific problems affecting the Australian farm sector. For instance, why are adequate funds not provided for debt and farm adjustment? The Australian motor industry, which is a multinational industry, has a plan that will cost our taxpayers $500m. The textile, footwear and chemicals industries have a plan to try to help them get through a difficult period. A whole range of industries have had their problems addressed in a serious and sensible way. For some two years I have been calling upon the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) to come up with some strategy to try to overcome the serious sectoral problems affecting the rural areas.

No industry has been hurt more than the dairy, sugar and wheat industries. I do not think that any sector of the Australian community is much worse off than the wheat growers and their families who are struggling, not knowing whether they will be on their farms at the end of this year. The wheat crop appeared to be promising in great areas of my electorate, but frost damage and drought have resulted in serious damage to the oncoming crop. I have spoken in the last few days to a number of bank managers, and they fear greatly for farming families in the northern wheat belt of New South Wales. The Minister, busy as he is with his mammoth Department of Primary Industries and Energy, has not a hope in hell of coming to grips with this serious problem because of the pressures that he has from the coal and mining industries and sectors of Australian farming. This is a very serious social problem which is not being faced up to by an unsympathetic government.

Why does the Government not recognise the importance of the agricultural industry, which will be vital in overcoming the great debt problem that underlies the economic difficulty facing all Australians? The Government must recognise that, with a gross overseas debt of $109 billion, now forecast to reach $160 billion by 1992-the equivalent of $41,000 per Australian family of four-it will be necessary to maximise the natural advantages that we have in agriculture because of both geography and the efficiency which has been built into these industries for some time. Even Ross Gittins, an economist with whom I do not always agree, drew attention to this matter this week in the Sydney Morning Herald of 7 October when he said, inter alia:
My other realistic thought is that part of our salvation-
he talks about Australia's debt problem-
more than it's fashionable to acknowledge, will lie not in a wholesale shift into manufacturing, but in greater diversification within the rural and mining industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear! They have woken up at last.

—He has woken up at last, but this Government has not woken up to the serious problem that is affecting the prospects for the living standards of the Australian people. I will briefly refer to another report that has come to hand, the report of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) on the wheat industry. In the current domestic economic environment, deregulation of the wheat industry would leave our unassisted growers exposed not only to a corrupted world commodity price structure but to the predatory trading practices of huge private traders. There are policies, outlined in that report, to terminate the guaranteed minimum price, abolish pooling, remove underwriting and return to the bad old days of exploitation of our wheat farmers.

SPEECH.PARA: This is all in the name of deregulation, the removal of market intervention and the so-called free market. Let us face it: there is no such thing as a free market, either in this country or internationally. The Australian Wheat Board (AWB) has served the interests of wheat growers well and, I might say, people generally, in the past 50 years. The AWB's recent record in the world is second to none. In recent years, the more flexible charter of the Wheat Board has served farmers well, especially in domestic marketing, Australia has been the only major wheat exporting country to sell its entire crop in a tough, shrinking world market over the past two years.

Why would one want to abandon the Wheat Board? Would it be to satisfy the demands of the traders? In a deregulated market there will be winners and losers. Honourable members can bet that if the IAC recommendations to the Government are adopted, it will be the farmers who will lose. The report is badly thought through. It ignores the fact that we have the least protected and least assisted farmers in the world. In the European Economic Community the level of assistance is 160 per cent. In the United States it is 100 per cent. In the manufacturing sector we have a level of a assistance of 26 per cent and in the wheat industry the level is 2 per cent.

Let this Government not fall into the trap, in the name of deregulation, of adopting the recommendations of that IAC report. If it does, it will destroy one of Australia's most important export income earners. I am sorry that the Minister is not here, even though the hour is late, to respond to some of the points that I have made. There are serious problems in these important export industries. Rural industry is responsible for something like 60 per cent, in net terms, of Australia's overseas earnings. It cannot be allowed to languish because of the policies that this Government has adopted-policies of costs that have been imposed upon the industry as a result of taxing fuel to the extent it has been taxed, and the failure to remove the tariff burden from input costs such as farm machinery parts and veterinary and agricultural chemicals. Those sorts of costs cannot be borne by an industry which is largely unassisted and trying to compete on a corrupted world market. Let us do away with this rubbish that there is such a thing as a free market, either in this country or in the rest of the world.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

The following answer to a question was circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has any work been done by his Department to remove the distinction between severely and substantially handicapped children; if so, with what results.
(2) Would removal of the distinction involve extra cost to the Government; if so, what is the estimated extra cost.
(3) When will the change, as recommended by the social security review, be implemented.
(4) How many children will be affected by the change in each (a) State and (b) category of disability.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) As announced by the Treasurer in the 1987 Budget, from December of this year Child Disability Allowance (CDA) will replace the existing Handicapped Child's Allowance. CDA payments will be made free of any income test and at a uniform rate of $112 a month, reflecting removal of the distinction currently existing between severely handicapped children and those marginally less handicapped. This also represents an increase of $20 in the maximum rate of payment of $92 a month. Payments of up to $92 a month are currently made for children who need marginally less care than severely handicapped children where the parents are in financial hardship.
It is estimated that the change to be introduced in December will cost some $20 million in a full year. Without the increase in rate, the cost would be about $12 million in a full year.
